explanation: The ending seemed arbitrary. The main action (i.e. the interaction between the woman and the brown-eyed child) happened a while ago, and it isn't clear why the story ends at this vague point in the future.

A couple things did not make sense in this story. It was unclear why the woman was in the hospital and her real baby was already at home. Presumably she was in the hospital to give birth, but she goes home and her real baby is already at home. It's also unclear why she should have more flow of breast milk because two different babies were nursing. Presumably this would happen if two babies were nursing at the same time, but not if two different babies nursed at two different times. The long-term emotional attachment the woman has to the brown-eyed baby also seems unrealistic. I didn't understand why she continued to be so profoundly attached to him over the long term.
I thought there was a good balance between scene and exposition. The pace is good. An improvement would be more background about Laura in the time before this experience.

The manipulation of time seems reasonable; the stretching of time around the time of the birth, and the compression of time as the story moves farther away from the birth is reasonable. However, the ending would probably be improved by a return to a scene in which time passes in the "present", rather than trailing off at a vague point in the future.
The story doesn't make sophisticated use of these literary devices.

I thought there was a good balance here, we get a description of events happening around Laura, as well as her feelings about what is happening, and neither outweighs the other. The exception is at the ending, where more specific action happening in the world would be helpful.

The fact that Laura is so emotionally affected by the mistake, and caring for the other boy, does not seem appropriate, or at least, it isn't explained. There may be some reason for her feelings, but the reader doesn't really understand why she feels such sorrow and anguish at being separated.

The only perspective we have is of Laura, and even then the reasons for the strong emotions she feels are not really explained, either by background exposition, or other allusions throughout the narrative.
This story avoids cliches, and the writing does seem original.
The form and structure does not seem original, both are familiar and straightforward.

It seems like the reader would come away with the idea that Laura endured a long-term emotional trauma that she never quite recovered from. I'm not sure if there is much more that the reader would take away. I think that for the story to pass this test, there would need to be more context and depth around Laura's character, including her background and the reasons for her feelings.
It didn't seem to me that there was much meaning or complexity apart from the surface action and the reflections from Laura's point of view.
The author does a good job in creating a believable world, with details like the smell of the baby who has just nursed, the baby's soft hair and delicate ear.

The only character which is developed at all is Laura, and even with her it is difficult to understand the source of her feelings, or much about her character, beyond the fact that she is anguished by the separation from the baby.

The end of the story feels arbitrary, in so far as the ideas at the end of the story don't seem to follow from the events at the beginning of the story. We are left with Lily's sense of peace because she had found art and motherhood. Yet, the connection between these two things is not clear in the story.

The story does not work together as a unified whole, and there are some aspects that do not make sense. It is unclear why Lily and the other woman decide to switch their babies. This doesn't seem like a logical outcome of a night of supportive conversation. It also seems absurd that the hospital would allow two people to simply switch babies. The encounter with the older man who knew Lily's mother also doesn't make sense. They are at a showing of Grace's artwork, so why does the old man say that Lily is an extraordinary artist? Presumably, her artwork is not on the wall. Besides, Grace is not her biological daughter, so how did Lily pass on her own mother's talent to her daughter? The ending of the story has redundant passages, and doesn't fit together with the first part of the story. How was the mix-up in the maternity ward related to Lily's discovery of her own artistic talent?

The summary of events over the course of the last two pages is rambling and redundant. The events here could be summed up in a more concise way, and some of the details could be more drawn out. For example, what were the communities Lily was working with? What work about social justice was she doing? These events could be explained in greater detail. On the other hand, the "mix-up in the maternity ward" is mentioned a few times, which seems unnecessary.

The last couple pages are characterized by a vague sense of time, which is repetitive and not tied to any specific chronology. We are told that "in the end" things happen, but then they continue to happen, so it is not clear when "the end" is. This is disorienting and confusing.
The language is straightforward, and does not make sophisticated use of these devices.

There is a good balance between action and Lily's interior thoughts, especially in the first half of the story. Things are happening around her, and she reacts to them. This balance declines as the story goes on, and we get more and more summary that seems removed from Lily's own character.

The turns taken in the story don't seem appropriate. Lily's decision to switch babies isn't really explained. The shift in focus from her daughter to her own art career doesn't really work, and the connection between them is not clear. The encounter with the man who knew Lily's mother has the potential to be interesting and surprising, yet, he praises Lily's artistic ability at an art show exhibiting Grace's art, and thus is confusing.
The other mother disappears from the narrative without much explanation, and Lily is really the only character whose perspective is developed at all.

The end of the story drifts toward cliche and uninteresting language. For example, "she brought together people from diverse backgrounds, bridging the gaps that divided them and fostering understanding." This sentence really doesn't say much of anything about what Lily was doing or why she was doing it. Another example: "Through workshops and mentorship programs, she empowered individuals to find their own creative voices and reimagine their realities." How did she do this? Who were the people? What were the specific consequences?
There is nothing really original about the story's form or structure.

Perhaps if the emotional connection between the hospital encounter and Lily's later life could be explained, there could be an interesting idea here about motherhood, creativity, support, etc., but as it is, these ideas aren't really developed together.
I couldn't discern much of any meaning or allusion below the surface meaning of the narrative.

Overall, no. There is good attention to details at the beginning, including things like Lily's room number, the pale faces of new mothers, the wailing of infants. This type of specific sensory detail fades over the course of the story.
Lily is the only character that is developed to any extent, and even then it is unclear why she does many of the things she does (e.g. switching babies, creating art for social change).

The end of the story is satisfying, the resolution coming with the end of the night, and the confusion and uncertainty that came with it, and the recognition of the other woman, and Marie's felt connection with her.
Every event and reference in this story seemed to move the narrative along, and reveal something important about Marie.

The story does a good job of filling in background and providing depth to the characters through details in the scenes. For example, we get references of Marie's fears and horror at motherhood, even as she is going through the procedures necessary to become a mother (going to the hospital, giving birth, staying in the maternity ward). Expository information about Marie is conveyed through descriptions in the scenes, which helps the author avoid tedious summaries of facts about Marie's life.
The pacing is well-balanced, in that the actions taking place over the night are balanced with Marie's thoughts about coming to the hospital, and ending up in the maternity ward.

This story makes effective use of metaphor, such as the reference to curtains lime amniotic membranes, or life as a tapestry of tangled thread. The allusion to the mythological Autolycus also invites some thought about the meaning of the name, and the theme of theft in the story (i.e. the switching of the babies as a kind of theft).
In my view there is a good balance between the inner life of Marie, including her sense of fear and forboding, as well as her sense of peace by the end, and the exterior world of the maternity ward.

The fact that Marie takes the other baby is surprising, even shocking, and yet it is described in such subtle ways in the narrative as to make it seem almost natural. This is the best aspect of this story, in my opinion. The reader is convinced of the propriety of this act through the subtle description of the action. If the action was described in a more straightforward way, we would be less sympathetic to Marie.
We get a little bit of the annoyance of the nurse, but nothing really about the other woman. Marie's perspective dominates the story.

At times the language gets a bit convoluted (e.g. "Marie imagined herself and the other mother entwined within some invisible snarl, a fabric that spanned outwards towards the concept of kin, weaving thickets of connection through the generations."). Yet, overall the language and style is original and avoids cliche.
I'm not sure if the form and structure is all that original. Still, it seems appropriate to the story.

I think the interesting idea here is the subversion of the way mothers are supposed to feel about giving birth. Marie is uneasy and fearful and horrified at motherhood, but finds peace in the connection she finds to both the other baby and its mother.

I think the story does operate at multiple levels. The hospital  is both a frightening, towering monolith, and a place of serene peace, as if surrounded by amniotic membranes. There are fragrant flowers and cold stone walls. These physical contrasts work together with the emotional contrasts we get about childbirth, which is described as both a frightening, and tender experience.

The world is described very richly, and there are plenty of details that make the setting real and believable. For example, "Fat bundles of stardust swaddled in textiles of sky-blue, daisy-yellow, or April-green" and "The air tasted honeyed, the sweet mixture of milk and warmth permeating throughout the room.
The focus is mainly on Marie, and so we can't really say that other characters are developed with any complexity.

The ending is abrupt, but its abruptness fits with the clipped language throughout the story. The ending provides a kind of resolution while also leaving the me curious and thinking about the meaning of what I just read.

The story does hold together well. Elements like the bleeding, the encounters with other new mothers, the question "did you seen my kid" help to give the story coherence, even when it gets strange and surreal.

Most of the story unfolds as "scene" but this is appropriately balanced with some exposition and summary, such as in passage like "When I was taken upstairs from the delivery room back to my own room, the porter had told me that I’d given birth in a part of the hospital that was built during the Cold War. I hadn’t known that I’d given birth underground. But there were several floors down there that had been constructed to withstand a nuclear blast.
Much of the time of the story is happening "now," there isn't a lot of stretching of time. This pacing works well, in my opinion, and helps to sustain a feeling of suspense and unease.

The language is somewhat clipped and abrupt, and helps to build tension and suspense. For example, "The hospital was still. The hospital gown was unfathomably long; it hung down between my legs. My strange, distant feet walked. The child lay like a shadow in the cot as I opened the door. The door made a sweeping sound." Similarly, the allusion to the women who have lost their breasts is effective in suggesting the narrator's pain and loss, and feeling of being alienated from her body.
I think the author does a very good job of bringing together the jarring atmosphere of the hospital with the thoughts and feelings of the narrator. Each seems to be a reflection of the other.

The elements that are surprising, such as the encounters with the zombie-like women, the disappearance of the baby, the discovery it is the "wrong" baby, the whitewashing scene outside the hospital, all lend an air of surreal suspense. These elements don't seem inappropriate, however, as the reader understands that these elements exist to evoke the feelings of unease and disorientation of giving birth in a hospital, something natural and supposedly happy and beautiful, surrounded by windowless, badly-lit corridors, subterranean nuclear bomb shelters, constant bleeding and discomfort, etc.
The perspective comes mainly from the narrator, and it is unclear what the other characters are thinking. The encounter with the other woman at the end is encapsulated simply with "time passed.
The writing seems quite original, and avoids cliche.

The surreal middle part of the story is original and works well. There is a strange "group cleanse" among the new mothers, all of whom are disoriented and out of sorts, which is bookended by the more realistic scenes that the narrator experiences in the hospital.

The reader is left with a feeling of disorientation, confusion, alienation, and is confronted by the fact that these feelings are closely connected to the birth of a child, who may or may not be even the child the narrator gave birth to. The final allusion to happiness seems to turn all of this on its head at the end in a way that is interesting.

The story is really rich in different layers of complexity. There are allusions to zombies, to pre-modern mutilations of women, to nuclear war, to being in a maze (i.e. the corridor, the hedges). All of these elements contribute to themes of confusion, pain, disorientation.

There are plenty of sensory details that help to evoke a believable, if somewhat surreal world. For example, "Blood ran down our legs, soaking our saggy hospital socks and mingling with the white liquid on the ground. The red and the white couldn’t agree, wouldn’t mix, but wove together in long marbly rivulets. A strange fog came down around the gable end, whose maintenance was our responsibility." Another great passage is "The room was blue. Yet the long white curtains seemed to glow with a sinister light, like two cylinders of glass filled with bleach. Gradually, the morning emerged outside the window.
The narrator is the single character who is developed with any complexity.

The ending is not particularly nuanced or complicated, nor is it satisfying; however, given the story’s broader issues with complexity, it is a fitting ending and feels neither rushed nor arbitrary. The progression towards acceptance and normalcy which the story leans on, for better or worse, reached its culmination in its ending.
Story follows a clear plot trajectory. It does not double back on itself and the progressions in the plot make sense.

The story has a lot of difficulty staying in-scene. At the same time, however, it does not fall too deeply into exposition, rather it maintains a consistent paraphrase, pulling into and out of dialogue elegantly enough to give the illusion of depth. Still, I suspect the story’s broader issues with complexity could be resolved by giving more space to in-scene moments.

In general, the pacing of the story is strong. Though the story has difficulty staying in-scene, it flows easily through time and is consistent in its use of temporal signposts. It could, perhaps, slow down a bit at the end, but that would be more in service of a level of emotional complexity that the story does not seem interested in exploring.

Though the language in the story is understated, it consistently and repeatedly employs cliches and uses adverbs in frustrating ways. For example, turns of phrase like “Laura's heart shattered into pieces…”, or “tiny bundle”, or the repetition, again and again, of “little boy with brown eyes”. Adverbs like “smiley” are also challenging to accept.

The story struggles with depicting emotion outside of outright statements. For instance, “Having fed him when she woke up, she grew attached to the little stranger in her arms. She spent a blissful few hours getting to know the little boy, his expressions, sounds and gestures” or “She begged the nurse to give her a few more minutes but the nurse insisted he be returned to the rightful mother immediately. Laura's heart shattered into pieces as she watched the nurse disappear down the hallway with the little boy“. Very rarely does the story rely on implication.

There are two ways to answer this. On the one hand, the story follows an easily anticipated trajectory—the mother and her child are reunited. The other child is remembered fondly and, in fact, his memory ultimately serves to increase the mother’s care for her own child. On the other, what makes this both interesting and frustrating is that the beginning of the narrative is profoundly ominous—the narrator’s obsession with the “wrong” child hints at a different story, one darker and more twisted. However, the story does neither follows that trajectory nor seems to incorporate its implications. Is that expected or unexpected? It works against what it suggests. I guess that is exciting in a way.

The narrator’s love for the “wrong” child is as close as the story gets to flexibility or to depicting ambiguity. At this stage, the story does not seem capable of dwelling in that complexity, allowing for easy and complete solutions to the dolmens being presented.

The story consistently displays a cliched and hackneyed understanding of the situation it depicts. This is especially challenging at the end: “ She hoped his mother held him tight and never stopped appreciating the gift she'd been given. She knew, in that short time together, her life had intertwined with a stranger's in a way she'd never forget” and “Her secret experience had opened her eyes to the fragility of life and deepened her appreciation for the blessings she had been given…Her life felt more complete than she had ever imagined, yet still, she kept the little brown-eyed boy tucked away in her heart - a symbol of the wonder and possibility each new life holds.”
The story follows a standard progression and resolves all of the questions that it asks about the nature of love and motherhood. There are no cracks in the solutions it provides.

Likewise, there is little nuance in the themes on display. Love is love. The “correct” order is restored and, indeed, the “test” of the narrator’s love is rewarded with a stronger reiteration of that order.

The story struggles at providing subtext or showing the narrative that it tells. Rather, the reader is told directly what the narrator feels and by extension what the story intends for them to feel, think, and believe.

Though not entirely without texture, the story sticks primarily to paraphrase and even vital characters to the plot, such as as the other “wrong” child are primarily described in broad and vague terms—to the point that I remember him only as “little boy with brown eyes” without any other characteristics.

The narrator superficially struggles in her encounter with the “wrong” child, but there is no meaningful change or development to her character. She does not come to see love differently or to new understandings about the world. Rather, her sense of the world is ultimately reiterated rather than complicated.

Many of the decisions the story makes are startling and baffling, starting with the mothers’ decision to swap children. By the story’s end, the rapid description of Lily’s life and career as an artist feels ludicrous, and the thought that this career and the child-swap might emotionally resonate in some way with a reader is deeply ridiculous.
The narrative consistently shifts so quickly that it is entirely implausible or nonsensical and includes scenes, especially in the second half with Lily, that are positively baffling.

Though the story does contain some scenes within its summary, all of them are ludicrous, starting with the conversation about swapping children and ending with the conversation about Lily’s artwork which appears from nowhere and means nothing.

The narrative pairs its absurd leaps in logic with equally massive leaps in time. Both are impossible to accept and the story’s attempt to wave these problems away with signposting like “Years later” is so goofy it is almost transcendent.

The story uses overwrought language throughout. For instance, early on: “Each room seemed to contain its own unique symphony of wailing infants, creating a disorienting chorus that reverberated through the halls”. This language is matched by the narrative’s overwhelming melodrama, so perhaps it is fitting, but the reading experience is more than displeasing.
There is no emotional experience to this story that is not outright stated.

The story makes unhinged decisions. It is bold and some of these decisions I might love in an entirely different context. As it stands, the narrative is structured in such a fashion as to destroy all possibility of an emotional experience for its reader.

Lily is an empty vessel. I do not believe she is really a character. She makes decisions that are ludicrous and no attempt is made to suggest a character who might make decisions like that—instead, the reader is expected to accept them and be emotionally moved by them, to put them in conversation with each other, as though they might build into something other than a nightmare.

I am tempted to answer yes to this because the narrative’s logic is so wild I can’t even fathom it! But I am not sure it is “thought” which is on display here—if there is, I am bringing it; on its own, it does not add up to anything.

The originality here is that the turns and twists this story takes are practically impossible to imagine. I love the robotic feeling of the child-swap. There is something there, a striking thing. Whatever that is, however, this story doesn’t explore it.
To be frank, I do not believe this story has themes. It does not feel as though it is intended to anything in particular other than to be words on a page which are connected to each other.

There is nothing happening in this story that is not stated outright, often to the point of real laughter on my end. For example, this description of Lily’s artwork: “Lily's art became a driving force in the fight for justice and equality. She used her platform to advocate for the voiceless and shine a light on the issues that often went unnoticed. Through her collaborations and exhibitions, she brought together people from diverse backgrounds, bridging the gaps that divided them and fostering understanding.”

There are attempts to create scenes here and there, especially in the beginning in the hospital, before the narrative speeds up. But those attempts are florid and insufficient. By the story’s end, there is no texture whatsoever. The reader is not told even what it is that Lily paints.

The characters are just names. Lily does something fascinating, devastating, but the decision is not explored. It is only praised. It implies that the story does not believe in love or cannot fathom it.
The story skips ahead rapidly and abruptly in its ending. The attempt to connect Marie and the real mother of “Autolycus” is ridiculous. It is also the baffling last note of the story.
The story does follow a logical progression and the plot remains focused. It is a small story insofar as it keeps itself relegated to one setting until the ending, when it attempts to jump forward.

While the story does contain scenes, it remains largely in paraphrase. This is not in itself a problem, but the over-the-top language of those paraphrase and the rhetorical questions it employs overwhelm the story and make the in-scene moments feel bizarre and out-of-time. Some of the dialogue is bizarre—“‘A lovely name—strong arms, you have there’”—and I cannot get over the child’s name.

For the most part, the story maintains a relatively strong sense of pace, keeping itself confined to one narrative period and location. However, it consistently loses itself in long passages of irritating and superfluous imagery which feel like filler in lieu of narrative complexity.

The language here is unbearably overwrought from the very beginning. For instance, “Marie noticed that each cry seemed imbued with an otherworldly power, as if it could influence the very fabric of reality”. The child’s name is also “Autolycus” which is hysterical.
There is minimal interiority here that is not stated outright, outside of the one moment I cited above.
The story follows a standard, linear progression. The only surprise is the adoption, but it is ridiculous. The temporal leap in the ending is a common one in short stories.

Marie is given no interiority. There is one moment where it is suggested: “Marie stared at the child in her arms. It must have been, for no one had taken him from her in the night. She nodded once more, although she was not quite certain”. However, for the most part, the character is depicted flatly on the page, without meaningful reaction to what she experiences.

Though there are moments where the language is bizarre enough to be striking, or absurd (“a distillation of desire”), it largely is written as a series of overwrought cliches from the first line: “There is no sound in the world quite like a baby crying”.

As I wrote before, the narrative follows a standard linear trajectory. It has some ridiculous plot moments, but they are not navigated through in a way to suggest experimentation or intentional subversion.

There are broad gestures towards a theme of randomness or interconnectivity, something transcendent guiding serendipity, but they are so vague it is difficult to parse what is being said. I would say that this story lacks a theme.

There is one moment of acknowledged uncertainty here, where neither the reader nor the character quite knows the truth: “Marie stared at the child in her arms. It must have been, for no one had taken him from her in the night. She nodded once more, although she was not quite certain”. This is the most exciting moment in the story, but the uncertainty is not mined for meaning.

Though I appreciate that the story has chosen a particular setting—Prague—it offers no meaningful exploration of this setting or its implications nor does it situate the particulars of the hospital in any kind of cultural context. Rather, it seems to float.
Because Marie has so little internal life it is challenging to discern whether she undergoes any kind of change or whether there is meaningful nuance to her character.

I think this would not be my ideal ending for the story—I would prefer something even less certain, which exploded an idea of parenthood and which did not return to a kind of reality that a consensus could be built around. However, it is not that sort of story and what is here is earned and expected and does not allow for easy answers. I especially liked the line: "The trees blossom in the street and I look at them through the window. I am an implement, a sweeping brush, who remembers the other child. It’s like happiness.”

Clean story that follows clear progression. Though it maintains a dream-like tone, it is never without coherence and the uncertainties around characters or the nature of reality (whether there is a child, what child, etc.) feels consistently intentional.

Story stays largely in-scene with only very minor digressions into summary or memory, all of which strange and interesting (" I remembered an old folktale in which a woman cuts off her breasts. Then I thought about Mutter Pappenheimer, a beggar woman in Germany, who had her breasts torn off with a pair of tongs in 1600.")
Story stays in-scene and uses beats of dialogue and repetition ("'Did you see my kid?"') to create a satisfying narrative cadence.

Very strong and subtle use of language here. Some examples: "“It was so small and scribbly, like a cracked casing"; "She sucked eagerly, a few drops of colostrum. It hurt. It was a dry pain. Like sex when you’re not wet”; "“The red and the white couldn’t agree, wouldn’t mix, but wove together in long marbly rivulets";

Likewise, while this is not a traditional depiction of emotion, the way the story floats through its narrative and world contains a number of different layers as metaphor, as fable. The story seems to work as it describes in its ending: "There was a strange sound, a gasp as I searched myself for the right feeling, but it was like clutching running water, and I realized then that I was laughing.”

The story takes on a strange and compelling tone and it functions almost like a dream. Moments like where the staff find the narrator's child suggest that there is and there is not a child and that it both is and is not the narrator's child. The questions of reality here work towards unpacking the disarming experience of childbirth and pregnancy.

Neither the narrator nor the external characters of the story feel like they can be trusted. This places the reader in the fascinating position of intuiting a reality, what is metaphor and what is truth. The complexity of the characters comes out of the metaphorical space the story occupies. It is effective, but non-traditional.
By staying in-scene and operating on a level of fable and large-scale metaphor, the story largely avoids cliche in its plot—equally, as I said above, the language is consistently fresh and exciting.

The narrative moves in an interesting recursive way through its moments of dialogue. The beginning and ending maintain a sense of narrative normalcy, i.e. that the narrator is in fact a mother with a husband, etc., which the rest of the story disrupts. I think there's another direction the story could have taken that is more original, but I cannot hold its decisions against it.

Though, again, I think the beginning and ending of the story ultimately limits the most exciting thematic possibilities here, the dreamlike logic which makes up most of the story questions the nature and consistency of identity, both internal and external.

The basic conceit of the story is to walk a line between allegory/dream and something like realism, which creates a subtext throughout. The story foreshadows this cleanly: "I’m talking about it now because my husband doesn’t believe me and our two other children don’t, either.” On a smaller level, a good deal of the dialogue relies on omission. This is the strongest aspect of the story.

The story does not aim for traditional realism; however, it effectively creates an atmosphere reminiscent of a dream through texture and language. For instance, "The paint was flaking off the walls like skin. We came to another door, this one held ajar by a bucket. My fellow-pursuer slipped through the crack, and I followed, taking the bucket with me so that the door could close. We were out among the weird shrubs now. The messy-haired woman was still ahead of us. Between the low hedges I saw several other women, bandy-legged, in the same hospital gowns, their laborious way of walking revealing that they, too, had just given birth. We followed.

The narrator exists in a foggy space and the fog never lifts. Her motivations are not entirely clear—is she looking for her child? Does her child exist? It moves into and out of this dream-space and few answers are given for her motivations outside of the beginning and ending, when it becomes clear the narrative functions as an allegory for the profound bizarreness of pregnancy and childbirth.
While the ending feels intentional, it also comes across as overdetermined and pat, with the whole story concluding on a series of cliches about gratitude and "the fragility of life.

The story feels unified in that the events proceed in a logical manner and circle around a clearly stated set of themes; however, it is not satisfying or engaging because the cohesion feels like a result of a lack of complexity rather than the resolution or balancing of tensions of some kind.

While there are moments of both scene and summary here, what is most striking to me is the way the story lacks an important type of exposition—context. We learn almost nothing about the character or her situation, which makes it very difficult to invest in the narrative as a whole.

While the opening scene of the mother nursing the brown-eye baby succeeds in slowing the reader down to confront us with the strangeness of the mother finding the wrong child in her arms, after that, the story stumbles on pacing, jumping ahead with overly expository and somewhat clunky sentences like "Laura struggled with her emotions in the following months." The author is clearly attempting to balance compression and stretching of time, but the story is not entirely successful in doing so.

The story contains almost no figurative language or literary allusion, and the language as a whole feels entirely expected and often cliche rather than artful or original (e.g. she tossed and turned, this secret ache in her soul).

This story manages to disappoint both in terms of interiority and exteriority: while a great deal of space is spent describing the emotions of the characters, those emotional are not particularly subtle or well rendered; at the same time, we don't learn enough about the exterior context of what's going on to maintain much tension or understand the greater significance of the story's events.

While the premise of the story manages to contribute a sense of surprise (babies switched at the hospital), the rest of the narrative unfolds in a way that deadens the impact of this initial "twist," and rendering the piece as a whole relatively predictable.

The story's primary character is presented primarily as an avatar of stereotypical motherly instinct; even her potentially subversive desire to claim another child over her own is attributed to primal desires that reinforce the assumption that the mothers of newborns are ruled by a biological instinct to nurture above all else.

The story contains quite a few cliches, including phrases such as "her heart broke" and "she cried inconsolably" to convey the main character's distress. On a broader level, the writing both conforms to cliches of language use and reinforces lazy stereotypes about the emotional life of a mother.
The story proceeds chronologically without novel use of structure, format, language, or style. It is conventional, but seemingly without an awareness of desire to comment on its own conventionality.

The world of the story feels quite narrow, without much engagement with a larger literary landscape or the political and cultural questions the subject matter might invite readers to consider (feminist thought, reproductive justice, mental health, institutional support for parents, etc.)

The story is mostly what we call "telling" (vs. "showing")—the author interprets the meaning for us, explicitly summing up rather than allowing the reader to use subtext to draw their own conclusions.
While there is a little bit of sensory detail here, it feels rote (blue eyes vs. brown eyes, wailing cries) rather than rich, tangible, and reminiscent of real life.

Although the story seems to believe it is delving into the feelings of its main character and does succeed in capturing some contradictions (for example, the mother both desires her real child and wants to keep the child she is given by mistake), it lacks the psychological realism and acuity to convince me that this is a truly well rounded character. The story provides virtually no backstory and fails to portray the mother's inner life with true nuance.

The ending to the story feels contrived and pat rather than meaningfully earned or even truly related to what proceeds it. This is also story that feels like it has multiple endings—several times, I imagine we might be coming to the close before another section began, creating a tiresome and repetitive reading experience.
The two main threads of this story: the baby mix-up and Lily's development into an artist don't feel meaningfully connected, resulting in a somewhat dissonant reading experience.

There are both scenes and summary here, but neither are fully satisfying, and the pattern by which they appear is repetitive: the story alternates between several, very similar scenes, and jumps forward in time that are briefly notes but not summarized in any meaningful way.

While the narrative does include moments of both compressed time, the use of this technique feels elementary, resting on simple transitional phrases like "years later" that don't do much to really make the reader feel the impact of time's passage.

The language throughout lacks sophistication—I didn't find any allusions to speak of; any idioms feel more like cliches than intentionally chosen turns of phrase; and where there is metaphor ("The gallery walls whispered her name"), it doesn't feel particularly original or additive.

While the story offers us perhaps too many descriptions of Lily's thoughts, her interiority does not feel believable—her interior life is filled with deep thoughts and revelations that lack the texture and nuance of real life.

There are surprises here but they feel mostly arbitrary—the reader is never given either the larger context or a deep enough understanding of the characters' motivations to understand, for example, why the women switch babies or what the significance of art is in the lives of Lily and Grace.
The story does not provide diverse perspectives, and the one perspective that we do get feels more like a greeting card or inspirational speech than a real person.
This piece is full of cliches, including phrases like "twist of fate" and "Lily's heart skipped a beat.

While this story fails to execute on a traditional three-act structure, it doesn't do so in a way that it effective or demonstrative of an original form. Rather, it proceeds chronologically from one thing to the next, without a satisfying sense of cause and effect or source of tension to drive readers onward.

While the story seems to be attempting to offer up some deep takeaways about fate and the power of art, it doesn't succeed in delivering its ideas in a way that feels supported by the plot or characters, which means the piece, at times, reads more like a collection of uplifting quotations rather than a real narrative.

The piece clearly has aspirations towards a larger meaning, but rather than allowing those to come through via subtext, the story delivers them explicitly and sometimes repetitively, which ironically undermines their impact.
There is very little sensory detail here—descriptions are primarily visual and often revolve around general adjective-driven phrases like "breathtaking" and "beautiful.

With the exception of the fact that her mother died when she was young, Lily's backstory is left out of the story almost entirely. And while we do see her discover her passion for art throughout the story, we don't learn enough about what it is about art that speaks to her to really appreciate this shift.

The ending of the story feels unearned—rather than being the organic consequence of a series of events, it is simply a big philosophical claim that emerges as the character looks back at the action of the story from years later. It isn't rushed, but it is overdetermined; more of an interpretation of the story than a real ending to the narrative arc.

The elements of the story felt somewhat incompletely stitched together: we have Marie's career as a linguist and her regrets over this pregnancy, which feel more grounded, alongside the surreality of the overnight at the hospital, and then, the somewhat metaphysical final paragraphs. Although another piece might be able to harmoniously move amongst these three modes, I wasn't sure if this story was successful in doing so.

While I wouldn't have minded a bit more exposition here to cut through some of the flowery descriptive language, on the whole, the story feels well balanced, with the hospital scenes grounding us in the present action and a few moments of exposition establishing the setting and Marie's circumstances.

The pacing of the story is relatively successful—the narration slows down in order to allow the reader to feel immersed in a few important moments (such at the crying of the babies in the stories opening or Marie's reverie, during which the narration explicitly states "Time seemed to slow and grow heavy, each second lasting what felt like a lifetime"), then speeds up ("Marie left the room an hour later" and "years passed quietly") in order to move the action along. It's not subtle or particularly creative, but this part of the story more or less works.

Metaphors abound here—the baby's name "might rest upon his skin like a downy plumage" and the main character "suddenly found her tongue dipped in ice" when she cannot speak. However, I would argue that sophistication entails not just the use of these figures of speech but also the ability to judge when they will add value to the story rather than serving, as they do here, of ornamental and often distracting flourishes. Throughout, the flowery language seems more likely to obscure meaning rather than enhance it.

While the story devotes a great deal of space to describing both Marie's interior and exterior condition, I'm not convinced the two effectively work together to tell a compelling story—I found myself rereading in order to determine what was real and what was in Marie's head, and I found the sections grounded primarily in her thoughts to be tiresome and overly abstract.

I found myself more baffled than surprised in reading the story—perhaps because I didn't really know or care enough about Marie to understand the consequences or significance of new developments. I also found the ornate style was such that I couldn't alway easily parse what was going on, which also inhibited my ability to be surprised or gauge what might be apt or expected.

The story really only contains one primary viewpoint—Marie's—and I didn't feel as though I got to know her deeply as a character. The portrayal of her interiority is handicapped by the overall sentimentality of the prose, which seems to prioritize pretty language, heightened emotion, and atmosphere over psychological believability.

Cliche is not a primary problem here; while there are a few turns of phrase that feel familiar ("sky-blue, daisy-yellow"), the writer also shows a proficiency for original turns of phrase (the "April-green" that follows the previous two color descriptions). That said, these original turns are not always apt and they are rarely concise—a phrase like "delicate membranes of privacy, like the fragile amniotic sac concealing a secret world" feel weighed down with adjectives—excessively ornate and sometimes distracting.

There was nothing particularly original about the structure or form here—the story uses a close third person perspective and proceeds in chronological order, with the action following the main character and her conflict along a relatively straightforward narrative path.

My sense was that the story wanted the reader to understand something about fate, time, and the soul, but while these concepts were explicitly named and commented on in the final paragraphs, the substance of the story as a whole didn't do much to illuminate a clear idea about any of these. The story seems to prioritize mystery and atmosphere rather than true substance, creating an illusion of depth perhaps, but no real meaning.

The writing style on display here seems to reach for subtext, but I found the flowery turns of phrase more often obscured meaning rather than illuminating some deeper truth. I wasn't sure what to make of the child's name—Autolycus is, classically, a thief, but it wasn't clear what he would be stealing in this context, which makes me wonder if the name was chosen intentionally and if so, why.

The story does offer some specific sensory detail—in particular, the screaming of the babies in the opening is described vividly. Later on, the story evokes the smell of lilies as well, a sensory image that feels a bit more rote but nonetheless helps to flesh out the setting of the hospital room.

Marie does have some complexity—we learn of her hesitancy around becoming a mother, which is in tension with her attraction to the child in her arms. We also get a glimpse of her backstory as a linguist, although I found that such a brief sketch of what had led her to the hospital raised as many questions as it answered. For her to be a truly rounded character, I'd like to see more of her motivations and personal history throughout.

The ending is one of the strengths of the story—the unexpected metaphor of the "sweeping brush" is evocative, and works to balance the explicit naming of a big abstraction like "happiness." While not necessary to conclude the plot of the story, this final paragraph reinforces the thematic concerns of the piece in a way that ultimately lends depth and leaves the reader with a pleasing balance of questions and answers.

The story feels coherent without being repetitive—even the moments of strangeness that diverge from the main thread of the story (for example the odd overnight white-washing scene) feel like they are contributing to the tone, atmosphere, and theme.

The story balances scene—including the capable use of dialogue—and summary appropriately. Very short fiction often doesn't require much in the way of exposition or worldbuilding, so it's fitting that scene is primary here; that said, we get just enough summary (the context about the Cold War construction of the hospital, for example) to contextualize the action and keep things moving along.

The story is effectively paced, allowing the reader to dwell in certain moments in order to sit with the narrator's sense of strangeness in her situation, while moving efficiently through less crucial action (such as the morning after the birth, which is summed up simply in the sentence "time passed." or the drive home, which is addressed in just a few short sentences).

The writer uses language in a way that feels mostly apt and illustrative: the character's pain at the child's attempts to nurse is "like sex when you're not wet" (an uncomfortable but vivid metaphor). Allusion—such as that to folktales and Mutter Pappenheimer—lends depth and suggests that the character is connected to a long line of women before her.

The exterior, physical detail of the story and the descriptions of both the main character and the other mothers is precise and well rendered. The piece doesn't devote much space to the explicit description of the main character's interior life, but I think this is an intentional choice to (1) display her sense of remove after the highly physical experience of birth and (2) make room for the reader's interpretation—and her mood and reactions to the situation at hand effectively show readers her internal state, making for a satisfying reading experience.

The use of surprise is another primary strength of the story—the story takes several unexpected turns, but presents each one in a way that enhances the piece's resonance rather than cheapening it. I think one key point may be that each surprise also contains a question for the reader to unravel about the possible reality of what is occurring: i.e. has the child been switched or is the mother disoriented from the experience of labor? does the mother come across a strange white-washing area of the hospital, or is it all a dream?

While I didn't find the main character to be unlikeable, she did feel realistic and layered. We don't read much about her motivations or beliefs, but my sense that this was appropriate to a story of this length and tone.

Cliche is not an issue in this story—and in its best moments, it is quite original in its use of image and language: "The white curtains poured more and more of their bleach onto us," "A sleepy nurse was eating sponge cake in the duty room." While there are less exciting moments (the description of the zombie walk, for example, felt less inspired to me), moments like the above point to imagination and voice.

I'm not sure this story is truly innovative in form or structure, but I would suggest that it uses a relatively traditional structure effectively—and there's an argument to be made that there is some genre hybridity here in the way it blends a literary style with some elements of horror or the surreal in order to get at the way the experience of birth is both very common and still incredibly intense, strange, and sometimes horrifying.

This story invites the reader to consider the essential strangeness of childbirth—the ways that this is an experience that connects women in uneasy communities, the tension between society's and our own expectations that we love and accept our children and the weird and often uncomfortable realities of what that looks like, and the gaps in the healthcare system that make this entire process more difficult. Without explicitly commenting on most of these themes, the story raises them in a way that certainly succeeds in provoking thought.

This is a story that thrives in subtext—the actual plot of the story, as with much literary fiction, is secondary to the deeper questions it raises and the themes it invites the reader to consider. One obvious example: I read the whitewashing of the gable as a metaphor for the labors of motherhood, in all its sticky and punishing realities; at the same time, we might understand the work of whitewashing, specifically, as referring to the way that society hopes to cover up much of this labor under ideals of the mother as a beatific or angelic force.

The world of the main character is rendered with sensory richness without getting bogged down in detail. Various details ("The door made a sweeping sound," "I could feel how the warm blood slid out of me like liquid from a test tube.") invite the reader into the environment of the hospital, and later in the story, the description of "the slimy milk of lime and blood" is downright visceral, vividly evoking the stuff of birth.

There's not much backstory here, but the context we do get (about her other children, and their life at home) helps to present the main character as a real woman with a life outside of the moments portrayed here. Moreover, her complexity comes through in her believably dissonant feelings—a sense of protectiveness over her baby in tension with the desire to avoid the girl child who may or may not be hers; the mix of "happiness" that she feels in the story's final lines set against the sense that she is "an implement.
I suspect I don't understand the reference at the end to Jansson's temptation. The end didn't make much sense, but I suspect there is meaning there that I am missing!
I think the story holds together well. It is a series of vignettes, but seems to be tied together by the central relationship between the narrator and Carl.

I think there is good balance here. A good example is this paragraph: "I give Carl severe shortness of breath. He misses his exam. Hisses into the hospital phone that I’m killing him. I’m crying. I like Carl. He didn’t beat me up. He gave me a slap. As you do in his circles. You hunt, shoot birds, decontaminate, dole out slaps. You don’t lie. You withhold love. I say I’m sorry. Sorry for being cowardly and unclear. For not knowing much about integrity and honor. But I don’t understand what’s being said. The mix of words and actions, tenderness, violence." It is a conversation on the phone with Carl in the hospital, but mediated through the narrator's thoughts and interpretation. We get both scene and exposition together.
The pacing seems balanced. The language is somewhat halting, but the narrative is driven along at a good pace. Nothing drags, or feels skipped over.

I don't think the story makes sophisticated use of these devices. The strength of the language is the way it blends violence and sex, and contrasts filth and cleanliness throughout the story. It is a sophisticated use of language, but I don't think it fall into the categories of idiom, metaphor, or literary allusion.

I think the story is successful in balancing the action and the interior thoughts of the narrator. For example, this paragraph: "When Martin drags himself to lectures, I borrow his porn mags, which he keeps in a rattan magazine stand that may once have held yarn or knitting patterns. A small boatneck sailor shirt for a grandchild. A beanie with a pompom on it. I think Martin harbors a lot of tenderness." We have all at once the action (borrowing the porn mags, description of the magazine stand), along with the narrator's imagination (what the stand might have held, and what it means for Martin's personality).

The fight with Carl at the costume party, and the narrator's leaving with the other Practical Pig is the surprising, interesting turn. It is the climax of the tension between Carl and the narrator, and ends in an unexpected way. Yet, it is not unbelievable, and fits the contours of the story as a whole.
I think we get a good sense of Carl, Martin, Lizzy, and Johan, through the narrator's description of them, although the point of view is always that of the narrator.
The story feels original, and avoids cliches.
I don't think the form and structure are particularly original.

I think the reader comes away thinking about the seeming contradictions in human relationships. The narrator apologizes to Carl for being cowardly and unclear at the end. Yet, I think the reader has the sense that Carl is the one who has been cowardly and unclear. The narrator feels comfortable and close to him, but is never really clear about what he feels for her. The contradictions are highlighted by language that emphasizes contrasts in filth and cleanliness, sex and violence.

I think the themes of cleanliness and filth, disgust and love, sex and violence, go a long way in highlighting the complexity at the center of the story, which is the narrator's conflicted relationship with Carl.

The story is very successful at evoking a believable material world with a minimum of text. An example is the description of Martin: his ring, the baby food click, wrapped in a blanket, grunting. Other examples include the description of the centerfold, and Johan's description of the smell between teeth.

At first, I thought this story passed this test, on second thought I actually think each character could be developed more. Each seems to be fulfilling a particular character type, rather than being a fully-formed, complex person.

The ending feels abrupt and unsatisfying. We aren't really invested in Jane's relationship with Johan, and their conversation feels very unnatural. It is like a bullet-point summary of a real conversation.

The story feels a bit unbalanced and unsatisfying. A lot of space is spent on explaining how Jane looks after her friends too much, and then the end of the story is very abrupt and not very interesting. In the beginning we are told Lizzy was agonizing over Martin's unanswered text, but then we learn Martin was pining for Lizzy, who was ignoring him. This was confusing.
Again, the problem here is too much exposition in the middle part of the story. When we get to the final scene, it feels too stilted and abrupt, not like a natural conversation.
The story starts to feel repetitive and drags in the middle. There is too much exposition on Jane's problem, i.e. helping those around her who take her for granted.

The metaphors seem like cliches and aren't very effective. Example: "Jane grasped Johan's hand tightly, navigating into uncharted waters with her compass pointing due north, toward the future - and toward love.

There is too much of Jane's interior world here. The conversation between people is too brief to give the reader a sense of the "exterior" world. For example: How's the garage band going?" 
"It's tough, but we're making it work. How about you?" 
"The usual," she said, with a wry smile. More description of the scene, or more conversation would be helpful here.
There is not much surprising. The climactic ending is a let down, because there is little emotional build-up or complexity.
The perspectives of the characters (other than Jane) are not developed.

The story does use cliches, such as "To face the seas of uncertainty, confront her fear of vulnerability, and finally start her own odyssey into the unknown?" or "Her friends saw her as the dependable one, the shoulder to cry on, the rational center of their universe. Inside, though, her own world was as chaotic as theirs. While everyone else stumbled toward love, she remained stuck in place, helping guide their journeys but unable to embark on her own.
There is nothing original about the form or structure.

There is nothing much for the reader to take away from this story. The reader understands that Jane makes herself too emotionally available to her friends, then decides not to, and gets together with Johan. It is a very flat, uninteresting story.

There doesn't seem to be much rhetorical complexity. The meaning of the story seems to be on the surface, and there are few themes or ideas developed beyond the description of the action and the narrator's explicit thoughts about them.

I thought there wasn't enough description of the physical world, and the action outside of Jane's inner thoughts. Where there is detail sometimes the passages are awkward; for example, "The morning sun streamed through her curtains as Jane headed to her favorite coffee shop, needing a dose of comfort and familiarity." If she is heading to the coffee shop, her attention (and thus the reader's) would not be on the curtains in her home.
The characters are flat and not developed. There needs to be more physical description, backstory, and conversational dialog.

The end of the story feels unsatisfying because even though we are told all of the conflict has been resolved, we don't really know anything about the details that brought the main character to that point. The source of the conflict was not apparent and wasn't felt by the reader. We don't even know what her famous research was about!

The main problem with this story is that it seems like the preliminary sketch or outline for a fully developed story. The plot points are all there, but there is little detail to help the reader understand why people think what they do, make the decisions they do, or to make the story interesting.
Scenes are not described with enough detail. It reads like an outline where details will be filled in later.

The story passes over important incidents too quickly, in a way that does not allow the reader to really understand what happened. For example: "Gradually, they started exchanging notes and discussing class assignments. Carl became her study partner, and soon, a romance began to blossom." What was it about Carl that Emma liked? Another example: "They explored hidden gems, swam in crystal-clear lakes, and danced under starlit skies. Emma found herself laughing more, feeling alive and free. She knew that she had made the right decision." More detail is needed here to understand what they did on the road trip, and why it was such a turning point for Emma.
The language is vague throughout. The story does not make sophisticated use of these devices.
Too much of the story is driven along by vague summary of what happened. We don't get much of either the interior world of Emma, or of the action outside.

The return of Carl to the story was a good twist, and it seemed appropriate to the story. However, like much of the rest of the story, we don't really know why this gave a sense of closure and peace to Emma.
We don't get the perspectives of characters besides Emma, and even this is unsatisfactorily simple and undeveloped.
There are plenty of cliches, for example, "embark on a journey of self-discovery"; "It was a crossroads"; "her journey of introspection and personal growth.
Not original in form or structure
There is nothing original or interesting about this story because it is so vague. It feels like reading a long synopsis on the book jacket.
There seems to be little going on below the surface here, and even the surface is vague and uninteresting.
The story requires more detail to create a vivid and believable world.
None of the characters are developed through dialog, description, or historical back story.
The ending felt abrupt and disconnected from the rest of the story. Carl is introduced for the first time here, and it feels like more space is needed to develop his character.
I would have said this story passed this test, except for the ending did not seem to work with the rest of the story. It felt abrupt and disconnected to the rest of the story.

There are places where more description and detail from the scene is needed. For example, in this passage: ""Hey, Stella! he cried earnestly, though he made no effort to push past the gaggle of hungry seniors. The hunger insinuated itself into Stella's memories, a concept that seemed symptomatic to her past but which she could not comprehend. The hunger she had felt earlier was somewhat satiated, but she knew it would never be entirely extinguished. These were the markers of Martin’s initial lodgment on her equilibrium scale: an earnest expression devoid of any shyness or uncertainty, and an ability to tug at her sense of self-worth with every follicle of awareness he was able to draw from her. In those moments, she had no idea that they would keep locked together in this delicate dance, cosmic entities tethered by a gravitational, inexplicable bond." What was the delicate dance that locked them together? All we know is that he said "Hey, Stella" to her.
The pacing seemed right for the most part, it did not feel too stretched or compressed.

This story does pretty well with metaphor. For example, I thought these were effective: "like heavy coins in a rusted tin box"; "It was as if he was now a silhouette, ever-present but never in focus"; "like hot wax dripping onto Stella's hand and filling in the spaces between her fingers." Others were not effective, such as this mixed metaphor: "She knew there would always be room for him on her mental canvas, and that the intricate threads weaving her past to her present and future would continue to bear his shadow.

I think the balance is too much on the side of Stella's interior world, and more detail and dialog could be devoted to the action happening around her. The scenes at the departmental reception and the campus shop feel like they need more description of the surrounding action.

The shifting of the narrative to different characters kept the story interesting. However, these vignettes centered around each character are not as cohesive as those in Story 1, where the connections of the supporting characters to each other, as well as to the main character, were better explained.
I think we only really get the perspective of Stella in this story.

The language seems original, if strange at times. For example, in this paragraph: "Hey, Stella! he cried earnestly, though he made no effort to push past the gaggle of hungry seniors. The hunger insinuated itself into Stella's memories, a concept that seemed symptomatic to her past but which she could not comprehend. The hunger she had felt earlier was somewhat satiated, but she knew it would never be entirely extinguished." The "hunger" seems literal at the beginning of the paragraph, but figurative by the end.
I don't think form or structure is original

I don't think there is much here for the reader to take away, although it is more interesting than Stories 2 and 3. This story needs more attention to ways to connect the supporting characters to each other. Each is connected to Stella in some interesting way, but their relationships to each other (and thus their significance to Stella) are not developed as much as they could be.

This story does pretty well with metaphor and figurative language, as well as with interesting, fairly complex description of characters and the main character's thoughts. However, I don't think there is a great deal of meaning developed, through symbolism, or the elaboration of literary themes, beyond the surface meaning.
More detail about the physical world, the things and actions surrounding Stella, would improve the story.
Most of the characters are not developed very well, and seem to be character types rather than real people, much in the same way as in Story 1.

Technically there's no way that this story could end that would feel natural and earned, since there's no plot and therefore no it can't end in a particularly satisfying way. But both Johan and Carl end their relationships with the narrator, and then the story just... stops. Technically, this is a natural ending to the story, since the story was about these two relationships. But the fact that the story doesn't extend beyond the relationships at all makes me wonder why we read it in the first place. Does the narrator not have any worth outside of these two men? Is the only reason their story is interesting because it intersects with Johan and Carl? It makes me wonder what the point was.

Yes and no -- the technical answer to the question is that, yes, the pieces of the story work together to form a whole. The story details the narrator's romantic and relationships with several men in her life, and advances somewhat chronologically. (They're sleeping with Carl, then starts to date Johan, then Carl finds out and is upset, and then things don't work out with Johan.) However, there's no plot to be found here -- the story just chronicles the various relationships and then ends.

There are no real scenes to be found. I suppose you could argue that certain moments like the costume party are scenes, but I personally wouldn't really consider two paragraphs of description a scene. Most key events are summary: "Johan says that he isn’t in love with me. He likes me. He’s interested in me. But I don’t have it in me anymore. I can’t be wearing Johan’s clothes. They don’t fit me. I can barely move. Nothing is disgusting.
The story seems to progress chronologically -- there are no scenes, things are just described, but the two relationships both progress from a beginning to an end.

I don't know about sophisticated, but there are allusions present in the text. Some work -- "Her lower back arches under the weight of her own willingness, and the cartridge belt burns into her skin like the lick of a whip. Or does it offer relief, like a doctor’s cool fingertips searching for an inflamed tendon?" And some don't -- "He looks like a member of the Ku Klux Klan. The American South. Mangrove swamps. Banjo on the porch. Root beer. Cornbread. Vio- lence. The heart is a lonely hunter." But they're there!

As mentioned earlier, there are attempts at interiority and exteriority, but they mostly fall flat. Take, for example, the final paragraph. ("I think of temptation itself. What it is. Of being able to give a correct description of the Venus of Willendorf. Of being on all fours with a machine gun. Of arching. Being wide open. And listening for the click.") It's clearly an attempt to be profound and sit inside the narrator's head, but if you really read it, it's just meaningless.

Yes and no -- there are some interesting, and unexpected, moments, such as the teeth moment with Johan. ("Johan says this: "The smell between the teeth, the one that comes out when you floss, is disgusting. Absolutely disgusting."") But I wouldn't say that's a turn, or particularly surprising. Ultimately, we don't know enough about the narrator, Carl, Johan, or their relationships to feel surprised about anything that takes place.

The characters are all given their moment to shine -- such as Johan's "teeth" moment above, finding the condoms under Johan's bed, etc. Again, there's not really enough about these characters to feel inaccurate; you could tell me anything about them and I'd believe it because they're still blank sketches at this point. I wouldn't say that any of the characters are unlikable; they all seem to have pretty surface-level relationships with one another.

There are no clichéd phrases that I can remember, but the entire premise of this story is a huge cliché. I mean, come on? Again: a story that aims at literary pretension about two surface-level and failed sexual relationships? That's about as cliché as they come. ("Cat Person," for one.)
The writing isn't bad, but there's nothing original about it. It's just a story about a person in two shitty relationships that end.
Per the above: it's really just a story about a person in two shitty relationships that end. There are no takeaways, there are no profound insights, we don't even get a sense of character growth.

Very surface level. As discussed in earlier answers, there's no complexity, no takeaways, and no growth. It just describes a situation that once was and now is not, and none of the parties seem particularly changed by it.

Yes and no. I wouldn't say there are really scenes here -- and, thus, the opportunities for sensory details are few and far between -- but one of the most evocative sections is about the black mold in the beginning, which feels sensory, so I'll give it to them.
Zero character development! The character doesn't learn anything or change in any way. I mean, refer to the last paragraph that I pasted in an earlier answer. What does that even mean?!

As per my earlier answer, it's clear how all of the different characters and their weight on Jane's life led her to setting boundaries and focusing on herself, entering into her new relationship with Johan.

Yes -- we get a sense of all of the different players in Jane's life (Lizzy, Carl, Johan, Martin) and how they drain and buoy her in turn. Each character adds up to influence her climactic decision to focus on herself and commit to her relationship with Johan.
There are multiple scenes -- Jane wanting to text Carl, Jane consoling Martin, Jane at the coffee shop, Jane meeting Johan -- and summaries, like Jane lying in bed at night considering her life.
The story takes place over a couple of scenes set over two subsequent days. Each scene feels like it's given equal consideration and weight.

Not really -- it's a simple story, and I don't think that it really needed metaphor or allusion to succeed. I didn't miss it. But of course that doesn't change the answer to this question: that it wasn't present. Well... I guess kind of? "Jane finally cast off her anchor, embarking on a journey propelled by the most powerful force of all. Jane grasped Johan's hand tightly, navigating into uncharted waters with her compass pointing due north, toward the future - and toward love." At the end that's an allusion, I guess.

Yes, the story does this well. We get a good sense of Jane's interiority. ("Jane gazed out her window at the inky sky, taking a deep breath. Did she have the courage to cut herself loose? To face the seas of uncertainty, confront her fear of vulnerability, and finally start her own odyssey into the unknown?") But there's also a good amount of exteriority, as well. (""I'm saying I'm done running. That I want you, and only you. If you'll have me." Jane smiled, warmth flooding through her as she pulled him into a kiss.")
I wouldn't say there are any turns in the story -- everything felt pretty in-tune, forecast, and expected.
The story fleetingly touches on other characters like Lizzy and Martin. They're not given any narrative weight at all, but we do understand who they are and why they do what they do.
Again, I don't think that this is a bad thing. But the whole "angsty college student figuring out how to manage friendships and a situationship" scenario isn't exactly original.
To be clear, I don't think this story needs originality in form or structure. But, no, it's told chronologically, it's very straightforward, and things progress in a linear fashion.

Technically? It doesn't really seem like an outright "message" of the book, but Jane does quite a bit of ruminating on the need to set boundaries with friends who take or expect too much from her, and it's only once those boundaries are set that she's able to take the next step in deepening her relationship with Johan. It's very possible that the reader might take that message -- the importance of boundaries and protecting your inner peace -- into their own life.

Although there all multiple levels of meaning here -- there's the inciting action, Jane's reaction to it, etc. -- they're all surface-level. Everything, from Jane's realization about boundaries to her decision to pursue Johan, is very explicitly stated.
There are good sensory details throughout. ("The familiar music of The Smiths drifted through the paper-thin dorm walls again as Lizzy agonized over Martin's unanswered text.")

As discussed earlier, Jane goes on a clear emotional journey throughout the story. At the beginning, she feels that she's being emotionally overloaded by the drama and struggles of her friends. In the middle, she decides that she needs to set boundaries and focus on herself. At the end, she has the bandwidth to pursue a relationship with Johan.

Yes and no -- the end of the story did feel natural and earned, as it "flashed forward" and showed Emma's successes, which were made possible by her journey of growth and the fact that she recognized that her relationship with Carl no longer served her. However, it also dragged on quite a bit longer than it needed to. I don't think that we needed the "days turned into weeks turned into months" epilogue.

Yes, everything in the story was linked and related, from Emma's relationship with her friends Lizzy and Martin to her relationship with her boyfriend Carl and how letting go of Carl and investing more time in her own creative pursuits allowed her to thrive in college and her academic research.
The entire story was presented more as summary than scene. The adage is that writers need to "show not tell," and this story was almost completely "telling.

The timeline here felt a little bit unclear. The first half of the story, which covered Emma's early days in college and her road trip with Lizzy, Martin, and Carl, felt fine, but then it jumped forward in spurts to talk about her ongoing academic studies. There was an "as days turned into weeks and months" flash forward, and we ended with Emma as an adult professional reflecting back on her college days. None of that felt necessary or balanced.
There aren't really any idioms, metaphors, or allusions present in the story.

There's very little interiority in the manuscript -- we're told what Emma is thinking and feeling, but that's not the same as true interiority, which is (as mentioned above) "showing" us by immersing us into Emma's POV and experiences. We also don't get any pieces of exteriority like dialogue; there's none present in the story.
There were no turns in the story. Everything significant that happened, like Emma ending her relationship with Carl, was very clearly forecast in the text.

We don't get a ton of the other characters in the beginning of the story, but we do get to sit with Carl and hear about his own growth at the end, in a path that's paralleled Emma's. We learn that their break-up served both of them well. So it wasn't just Emma that got good character development.
As discussed above, the entire premise of the story -- a young woman in college learning how to balance her relationships and her personal growth and studies -- is hardly original.
The story progresses chronologically, and is about a young woman in college learning how to balance her personal relationships with her own growth and studies. None of that is wholly original.

I suppose that a reader could follow Emma's journey and take away the message that it's a good and worthwhile pursuit to focus on yourself and your own interests and personal and professional development, even over other people in your life. But I wouldn't say that's the point of the story, and it's hardly a unique or original idea.
There is zero subtext in this story. As mentioned earlier, the story is awful at "telling not showing." The entire thing reads like a synopsis of a story rather than a story itself.
The story tries in the beginning. ("The coffee shop was buzzing with energy as the scent of freshly ground beans filled the air.") But that ambition is brief and quickly abandoned.

I wouldn't say that no character feels like they're present simply to fulfill a plot requirement -- Lizzy and Martin drop out pretty quickly, and Johan is only mentioned once, clearly as a remnant from some sort of prompt. But Emma is given significant character development, and Carl, the only other prominent character, is very intentionally given development to match Emma's own.
The story ends incredibly abruptly, in media res. There's no real ending, it just... stops right in the middle of a paragraph.

There is no narrative propulsion to this story, nor a beginning, middle, or end. The story only describes various scenes of Stella interacting with Martin, Johan, and Lizzy. There is no plot to speak of -- except of, perhaps, Stella's growing dislike of Martin, although that's a stretch -- and it ends abruptly.

This story is only scenes -- there are too many scenes! -- but, yes, there are scenes present, as well as summary, and they feel... reasonably balanced, I guess? It's not well executed, but it's there.
There's no real sense of time here -- it just describes various scenes, and it's mostly unclear how they relate or are situated with one another. They each exist wholly in their own space.

There is so much overwrought idiom and allusion in this story that it's clear the importance of such was fed into an AI prompt. "Martin was another envelope addressed to the past, and like the many other letters, undeserving of postage." "She could feel the weight of them on her soul, like heavy coins in a rusted tin box." "Their friendship was a slow burn, with the occasional scalding, like hot wax dripping onto Stella's hand and filling in the spaces between her fingers." It's so clunky!

I wouldn't really say there's any interiority here. There are certainly attempts, but they're rather nonsensical. ("Stella liked Johan because he was foreign and probably lonely, and more importantly, elegant. The fact that he was already entrenched in the PhD program was a source of comfort for her—his future was as impenetrable as her past seemed.") Stella liked Johan because he was foreign and probably lonely? How does that make sense?
There are no turns! It's impossible to have a turn when there's no plot.

Yes, the story provides the perspectives of Stella and Martin, as well as Johan and Lizzy.
