Although they're not all presented convincingly and accurately: Martin seems to be well-liked at first, but then is suddenly disliked with no real explanation as to why the transition took place. It's explained that he's loud, gregarious, and talks too much -- that he can't read the room -- but there's no transition between liking him and not. We like him in one scene, we don't in the next.

I... guess there are no clichés? The good news about nonsensical phrasing and no plot is that it's all original! ("Time travel, Stella thought to herself, must be reserved for memories, as only therein can humans experience both pain and pleasure without the physical strain.") It sounds like a cliché, but it's actually so nonsensical that I'm sure nobody's said it before.

I suppose you could say that the story is original such that there's no plot and simply a collection of mostly unrelated scenes, but I don't think that's an intentionally original decision so much as it is a lack of skill.
There are zero takeaways here. How could there be? There's no plot or character development!

There's really no subtext here -- everything is spelled out for the reader in painful detail. ("The fifth time Stella saw Martin, she was starting to feel his weight on her scale. "Hey, Stella! he bellowed, stretching out her name like a pair of pants that had narrowly stopped fitting.

She fought back a sigh.")
There are no sensory details present in the text.
There is no character development present in the text. It's hard to have any development, when the timeline of the story is unclear and it's not really known how the scenes relate to one another.

As the story does not follow a conventional arc, the ending doesn't provide a definitive answer to the protagonist's problems. The ending connects with the opening of the piece through the reference to a naked woman holding a machine gun, and cleverly morphs that image with the sculpture of the Venus of Willendorf.
The story does not follow a conventional narrative arc but it's nevertheless engaging. The series of images presented come together through the narrator's voice and the impact they have on her life.
Specific scenes are very vivid, such as when the protagonist is slapped. This is well-balanced with other moments when the relationships between the other characters are summarised.

This is a very short piece but it feels packed with action and there is a sense of the character's development through her relationships with the men in her life. The author is skilled at using short sentences to accelerate the time of the story.
The author shows a skillful manipulation of language. One remarkable instance is when condoms are compared to 'dry petals, a thumb brace, masking tape.'

This question doesn't necessarily apply to this story. This is because the narrator is intentionally avoiding introspection, it's a story about casual sex and encounters and not thinking much about its consequences. There is a sense that the protagonist is hiding what they would like to say or how they feel, which suggests an interiority which we don't get access to; for that reason I would give the story a pass.

This story isn't trying to be surprising, however certain scenes catch the reader off-guard and add to the narration. An example is the slap scene, but generally the story isn't concerned with twists.

The male characters in the story tend to blend together slightly, this is a possible fault of the shortness of the piece and the breezy tone it adopts. However the secondary characters serve to show new and interesting facets of the protagonist.

The story very deftly avoids clichés. A way it does so is by keeping its descriptions short and its images fresh. An example would be the description of the Practical Pig: 'He looks like a member of the Ku Klux Klan. The American South. Mangrove swamps. Banjo on the porch. Root beer. Cornbread. Violence.'

This kind of story isn't new and pervades in many autofiction narrations. The author, while keeping the reader engaged, doesn't do enough to be qualified as original. An interesting use of images and description is the closest it amounts to originality in form.

As said in my previous answer, this isn't a new kind of narrative, but a new take on a popular kind of autofiction writing. I would say that the reader obtains a new perspective rather than a unique and original idea.
By leaving out many things, the story hints at a rich undergrowth of sensations and feelings. The final paragraph is a very skilled use of subtext through the reference to ancient erotic art.

There is little sensory description of the world that these characters inhabit, but what we get is enough to imagine the rest. The first paragraph is one of the most sensory, with its description of black mould on the walls. Another image that stood out to me was: 'I embrace him. He is moist and engorged.'

This is a tricky question to answer since, as this is a flash fiction piece, there isn't enough time nor the need to develop each character fully. There is a sketch of the narrator's feelings and the sort of people she relates with. I wouldn't necessarily fault the story for this lack of development, however. After all it succeeds at what it's trying to do: capture a young person's feelings and experiences at a very particular period in her life.
The ending fails to resolve any of the problems set up by the story in a satisfactory way. Instead we get a fairytale ending that reeks of conformism.

The story has such a predictable and uninteresting plot line that it fails to be engaging or satisfying. The repeated reliance on trite images and sentiments bars any sensible reader from engaging with the piece in a meaningful way.

There are some very bad paragraphs where the narrator discusses her friend's relationships in very dry and uninteresting terms. These do not add to the narrative but instead give the whole text a feeling of unreality.
There is no attempt at compression of time. The story is straightforward and tricks the reader into a straightforward conclusion.

There are some laughable attempts at metaphor. One of these occurs at the end of the story: 'Jane grasped Johan's hand tightly, navigating into uncharted waters with her compass pointing due north, toward the future - and toward love.' This isn't sophisticated or even insightful.

There is no heart or real observation in this story. It has the same emotional range that is so distinguishable in AI-generated stories: a character has a challenge to overcome, certain obstacles come up but they are eventually resolved and the protagonist learns from their experience. Such a trite formula does not lead to 'creative' or valuable writing.
There are no turns per se, and the problems set up at the beginning are resolved in a predictable way. The narrative arc is very flat and disappointing.

The perspective of the protagonist feels so detached from any sense of reality that we can't imagine it's convincing or accurate. It feels like a robotic attempt at understanding how humans feel about other people.

The form is full of clichés and so is the writing. This becomes especially apparent in the romantic descriptions: 'Being with Johan felt reckless and alive.' These fail to convey any emotion to the reader.

As I've described in my previous answer, the structure is not original but rather a recycled formula. What was interesting about the 1st story (descriptions of sexual desire, catchy images) are watered down to a parody of itself, which lacks all the formal inventiveness of the previous story.

The recylcing of forms and shallowness of thought will fail to make an impact on any discerning reader. The story is too transparent about what it's trying to achieve or how it's trying to make the reader feel, which is never a good thing in literature.

The text operates on a single, surface level throughout. The attempt at tying together the protagonist's assessment of her friend's relationship problems and her own successful relationship is not effective.
There are no attempts at realistic world building precisely because the story is rooted in cliché and outdated forms. Besides there are no descriptions of the world that these people inhabit.
The sensations that the protagonist experiences do not feel real or relatable. Instead they seem like the product of a bad TV script, or an unsuccessful attempt at a sitcom.
There are several turns where we are led to believe the story is about to end, but then it does not. So when the ending finally comes it's disappointing.
The story is too long and loses the reader's attention throughout. Just like the previous story, it is too transparent about its intetions, which it fails to accomplish.
There is little distinction between scene and summary. The scenes feel like they're being glazed over, almost like summaries themselves.

There is a very clumsy attempt at time compression in this text. This is signalled by the opening of the paragraph usually: 'Days turned into weeks, and weeks turned into months [...] As days turned into weeks and months.' This is not sufficient to keep us interested or to keep an accurate track of the timeline of the story.

The images are overused and bland. There is a lack of specificity which makes the whole reading experience vague and uninteresting. An example of such image is this: the 'scent of freshly ground beans' — not terrible, but not good either.
There isn't a successful description of the characters' interiority. We are only offered reductive explanations for their actions.
There are too many turns to keep track of. None of these are interesting, and their abundance makes them tiresome.
We only really get the protagonist's perspective, and it does not feel convincing or compleling. This is in part due to the excess of clichés.
What passes as psychological insight in this story is simply clichéd self-help talk. This is an example: 'She was excited to take on the next chapter, eager to see where her journey would lead her.'
The structure of the story doesn't hold together. It's too long and unfocused, the opposite of what makes a flash fiction piece work.

The average reader will be bored by this story and put it down. There is no substance to it, no reason to keep reading it. It isn't informed by a discerning, authoritative mind who is organising thoughts in a beautiful or original arrangement.

There is no subtext. Instead we are offered the language of business and corporations: 'single-minded focus,' 'reconnecting on a deeper level,' 'the power of personal growth and following one's personal path.'

The clichéd ideas and images fail to make the world of the story believable. 'And as the coffee shop continued to buzz with the trappings of student life...'. This does not capture what being in a coffee shop actually feels like.
The protagonist goes through several transformations and events, but there is no sense of real development. This is because the ending is too clearly manufactured to deliver a message.
There is no resolution to the very basic plot elements raised by the story. The story simply drops off at the end
There is hardly a narrative. The story feels loose and unfinished.
The scenes are unsatisfactory despite some poor attempts at dialogue and description. This is mostly because of the exasperating metaphors and strained similes the author indulges in.
There are some attempts at manipulating time, but these don't lead anywhere. The story is clumsily divided in different sections which don't contribute to the development of the plot.

The writer overindulges in bad clichés and excessive metaphors. One example (of many): ' Painful memories were a reminder to Stella that she had grown and evolved, the college campus serving as her growth rings.' This borders on parody, but it lacks the self-awareness to be called that.

There is no interiority as seen in the ending which does not fit into the rest of the story or is justified in any way by the protagonist's earlier motivations. There is a fan fiction-y tone to the piece and to its (lack of) emotional development
There aren't any turns. The protagonist falls for a man, then for another one, and picks him in the end.
We only get one perspective which is hardly developed or satisfactory. There is an attempt to introduce other perspectives through dialogue, but this is so mediocre that it fails to accomplish that.

There is an exasperating amount of cliché. This line is an example: 'The hunger she had felt earlier was somewhat satiated, but she knew it would never be entirely extinguished.' It is neither illuminating or original.
There is no originality of form here. The story is poorly structured and fails to resolve even the most basic of plot elements.
I can't imagine the reader would get anything from this story other than a recycled perception of romance. The story is also unfinished, which doesn't do it any favours.

The story fails to even tell a convincing tale, let alone have any implication of subtext. While the previous two stories were very clumsy at delivering a message, at least they had a message to offer.

The author mostly relies on vague and unconvincing metaphors, which do not capture the likeness of real life. An example is this sentence: 'Stella found herself reminiscing about the tightrope she had been traveling on during her first year at university, where the landscape bordered the unmanageable and ungovernable.' It fails to create an accurate image of the university.
The character of Stella feels flat and shallow. This is because her actions at the end of the story are dissonant from the earlier parts of the story.

The ending certainly isn't abrupt, but it bears the classic AI trademark of not knowing when or how to end the story. There are many, many, many paragraphs that state, and then re-state, and then re-state again how the construction changed the faculty and how improved they and their "legacy" is after the repairs have been made. ("As the academic year drew to a close, there was a sense of accomplishment and relief emanating throughout the halls of Reedwood University." "But it wasn't just the building that had been restored; it was their spirits as well." "As the summer sun bathed the newly refurbished building in its warmth, there was an air of optimism among the faculty." "And so, as the academic year came to a close, the faculty of Reedwood University stood united, knowing that they had weathered the storm and emerged stronger on the other side." "The repairs at Reedwood University were more than just a restoration of the physical building; they were a catalyst for personal growth." And it continues...)

Yes, the elements of the story form a natural progression: it begins with the interminable and insufferable construction work on Reedwood University, then the work completes, and then the staff of the university learn how necessary the work was in improving the university, and the newfound revelation and the improved facilities bonds them together stronger than ever before.

There are both scenes and summaries in the book -- it begins with a scene ("Dr. Elizabeth Thompson, a professor of history, paced her office, her footsteps creating a syncopated rhythm with the dripping sounds from above.") -- but there's only one brief scene in the beginning, which is quickly abandoned for summary. (I've already pasted in an earlier answer the many, many paragraphs that close out the story, which are all summary...)

The stretching of time did not feel balanced -- we only get a page or so of the teachers suffering through these repairs, and then we get interminable paragraphs and paragraphs of how much the repairs have changed them afterwards. This led to an imbalance: the reader didn't really see the suffering, and so the mountainous descriptions of cathartic joy feel unearned and out of nowhere.
No, there are not really any idioms, metaphors, or literary allusions present in the text.

The story is pretty surface-level, and focuses mostly on interiority by describing the faculty's frustrations and woes and then their exuberance once the repairs are complete. Otherwise, the characters are passive and don't exhibit and exterior displays.

There are no turns in the story. I suppose it could be considered a turn that the faculty realize how necessary the repairs were at the end and the new facilities seemingly change them forever, but that's both unsurprising and not really appropriate (given the magnitude of their about face) so I wouldn't consider it one. Otherwise, things progress naturally and as expected: there are repairs, they're annoying, the repairs end, the faculty is grateful.

Technically, yes, there are the perspectives of more than one character: we see Dr. Elizabeth Thompson, as well as Dr. Jonathan Miller and Dr. Sarah Morgan, both at the beginning and end of the story. Their perspectives are conveyed both convincingly and accurately, but that's also because they have no character: they're only given two or three sentences of description each. It's hard to say that something is inaccurate when you have no idea who this person is.

Technically, yes, there are clichés present -- the writing is surface-level enough! Technically, the very idea of disruptive construction, academics who like their peace and quiet, etc. is a cliché, and for me that falls under the category of "there are no original story ideas anyway.
There's no originality present. The writing is rote and unimaginative, and the narrative progresses in a linear and entirely expected fashion, as described in an earlier answer.

I suppose that you could argue that the reader will take away the concept that sometimes we must persevere through hardships in order to reap the rewards on the other side. But that's hardly a unique and original idea, and it's a stretch to say that the author of the story intended for that takeaway, I think.
Everything in the story exists at a pretty surface level state.

The sensory details are sparse, but they are there. Only in the beginning: "The incessant dripping, the sodden carpets, and the lingering smell of mildew permeated every corner of the building. It was a tangible reminder of their collective distress." There aren't really any sensory details later on in the story. But they are included in the beginning, so there's that.

The faculty each go on their journey of displeasure and discontentment, which ends once the construction ends, and they are inspired to go onto greater and greater heights. ("Dr. Miller, once frustrated by the constant noise and dust, became more patient and understanding. He felt a deep connection to his colleagues, as they had all endured the same trials together." "Dr. Morgan, who had previously despised the crowded faculty lounge, now saw it as a symbol of unity and strength." "The bond among the faculty became so strong that they decided to take their newfound resilience beyond the confines of Reedwood University. They organized a series of motivational talks and workshops for other academic institutions, sharing their journey of overcoming challenges and finding strength in the face of adversity. Their stories inspired countless others who had experienced their own trials and tribulations.")

Yes, the ending fits with the rest of the story: we get to see the end of the repairs, that the repairs were successful, and how going through this period of trials and tribulations has brought the staff closer together. I wouldn't say that the ending is well-written -- "Thus, the story concludes..." "Finally, it was the enduring strength of the faculty..." -- but it does fit with the rest of the story in terms of theme and tone.

Yes, the progression of the story makes sense: it begins with explaining the faulty construction that's been done on the faculty building and the resulting damage due to the rains, then details the arduous repairs and the strain that it put on the faculty, and ends with some sense of peace and order being restored once the repairs are complete.

There were no scenes present in the story, only summaries. We didn't even get characters! We're told of individual "department heads," but they're never given names and never appear past the initial vignette. I'm not really sure that you could have scenes without characters!
The internal chronology of the story didn't feel slow or rushed. It described each stage of the damage, repairs, and aftermath with what felt like equal attention.

There are literary devices used within the text -- "A now-yellowing copy of the complex blueprints had been unearthed from a forgotten cabinet, their unfurling before the twitchy, anxious faculty reminiscent of a long-overdue revelation, a band-aid being ripped off an old wound." -- but there aren't many, andI wouldn't call them sophisticated. (The above is, to a degree, nonsensical. Once you strip away the fluff, you're left with a sentence saying that the blueprints unfurled like a Band-Aid being ripped off of a wound?)

There's really no interiority -- as I've mentioned in previous answers, there aren't really any characters apart from very, very, very rough sketches of individuals in the department, so there's no real way to get interiority from them.
No, I wouldn't say that the story had any turns -- as discussed in an earlier answer, everything progressed in a way that seemed fairly expected and appropriate.

As mentioned earlier, there aren't really any characters in the book. Figures are given vague descriptions ("the department head," etc.) but nobody with personalities or motivations beyond a brief moment of frustration or protest. Thus, there aren't really any perspectives.

The story feels pretty clichéd to me, maybe because it's so generic (i.e. no characters). But there are paragraphs that end with, "Thus, the story concludes," and meaningless aphorisms like, "That time was, above all else, an extraordinary period of trenchant disputes, heated challenges, deep introspection and, ultimately, acceptance and endurance - a testament to the unwavering spirit of academic persistence." I guess they're more generic than clichés, but still.

I suppose one could argue that it's original to tell a surface-level story with no real characters in it, because nobody else has really done that before, but I don't think that's a function of originality... otherwise, things pretty much advance along as expected. There are repairs, they're annoying, the faculty goes crazy, they come out the other side. Nothing new or surprising.

Again, everything progresses as planned and there are no characters to speak of, so I'm not sure how one could obtain anything from this story. I suppose that you could argue there's a "lesson" in the sense that the story ends with a group of individuals finding commonality and bonding over adversity, but that really feels pretty tacked on at the end, and I think it would be a stretch to say that the story is moralistic in any way.
It's hard to have subtext when there's no dialogue, no characters, and no interactions between characters!

Yes, there are some good sensory details. "The Complex had transformed into a bewildering network of spaces, twisted by snaking two-by-fours, serpentine copper pipes, and plywood bridges. External experts continuously slathered on tar, sealant, and temporary cladding at remarkable and ever-increasing costs. In order to keep the walls dry, workers employed propane heaters, further adding a faint petroleum scent to the persistent smell of dampness.

Again, there are no real characters here, and those that appear are unnamed and present for a paragraph at most. There's no development to speak of, and the development that does occur to end the story happens to the collective as a whole, rather than individual characters.

Yes, the story ends as the day itself ends, which is natural. I'm not sure about earned -- the nostalgia that Professor Grey feels seems rather abrupt, given that the entire story that preceded it focuses on his frustration and annoyance with the building and its administrators. But it is an ending, and it doesn't seem wholly inappropriate to the character.

The story takes place over the course of a Monday, as Professor James Grey arrives at work and observes the decrepit workspace around him, struggles to get any work done given the work hazards and distractions, and then reflects upon the (imperfect) history of the building as he leaves in the evening.

There are both summaries -- "After making a few phone calls, he managed to gather a group of like-minded professors the English and History departments who shared his concerns over the neglect of the old tower. They spent several hours over the next few days meticulously planning and preparing to ensure their message would be heard clearly by the administration." -- and scenes -- "Professor Grey slowly climbed the four flights of creaking stairs that led to his attic office on the top floor, each step threatening to give out under his weight. The staircases were made of an ancient wood that protested with every movement as he climbed towards his office. His frail body and advancing age made the hike up the stairs a dangerous endeavor each morning he came into work. Most of the offices were empty over the summer, but he could hear muffled cursing coming from Dr. Lisa Hart's makeshift laboratory on the second floor.
The time in the story is well done -- as mentioned earlier, it takes place over the course of a day, which is an appropriate and effective way to present time.

Nothing notable, and I'm not sure about sophisticated, but there's some higher-level engagement with language here: "After dedicating over two decades of his life to this institution, the neglect of the old tower felt like a betrayal of the ideals that had drawn him to academia.

The story is mostly interior, describing Professor Grey's thoughts and emotions as he goes about his (rather anti-climactic) day. (" He took a deep breath and resumed his seat, picking up the papers once more. The noises raged on around him, but he focused his attention on the analysis in front of him, red pen scribbling comments and suggestions in the margins. For a moment, all faded away except the thoughts and ideas on the page. His calling had always been to open minds, not bemoan circumstances beyond his control.") It's appropriate for the story, but doesn't really involve much exteriority.
I wouldn't say that the story has any turns, unless you count the "turn" that Professor Grey ends the story with a newfound appreciation for the building.

The perspective of Professor Grey is portrayed convincingly and accurately, but his is the only perspective in the story -- the story follows him and doesn't really involve meaningful interactions with any other characters. ("The disturbances disrupted his concentration, and he let out an exasperated sigh. The repairs never seemed to improve the status and conditions of the building. The stall tactics of the contractors and administration drove the professors and students of the tower to utter frustration.His eyes drifted to gaze out the arched window, observing the students walking below on their way to midmorning classes. Their lively chatter and laughter drifted up to him, reminding Professor Grey of his own college days when he had studied under his mentor in this very same office.")

Its crumbling halls had witnessed the transformation of young minds, shaped by those devoted to cultivating wisdom and intellectual curiosity.Though the university claimed to prioritize progress, their actions showed a lack of care for the foundation on which their institution had been built. However, as long as there were still devoted professors fueling student minds with passion for knowledge within its walls, the old tower would stand as a monument to the timeless ideals of academia." I'd say that paeans to crumbling halls of education and the power of academia is pretty clichéd.
The story is chronological, doesn't contain any surprises or hybridity, and makes sense as it follows Professor Grey throughout his day.

Not really -- one of the "themes" of the story could be that old things have value because of what they've been through and what they've seen. But I hardly think that a reader will finish reading this with the takeaway that they should put up with decaying and crumbling infrastructure as Professor Grey does in the story!

Everything seems pretty surface level and self-explanatory to me. For example: "His mentor had instilled in him a deep appreciation for literature and passion for education transcended the challenges of the setting. Professor Grey was determined to maintain that same persevering spirit with his own students.

Yes, there are actually quite nice sensory details. "Dusk fell softly outside the great arched window, the chatter of students now replaced by the chirping of crickets. The repairs had ceased for the day, leaving an unnatural silence in their absence." I liked that section a lot!

I'm not quite sure how to answer this one -- technically, yes, Professor Grey develops throughout the story. It begins with his frustrations regarding the building and ends with his reflections on how there's a story and history to be told within those flaws. But I get the sense that he's going to show up to work the next day and be frustrated all over again -- the story didn't impart lasting change to me, just a temporary moment of reflection.

Yes, and the story ending here feels more natural than the previous stories, because it follows the truths of human behavior. Rather than finding some profound meaning in their suffering, the professors here accept that nothing will ever change, and just keep living their lives in hopes of tenure. It's bleak and darkly humorous.

Yes, the story tells a satisfying tale of an apartment building undergoing construction and the trials and tribulations that befall its academic residents while construction is underway. The disparate elements of the story work together -- there is a beginning, when construction is announced to start; a middle, where the construction and the corresponding drama ensures; and an end, where the professors essentially give up on their complaints.

Yes, there are both summaries -- "For three weeks, the noise level was terrible, from nine to five, Monday through Friday, with no pause." -- and scenes -- "Within an hour, a fit young man arrived and handed everyone he met a business card. The card said that he was the vice-president of the company. The man noted the places where water was still seeping in. He said that there would likely be mold growth, and, should the mold be the color of soot, coal, or volcanic ash, they would need to call in the hygienist to culture it. Not all strains are toxic, he informed them. Some were perfectly O.K. In addition, he’d gone up to the roof and found no visible faults around the pulley system, so perhaps the leak was a preëxisting condition that had suddenly, coincidentally, got worse. "Things like this do happen, he insisted, and added that, once the scaffolding was removed, the foundation would naturally rise up, against gravity, to its previous position. Then he tipped his hard hat at the professors and wished them a good day.

Yes, the story feels appropriately balanced. We go through the length of the construction process and get the highlights -- it doesn't feel like we're missing anything, but we're also not spending time on meaningless scenes, either. It's well-paced.

I'm not sure if they're sophisticated, per se, but yes, they're present: "So this is what it must feel like to live inside a tooth that a dentist is trying to drill. The tooth occupied her thoughts nightly.

Not really -- I would say that the story tells more than it shows. (Look at the example above, of the conversation between the two married professors. We don't really get any interiority from either of them, and we're told what they're thinking and feeling rather than shown it.) It's an effective way to flit around a large group of characters, but I wouldn't exactly say it's balanced.
Yes, it felt both appropriate to human nature and somewhat surprising that the professors just gave up and accepted the leaks and faulty construction as their new way of life.

Yes, the story inhabits the perspectives of several characters, including characters who disagree with one another. ("The math professor was married to the East Asian Studies professor. Not that ironically, the former was Asian and the latter white. Between gallons three and four, the former had drafted an angry e-mail to the school, but then stared at her unnuanced message. She worried about being the squeaky wheel, when she and her husband had upcoming third-year reviews. Still, she asked if he could rewrite and send the e-mail, given both his nuance skills and the fact that the administration might take him more seriously. That would be taking advantage of his privilege, he thought, and shook his head, but encouraged her to send the e-mail, since she should feel empowered to and he was never going to stand in her way. A quarrel about feminism followed. No e-mail was sent.") Although all of the characters mostly align with one another -- they all hate the construction and want it to end -- those perspectives were, I felt, conveyed convincingly and accurately.
I don't think that it's necessary original to follow the story of apartment repairs gone wrong, but I didn't notice any cliché throughout the story.
The story is chronological, doesn't blend genres, and is pretty standard in terms of language and style. There aren't really any significant twists or turns in the narrative.

Not really -- the only idea that's truly presented is that there can be no victory in the face of a corporate behemoth and that resistance is futile, which I'm sure is not intended to be a "moral" of the story, nor is it a unique or original takeaway.

Since the story tells rather than shows, it doesn't really have the opportunity to engage in much subtext. The very nature of telling is that it's all surface level and presented to you at face value.

Yes, there are good sensory details throughout. "The walls of the water-filled units now felt spongy." "He said that there would likely be mold growth, and, should the mold be the color of soot, coal, or volcanic ash, they would need to call in the hygienist to culture it." "In the history professor’s bedroom, a paint bubble, the height and width of a man, appeared on the wall overnight. He poked the bubble, afraid that it might actually be a person, like his department chair, and was sprayed, drenched, in brown water.

Since the story follows all of the residents of the apartment complex, I wouldn't say that any character is developed with any complexity. They're each given personalities or characteristics to help them stand out, but we only get to "know" any of them for a paragraph or two at a time. Most aren't even given names!

The ending feels more like the conclusion to a mediocre essay, attempting to make a point about the 'spirit of resilience' which isn't convincing and cheapens the whole story (if one can call it that)

The story follows a logical progression. However it's hardly engaging and not very satisfying -- the problems faced by the university don't seem real enough, and since none of the characters are engaging the reader doesn't very much care what happens by the end of the story.
It felt like there was much summary and few detailed scenes. Attempts at dialogue were unconvincing.

The piece spends too little time describing what ails the university and its staff, so that we don't particularly care about their plight to begin with. Then most of the story is spent making vague generalisations about improvement and overcoming hardship, which even a mediocre writer would know to get rid of.

The metaphors employed are very poor. The dripping of rain is described as 'a tangible reminder of their collective distress' – metaphors are meant to allow the reader to form connections, not to offer up answers so bluntly and grotesquely. One particularly bad metaphor stood out to me–that of the 'scars' which marked the university building—and it's repeated a few paragraphs later!
As explained above, the characters are never given an interiority that's convincing or appealling. The story lacks any kind of 'emotional' impact.
The story is not surprising. The plot follows a predictable, inane, almost condescending progression.
The story never penetrates into any of the characters it brings up. The tone of the narrator is droll and robotic.
As discussed in previous answers, the metaphors are clichéd, the structure is clichéd, and the characters are plain. So I wouldn't call it original.

The story is structured like a subpar undergraduate essay. Form never even entered my mind; the tone of the story is so trite and uninteresting that the "author" clearly had no consideration for form.

The setup for the story has the potential to be interesting. A university building overrun by flooding could lead to absurd and surreal scenarios. However the predictable turns that the story takes make this go to waste.
The story is as transparent as a traffic sign. It drills its themes with tiresome insistence and doesn't offer the slightest complexity
Not exactly. The only passable image was that of the university walls 'peeling and discoloring'. Other than that there's very little in terms of sensory description.

The characters are not really important to the story; the university as an idea is. A childish conception of 'resilience' and 'camaraderie' (words which are repeated tirelessly in the piece) seems to be more important than any sense of character or real feeling.
As in the previous story, the ending feels like a moralistic success story which neither works nor has any place in literature. It doesn't feel like the story justifies its ending.
The story follows a logical progression and the ending, although unsatisfactory, matches the rest of the story.
I feel that there is too much summary in the story. We never get much insight into the events described.
The pacing is more successful than in the previous story. There are enough incidents to keep the reader interested throughout the story.
The story makes poor attempts at metaphor which result in a bad parody of a gothic style. These threw me off while reading the story.
There is no introspection, and therefore no balance between interiority and exteriority is possible.
There isn't exactly a turn, and narratively the story falls flat. There is a problem, the characters persist, and the problem goes away -- not very convincing.

There are some interesting moments, especially those to do with the different faculties of the university. '"Gnomons," one distressed sophomore muttered, "crossing the River Styx."' This line stood out to me as one that had potential to be funny, but its meaning is simply gibberish.
The themes are clichéd and so are the characters representative of each faculty, so no.

The plot is straightforward and structurally the story isn't interesting or remarkable. There are some poor imitations of a gothic or baroque style at the start, but the 3rd and 5th paragraphs sound like a research essay, making for a jarring experience to read.
The underlying idea of the story is that resilience and friendship help overcome problems. This is neither original nor amusing.
As in the previous story, it is very clear that this is an AI generated piece which lacks any sort of complexity. There is no subtext and the story operates on a surface level.
The images are too wordy and unconvincing. They don't feel like they're the work of a skilled writer.
The characters embody types and are not believeable or at all memorable. Instead they are archetypes of what their professions represent.
The ending left me indifferent. There is no sense that the characters are facing any meaningful dilemmas, nor that the story is headed towards a resolution or change
The story doesn't add up to anything. There is the sketch of a problem, but no attempt at a solution, or no meaningful challenge for the protagonist or the reader.
The scenes are not particularly developed. There is a certain balance between summary and more detailed scenes.
Some appropriate uses of flashback/memory, but generally it shows a lack of skill at utilising time as a narrative device.

There are some attempts at metaphor, but they aren't sophisticated. As we've seen in previous stories, there is one grotesquely overdone simile: 'Like the building, his field of study was antiquated compared to the technical fields emphasized today in this science and technology era.'
There is at least an attempt at interiority, but there is no emotional core to the story, no real heart.
There are no turns, so I wouldn't say so. The story is very straightforward and disappointing in regards to narrative.
There is a single character and we observe his thoughts. The turns that his thoughts take are not very convincing or realistic.

See above. Because it is not an original idea, it relies on clichés that makes the reader roll their eyes constantly. C.f., the last paragraph: 'Though the future was uncertain, that flicker of hope remained as steadfast as the old tower itself.'
As discussed previously, the story is poorly structured and not original in either form or structure. This makes for a shallow reading experience that does not surprise the reader.
None of the ideas or themes discussed here are new or interesting. This is because the story too clumsily reveals what it's about, or what it purports to be about, early on.
This is esentially a story about bad plumbing and man's resilience... so much for subtext.
The opening has some potentially interesting visual details, but the story flops later on. The details are unsatisfactory because they're not original or developed.
It is a good idea (though certainly not original) to channel the story through a single character, but the protagonist of this story lacks complexity and isn't compelling.
The ending matches the tone of the rest of the story. It's a cynical, dry-humour sort of ending, which is not particularly new or interesting but neither is the rest of the story.

The story is convincing and at the end the reader becomes aware that the university is not going to resolve its issues but pass the burden onto the professors. Different voices come together to tell the story.
The bits of dialogue are useful for building scenes, and generally I didn't feel that the story was mostly a summary as I did with the previous stories.
The story has a good pace, it knows when to skip forward in time to propel the narrative. This makes the reading enjoyable.
Some quite amusing images, such as "So this is what it must feel like to live inside a tooth that a dentist is trying to drill." Others, less successful in my opinion, like the 'Spaghetti-like ropes'
Although interiority is only disclosed in passing, these moments are enough to sustain the story. Even though the characters stand for the discipline they teach, there are some moments of humanity.
The narrative action is appropriate, but not surprising. I think the story lacks much interest because of this.
The story hints at distinct characters and their personalities. These are convincing because their dialogue is life-like and amusing,
The images feel fresh and interesting, the characters are not mere archetypes, and therefore cliché is avoided.
Some interesting uses of form, such as the contractors' slide shows, and the reference to e-mails being sent across the departments.
The idea itself is not very original, i.e. about the bureaucracy in academic settings, but the way in which it is presented is, if not new, at the very least interesting.

Some interesting allusions to the university setting, which show a certain sense of humour and engage the reader in the belief that there is more to the story than appears at first sight. The ending is cynical and implies that no change will be accomplished.

There's few sensory details but they're convincing. An example: 'committing indecent exposure, for example, running buck naked across a green field in a Superman cape, as the six-year-old son of the dance professor had done during his first soccer game.' The image takes an unpredictable and entertaining turn.

There isn't much character development, but that's also the point of the story. Professors are just doing what they can to get tenure. This story isn't trying to be an accurate character portrait, and that's not a bad thing.

It didn't really make sense that all of the professors decided to go into motivational speaking after the construction ended? Somehow they felt like they were very resilient due to enduring a natural and like uninteresting event together? I just don't think the construction made sense as a conflict and all of the professors seem really pathetic and annoying due to their lack of resilience through a common situation.

The story was basically about professors being upset about construction going on at their university, then being happy when it ended. none of the professors actually did anything about the problem and instead waited for the construction to finish. It felt like nothing really happened in the story and I found it to drag for a long time.
I think the scene-summary balance is fine. There is a solid amount of scene, which I thought was okay, and summary was used to move the story forward in time, which was also helpful.

The construction ends at around the middle of the story, after which the narrative just follows the professors being happy that it has ended. It should have ended very close to the end of the construction but instead dragged on in a redundant sense that didn't make sense as a narrative arc.

No. The story wasn't interesting in terms of language and I didn't derive any meaning from it. The writing felt like it was written for a school assignment in its genericness and lack of tension and conflict.

No. The professors are externally annoyed at the construction noise and internally annoyed at the construction noise. There was no emotion in the story so there was no way for it to be emotionally flexible.

The story had really no tension or problems: a mandatory construction event (university buildings do need to be repaired? why didn't the professors just go somewhere else?) occurred and made a lot of professors grumpy. The construction inevitably ended and the professors became happy that it ended. There was nothing really interesting that went on and the professors were really annoying because they all seemed really unable to endure normal life things for no reason.

No. The professors aren't distinct from each other as their only traits are that they are annoyed about the construction and then decide to become motivational speakers. Pretty boring and also extremely one-dimensional.

The story didn't really engage with any complex topics or ideas, and felt really cliche in that it was just about professors who were all irritated with construction and then were happy when it ended. I don't really know what the point of this story was as the characters were entirely passive and indistinct from one another.
The story format was standard and chronological. It was paced poorly so the ending was really long, but I wouldn't take that as originality in form so much as incompetence at basic writing.

No. The story followed a bunch of professors who were annoyed at a construction noise and then stopped being annoyed once the noise ended. It was poorly written to the extent of being unique in that it was not good, but I don't think it was intentionally or positively original.

No. The story is really shallow and I don't understand what the person who was writing this was thinking. The professors are annoyed at construction noise. The noise ends. The professors are happy. Then the story ends.

It didn't make sense to me that the professors continued to work in a building that was under construction (was it safe to be in that building? Why couldn't the go somewhere else?). I couldn't see how the construction was actually disruptive to their lives and the rest of the world was poorly contoured.

None of the characters grow. They are entirely flat and homogeneous. Eventually not being upset about noise because the noise ends does not count as character growth. Somehow they are able to make careers as motivational speakers? For people who hear construction and then stop hearing construction? Please make it make sense.

The ending, with the professors completing the task of making the building waterproof, felt natural albeit predictable. I wasn't really into the moralized "diverse people banded together despite their differences" narrative ending but it did make sense for the story to end there even if it felt cringey.

This story was about how professors from different fields banded together to fix a leaky faculty building. I wasn't really sure what this story was trying to accomplish in terms of idea or character, so I felt unmoved and a bit confused as to the point of it once I finished it, but maybe part of this is because I read so much for character.

The story has a good scene-summary balance, with enough details about the troubles the characters endure to produce a lasting image. I think the story makes great use of scene and that the scenes stick in your mind due to their specificity of language and image.

The story is paced fine. We see the extent to which the leak causes problems in the professors' lives and the trouble that living together caused. While the professors were caracatures rather than real people, I think that at least they were amusing. The story really ended close to when the leak ended, which made logical sense to me as a reader.

The story had interesting images (such as the biologists and their buckets of frogs) that I found pleasing to read. Some strange situations re: professors and their belongings/items were amusing so I thought those images were working fine.

There isn't really any depth or interiority to this story. But, the story has great exteriority and external conflict re: the leak and professors being forced to share rooms with professors who clash with them/make their work difficult.

There were lots of surprising images in this story; of an archivist in an oilskin slicker, petroleum scents, buckets of frogs, etc. These images were surprising and kept my attention due to their uniqueness and surprising introductions.

The characters clash due to their annoyance with each other's habits and lifestyles, which I found amusing and also true to life. Characters have different perspectives on their work and how they live their lives, which I thought really worked for this story and allowed contrast.

The story's ending was pretty cliche, with the professors banding together against their differences to fix the leak. That was pretty corny and there wasn't really any particular incident that caused them to feel closer to each other. Because the banding together was unearned, it read as cliche.

The story follows a linear format in which a leak occurs, the professors try to fix the leak, the leak causes professors to have to work in close quarters, and then the leak resolves due to teamwork. Again, I think it's fine to have an unoriginal structure as most stories follow fairly linear formats. So, it was fine here.

The story has some original images (the oilslicker jacket, the frog bucket) that felt original and generative. Other than images, I don't think the story was particularly unique, but this is a good start.
This story was really surface-level but it was amusing to read! I don't think this story is one that needs to be meaningful but I enjoyed it.
Yes! The world feels lived-in and real, with the deluge of rain adding a genuine problem. The story is exaggerated and silly, but the tone is consistent and thus the world seems to fit the story.
The characters don't really develop as they don't really have desires and personalities. This wasn't really a character-driven piece and as such there was no development.

This story felt a bit more interesting in its ending as Professor Grey's protest wasn't resolved. I kind of like it when stories stop right before where one would think they would stop, but I didn't feel like the ending was earned because I wasn't sure what exactly caused Professor Grey to protest and what was at stake for him because of his protest.

While I enjoyed the characters in this story, who have been the most vivid of this set of stories, I didn't find the story to be particularly conclusive in the sense that there wasn't enough build up or risk for Professor Grey to start his protest. I think this story could be pretty good and satisfying if Professor Grey had more at stake and if his relationship with his mentor had more depth.
Yes! This story was mostly in scene and moved pretty seamlessly through time.

The story was paced well. We are introduced to Professor Grey's life and the problem with the university not maintaining the tower. Then, we see the problem escalate and then we see Professor Gray taking action against it (again, it would be good to have more build-up, but that build-up can maintain the current pacing).

The story doesn't really make great use of language. The language was simple but this story had better descriptions of setting and of how Professor Grey had difficulties moving through the world because of his age. I found the world of the story to be pretty lived-in and fun.

The story didn't really have a lot of interiority with Professor Grey or his mentor that seemed to change the stakes of the story. There was good exteriority in the escalating problems of the tower, but I felt like these could have had a bigger impact on Professor Grey's character arc.

The story doesn't really have any twists and turns. However, the story was great because we were following Professor Grey so closely, and I was more interested in following his narrative and development than seeking twists and turns.

Yes! Professor Grey is an interesting character to follow because he's an old guy who works in a tower all the time. As a result, I found his perspective unique and interesting (we don't get a lot of stories about old guys confronting problems).

The story was almost free of cliche except for the ending, in which Professor Grey realizes that he should stand for what he believes in without really any inciting incident for this. So, I think again that the originality would come from the earned-ness of the moment.
This story was linear in terms of its structure. However, this was fine for the story and it did end in a good and surprising place (before the end of the protest).

This story wasn't really original (it's about a guy who is struggling with his building crumbling), but I found it enjoyable. I think if Professor Grey were more unique and developed, that the story could be more original.

The story is surface-level. However, I think if Professor Grey's character is engaging enough, that the story doesn't really need to be deep and meaningful. It just needs to be honest to his experience.
Yes! The tower Professor Grey works in feels lived-in and real. I loved the tangible details of the tower crumbling and thought they were textured well.
Professor Grey needs more motivation for choosing to protest. I'd also like to know what's at stake if Professor Grey chooses to act even without support.

The ending line is perfect. The story's lack of positive conclusion really emphasizes the fact that the struggle for better conditions that the characters fought for throughout the story was futile, and the callousness of the tenured professor at the end really further emphasized that. I was impressed by how much the story was able to accomplish in such a short time.

This story was a political critique of race and its relation to tenure and the university system. It was ironic that the apartment (which was a metaphor for the university) did nothing to fix the problems and the problems only increased but there was no more protest. The last line, about "when you get tenure", was ironic and worked really well.
Great use of scene and dialogue. The summaries were also cleverly interdispersed and passed time intentionally and efficiently.
Yes! The story was paced well and felt even throughout. The story really felt like it was moving toward a conclusion so the ending was surprising despite making perfect sense.

The apartment functions really well as a metaphor for the university and as society. It is never drawn explicitly but the smart political critique made it clear without being too in-your-face about what it symbolized.

Yes, the story balances interiority and exteriority well. I felt like the story focuses more on exteriority but it's definitely clear how the story reflects the broader anxieties of our society (in which governments don't seem to fix problems) as well as that of professors (universities don't improve conditions).
The story ends with a surprising lack of assistance to the community seeking help. Then, the final line from the tenured professor is really ironic and surprisingly callous.
The perspective seems to be fairly homogenous, with little difference between characters and their desires for fixing the apartment. But, this was fine and appropriate for the story's scope.
The story really lacked cliches because of the original way in which it was written. I thought the sentences were structured well without reliance on corniness.

The story definitely felt kind of weird in a good way. I felt like the story's structure around the construction and how it moved from character to character to apartment to apartment was really odd, which I enjoyed!

I don't think the story was particularly original in terms of its themes (government/university negligence), but the way it was written was unique! In that the apartment was a metaphor for society of the university.
Yes! The story does operate at several levels of meaning. The fact that it's a metaphor for negligence and inequity works here and makes a person think about these political issues.

Yes! The apartment's problems are clearly defined and the story felt true to the experience of living in a diverse apartment with lots of structural problem; all the way down to the mold and the people working there saying that it didn't matter.

The characters in the story eventually gave up on their fight, but I don't think this was really development so much as a giving in. But, this story was really about a larger political issue rather than character development.

I think it is a very satisfying ending, it leaves the reader with a wonderful mixture of emotion: the fact that the narrator's father is doomed and soon will be gone is right there along with the ecstatic joy on the dance floor, with "Gloria" being performed. It is a quite cinematic moment, and I think it works very well as an ending.

All the elements of story work together well. The author provides the historical context amid the AIDS epidemic, details about her father's world, and her own in a way that feels balanced and harmonious.

The author uses scenes very effectively to convey the emotional experiences of the narrator. For example, her narrative exposition about the difficulties living as a gay man in the 1980s is framed by her observing her father and the other men moving freely and joyfully on the dance floor.
There is a good balance between the flashbacks, descriptions of the narrators life away over a long period of time, and the events that take place on the cruise.

I don't think this story uses literary allusion, metaphor, or idiom in a particularly sophisticated way. The language is pretty straightforward, and the strength of the narrative is in the way that specific details, about clothing, the physical surroundings, drive the story.

I felt there is a good balance; a lot of the story is the narrators interpretation of her experiences, but we also have a clear idea about what was actually happening, both in flashbacks and on the cruise.

The narrator's happy encounter and friendship with Claire and Tom was appropriately surprising. The reader wonders whether these people will be like other people she has met: judgmental and distant, but they turn out to be good companions, if only temporarily. The narrator's father's death is not a surprise, as it is mentioned early in the story. Still, the realization that the dance is the last one they will have together is somewhat shocking and quite sad.

We don't get too much directly about the perspective of the narrator's father, or Tom and Claire. Yet, I still felt they were convincing characters, probably because the small details the author includes about them are enough to suggest something about them. For example, her father's coming home in the morning, making pancakes, sleeping, and then taking her to the beach—this is a brief and simple list of events, but it manages to convey a complex character who is living the life he wants for himself while also showing care and attention to his daughter.
The author does a good job of using language that avoids cliche.
I don't think there was anything particularly original in the form and structure, they felt familiar.

I think the story was successful in exploring the relationship between father and daughter in unconventional circumstances. The way in which the feelings of awkwardness and self-discovery of adolescence are put beside similar themes in the lives of gay men at a particular point in history makes for a very interesting story.

I thought the way the author insisted on her comfort and familiarity around her father's gay friends contrasted with her descriptions of her own awkwardness, as well as the impending death of her father, which is established fact right from the beginning.

There are plenty of examples of sensory details that evoke the time and place really clearly: the stonewashed jeans, various fabric of the clothing worn by the men on the ship, the bingo-caller, all are very nice details that make this world believable.
Yes, there is enough small detail about even the minor characters Claire and Tom that make them seem real, and not just plot devices.
The ending feels very abrupt, and it is not really clear what the narrator's "newfound understanding" of their father was.

There are parts of this story that simply don't make sense, and it is unclear how they are related. For example, the paragraph that begins "As the cruise wore on..." was particularly nonsensical. Other aspects of the story are jarring, such as the mention of the shared showers and the safe, and it is unclear why they are included.

It is hard to tell what is happening in the scenes, and where scene ends and exposition begins. This passage is an example of this: "However, such counsel left me feeling unfulfilled and restless as dusk approached all too soon. Sensing my yearning for more, my father acquiesced to my desire for a dance, allowing our hands a brief, tender connection that forged a visible harmony around us.

Although the story feels very disjointed and nonsensical, there aren't really any problems with how time is presented. However, everything seems to be happening on a very flat (I'm not sure how to describe it) timeline, where things are happening almost outside of any discernible chronology.

The story does not make sophisticated use of these linguistic devices. Metaphor and simile, where they are found, are not really effective (e.g. "moving in unison like a flock of seagulls—impossible to separate yet full of concealed stutter steps and sudden twists"). It also doesn't really make sense.

Again, like the issues with exposition and scene mentioned above, in this story the differences between the narrator's thoughts and the actions happening in the world are hard to discern. For example, is the part about the wigs happening in the narrator's mind/memory? Is the father actually doing something with wigs? (and why?)

There are surprising turns but they don't seem appropriate. For example, does the father have romantic feelings for the child (i.e. "At the same time, he maintained a cautious distance between our bodies to suppress the dangers he believed were lurking within his ailing heart."). Another example is that it is not clear why the father is "condemned to die.
The only perspective represented seems to be that of the narrator.
The story doesn't use many cliches. It does seem original. However it doesn't make much sense.
There doesn't seem to be anything very original about the form and structure.
I don't think so, the story did not make a lot of sense to me. Maybe I am missing something.
Again, I may be missing something, but I don't think this story makes much sense on the surface level, let alone at the level of subtext.
There are a lot of jumbled up details about things, but they don't evoke the sense that this world is real or believable.
There is no character development to speak of. Even the narrator does not seem to be developed coherently.
The end of the story is redundant and too long.

The end of the story is redundant, and goes on too long. In addition, the description of the final dance under the stars comes before a description of a lot of other activities, whereas that dance should probably be more of a climactic moment.
Yes, with the exception of the end. Too much exposition at the end.

The author does a good job of compressing the time around the various activities they did on the cruise and at ports of call, and focuses more on the dance under the stars. However, as I mention above, the dance should be the climax. The timing of the father's death is also unclear. The reader is left with the impression that he died as soon as he stepped off the ship in Miami.
Metaphors are not very interesting. (e.g. The star is like a dimaond; the sun paints the sky.)
I think the author is successful in balancing description of events on the cruise, and the thoughts of the narrator.
There wasn't much that was surprising in the story. They went on the cruise, had a nice time, made some memories before the father died of cancer. There wasn't much in the way of unexpected twists.
We don't get a lot from the father's perspective, he comes off as a rather one-dimensional character.
There are a lot of cliches. The last two paragraphs consist of more cliche than original writing.
There was nothing very original about the form and structure.

As I mention above, the story is pretty basic. The son makes some nice memories with his father before his father dies. The idea that the son is also learning something about his own sexuality is not really developed, and feels a bit tacked on.

Most of what is happening in this story is at the surface level. At the end, the reader is confronted directly with what the author wants the reader to take away. There is not really any subtext from what I could tell.
The author does furnish the world with details that makes it believable and real: descriptions of the food, of the activities off the ship, of the night sky.
I think the father's character is rather flat, and could be given more depth through the use of more conversation between the son and the father.
The ending of the story is too drawn out and redundant.

The end of this story is redundant, the author keeps repeating the same ideas over and over. The story does not feel coherent because of this, nor does the story feel authentic; the voice of the author is very one-dimensional.
The author does balance scene and exposition pretty well, with the exception of the long ending, where the same ideas are repeated again and again.
Time is stretched out in an unsatisfying way, after the cruise. Aside from the narrator's reuniting with Evan, much of the second half of the story seems to not exist in any particular time at all.
This story does not make sophisticated use of language. Some phrasing is awkward (e.g. "heart in heart"). It is also strange that the author refers to her father by his first name, more than once.
Both the thoughts of the narrator and the action and conversation happening around her seem very formulaic and not very believable.

The reuniting of the narrator and Evan could be a surprising and interesting turn of the story, but it isn't really developed in any detail. They reminisce and share memories in a very vague way, and then they are together. The father's death on the cruise is surprising, but also abrupt, and not all that believable, particularly his dramatic whispering of his final words, which turn out to be vapid cliches.
All the characters seem to be one-dimensional, and not very developed. They tend to communicate in uninteresting cliches (e.g. "'Life works in mysterious ways,' he mused.")
As I mention above, the story is full of cliches, and there doesn't seem to be much original about the writing.
The form and structure are not original.
There is nothing really unique or original about this story. It seems like one cliche after another. An example is the final paragraph, which is comprised exclusively of shallow cliches.
There doesn't seem to be any subtext, and the surface level action is not engaging to the reader. As a reader, I did not care about the characters.
The reader doesn't really get a good sense of what the surroundings and material world are like in any of the scenes.
All the characters feel flat and underdeveloped. They speak like robots.

Yes, this story's ending does overall feel natural and earned. As a reader, I was relieved to see what the story ended on a scene--brief as it was--rather than summary, since so much of the story itself was bound up in the narrator's explanations of what was happening rather than letting us see what was happening. The ending didn't really have much resonance for me as a reader--mainly because the narrator said things to make the reader believe that the stakes were high (e.g., the father's illness and the precariousness of those in the gay community), but, as a reader, I never really could FEEL that the stakes were high. (I'll save more on this for the scene v summary question later.)

Yes, overall, the story passes the test for coherence because it contains a logical progression of ideas and plot points, and each of the characters or plot points brought up contributes to a somewhat unified whole. The story moves from scene to summary with some ease, and there's nothing hard to understand about how the scenes are progressing from one to the next.

No, this story does not display an awareness of and insight into scene v summary/exposition. The story is so heavy on exposition that it makes the whole story sort of "mush out" into un-memorability. I've just read it, and I'm a pretty careful reader, but if you asked me to name some particular moments from the story, it'd be difficult beyond that necklace/disco ball comparison at the beginning; the fact that the father was wearing white jeans (which felt like a peak-80s/90s detail--lovely) at one of the dances, and her dress at the ending. I think this is in large part due to the lack of slowing down into scene throughout this story. We never get dialogue except some sort of throw-away "You here by yourself?" dialogue with Claire and something about where they live with random, undeveloped high boy. Partly because of this, I don't feel like I have a felt sense of this narrator really at all. I *believe* that she could be a dynamic, rich character that we could care about, but I don't right now really at all, and I think that's due in large part to how expository the story is.

No, the story's manipulation of time doesn't quite pass the test as a successful story. I mean, the use of time here is...fine? but the story is just fairly underwhelming as it relates to pacing, I believe, and is part of what makes it feel like it's written by a robot. Even those moments that I feel like *would* be slowed down for dramatic effect (e.g., when the narrator finally meets Tom in the gift shop with Claire) just aren't; everything feels slightly rushed and glossed here in this story, and as a result, moments like that ending--which I think is supposed to be a moment in which the reader feels something--fall flat.

No, in the end, I don't believe this story makes sophisticated use of idiom, metaphor, or literary allusions. Granted, this story's style doesn't seem to be one concerned with or interested in allusion or other figurative language particularly; the story overall is very didactic, which often (as here) leaves little room for sophisticated use of metaphor/etc.

No, there's a few things that "happen" in the story, but it's soooo exposition-heavy that it feels more emotionally absent than anything. Unfortunately, the lack of exteriority isn't made up for with interiority either; we are *told* plenty of things that would seem to be emotionally "big" moments for the narrator (e.g., "So I hid. I lied. I deflected. I covered up. And, most of all, I worried that I would be unmasked as the daughter of an H.I.V.-infected homosexual."), but we aren't, as readers, ever "shown" what that worry looks or feels like, for instance. This is one of the main areas in which the narrator feels robotic to me as a reader.

No, there aren't turns here that surprise me as a reader at all. I actually felt like the opening--weird as it was with the hat-tip to a travelogue (February, 1991) that never comes up elsewhere in the story--is one of the most surprising and successful parts of the story because it presents a situation that has built-in stakes for all involved and all manner of possibilities for tension. However, the story itself doesn't proceed in this way; I think we're meant to believe that the trip was meaningful, transformative, something for the narrator--but instead, it just feels like the moment that spurs the entry into talking about the speaker's family, rather than anything more meaningful. Nothing in the story feels surprising beyond the initial situation of it, which again, feels novel and compelling (but underdeveloped).

No, we don't get diverse perspectives here, unfortunately. The narrator, for me as a reader, is neither likeable nor unlikeable; she feels detached (but not in an interesting, Modernist or postmodern way). In part because there isn't dialogue to speak of, we don't get glimpses into other characters here, and so what we have from her POV is all we get--and again, it's not a POV that feels, to me as a reader, compelling or believable.

Yes, I think the story is somewhat original and doesn't contain a lot of cliches in terms of phrases or language use. There's something akin to cliche that does happen a lot, though, and I don't know exactly what to call it, but it's in telling the reader too explicitly what the story means or is supposed to mean. It's like the story doesn't trust the reader enough "get" it--which, to one of my students, I'd encourage them to make sure they develop the story enough so that they CAN trust the reader enough that they'll "get" whatever it is. An example in the story is when the narrator says, "This was their turf; I was just a visitor. More liberated than at school, but still an outsider, and, because I had always lived in a state of hiding a huge part of my identity—my family story—I questioned my very self." Bleh. (What follows this--"I didn't know how to move"--is a much more evocative starting point to getting to all of those ideas, I believe.)

No, this story feels pretty mundane and ordinary in its use of form and/or structure. It actually reads more as a personal narrative to me than anything else--and while I think that a personal narrative structure could be really useful for a story like this, it doesn't gain much right now from the woven nature of the structure. Starting in some sort of scene--and ending in a scene, of course--is delightful, but the scenes themselves are not developed enough to feel like it's actually fully a scene in either case, and the drifting back from the opening paragraph into explanation of the family/etc. seems expected and underwhelming.

Yes, I think the story is actually successful in this way. My issue here is with "average reader," I guess; I'm not sure if it's the average of, say, the general American population, or the average of college students, or what--and I think the "unique and original idea"s in this would seem a lot less so for some populations of people than others. But I do think, overall, that some of the narrator's insights (e.g., that she felt most "at home" in this place among gay men, even though she herself wasn't a gay man; that she could see the toll this cultural moment of the late 80s/early 90s was having on these men; that she found companionship and understanding supposedly from people like Claire and Tom) could feel unique or original, depending on the readership.

No; this is a story that COULD have so much subtext! An exciting amount of subtext! because of the differences (at least on the surface) between the narrator and the men on the cruise (and, it's suggested, perhaps between the people who work on the ship and the guests), but because the whole dang thing is so expository and over-explanatory, we aren't given the chance to read for subtext. What we see is what we get, and--just in case you didn't get it, reader!--often it's then doubled-down on so that the reader is hit over the head with the "meaning.

No, overall, the story doesn't make the fictional work believable at the sensory level. There are a few moments where this starts to happen--again, that necklace that mimics the disco ball lights, the description of the gift shop as "a small square space filled with toiletries, candy, mass-market paperbacks, and trinkets. A statuesque young woman in a uniform two sizes too large stood behind the register." Finally, my brain says--here's a place where we can actually exist with this speaker and see her interact and engage and see the way she sees the world. Ah, but no; as soon as this start, it shifts back into telling me things as a reader.

No, not quite; as I've said throughout here, the narrator is obviously the best fleshed out, but even she is underdeveloped, and the characters like Tom and Claire feel like placeholders. Even the father, with whom it feels like we should be intimately involved on a narrative level, feels glossed. Now, I could make the case that the thin-ness of his character as described or experienced by the daughter makes good sense given the way we see she's been made to conform to his life--but this is a stretch for the story as it's written now, and isn't supported by other aspects of the story.
Yes, the ending here feels like it comes at the right time. The whole essay is a bit forced for my taste, but the ending here feels pretty well managed, if a little too expository and explanatory.
Yes, this story holds together as a story pretty well; the progress of it feels somewhat natural, moving from the present moment of the story back to exposition and back again to the ship.

Yes; overall, I think this story does a pretty good job of showing an awareness and insight into scene v summary. I am *so* relieved in this story to see dialogue! It brings these characters to life and makes it so that we can start to see something memorable about these characters and/or the narrator.

No; this story doesn't have the narrative balance of pacing appropriate for this sort of short story.
