While it's heaps better at this than the first iteration, the story here is still trapped in lumping so much of the story into dense paragraphs as opposed to slowing the reader down in order to move us through the narrative strategically.

Yes, overall, the story does use idiom, metaphor, and literary allusion to good effect. The opening paragraph's description of "a week-long voyage aboard a magnificent ship called the Devotion appeared to be the ideal way to spend a solitary summer vacation before the imminent storm clouds of adult responsibilities and expectations threatened to take my father away forever" sets the tone nicely for the story as a whole.

No; I think the story actually balanced interiority and exteriority pretty well, but the result doesn't feel like emotional flexibility or even pathos more broadly (in general). This comes down in part, I think, to the formality of the narrator's diction and tone. When it's in dialogue--such as the father's abacuses and yores, etc.--it can be sort of charming and quirky and engaging, a nuance of the character. However, I think that when it's so formative in terms of the way the narrator understands the world, it serves to distance the reader rather than pull us closer.

Yes; the story isn't rife with turns, but when it does happen, I think they're surprising and appropriate (if understated). The tenderness of the relationship between the narrator and her father was endearing and somewhat surprising given the opening; sentences like "My father was weak on the subject of the past; although when pressed, he would discuss Kierkegaard and suffragettes with some authority. I sought retroactive advice on World War II, and, as his hazel eyes scanned my features, I felt as if he were examining a map that charted his own ancestral lineage" made me genuinely interested in this narrator and her POV.

Yes; I actually think this is pretty well done here. The inclusion of actual language from the father and even the one-liner from Dan reveal important nuance about these characters. The narrator herself and the father seem like somewhat diverse characters from one another, and I think the story gives a pretty good sense of them.

Yes; I'm saying yes here because the cliches that do appear come in as idioms ("spin in her grave," etc.), and it feels very reasonable and appropriate for characters themselves to use idioms. I will admit that the idioms or metaphors sometimes feel forced--again here, the feeling that this has been written by a robot--but it's generally well handled and not off-putting necessarily.

Yes; the overall form isn't particularly novel, but the measured way it moves between scene and summary feels unique to this story and effective. This is partly due to the way the story managed scene and summary, as described above.

Yes; here again, while the overall diction and tone is off-putting to me as a reader, the ways of seeing the world feel particular and noticeable. If I were working with a person who'd written this, I'd encourage the writer to slow down even more in those scenes and develop them some more, so that when we get to what are supposed to be emotionally charged moments, we really feel them to be such.

No, this isn't working yet here either, for me as a reader, because of the overt, explicit telling done by the narrator. This is much more nuanced than Story1, but still here, the narrator declaims things like "imbuing us with a magical memory that would endure beyond the duration of our journey" or "This safe did not merely house valuable possessions but also served as a storehouse for memories and secrets that might, in another life, have been entrusted to our hearts." Ewwww. Nope. I love the figure of a safe in this room as being representative for something, but when it's called out like this by the narrator--rather than developed through other rhetorical moves--it cheapens the whole story.

Yes, the story itself feels believable at a sensory level, though I wish there were more of this throughout the story! The unbelievability feels, for me as a reader, at the level of the narrator speaking like this, rather than the world that's been created.

Yes, I think for the scope of this story, the characters are developed pretty well. I mean, ol' Nigel is given short-shrift but that feels fine to me because he's just there to show desire and to be an object of her increasing affections, not as a real character.

No; while the ending feels believable, it also feels too easy and therefore unearned. This story has much going for it, but the ending--while natural--doesn't feel satisfying because it's the sort of ending that we could've predicted from the first sentences of the story: dad and son go on a formative trip where the narrator son learns lots about his father than himself. This ending--that the father will always be with him, even when he has died from the cancer that vaguely looms in the story--feels obvious given this set up.

Yes; this story holds together pretty well. There seems to be a connectivity to the scenes and ideas, and the emotions of the story emerge in pretty believable ways. There aren't any throw-away characters or scenes, and the cruise itself seems to actually add to the story rather than being tacked on.

Yes, this story does a pretty good job here. There's a LOT of explanatory statements that just tell rather than show (here again, it feels like the reader isn't trusted enough--or the writing isn't trusted to be strong enough--to get the ideas across), but in general, the scenes are well handled and descriptive.

Yes-ish; the pacing here feels mostly successful, if a bit boring. But the management of the compression or stretching feels...sufficient. Like, this isn't a story I'd care to re-read because there's not enough going on in and it isn't paced such that I want to return to the text, but it's not egregiously bad or anything, so I think it passes the test with a C.

No. I wanted this to be better, but the story relies on too many cliches in the form of metaphors and idioms. Almost all of the figurative language here comes in the form of cliches. Examples of this later, but bleh.

No, this is a story that's heavy on the exteriority with not much to offer for interiority. Again here, I think that emotional flexibility is better accomplished with less telling and more showing. This story almost accomplishes that by giving us some memorable, unexpected scenes, but then when the narrator gets to the "analysis" portion, it feels like the story gives in to the easy option.

Yes. The flirting, the father's illness, the dance (for example) all seem to come in carefully but not too tentatively, and end up rounding out characters rather than feeling like they come from left-field. Obviously, this isn't the sort of story where we'd expect cataclysmic shifts or aliens or some other huge, narrative plot turn, so I think the shape and scope of these turns are appropriate and somewhat surprising.

No, to my mind, this story feels a little too one-flavored. There aren't a lot of distinguishing characteristics provided for anyone besides the narrator; even the father feels like a B+ version of the son. I don't find this super problematic for this story, since it's so closely concerned with the father/son relationship, but I wouldn't say it offers much in the diverse perspectives department.

No. I wanted this to be better, but the story relies on too many cliches--from "bright as a diamond" and "He was my compass, guiding me home" to "His love lit my path, a beacon piercing the darkness" and "we danced like no one was watching." Nope nope nope. As is the way with cliches, these moments felt gratuitous and empty, rather than description that enriched or nuanced our understanding of characters or situations.

No, the form and structure here are fine, but nothing that effective. The language and style are somewhat energetic and engaged, but I wouldn't say that it's particularly original--either in exposition, scene description, or dialogue.

No, there's nothing particularly unique or original in terms of ideas here. Sentences such as "I only hoped, in some small way, it brought Dad the same joy and comfort his bravery had given me. His unwavering love lit the path to accepting myself when the way ahead was dim" feel a bit overdone and, again, too expected. There's an overall lack of complication to this story that, even though there's supposedly some tension, makes it too one-note and lacking memorability.
No, there's no discernible subtext here. The surface level actions are explicit, and the feelings--or any subtext--are overwritten by the narrator's explanation of what something "meant.

Yes, the use of description is often well done here. There are many descriptions that appeal to the reader's senses; descriptions like "all glass and chrome" and the descriptions of the ports of call were particularly effective.

Yes; while there aren't a lot of characters in this story, the narrator is pretty fleshed out, and the father feels somewhat nuanced. No one feels added just to move the plot or anything. (In fairness, there's not a huge plot to begin with, but still, the characters feel finely described and created.)

Yes; if anything, the ending feels belabored and drawn out. The last...6? paragraphs all feel like they're signaling the ending, but then it just keeps going, so that the reader feels a little speed-bumped along to the ending. So this does, indeed, pass the test, but I don't think it's particularly successful or strong.

No, this story struggles hugely from the time the cruise ends in particular. I think we're meant to feel character arcs, particularly of the narrator and Evan, but it feels somewhat arbitrary and like the veneer of harmony rather than something cohesive.

No; without the post-cruise epilogue-type part, I think this would definitely be successful, but the whole overall explanatory final three pages are painfully slow and expository. Even when it seems like it's trying to create a scene with the house and cozy writing room, etc., the pacing seems interminable.

No; without the post-cruise epilogue-type part, I think this would be more successful, but the whole overall explanatory ending three pages are painfully slow--and not in a way that makes sense for the movement of the story. In fact, the pacing seems to get super wonky here for me as a reader; those last three pages drag on and on, and it's hard for me to end up caring about the speaker and Evan at all because it's all so general feeling by the ending.

Yes; while these aren't particularly lovely or striking, the idioms and metaphors used are believable for this narrator for the most part, and idioms like "words rang in my ears" and "everything under the sun" felt easily used. The metaphor "We explored the ship like a twister, leaving a trail of memories in our wake" was memorable.

No, I don't think so here; the interiority is forecasted too easily (e.g., "I wasn't ready to say goodbye to Evan or my father") and as a result, it doesn't actually feel like it's using pathos strategically at all or letting us into the subjective experiences of the narrator (or anyone else).

No, there aren't really any particular surprising or appropriate turns here, mainly I'd argue because there's not a lot at stake to start with. Yes, there's a lurking "terminal illness," and obvious affection between the daughter and father, but beyond that, the "tension" seems to exclusively comes from...whether or not she and Evan will get together in the end? which is not much to go on for me as a reader at least.

No, the narrator is the best fleshed-out character since we get the world from her POV, and even she is fairly one-dimensional here. Evan seems to be a token love interest, and the father is a somewhat forgettable, token loved-one-lost here.

No, there are a woeful number of cliches here in the description; "drawing people to him like moths to a flame," "I wanted to soak up every ounce of this experience," "It was a force that could move mountains and heal broken hearts" and "as I held my father in my arms, that truth became crystal clear" are the most egregious (oh, as it the "glimmer of hope"). If these were in the words of characters, I'd be a lot more understanding of it, but this is the sort of narrator who would be a super pain to be stuck at a dinner party with. Soooo many cliches.

No, this is a very situation-driven narrative for the first two-ish pages, and then the story devolves into terse paragraphs of "happenings" to deliver us to the excruciatingly long ending "about" the memories and mementoes, etc.

No, this story feels robotic in its attempts to capture the imagination of the reader; it's like the story knows the tropes to play around with (e.g., love interest, dying parent, vulnerability, pride, summer fling that turns into something more) but doesn't know what to do with those things beyond that starting point.

No, this is surface-level only, sadly. There is much hope for me as a reader early on that the story will leave us with something meaningful; the set-up of the "goodbye cruise" for the terminally ill father is striking, and early on, this seems to be a narrator who is aware of and interested in her surroundings. However, as the story progresses, the whole thing seems to stall out, and any attempts we had at subtext are wiped out by the cliches and expository ending.

No; while there are some descriptions that are well handled, there are strange moments that again feel robotic (e.g., referring to the father's sickness as a vague "terminal illness"; a weird time when the narrator calls her father, in the narration, "Marcus" rather than "my father" or even "my father, Marcus" (which at that point is already established). These might seem like small transgressions, and they are--but they give the story the distinct feeling of being written by someone or something that has a knowledge of what stories do but not a deep, lived knowledge of how they should work.

No; as above, Evan feels like the simulacrum of an interesting love interest, but he's one-dimension and handsome and says bland things like "your dad would be so proud of you." The father feels more complicated, but not a lot more, and not enough to make his eventual dying feel like anything (nor to do feel or see this being felt by the narrator).
I predicted that this text would end with a moment of joyous dancing while reading its opening paragraph; however, the reader can sense the narrative threads building towards the conclusion.

The essay follows a coherent path, though the amount of material dedicated to its structural elements is unbalanced. We begin with a paragraph set in the narrative present - a specific day in February, 1991 - then spend 5 expository paragraphs setting up this moment. When we return to the narrative present we reach a celebratory conclusion that, though anticipated, flows logically from profoundly impactful childhood experiences described in the expositional paragraphs.

The essay is comprised almost entirely of summary and exposition, with brief dips into scene. There is little in the way of dialogue or direct interaction between characters. However, this appears to be a function of its genre (personal memoir) and the narrator's formal register.

The amount of space given to expositional information and narrative is unbalanced. Similarly, we spend paragraphs reading about things like the gift shop where Claire works, which in my opinion are digressions.

There is little use of idiom and metaphor, and I was unable to identify literary allusion in the text. On my first read, it was difficult to understand the 'ghost' metaphor at the top of page 3, but on reread it functions as an apt characterization of the narrator feeling like a mere idea or acquisition in that moment.
Though this is a highly interior narrative, the narrator's growth is expressed through her actions; this provides the exteriority that lends the piece its emotional heft.

Most of this essay is devoid of turns. I inferred, broadly, almost everything to come in this essay from its opening paragraph. However, I did not anticipate the characters of Claire and Tom. Their presence in the essay feels shoehorned in, especially because we spend more time with them than we do with the narrator's father. That being said, they appear to be the source of human connection and acceptance that leads to the narrator's ability to let loose in the final paragraphs.

The narrator is highly likeable and sympathetic; however, her viewpoint and experiences leave little for the reader to object to. The few characters besides the narrator are barely present in the text.
Although I feel this essay conveys an unconventional life through fairly conventional writing, it avoids cliche.

On a line level, idiosyncratic sentence structures and punctuation usage abound. For example, commas are used like this, often paired with em dashes. This creates sentences that have an odd rhythm and are sometimes difficult to parse. Quotation marks in this text are applied in a distinctive fashion in which a quote is indicated like "this, but never closed with a second quotation mark. I can't imagine that is intentional.

The narrator describes a highly unconventional life story, especially for the time period it covers. Her movement from a state of inhibition and outsider-ness to one of relative freedom and connection is what leaves a lasting impression on the reader.

I had a difficult time identifying subtext in my first read of the text. However, on reread the fact that the internal growth of the narrator is inferred by the reader rather than told explicitly does convey implicit meaning.

Details like the narrator's cobalt velvet jacket with a shawl collar and the cruise ship crew member's "dark hair forming a soft wave across the top of his head" add sensory depth and believability to an otherwise expositional narrative.

Though the secondary and tertiary characters in this essay are flat and do not change over the course of its story, the narrator changes in an appropriately complex way. Her movement from feeling marginalized in both straight and gay spaces to feeling the freedom to dance on the cruise ship turns her into a well-rounded character.

It is unclear what lead to the narrator's new appreciation of their father, or how that appreciation is different than it was at the beginning of the essay. Multiple threads are introduced (adult responsibilities and expectations, the father's impending death, the narrator's crush on Nigel, the effects of gentrification, religion, the unconventional personalities onboard the ship, Dan) and either dropped or insufficiently developed. The ending does not seem to result from a narrative logic.

The story's frequent allusions to religion and God doesn't seem to pan out in a narratively meaningful way. Similarly, the narrator's evolving appreciation for their father is insufficiently developed.
While I feel the scenes and themes of this essay are underdeveloped, it does use both scene and summary to tell its story.

The piece is moves from one topic to the next with almost every paragraph. The elements with the highest stakes (the narrator's relationship with their father, the father's health, the narrator's sexual longing) do not receive sufficient attention or space in the text.

There are many allusions to religion in the text; however they aren't effectively incorporated into the text. Metaphors like the ship being a "contemporary rendition of Noah's Ark" and rubber, latex, and sweat drifting on the surface of water "like a school of inky slippers" don't make total sense. The idea of "contact" suggesting extraterrestrials rather than AIDS is an positive exception.
The events of the essay are conveyed mainly as observations on the part of the narrator. The level of interiority is too limited for the piece to have emotional depth.
The piece introduces several surprising turns, but they don't go anywhere. The father's skill at making wigs is interesting and fun, for example, but it isn't developed further.

The reasons behind the narrator's actions are hazy to me. Similarly, each time I encountered the father, he seemed like a different person. I don't know why he wouldn't dance with the narrator at the beginning of the essay, nor what changed in that regard by the end.
The story introduces a number of unique and interesting ideas. They are just dropped too quickly.
The language of the piece uses overly-familiar phrasings and sometimes-stuffy diction. The structure and form of the piece is conventional.

Because the threads introduced in the piece are insufficiently developed, the reader isn't able to gain much insight from it. It's difficult to ascertain a new perspective or insight articulated in the text.
it's possible that I simply missed something, but I cannot identify subtext in this piece. The elements of this essay that are not directly stated are hard for me to understand.
The sensory details in the piece are generally vague and sometimes confusing. The description of the material and smell of the father's wigs is a notable exception.

The father's character was hard to wrap my head around. Many of the things he says are inscrutable to me. The motives and traits of the narrator are easier to understand, but conveyed in a surface-level fashion. The tertiary characters are barely present in the text.

The ending doesn't seem to result from narrative logic. Additionally, the narrator's sudden switch to addressing the father directly is tonally and logically abrupt. The father seems to have died, but when is unclear. The narrator's relationship with their father seems minimally changed from the beginning of the essay to its conclusion.

The story seems to attempt an ending twice, using an almost identical phrase (I clung tight... not ready/unwilling to say goodbye/part) in both instances. It is unclear what narratively leads the reader to the conclusion.

While the piece does move from summary into scene, the scenes are too brief and underdeveloped to be effective. This is especially true at the end, where the father tells the narrator that he's their very own wishing star, an idea that is reiterated several times in the expository ending.
The story unfolds in a straightforward manner. There is little compression or stretching of time.
The attempts at metaphor (dad as star/diamond/rock/compass/beacon/setting sun) are clunky and awkwardly introduced. I don't see idiomatic language or literary allusion in the text.
The emotional lives of the characters are told to the reader, rather than conveyed in a convincing manner. The story is told in a heavily external, summary fashion.
There aren't really any plot developments or revelations to speak of.
The secondary and tertiary characters are flat or conveyed in a summary fashion. The narrator seems to end the story unchanged from its beginning.

The metaphorical language in this piece consists of overused ideas and comparisons. The father is the narrator's hero, star, compass, diamond, sun, etc. - all language that readers will have encountered countless times before.
The story is told in a straightforward, conventional manner. The exception to this - what appears to be an ending attempted twice - doesn't seem intentional.
The ideas in this essay lack complexity. I can't identify original ideas in it that would stay with a reader afterward.
I cannot identify subtext in this piece. It is conveyed through surface-level observations.
The sensory language is too vague and simple to create a believable world. The world of this story is conveyed with minimal description.
Neither the narrator nor their father is fully defined. Their relationship lacks depth. There doesn't appear to be meaningful character growth in the essay.
The ending is abrupt, summary, and attempted several times in a row with increasingly similar language. It does not seem to result from a meaningful narrative logic.

The story lacks logical coherence. It attempts to end, in very similar ways, several times in a row. It appears to be telling two stories at the same time (the narrator's relationship with Evan and the story of their father's death) and unwilling to commit to either, The events are conveyed as facts that happened in sequence, but without the level of casual interaction that one expect from narrative prose.
The story is highly summary and expositional. Its scenes lack narrative and emotional depth.
The essay unfolds at a simple, staccato pace. Years do get condensed into clauses ("Months turned to years") but without dramatic effect.

The idioms and metaphorical language in this piece are overly-familiar and simple: a heart full of emotions, moths to a flame, a whirlwind of emotions, butterflies in one's stomach, etc.  I do not see literary allusion in this piece.
There is little, if any, interiority in this piece. Its events are conveyed almost entirely through the characters' observable actions and dialogue.
The only surprising structural element of this essay, its repeated attempted endings, is surely unintended. Either way, it is more confusing than effective.
The perspectives expressed by the characters are too simple to be relatable or believable. Each character in this piece behaves in easily predictable ways that do not feel realistic.
The language in this piece is rife with cliches.
The language, plot, structure, and style of this piece are all highly conventional.
It's difficult to identify original ideas or content in this piece.
I cannot identify subtext in this piece.
The world is conveyed through flat, simple details. The descriptions are overly familiar.
The characters, including the narrator, are uniformly flat and static. They and their interactions lack emotional depth.

The end of the story does not feel natural, it just is the cessation of the text which has been repeating several times for much of the story. The language is vague; the sentence "His art would continue to inspire, teach, and touch the hearts of those who beheld it, for the stories he had shared would forever remain etched in the collective consciousness of humanity" doesn't leave the reader with anything specific or interesting to ponder.

The story does not form a satisfying whole. The events are presented in a vague way, and narrative seems to ramble. Words are repeated again and again ("solace", "tapestry"), the man's art seems to be discovered twice, and the story kind of rambles to the end.
It felt like too much space is taken up with vague summary of the same things, the man seeking solace, and creating art.

Time feels stretched out in a vague way. That is, a lot of time goes by, with a lot of text dedicated to it, but much of it is repetitive. One detail that seemed off was when we are told the wailing of sirens is in the distance, but then we get the phrase "as darkness began to descend..." implying a more gradual, longer passage of time, but the vehicles with the sirens arrive after this. The time feels unrealistic here.

There is a lot of vague language which feels tired and redundant. The word "solace" appears nine times, "tapestry" appears four times. Metaphors are not very sophisticated (e.g. "The woman's face served as a canvas for his tales" and "Like the mountains, he too had played witness to countless tragedies and triumphs, each a minor chapter in the grand tapestry of life"—tapestries don't have chapters).

There is not enough detail in the scenes or in the interior world of the man for the reader to care much about what is going on. What so affected him about the woman? What did his art look like? What happened to him along the way? He just keeps looking for solace in the woods.

The discovery of the cabin with the photo of the woman holds the possibility of being an interesting twist. However, it seems unlikely after so many years that the man would remember the face of the woman in the wreck. It feels contrived and implausible without more detail around it.
The main character's is the only perspective we have, although much of the perspective is actually that of the omniscient narrator.

Much of the language is vague and there are a lot of unsatisfying cliches. For example "The tumultuous scene before him mirrored the ever-changing nature of existence itself. Like the mountains, he too had played witness to countless tragedies and triumphs, each a minor chapter in the grand tapestry of life"; "Through his art, he hoped to capture the essence of the woman he had encountered and the resilience of the human spirit;" " He always carried her memory within him, a constant reminder of the fragile beauty of life and the importance of acknowledging fleeting moments of connection.
The form and structure are not original.

There is no interesting or original idea in this story. There is a lot of vague language about "the power of art" but not enough detail, history, character development for the reader to take much away from it.
There is not any real rhetorical complexity here. The language is vague and fails to address any kind of thematic complexity or layers of meaning.
There is not enough detail to provide a sense of reality. For example, we have no detail about what he painted, or what the woman wrote in her journals.
The characters feel flat and undeveloped. More detail about the man's life, his history, his artwork, his interactions with others, are needed to give depth to his character.
The ending felt appropriate. Finch was left again in the quiet wilderness after the body of the woman was taken away, back to where he started.

There were parts of the story that didn't make much sense. The things that Finch uttered did not make much sense. The way time passed was confusing (I'll discuss this below in the time question), and the way Finch seems to get distracted on his walk to the town to find help doesn't really fit with the rest of the story either.

I thought there was good balance here. The description of events is pretty vivid, and this is combined well with explanation that fills in Finch's thoughts. For example, "The relief on his face was evident, and as he slumped back into the truck bed, Finch leaned onto his knees, observing the landscape as they ventured back through the wilderness. His mind, like the wind, swirled with chaotic thoughts of grief and disbelief.

The pacing of the story was good, the narrative moved along in a way that did not drag and did not skip over too much. A confusing aspect had to do with the time of day. We're told Finch went out in the morning ("The engine of his breath and the rhythmic sound of his boots on the brown, loamy soil were the first noises to break the serene silence of the morning.") We also learn the nearest town is eight miles away, but he doesn't think he can get there and back before the sun sets. But if he moves at a brisk walk, he can go three miles in about an hour. So, let's say it takes him two full hours to get to town, and two full hours to return, it would still presumably be the afternoon.

There are several weird sentences, which don't seem to capture the way anyone would talk. For example, Finch's statements "So unsimulated is this place"; "What a deuce of a land it must be, this land I am in!" and "In the solemnity of our days, we cloud upon each other, one hurrah to another.

I thought there was a good balance between description of the action, and Finch's own thoughts. Of course, as I mentioned earlier, what he actually says doesn't make any sense, even if we get a good idea of his thoughts from the narration.

Finch's happening upon the car wreck is a surprising event which also seems reasonable. Some problems here with the details, though, are that his first encounter with the car is described like this: "As he reached a bend in the road, his journey was suddenly halted by the tragic sight of a swerving 1950s coupe. The car had flown off the road into the underbrush, making a disastrous impact with such velocity that it wrapped around a tree." Did he see the car swerving, or did he see it in the underbrush? Later, we understand he must have seen it resting, but this raises another problem, because we are told about the woman: "It was possible she had been in such a state for days or even weeks." This is confusing when we learn later that the men looking for the accident had just been told about it, presumably because someone had witnessed it just happen. It seems less likely that they would be called to it weeks later, at precisely the moment when Finch found it.
We really only have Finch's perspective.

The writing does seem original, if strange and nonsensical at times. Some odd phrases include "the men took final accounts of the wrecked car, lamenting its crushed state as if it was a prized possession" and "As he walked by, the wind blew an ominous gale in his face, causing him to pull his tartan scarf tighter around his neck as he hurried on, rattled by the bad omen that seemed to linger in the air.
The form and structure seem pretty standard.

I don't think there is much for the reader to grapple with here. The ending does not do a good job of tying together the themes of the story, and instead the story ends with a pretty vague set of phrases that are overly general: "In this desolate landscape, Finch found solace in the company of the mountains, whispering a transcendent symphony of fleeting past, the impermanence of events, and the undeniable continuation of life itself. Finch looked off into the wilderness, a new sense of purpose filling him as he thought, "In wilderness, illogic is pursued, and logic is denied, but life moves on." And with that realization, he began his journey back into the peculiar, untamed world he called home, with an appreciation for the fleeting nature of life and a newfound determination to not take it for granted.

There is not really much meaning below the surface. The action carries the story along, but without much rhetorical complexity which could be developed through more detail about the main character, particularly his back story.

The story does have good details describing the physical world, including "Below, the land sloped steeply away, leading down to a greenswept valley, glistening with morning dew. A river coursed through the bottom, fed by the spring thaw and summer rains and various mountain lakes, whose still shores no foot had disturbed" and "When they finally returned to the accident scene, the sun had fallen considerably, casting lengthened shadows that left an eerie unreality over the disturbed surroundings. Amidst the gathering gloom, Finch pointed the men in the direction of the woman’s body, smeared with congealed blood upon her leg.

I don't think Finch's character has much depth. What we know about him is based on descriptions of his reactions to things happening around him. He feels grief and disbelief, but we don't have much information about his past or background to give him much complexity.
The ending felt natural. John stayed with the woman until the ranger came, and then was left alone to ponder what had happened. It made sense and did not seem arbitrary or abrupt.

Overall, the story forms a coherent whole. One exception to this, though, is the fact that the main character stayed with the woman for so long. If his goal was to get help, and his phone didn't have a connection, presumably he would have walked back the way he came. It isn't clear why he was stranded there with her, especially since she was clearly dead and did not require his presence.

There was a good balance here, particularly as the memories of Alice came to John's mind amid the scene of the accident. The language around this was a bit awkward and unrealistic at times, e.g. as John started sobbing uncontrollably at his memory of Alice. This may have been his reaction, but it seems unlikely given how focused he is on getting help for the accident scene in front of him. One might expect him to break down later, when he is alone at the end of the story.
The pacing was good, important details were stretched, and longer periods of time without as much detail, as John was waiting, were compressed.
The story does not make sophisticated use of idiom, metaphor, or allusion, and language is awkwardly repeated in a few places ("clearly deceased," "rivulets of blood," "inky sky").

There was good balance overall between the action and John's thoughts about it. Some details were confusing though, such as "His heart clenched at the sight. This was no stranger, this was someone's daughter, perhaps someone's mother." He reacts this way when he sees the name, but presumably seeing the name would make him recognize her as someone he knows, not just that she is a real person (this of course would be obvious with or without her ID).

I thought the phone call from the husband was both surprising and appropriate. It was very dramatic, and brought some depth to the character of the woman. It was also appropriate and realistic given the circumstances.
The main perspective is that of John only.
The writing felt original and avoided cliches. However, the repetition of language made the writing seem mechanical at times.
Form and structure don't seem original.
The story was understandable, but there didn't seem to be much depth, even with the detail that John's wife had recently died. I didn't feel like there was an original idea here.
The story seemed to exist mainly at the surface level. We understand the resonance with the death of this woman with the death of Alice, but this is about the extent of the deeper meaning here.

There were good details that made the world believable, such as "He recalled learning to drive on these winding roads, clutching the steering wheel with sweaty palms as his father grasped the passenger handle with white knuckles, warning him to slow down" and "The accident must have just happened, for the engine was still ticking, motes of steam rising from the dented hood" and "He spotted a wedding band on her left hand, glinting in the pale moonlight.
John's character did not feel completely developed. More detail about his life, and his past with Alice would help with this.

The ending is satisfying, even though the action is not really resolved. The themes of impermanence, of abandonment have been introduced, though. The main character feels abandoned, even though he is alive and supposedly staying with the woman so as not to abandon her. The irony is that she doesn't require it, as she is already "beyond danger.
This story comprises a unified whole, each part makes sense and fits together with the other parts.

The scenes are vivid, the discovery of the car, the discovery of the woman, the sounds of the distant ambulance, of the rustling in the bushes. These are balanced with the memories and monologue of the main character, which give insight into his own thoughts.
The pacing of the story is good, not too compressed, not too drawn out.

The story makes interesting use of allusion, such as the main character's story about the movie theater where the projectionist narrated films. The parallelism with the main character as the narrator or interpreter of events for the dead woman is interesting. There are also references to the impermanence of things, like the cinema in Bucharest, and like the forest used in the German film.

The inner thoughts of the main character are blended well with what is going on outside him. An example of this is: "He sat for a while without talking, as if it were her turn to speak. Then he heard some movement in the trees. It felt to him like a substantial presence, maybe a bear. He had heard that these mountains were heavily populated by brown bears, and it was illegal to hunt them. In that moment, he felt alone. Abandoned.
The discovery of the car and the woman are surprising, but are appropriate, and form the basic structure of the story. The story is interesting, but not unbelievable.
We get the main character's perspective of course, but we also get that of Alex, though the main character's own imagination.
The writing seems original and avoids cliches.
The form and structure do not seem to be original.

I think the reader will find this story interesting in that it suggests themes of impermanence in the world, amidst the most permanent of all conditions, i.e. death. The natural world persists in emptiness and silence, even as we humans try to fill the space with conversation, even with those who can't respond.

There is a good level of rhetorical complexity, combining themes of the silence, emptiness, and impermanence of nature with the sounds of the living, including the screeching of car tires, sirens, and the voices that narrate everything that is happening, whether in a Romanian cinema, or on the side of a cliff.

There are good details that bring the world into vivid focus, such as "He could see fresh signs of damage—the tire marks at the edge of the gravel road, where the car must have gone over, and the scrapes where the undercarriage dragged across a rock, leaving behind a screech in the trees. The wheels of the car were pointing upward, as if the world had been turned on its head and the car were now going to continue driving across the sky" and "The radio was on, the real world still keeping in touch. He turned the car off but then decided to leave the tail lights on, so the rescue services would find them more easily if it got dark. The interior of the car smelled of coffee. There was a paper cup on the ceiling, the contents all over the dashboard.

We get a good insight into the depth of the main character's life, though both his reaction to the accident, as well as what he says to the dead woman, and through the narrator's filling in the blanks.

No; although the ending doesn't feel rushed (since the story seems to carry on long after the point it should've ended), it denies the reader a sense of closure because of the weird tonal issues which are at odds with the grandness of the setting and the "big ideas" that are so readily explained by the narrator.

No, the story fails to pass the test here. It's as if everything in the story is *too* connected, too tightly wound to be satisfying. The main character's insularity is jarring in the beginning, and by the ending, it feels as if the entire story has tried to serve as a showpiece for this character, despite there not being a lot about him that feels remarkable or nuanced.

No; as above, the story shows a lack of understanding of how to balance scene and exposition. A description such as "his steady voice faltering in the face of an incomprehensible tragedy" feels like such a missed chance; instead of actually letting us see (or hear) something, the story settles for explanation and didactic statements. These weigh the story down.

No; the moments that seem like they should be drawn out, or could benefit from being drawn out (such as when the man finds the car wreck, when he finds the cabin, on a "representative" walk that'd taken on new meaning after finding the wreck) are slowed down but not effectively here. In other words, time in the story is spent in these moments, but the information provided there doesn't actually deepen any kind of understanding of the characters or situations.

No, not quite. The story does use a fair number of metaphors, and a few if them are quite arresting (e.g., "It was as if the world had collided with itself" when describing the wreck site), but overall these don't add up to anything cohesive. 

As a side note but worth mentioning is the overwhelming creepiness of the metaphor that "The woman's face served as a canvas for his tales, etching the stories of his past across her motionless features." The scene, the situation, the description is utterly chilling, and I thought this was going to be something developed and followed up on by the author, but everything progresses in the story without touching on this again.

No--there's very little by way of exteriority, despite the fact that the story sets itself as so tied to nature and the ways people interact with and are impacted by nature. There is, of course, plenty of interiority, but it's heavy-handed overall (e.g., "The tumultuous scene before him mirrored the ever-changing nature of existence itself. Like the mountains, he too had played witness to countless tragedies and triumphs, each a minor chapter in the grand tapestry of life."). Sentences like those feel, at best, like writing only concerned with advancing Big Ideas, and, at worst, like lazy writing.

No; I actually think the initial surprise of him finding the car wreck is pretty well done, but then the story "jumps the shark" when he finds--wait for it!--that very same woman's abandoned cabin. This feels really contrived and heavy handed.

No, this story doesn't do much by way of diverse perspectives. I suppose the main character is unlikeable for the way he recasts the world in his own image (then again, I realize we all see the world through our own lenses, with ourselves at the center of our own world), but the narrator and story itself doesn't give us much beyond sort of platitudes and vague inspirational quotes like "he embraced the wilderness that surrounded him, finding solace in its untamed beauty and profound stillness" and "Through his art, he hoped to capture the essence of the woman he had encountered and the resilience of the human spirit.

No, here again, the writing stalls out at the level of being predictable overall. It hits upon the theme of the transience of life and the majesty of nature, and then it just recasts this idea again and again throughout the story.

No, the form of the story doesn't give us much by way of form or structure that is memorable or that does much to advance the story in a meaningful way. The best that can be said here about form is that it doesn't particularly get in the way of the story, but it doesn't help it, either.

No, there's not a unique or original idea presented here, I'm afraid. The ideas here don't go much deeper than the surface, in ways that feel overdone and fairly cliched. The outrightness of statements like "finding solace in the reminder that life was transient, that every experience, no matter how profound, eventually returned to dust" make it feel like overtrodden territory.
No. There's only surface here, and any possibility for subtext is destroyed by the story's reliance on overwrought statements and heavy-handed proclamations.

No, the story doesn't offer much that appeals to the senses beyond a stray description here and there. Rather than descriptions that connect to us on a sensory level, the story gives us vague summary like "As the man's work gained recognition, his paintings and photographs were exhibited in galleries and museums across the world. People were drawn to the raw emotion and authenticity captured in his pieces, a reflection of his encounter with the tragedy on that fateful day." This is overwhelmingly forgettable because it's so summary-driven.

No, there aren't many characters here to start, and the main character here is a sort of non-character for the lack of care with which he's described or crafted. He feels like a cut-out of a character rather than a fully developed one.

Yes, the ending here does feel natural and earned. I am *not* a particular fan of the ending writing itself, as the final paragraph puts too tidy a bow on the "meaning" he found (rather than leaving the reader with something to ponder), but I do this it's purposeful. For my money, I'd advocate for ending the story a couple paragraphs earlier, so that it finishes on more of a scene--but this is an unoffensive ending.

Yes, I think this story passes the unified, engaging test. It's an odd story, to be sure--mainly because of the over-the-top unbelievability of the main character's voice--but the respective parts add up to a pretty cohesive whole.

Yes, overall. As above, there's a pretty well handled sense of when to slow down here, and the story moves as a fine clip, which is at least partially due to the balance between summary and scene. I will say that the scenes themselves are a little too fleeting for my taste--I think slowing down even more and waiting in description could help quite a bit--but I still think the story passes the test here.

Yes, I think the story passes this test in terms of pacing and timing overall. The description and narrative movement slows down at strategic points--finding the wreck, the character's struggle with what to do next, the reminder of childhood at the lake, etc.--and the pacing generally hums along without stalling out. 

As a note, this isn't *strictly* a matter of pacing--more stylistic--but the story overall has the quality of things being a little too...modified, as if the writer is trying too hard to write Importantly, if that makes sense. Rather than 'the sight of 1950s coupe' it's the "tragic" sight; a "brutal accident," etc. Now, of course modification can add a lot to writing; however, the story does tend toward these editorializing modifiers, which feels a little too easy of a tactic for me as a reader.

Yes; I'm a bit torn here because the story is *nearly* overwhelmed by the peculiarity of some of the metaphors (e.g., "The wrist was cold and waxy, with the appearance of a raw parsnip plucked a few days before"), but the story overall is handled with some restraint in its metaphor. An example of a successful metaphor--unusual enough to be interesting, but not so unusual as to make it obvious that it wasn't dreamt up by a human--is this: "he spent his days either socializing with mourners or wandering in the mountains, through the numerous roads and paths that crisscrossed it like a tapestry bordering on disintegration at its seams.

Yes, I think this is ultimately successful. A phrase such as "oddly enough, they were each other’s only company amidst their lonely surroundings" feels true to this world, and shows the main character's connection to the outer world as well.

No; despite the overall success of this story, I wouldn't say the story contains turns that are particularly surprising. The universe of the story is one that is nearly apocalyptic in its desolation, and so I would think that something as jarring as the wreck and finding the woman's body would stand out, but the pacing and description of the story stays pretty constant throughout. More description, or a shift in syntax, or *something* that strikes the reader as different would help the "turns" to feel like more here.

No; and this comes down for me mainly to the "convincing" aspect of the test. it's one thing for a peculiar narrator to have an internal monologue that is also peculiar, in its ideas or phrasing or dialect/idiolect/etc. However, the words that are put into the mouth of this main character are, for me, entirely unbelievable. From the slightly nonsensical (e.g., "So unsimulated is this place") to the just plain weird (e.g., "What a deuce of a land it must be, this land I am in!"), the way this character speaks strains credulity.  

And the crime of it is that the only other time we get spoke words in the story, it's well handled! When the driver says "Sir, we got word of an accident down the mountain," it sounds dialectically believable and idiomatic and great! This makes, for me, the fact that the main character speaks like a C- version of a Shakespearean side character all the more noticeable.

Yes, this is successful here I believe. The story doesn't feel like a cliche, and generally avoids cliches themselves. There's a novelty to the descriptions and insights here, even if it does go too far in the other direction sometimes.

Yes, although it pains me to say this here, I think the story does show some originality in its form. The structure itself is pretty well handled and seems to suit the subject matter, and the style of the piece--overdone at times as I think it is--generally gives the reader something to hold onto in terms of its shape.

Yes, overall I think this story can give the reader a somewhat original understanding of this man's connection to the land. It feels to me written in the image of McCarthy's _The Road_, or like it's trying to do similar things--the grandiosity and perspective of the main character, the desolation of the land combined with the "incursion" of the man-made and tragic.

No, I think this is an area for possibility for this story still. The surface here is pretty richly painted, but there's not enough nuance for subtext to be at work here, I believe. There are moments that *could* be symbolic or commentary or hidden (the way the wreck is described, the description of the world as "sepia-toned photograph, etc.), but it fails to be developed as the story continues.

Yes, this fictional world feels believable for the mountains of Appalachia. Again here, my hesitation in this criterion is the entire unbelievability of an actual human speaking like that, but the world building itself feels successful.

Yes; this is a close call for me for the voice issues I've mentioned at such length at this point, but in terms of character development itself, it feels believably done. Sure, the truck guy is there just to keep the story moving, but the way he speaks is so believable and has the cadence of real, actual speech, which is a relief in light of our main character's penchant for speaking like a robot version of soliloquy.

Yes, although I don't think the ending is particularly strong because it ends in "moral of the story" territory, it is at least framed nicely within the confines of the end to a long night. The story ending on John's thinking about Alice and the mountains also feels fitting given the focus of the story itself.

No, the story doesn't quite pass this test here. There are a fair number of cohesion problems in the story (time issues, mostly) which makes the story feel underconsidered or under-edited. I do end up caring about John by the ending--he's drawn as a caring, good person--but the threads of the story don't unify quite enough for me here.

Yes, the story here is pretty successful. Information is delivered in manageable chunks for the reader, and the story is willing to slow down enough to give us scenes that overall feel believable. The exception for me here is in the answering the cell phone "scene"; it's written as a scene, but nearly the whole thing is glossed over with summary, which makes it lose a lot of its impact.

No, this feels hard to manage here. As mentioned above, there are some jarring narrative inconsistencies in the story (i.e., John "rushed over quickly but saw immediately that the female driver was motionless, clearly deceased, her pallid face marred with rivulets of dried blood"; the next paragraph then says, inexplicably, "Rushing over to investigate further, he saw a woman slumped over the steering wheel, airbag deployed but lifeless, clearly deceased. He whipped out his cellphone but there was no signal. Holding back panic, he checked for a pulse multiple times, to no avail. Her pale face was marred with rivulets of dried blood, her limp body twisted in a way that signaled her neck was likely broken."). This serves to break the believability of the story. (The other notable instance of this was when the narrator says that the accident must have just happened, but then John feels her "cold, clammy skin.") While these elements might not seem strictly related to pacing, they make the story hiccup weirdly, and pull out out of the story-world into the world in which we're reading a story (which works against the suspension of disbelief that comes with fine writing).
No, this isn't quite sophisticated enough to pass the test here. There are some idioms and metaphors used, but none add up to a richer experience for the reader.

No, this is a story that's a bit too interior to be wholly successful I believe. There is plot movement, but there's a lot of time languishing--which *could* be useful to make the reader feel the waiting that John does with Jenny Thompson's body--but right now, it feels unremarkably handled. In part, I think this comes down to the fact that the story feels very average syntactically; nothing different seems to happen with sentence structure or description throughout, so everything takes on the same feel as everything else.

No. Although I find this story to be successful in some areas, the turns that happen in the story feel a little abrupt (as in the case of finding the wreck) and/or manhandled (as in the case of the shift to John answering the woman's phone, which mysteriously has signal). I was genuinely surprised to figure out what was happening with the phone ringing, but the "scene" as mentioned above feels rushed through, so that it feels like a little too much for story to sustain.

Yes. I'll answer yes here because the perspectives offered are finely handled, though there's nothing particularly diverse about perspectives offered here. But there's also nothing objectionably done here, so I suspect a yes is the best answer, since I feel like I can understand the characters' motivations and the reasons behind their actions.

No; unfortunately, the story contains some cliches as the level of language (e.g., "each recollection opening the wound anew,"  The darkness seemed poised to swallow them whole"), and the entire set up of the story as one that pairs a man's personal tragedy with that of another feels a bit overdone.

No, the story misses the mark here I believe. In addition to the narrative inconsistencies mentioned earlier, the writing settles for a fairly predictable, sun-up to sun-down structure, and there's not enough notable or memorable in the writing to make it stand out in other ways. There's a sort of slap-dash quality to some of the statements, too (e.g., "her loved ones who would soon get the terrible news" after he's already talked to Jenny's husband), which make it feel like it wasn't revised and edited properly for structural and/or narrative cohesion.

No, there's not too much that's original by way of ideas here. When the narrator describes putting the jacket on Jenny's body as "a small act of compassion for this poor soul," it feels like this is supposed to be part of the grand idea of the story, but John's staying with Jenny Thompson's body, and even talking to her husband on the phone, feels too "evened out" to be particularly meaningful. In other words, the cadence of the narrator's description and pacing don't change when it comes to these moments, and as a result, what I think is supposed to feel like a vigil for the dead, an act of compassion for a stranger, instead ends up feeling so interior and unremarkable.

No, the story doesn't give us quite enough to build up subtext here. What we see is what we get with John and his story, and although there's parts that are successful in the story to be sure, the creation of subtext feels lacking. Part of this might be based in the fact that we don't really get to see John interact with many other people; the phone call feels like the biggest opportunity, but it's given to us in summary mostly, which mitigates any subtext clues we could get otherwise.

Yes; narrative inconsistencies aside, the sensory descriptions here do tend toward feeling like the world is believable. Again here, I would've benefitted from more scene and description, but details like the ticking of the engine feel of-the-world and compelling.

Yes; while John doesn't really undergo meaningful change in the story (despite what the ending would seem to want us to believe), the way he connects his person tragedy of losing Alice to the death of this woman and the loss to her family feels believable.

Yes; the arc of the story feels very well realized, and the sense of closure comes not just for the main character but for the reader as well. The fact that we are denied what might masquerade as closure elsewhere--emergency services arriving, "answers" about who this woman was or Alex, etc.--actually feels like the "right-est" kind of closure for this story: We're left with the main character struggling with his sense of responsibility and compassion in a foreign place without a guidebook for how to correctly do this act of kindness and vigil (and bear-scaring-away).

Yes, this story has a unification to it that helps it hold together throughout. The satisfaction that comes by the story's end is due, at least in part, to the fact that we have a believably nuanced character who seems to have actually, really been affected by this tragedy--not just seeing the tragedy as a mirror version of his own, but understanding his own experiences (somewhat mysterious as they are) in the context of his "job" now, which is to bring comfort to this woman. The fact that she's dead and "beyond" comfort is, of course, what makes it actually about the main character, and this complexity is what makes this story cohesive and infinitely believable.

Yes, this is quite well done here as well. There's a good amount of exposition here, but we're always dragged back to the scene of the wreck. The author doesn't let us lose sight of the context here, and that's part of what makes the scene/summary balance really useful and strategic here.

Yes, yes and yes. I am in love with this author's use of suspension and compression of timing in the story. The shift in syntax to the declaiming, succinct, "Everything was calm now. Nothing more could happen" feels rich and nuanced and like revelation for the reader because we are understanding how the main character is describing the world and situation to himself, what he's saying to self-soothe as much as anything else. He's not telling us what we should believe about the situation; it's like we're allowed to "overhear" the conversation he's having with himself and the woman's body. It's super effective.

Yes, the metaphors here are carefully meted out, so that they actually support the ideas of the story rather than overwhelm them. A description such as "the components of emptiness; It was as though the landscape were in shock" is arresting and captures a feeling while deepening our understanding of the plot points and character(s).

Yes, and this is one of the story's main strengths, I believe. It's exceedingly difficult to make a story so compelling with so little interaction between (live) characters, but this author manages it beautifully, such that we feel the resonance of him singing at the end "to scare off the predators" as an act of solidarity and compassion and reclamation. The interior landscape is built here and then "shared" with the reader because the main character "shares" it with the woman's body: it's a weird and slightly unsettling detail that rounds out the interior-made-exterior here nicely.

Yes; the turns here are mostly of the interior variety (the information given to us through the main character's talking to the woman), and even so, they are artfully done. We are given enough information to feel for our main character without the story feeling like it's only there to tell us his story, if that makes sense.

Yes. This story isn't huge on diverse perspectives, since it's so linked to our one main character, but the ways we see him interact with the woman('s body), the person at the hotel on the phone, and even the imagined interaction with Alex present perspectives in a convincing way.
Yes. The story is free from cliches, both of the narrative and language variety.

Yes, this is well managed as well. In addition to the compelling way the author crafts the narrative itself, the language and style let us weave in and out of memory and the present moment, and the fluidity of these different landscapes makes it both original and believable.

Yes! The bones of the story--solitary man finds woman's body from a car crash in an isolated place, wrestles with his own and others' mortality--have of course been seen before, but the ideas (built through the backstory we get through the main character's storytelling) feel human and nuanced and compellingly articulated here.

Yes. There is so much richness here; I'm still thinking about the subtext of the "running commentary, delivered in a flat, disinterested tone, as if the translator had seen this movie a million times, there was nothing new in it for him. And sometimes, he told her, the voice disappeared, leaving the audience guessing. Maybe the invisible translator got distracted, lighting a cigarette or eating a sandwich, or maybe he was so taken by the action in the movie that he was suddenly unable to speak. Then the voice would come back and rush through long scenes in a few breathless lines." Oh, my gosh. This is artfully done here, lending layers of meaning to the situation of the story and that which we image for the main character. The idea that the main character comes back to (in some form or fashion) a few times, that "in that moment, he felt alone. Abandoned. He had been left behind in the living world, while she lay beside him, beyond danger. He had a duty to stay alive, to feel hope and to be interested in the future, while she had come to some peace with herself. Nothing could hurt her now" feels connected to the character's own story through what he says to try to "help" her. I love it; we see him self-soothing in his own panic through the lens of helping her, and the inclusion of parts of his (presumably real) story help to make the whole situation more meaningful for the reader.

Yes, and I can't state this strongly enough. This place feels *so* real: "the tire marks at the edge of the gravel road, where the car must have gone over, and the scrapes where the undercarriage dragged across a rock, leaving behind a screech in the trees," "The radio was on, the real world still keeping in touch," and descriptions we get from the main character's memory all add up to a world that feels not just real but one that's been actually experienced by the characters.

Yes, our main character is wholly complex. Even the ways we see his talking to the woman through summary--which is very, very hard to do, indeed, show us something of him as a real-seeming person: "He told her not to worry, he would stay with her until they arrived, even though it was almost fully dark by then, only the stars out above them and a black infinity in the trees." This is ALSO exceedingly hard to do, I'd argue, in the third-person, but the author accomplishes it beautifully by attention to sentence structure and language.

None of this story is natural, and the ending is no exception. There are many reasons for this, but the main one is that the events in this story are simply things that don't actually happen to people in real life. Each event seems to be better for the protagonist than the last, arbitrarily boosting him up through life without any tension or doubt. The end is the same.

This story's only cohering elements are the constant, perfect triumph of the protagonist through roughly connected, almost nonsensical events, and the narrator's almost narcissistic identification with him.
There are really only two scenes here, and only one of them really counts as a truly present scene. Everything else is very rushed summary.

Time seems to stretch and compress only to do what the writer wants to do in a given moment. In other words, this is a piece in which the writer forces events onto the story instead of discovering what the story itself requires.

Instead of simply telling the story, the narration tries to tell the reader how to feel, repeating melodramatic words and phrases like "solace," "beauty," "testament," "sanctuary," and "unyielding desire." This persistent melodrama bears the mark of a writer who is not experienced in writing fiction in English.
This is difficult to say. This balance is definitely the least problematic element of this story, but that seems partially to be because it is almost entirely summary.
Unsurprising elements like the protagonist's constant success felt predictable and unsurprising. The discovery of the cabin, while surprising, felt unearned.
The story only presents one perspective, and it is not convincing.
This relates to the use of idiom in the story. Linguistically, this story dips into cliche at every turn, by using melodramatic "beauty" words.
While the structure used is not common in short fiction, that is only the case because it isn't much of a structure at all. Narrative structures are based on tension, and this story has none.

I'm not sure what the thrust of the story is. A random man seems to co-opt the death of a woman he does not know and use it for his own artistic and financial gain, while somehow gaining a sort of connection to her, even before he knows anything about her.
This story suffers from being impacted: the surface and the subtext are meant to be one and the same. This makes neither of them successful.
At the story's beginning, there were some good sensory details, like the snow under the man's boots. Those did not continue to the rest of the story.
The dead woman is very obviously a plot device.

This story, like the first, sums itself up in a way that seems to suggest that the story was not actually for itself, but for the sake of some predetermined over-arching moral or thought: the fleeting nature of life, etc. This theme should be something that the readers gather naturally by the end, not by the narrator telling them how to feel.
Satisfying is a strong word, but this story happens all in one short period of time--important for a story of this length--and its elements, for the most part, work together.
See above.

This story handles time nicely, and that's related largely to its use of summary and scene. It uses just enough summary at the beginning to drop the reader in, and once we're in, everything happens in one time period. And in the scenes, enough time is spent on the surrounding world to realize it, but not get bogged down in it.

Again, sophisticated is a strong word, but this story does show a working knowledge of both denotation and connotation, and worked to set a mood through its literal description, instead of telling the reader how to feel about things.
There is a nice balance between the character, Finch, and the world around him.

While this story is more enjoyable to read than the first, its narrative structure is strange and lacking coherence: There is a man; this man discovers a car accident while walking; he is conveniently picked up by strangers; the end. The events are governed by coincidence, not by necessity.
The protagonist of the story is convincingly strange, but that is all. The things he says are odd, but don't give the reader any real insight into a particular perspective.
The similes and metaphors in this story were perhaps its greatest strengths. They were mostly interesting and original.
See answer 6.
The fleeting nature of life is the least original of ideas, perhaps second only to the solace of nature; so, no, the readers will not be learning anything new, if they are adults.
In order for there to be subtext in a story, things must remain unsaid. Because this story chooses to tell the reader all its intentions at the end, it removes any possibility of subtext.
The writer uses many vivid verbs, sufficient literal descriptions, and evocative figurative comparisons.
The characters seem to be operating at the appropriate levels of roundness and flatness, however, there seems to be no development of them whatsoever.

This story still explains the protagonist's feelings far too much, but even so, this ending feels much quieter and realer than the stories before it. The sensory presence of absence in his bed worked well at the end.
This story's parts work together well. They're believable enough and emotionally resonant.

This story seems to try to eliminate summary wherever possible, and that is the right impulse. This story is the most engaging and emotionally resonant so far, largely because of this excision of summary and prioritization of scene.
Simply, yes. The past is dealt with in thoughts only, while all the story's actual events happen in the present, in scene.

My first thought was no, since I couldn't think of any examples off the top of my head, but on second thought, that seems like a mark of fluency and fluidity. Though there aren't any examples of truly great or startling metaphor, the plainness of this story's telling seems to demonstrate some experience and fluency on the writer's part.

It does achieve more emotional flexibility than the other stories, but this story's primary way of communicating interiority is still through telling, through directly explaining the protagonist's feelings, which is not an effective way of creating a believable interiority.

My true feeling about this question is more neutral than positive, but if I have to pick one, I'll choose yes. While none of the event in the story are very surprising--except for the beginning, in which the story doesn't have enough context to actually be surprising--most of the events ARE appropriate for the story, setting, and scene.
This question does not completely apply to this story in particular, since it isn't undertaking to represent diverse perspectives, but the perspective that it does portray is fairly believable.

This story is still operating on many common, faulty, clichéd story devices. One is the dead wife; one is the vulnerable--or, in these cases, dead--strange woman in need; another is the protagonist who is not someone with real agency, but someone to whom things just happen; and the last is the ending that sums up the main idea of the story: life moves on indifferently. These are all pretty clichéd ideas.
This story does not do anything particularly original in any of the ways described above.
The reader will not gain a unique or original idea, but they will have had a particular emotional experience that is somewhat effective.
This story almost achieves subtext, but it still clearly states its subtext, which again makes subtext impossible.
The writer's use of light and darkness, silence and sound, work well and compliment the story.

I'm sort of neutral on this. The characters do serve their purposes, and they are developed enough to serve them, but their purposes are largely to satisfy plot requirements that allow us into the interiority of the protagonist. So, the other characters still feel used, rather than truly alive (or truly dead).

This ending does have both a sense of arbitrariness and one of just-so-ness, but it is the best by far, and it gives the reader interesting insights into the protagonist himself, without overstating them.
This story brings together separate lives, experiences, and sensations to create a coherent, unified story.
This story spends almost all of its time in scene and handles summary very cleverly and awarely.

The handling of time here is nearly perfect for this story. There is a sense of past, but it is without flashback, and its exposition feels natural because the protagonist is explaining it to the dead woman.

The language used in this story is an example of what the beginning of language mastery actually looks like. There are no, or very few, standout idioms or metaphors or literary allusions, but the plain language in which it is written is just the kind of language that serves it best.
This writer's treatment of surroundings is spare enough not to distract from the protagonist, but present enough to inform our view of him and his situation.
This story's use of insight into the protagonist's life through summary is effective and contains surprising elements that then become relevant in the real life of the story.
There is really only one perspective here, but it is convincing.

Some of the language about the danger and beauty of the mountains is a little clichéd, as is some of the language about the passing nature of life and experiences, but mostly, this story is effective, and the clichés do not distract too much.
Ending this story before the ambulance arrives and in the tension of not knowing if/when it will is an original and effective move.

Again, perhaps not an idea in particular, but an experience, a feeling, and a set of ideas together. I think everything about the protagonists' life--from his need to talk to the dead about it to the actual events of it--is unique and interesting.

This story has some subtext because it does not explain everything that happens. Disparate events and thoughts happen and are pushed together, but they're not explained; they're just made to sit together. This is the beginning of subtext. It isn't particularly rich, but it is subtext.

There is a very fine level of detail here. From the scrape marks left on the rock, to the flashlight on the woman's phone, to the nothingness of the woodland sounds, the sensory details in this story are working effectively.

There is only one real character in this story--the man. The woman is more of an object used to reflect the man. Maybe that is a fault, or maybe it works for this story. I lean toward the idea that it is a fault, simply because I could easily see this story as the end of a much longer story about these two people's separate lives converging in this accident. In other words, when I think about it, the woman still feels like a plot device, but in the experience of reading the story, her passivity does not stand out or distract. So, I'm sort of neutral on this question.

The end is where this story goes off track. The conflict between Jane and Emily, and the challenges she faces as a newcomer and interloper to high society just fades away because...Paul was by her side? The ending seems abrupt, uninteresting, and inexplicable.

There are a couple of issues here. One is the confusing detail of Emily telling Jane to get ready for guests this evening at 8:00. However, Jane goes to bed, wakes up, and the guests then come at 8:00 that evening, i.e. the day after Emily said they were coming. The story also seems to lose steam toward the end. The first part of the story is quite interesting, mainly due to the tension between Jane and Emily; the reader wonders how Jane will manage, especially when faced with what seems like an intimidating dinner party filled with social elites. However, it isn't clear how this conflict is resolved by the end. It seems that simply having Paul by her side (a phrase repeated a couple times in the story) is enough to resolve the tension and conflict. And yet, this does not seem realistic or satisfying.

There is a good balance between the detailed scenes (e.g. the shopping trip, getting into the luxurious car, encountering Emily) and exposition (e.g. Jane's reflection on the hugeness of her new house, and its comparison with her family's humble circumstances).
The pacing was good, there were no aspects that seemed too overly drawn out or compressed.

For most of the story, Emily's condescending, upper-class way of speaking is effective. You can feel her insincere contempt in her language. However, by the end of the story, the language slips into less interesting, cliche expressions. For example, the metaphorical expression "Her love for Paul shone as bright as the stars, a beacon guiding her through nights that once seemed endless" seems really bland.
I thought there was a good balance between exterior events, such as Jane's trip to the shop, her ride in the car, and her encounter with Emily, and her inner conflict caused by Emily's condecension.

I was expecting some twist or drama at the point of the dinner party, but nothing happened.
