I was invested in Jane's character, because the details of her situation and the challenges she faced were developed very well for most of the story. But then, the story just ended without any conflict or resolution.

I thought Emily's character was presented pretty well, as was Paul's. Emily's condescending tone and language really came through on the page, and Paul's reaction to his mother's treatment of Jane was also a brief but interesting insight into his persona; the reader understands him to be unwilling to confront his mother, or even understand Jane's negative feelings about Emily.
Overall, the story avoids cliches, and uses language with a lot of interesting detail (although some of these details are repeated; there are a couple of "plush carpets" for example).
The form and structure seemed familiar and not remarkable.

I think the reader is ready to engage with an interesting idea, perhaps about the ways individuals need to balance who they are and what others expect of them. However, this idea never gets developed, and instead the story ends in a "happily ever after" way, without much explanation for why Jane suddenly felt at ease.
Especially by the end, this story doesn't seem to have had much meaning beyond the actions that take place.
There are plenty of details that make the world believable, for instance, the buttery seats and plush carpet in the car. Yet, some words are repeated too frequently (e.g. lavish[ly]).
Emily's character is developed well in the first part of the story; however, she doesn't appear at the end of the story, and this is an unsatisfying loose end.

The ending is much too long. It is repetitive and vague, and doesn't really explain how the tension in the first part of the story is resolved. Presumably Emily accepts Sarah into her family and her social circle because she is a good writer? This seems implausible, and the space taken up with vague description of Sarah's recognition and success doesn't really contribute to an interesting story.

The story seems to lose its focus at this point: "With the haze of uncertainty lingering in the air, Sarah found solace in her journal, pouring her heart into its pages." This sentence comes right after what seems like an important turning point in the story and the relationship between Sarah and Emily, that is, Emily gives Sarah a glimmer of a compliment, but then follows it with a stern warning. The reader wonders what will happen, and how Sarah will handle the ambiguity of the situation. However, the story then takes an unusual turn, as the uncertainty of the moment somehow fades into Sarah writing a best-selling book, vaguely about her own life. The rest of the story spirals into a vague and repetitive paragraphs about Sarah's success and how her problems have been resolved. A particularly loose end is the character of Lily, who is mentioned as a close supporter of Sarah, but then fades from the story, occasionally mentioned along with Sarah's children.

The first part of the story is successful in balancing scene and exposition, but the story after  "from that day forward" is mainly taken up by lengthy and repetitive summary, in which nothing very interesting happens.

Much of the story is a compression of time ("years turned into decades") which seems unnecessary, because the events that happen during those times are repeated several times. The author thus compresses chronology, but draws out repetitive description of what happened generally over that period.
The story does not make sophisticated use of these devices. Metaphors, when they appear, are common and predictable (e.g. love story like a fairy tale, canopy of stars, beacons of hope, etc.)

There is too much "exterior" for the last several pages of the story. The reader is told that Sarah's career took off, she gave back to the community, she remained close with Emily, etc. None of this is experienced by the reader through Sarah's own eyes. The effect is a flat, almost bullet-point-type exposition of the facts of the rest of Sarah's life.

The resolution to the main conflict, i.e. Emily accepts Sarah because she is a good writer, is surprising, but also doesn't seem plausible, and thus isn't an effective way to move the story along, or to resolve the conflict.
The primary perspective is that of Sarah, and in the second part of the story, even Sarah's point of view seems to fade into that of a narrator who stands apart from Sarah's personal experiences.

There are plenty of cliches in this story, expressions that are overused to the point that they fail to convey any precise meaning or feeling. Some examples in this story are: beacon of hope, the power of storytelling can change lives and that the true magic lies in embracing our authentic selves, paying it forward, the transformative power of love, acceptance, and the pursuit of one's true purpose, etc.
The form and structure is straightforward and does not seem original.

The reader, who may have become invested in Sarah's prospects in a new family with a difficult mother-in-law, won't find much to reflect on in this story. Sarah became a great writer and everything turned out fine. It is not a very interesting idea.
There doesn't seem to be any layer of meaning or significance below the surface meaning in this story.

The details that make the world believable in this story fade away by the end of the story. For example, by the time we get to this paragraph, there is nothing in the language to suggest anything specific about the characters' surroundings, or even what they talked about: "From that day forward, Sarah and Miss Emily forged an unexpected bond. They would while away the hours discussing literature, politics, and their shared dreams for a better future. Each taught and learned from the other, proving that acceptance and growth could come from the most unlikely of sources.

The characters do not seem well-developed. Even Sarah's character seems one-dimensional. She faces a difficult relationship with her mother-in-law, she writes a book, and everything works out. The character Lily is simply mentioned, without much development at all.

Nothing really happens to bring about the end of the story. Felicity simply continues to feel alienated from her former life, but also hopeful for a change (i.e. "a single breath of air"). The ending thus feels arbitrary and unsatisfying.

The story lacks a narrative that moves it along; things don't really happen in this story. Much of the text is very wordy figurative language that tends to repeat the same ideas again and again: Felicity comes from a humble background, and feels out of place and anxious with her new surroundings.

My answer here is related to the last one. I think the story would be improved with more "scene" and less exposition about Felicity's life, as she tries to adapt to her new life in circumstances she is unaccustomed to and where she is uncomfortable. We are told that a lot of things happen (e.g. she forgets her mother's cooking, the music of her youth, etc.), but the idea that she was losing her sense of herself and her background could probably be conveyed through scene vignettes, rather than the reader being told that they happened.

The middle part of the story between the point where the character of Miss Emily is introduced to the reader, and when Felicity actually meets her in the Hamptons, is too long, and feels repetitive. We do get some details about Felicity's background, which is good, but overall much of the story drags.

This is one of the major weaknesses of the story. Most paragraphs are filled with a lot of figurative language that becomes muddy and convoluted. An example of this is: "Both a symbol of her ceaselessly persistent desire for acceptance and an ever-present reminder of her unattainable dreams, it lay hidden within the intricate labyrinth of her soul – a secret tableau of her deepest fears and fervent hopes, interwoven like ivy around the columns of her gilded prison." Another example that is both convoluted and nonsensical is "the metronome counting her husband's footsteps ticked at the same, unchanging beat, pulse aligned with hers when they trespassed upon the marbled floor of the Met, hallowed ground for the privileged few who dared to dance with their lifeline tethered so precariously to the stability of a supermarket chain." 
Many of the metaphors don't really work or make sense. For example: "They were buried six feet under in a whirlpool of suspicion and confusion, waves of uncertainty lapping against the shores of their tender hearts." Here we have a burial, which takes place underground, but here the burial is in a whirlpool. Furthermore, a whirlpool doesn't create lapping waves on the shore, but rather a strong vortex. Another example is "bit like a snake's venom." A venomous snake bites, but venom itself does something else (poisons?).

The story is heavy on the interior, in the form of narrative explanation of Felicity's thoughts and feelings. The "exterior" interactions and dialog is very limited, and is mainly confined to the brief conversation Felicity has with Emily in the Hamptons. The flashback dialog of her father is an exception, but is also confusing, because he mentions a Steinway in lamenting about the poor quality of his violin (one might rather expect him to mention a Stradivarius).

Nothing very much unexpected happened. The narrative continues on a pretty straight path, and tapers off at the end. Felicity feels uneasy about her life married to Edward, uncomfortable with her mother-in-law, and there isn't much deviation from this narrative path.
We don't get the perspectives of anyone except Felicity, and even she does not have a lot of depth or complexity.
The story manages to avoid cliche pretty well. The problem with the language is overly wordy and convoluted figurative language that in several cases doesn't make sense.
The form and structure is not original.

The reader will finish the story understanding that Felicity has continued to be uncomfortable with her life married to Edward, but is always hopeful for a change. There isn't much more to it than that, and thus there doesn't seem to be much of anything original or interesting to take away from it.
There is not much going on below the surface narrative: Felicity is anxious and uncomfortable, and regrets losing touch with her past.

So much of the text is comprised of figurative language that not a lot of attention is given to building the actual sensory details of the world that Felicity lives in. Some of the descriptive language doesn't make sense. For example, at the beginning we get the phrase "when she felt Edward's fingers encircle her wrist, a firm yet loving grasp that took her breath away." Thus just seems weird, and not really a loving grasp that would take someone's breath away.
The characters are not really developed with any depth. Even Felicity seems to be a rather one dimensional character.

The end of the story is good. Although the conflict in the relationship between the narrator and Emily is not resolved, the ambiguity of the relationship has been throughly introduced and explained to the reader, leaving the reader to ponder these ambiguities themselves (primarily the tension between love and revulsion between the narrator and Emily).
This story has a satisfying unity, and holds together well. The dialog, the action, the background explanations from the narrator all feel balanced.

Scene and exposition are balanced very well, I would answer this question similar to the way I answered the previous one. Most action is taking place in the "present," while past events appear in a combination of scene vignettes, along with the narrator's own explanation of their meaning to her.

The pacing is good. Most of the action takes place in the weekend or so that Emily and the narrator first meet. Other periods of time, such as the couple's first meeting, the narrator's parents' death and her finding her way on her own, are compressed in a way that is not too drawn out, but also gets across the most important details.

The story does a good job with these techniques, particularly with literary allusion, for example, when Emily tells the story of her son bringing home a bloody dead pigeon. The reader is meant to understand this story as an allusion to Emily's son now bringing home the narrator, and the combination of the son's happiness, Emily's happiness and relief, contrasted with the image of death is very effective. Similarly, the final appearance of the raccoon looking for trash, and the use of this double meaning of that word, is also effective.

There is good balance here. We get the narrator's thoughts and interpretations about events, but we also get detailed descriptions of events, both happening in the present, and those that happened in the past.

The main narrative turn, i.e. Emily's abrupt change of demeanor, is both surprising and appropriate. There has been foreshadowing up until this point that not everything was going to be great (e.g. the idea that the narrator used to not notice things that Emily notices, along with the phrase "But I didn’t think of things like that, impressions—first impressions—what they mean and how people don’t change their feelings about you even years after"; the reference to the dead pigeon). Yet, the reader doesn't know what will happen, and so Emily's change is surprising, but also feels appropriate to the structure of the story up to that point.

Both main characters (the narrator and Emily) are developed well. For the narrator we have her own thoughts, and for Emily we have good details in both her dialog and the description of her actions to get a complex sense of her. An example is this passage: "Miss Emily was so at ease. Talking with the salesgirl, asking her to bring us things in a size that would be a better fit. Asking the salesgirl her opinion about what young professional women wore to the oﬀice these days. She told me that, since her son worked in an oﬀice, she didn’t want me to feel out of place. I would never buy these things for myself, I said. I don’t have that kind of money to spend, I told her. She said she would take care of it. She was so happy to be in a position to help, and all that mattered was that I loved the things I picked out." Emily is being generous, but also controlling and with her own motives in mind.
The story seems original, and avoids cliche.
I don't think any the story uses any of the examples of original form and structure as described in the guidelines for this question.

I think by the end of the story, the reader is confronted with an interesting idea: how can love and revulsion, two seemingly opposing emotions, be so closely related? Emily's love for her son, and professed love for her daughter-in-law, seem to be tangled up with her contempt for her daughter-in-law's background, profession, lack of resources. We understand that these conflicted feelings arise out of Emily's own background as "trash.

This story is successful in offering layers of meaning: references to death with the description of the pigeon, and the car accident. The idea of fixing and cleaning, with the references to the son's request for his mom to make and fix things for him as a child, the scrubbing in the apartment, the reference to dry cleaning.

I think the story is very successful is creating a believable and detailed world. Examples of this are "I was wearing jeans and a pair of old runners, and a sweatshirt several sizes too large. My hair was tied back in a low ponytail. I wasn’t wearing any makeup;" "The feel of the cash-machine tray as it popped out and hit me on the arm was like an old friend checking in throughout the day;" "I hadn’t noticed the stains on the outside of the toilet bowl, or inside just around the rim. I didn’t know things could get into those kinds of places, at that angle.

Both the narrator and Emily are well developed. The son/husband is not developed, although this seems by design. The story is about the narrator and Emily, and the ways they differ and are similar to each other.

No, this ending doesn't feel earned. It's underwhelming, I'm afraid--so in a story in which not much happens, I guess it does feel "natural" for the story, but I wouldn't call it successful. It ends in a lackluster fashion without any real sense of accomplishment or triumph on the part of Jane (or anyone else).

Yes, this story is exceedingly logical in its progression--*too* logical to be wholly satisfying, I'd argue, but certainly fulfilling the criteria here. The movement of the story moves pretty consistently forward, and although the actions and dialogue don't present much to wrestle with for the reader, the story seems ultimately served adequately by the way the elements come together.

No, here again, this story suffers from a lack of instincts when it comes to scene versus summary. There are very few scenes themselves painted for us, and when they are, they don't seem to add anything novel to our understanding of the characters, relationships, or situations. For instance, the famed ballroom dinner party whatever seems to have a somewhat transformative effect on Jane (re: her confidence), but all we really get of it is that "[Paul] made her feel like the only woman in the room, showering her with affection and keeping a secure arm around her waist." Bleh. Nothing to see here, I'm afraid.

No, for me as a reader, the manipulation of time doesn't contribute any sense of suspense or any means of applying a lens to understand a character better. There's a weird narrative inconsistency that seems to happen between para. 12 and 15/16 (dinner is "this evening [...] promptly at eight" in para 12, and then she wakes "early next morning" without having attended the dinner yet in para 16), which at first I thought was something fun and novel and unexpected--Jane slept through this important dinner somehow! What will happen next?--but instead, it just seems like a mistake since it's never addressed. This is a minor editorial matter, but it's related to the overall mundane way the story progresses.

No, I think ultimately this story doesn't use idiom or metaphor to good effect. The idioms seem fluently deployed and appropriate to the situation, but they don't do much of anything to enrich the characterization or add depth to the story.

No, there isn't much of a balance here in the emotional tenor of the story. From what's said, I know cognitively that we're supposed to care about Jane and be "on her side," but she's quite underdeveloped, and as a result, even the interiority we get from her is just one thing over and over again: anxiety over not being of this "world" of moneyed society.

No, this is (in my estimation) the biggest issue with the story: there's pretty much NO tension to be had in the story, despite Jane's set-up as a sort of Miss Doolittle-esque country-girl-trying-to-make-it-in-high-society character. And yet! And yet. Even the scenes in which there is supposed to be tension literally between the two characters--the Emily and Jane interactions--are described in the barest terms. This makes the characters sound stilted and unmemorable, and does little to make us actually feel Jane's out-of-placeness or other feelings in the story.

Yes, I think the story passes the test here. While they're forgettable, the characters of Emily and Jane are at least supposed to be contrary to one another, and Emily's brusque tone does seem to fit with what's been said about her. She's certainly unlikeable, but because of the narrative, it's also possible to see that she believes she's "looking out for her son" by acting a jerk. (Unfortunately, Paul is a nothing-character--as stock as they come--with seemingly no discernible qualities whatsoever.)

No, as above, the plot itself has been super overused--which is not to say that it couldn't ever be done in an original way (after all, denying expectations in a story is a thrilling way to approach storytelling sometimes), but it's not the case here.

No, with the time inconsistency mentioned above aside, I'd say there's nothing particularly unique or innovative in the story. From the themes to the ways the characters and narrator speak, it feels pretty run-of-the-mill.

No, this story seems to rehash well-established territory without revealing anything new or a different or compelling way of understanding it. Sadly, this story seems neither to entertain, inform, provoke thought, challenge ideas, provide comfort, nor raise awareness.

No, this one's a definite no from me. The denotation here feels like all there is; we have no reason to believe anything is anything other than what is seems to our narrator. We hear Emily's judgy, and then we see her, judgy. We hear Paul is a good guy, and then we see him acting loving and supportive. Even the palatial estate seems to be, in fact, palatial. It's not to say that contradiction is all that can build subtext, but it doesn't hurt, and there's no evidence of that--or much else--here in this story.
Yes, this story does feel believable from a sensory perspective. It's a bit thin for my taste in terms of sensory descriptions and imagery, but what's here feels appropriate enough and useful.

No, the characters here all feel pretty flat: no feeling any of them has, and no description of them, reveals anything unexpected or nuanced. They all feel like background characters or characters from central casting to stand in for the parts of Country Girl Who Married Rich, Judgy Mother-In-Law, and Rich, Probably Handsome, Blandly Nice Husband.

No, the story here ends in much the same way as it progresses for the most part--in summative, conclusionary "wrap up" rather than an ending that feels purposeful. I mean, the ending isn't out of "character" for the story itself--the story hits the "inspirational transformation" gong over and over again post-book conversation--but it doesn't feel like it provides a satisfying resolution. Instead, it feels like the writer ran out of things to say a couple pages back and decided finally to end the dang thing.

No. This story doesn't feel disjointed, but the pieces don't seem to add up to much as the story progresses. There are what feels like countless paragraphs that stall the story out (post-book conversation between Miss Emily and Sarah), and really for the entire story following that scene, the story seems to stall out in recapitulation of the same ideas.

No, I'm afraid not. This story struggles to find its footing once the tension from the opening of the story is "resolved" (the conflict with Miss Emily). In those last three pages, the writer resorts to clumsy "transitions" that nod toward scene but instead just set up MORE summary; the vagueness of "One summer, as Sarah stood by the lake behind their cottage, watching her children play in the water, a sense of gratitude washed over her" stands out. "One summer" gives me hope as a reader that we'd be linked in time and space somewhere, a hope that's crushed once the sentence continues.

No, and this is an element that I feel like could've had such promise! The story chugs along fine in the very beginning, but then we get the last three pages of the story where it's time jumping and summary after summary, so that these last three pages feel washed out and dull.

No, this story doesn't add much in the way or idioms, metaphors, or literary allusions for me. The characters speak somewhat like robots, and the narrator's limited omniscience locks it here into fairly expected turns of phrase rather than language that provides further understanding for us of characters and situations.

No; with the amount of summary here, it feels like there'd be ample time to balance the interior and exterior, but there's a lack of trust on the part of the writer, so the story resorts to saying the silent parts outloud rather than letting the reader arrive at them naturally. Statements like "Sarah knew she had a lot to prove, not only to Miss Emily but also to herself" and the dialogue tag "she said, surprising Sarah" show this unwillingness to let the reader connect pieces themselves.

Yes, although I don't find it to be particularly compelling, the turn of Miss Emily accepting Sarah because of her book does feel surprising and somewhat satisfying, if a little too easy. Sarah's decision to become a writer also feels surprising somewhat, and helps to develop her as a character that is (slightly) more than a bit character.

Yes, I think the treatment of Miss Emily here is okay, and that she is capable as a character of development and change feels satisfying overall. (The scope and "amount" of change doesn't feel particularly believable since it's told to us in so much summary, but that's a different matter.) Sarah seems somewhat complex, if a little expected overall; Michael is a stand-in for getting Sarah and Miss Emily together, but that doesn't seem like a terribly large problem for the story since he's just the impetus to give us our story.

No, unfortunately, there are many cliches here, which work against the story as a whole (e.g., "like something out of a fairytale"; "Michael had proposed on a moonlit evening under a canopy of stars"; "took her breath away"; "pouring her heart into its pages"; "as the sun set on Sarah's remarkable life"). As cliches do, phrases like these keep the story locked into the surface level of explanation and work against deep understanding of characters or situations.

No; as above, the story seems to laze about with "transitions" like "the turning point came" (woof) that editorialize rather than inform. The story's progress feels hampered by its traditional narrative form.

No, this story feels fairly trite in its ideas. There are elements that would seem to set the story apart from any other story of discord within a family because of an "unsuitable" marriage, but ultimately the story just keeps hitting the one note, and the tension of the story dissolves entirely post-book conversation.

No, this is a story in which the narrator just announces everything rather than letting the reader come to any conclusions themselves. As a result, any subtext is brought right to the surface before it has a chance to make an impact. Nary a bit of subtext to be seen here, unfortunately!

No, this story doesn't offer much in the way of sensory appeals. The stabs at setting and image are fairly expected (e.g., "The sprawling gardens seemed to stretch for miles, beautifully manicured lawns surrounded by vibrant flowers in full bloom") and so make the story read as a sketch of a story rather than a fully realized piece.

No. I'm a little torn here, to be honest; I do think that Miss Emily and Sarah are developed in suitable ways, but then there's Michael, who is such a non-entity in the story that I can barely remember his name. He's the definition of a plot requirement character, and even Miss Emily herself feels staged to give Sarah something to fight against in the beginning.
No; when the ending finally comes (not a moment too soon), it feels like it's only here because the writer abandoned any hope of reconciling the ideas and conflicts within the story as a whole.
No, this story doesn't end up working together through its various elements. The descriptions are too wide reaching and various threads are started then abandoned before the impact is borne out.

No. While the story does indeed include some scenes, and to okay effect, there is a balance between scene and summary missing throughout, so that the story isn't effective in this regard. Much of the story is relegated to exposition, and as a result because of the unremarkable nature of the observations on the part of this narrator, much of the story is just forgettable summary.

No. There are some places where the story slows down and tension builds (such as the first paragraph and the paragraph of description of Felicity's childhood home), which are somewhat satisfying. However, especially as the piece continues, the story gets too relaxed and includes phrases like "as the years passed" rather than actually complicating or resolving anything.

No, this story certainly includes a LOT of metaphors (and some allusions), but none of them is very well handled, I'm afraid. The allusion describing Felicity as "a scarlet letter in a room of haute couture" is complicating and confusing, and the wealth of similes alone makes it difficult to gain footing in the story. Some of these could be okay if they didn't go into such detail ("She wore the title like a thief" could be okay and interesting, but when it continues to belabor it to the point of nonsense: "not a particularly skilled or dedicated thief who practiced his wicked craft by night, but an incompetent thief who desperately wanted to belong elsewhere"), but others are just plain weird in the context of the story (emotion describes as "like bread dough left to rise too long, spilling beyond the boundaries of its bowl").

No; in general, I think I'd find that stories that are overly interior have a stronger possibility of being successful than stories that are overly exterior (for me as a reader), but this story doesn't gain much from all of the interiority on Felicity's part. There are a few exceptions for me here (which I'll mention next), but overall, the story feels like it knows there SHOULD be emotion in a story but doesn't quite know how to handle it yet.

No, there aren't turns here particularly, and when something surprising does "happen" (mostly through interior thought), it's abandoned almost right away so that it ends up feeling like an inconsistency rather than something purposeful and strategic.

No. Miss Emily here is, I think, supposed to be a sort of counterweight to Felicity, but Emily is such a hollow character, and gets so little air time in the story, that she's not even given the chance to be presented "convincingly and accurately.

No, there are cliches aplenty here, particularly as the story resorts to more and more metaphors; "like a gaudily painted ship, painstakingly crafted by skilled artisans, yet unmoored from its secure anchor, she began to feel herself drifting away" and the extended metaphor of the metamorphosis both feel overdone and stale here.

No, there's nothing much innovative here about narrative movement, genre, plot, or language/style. The only bit I thought was notable in this regard (and not in a successful way) was the amount of time that passed in the story before we actually meet Miss Emily--but this doesn't seem to gain the story much and if it were a strategic choice on the part of the writer, I don't see how it adds up in the story as it progresses.

Yes, as much as it almost pains me to say it, I do actually think that readers could come to a unique and original idea through reading this story. For me as a reader, this comes in the form of the paragraph that says "In trying to replace the memories of her humble beginnings with a newfound grandeur, Felicity was slowly but surely erasing her own past, her own identity. She began to forget the torn, yellowed pages of her favorite childhood books as she filled her mind with the titles and authors that lined Edward's family library." THIS IS SO COMPELLING AND INTERESTING! I read that and thought, okay! Here we go! This is going to get into some fascinating ideas! But then this gets set by the wayside in the next paragraph, with the more trite and expected statement that "[h]er heart ached for the authenticity and raw emotion that she could no longer access.

No, despite the possibility of the complicated idea of Felicity's new life "overwriting" her past that comes up in the story, there doesn't seem to be rhetorical sophistication here. The surface level itself doesn't always keep the reader engaged, and the lack of subtext only furthers the feeling that the story stays too light on its feet for its own good.

No, overall I don't think the story passes the test here. I am wooed periodically by some of the details, which sometimes feel intriguing (e.g., the grandmother's handbag in the beginning, the description of her childhood home as "little more than a collection of loose springs and splintered wood"). However, overall, the specificity--in sensory details and, as mentioned earlier, at the level of metaphor--tends to overwhelm rather than elucidate. (I'm thinking particularly here of "She was no longer the girl who traded in Hamburger Helper for ground turkey and canned spaghetti for homemade noodles as soon as she could afford to.")

No, I'm not convinced any of these characters is particularly developed--even Felicity, who gets the most time because of the narrator's POV. I believe there was potential for Edward here, but he ends up just sort of being a pair of hands that guide her around mostly. And Miss Emily is about a well developed as the mentioned father --which is to say, not really at all.

Yes! The raccoon at the ending knocked the breath right out of me! What a thrill this was of an ending. It's super successful how it ends still on our main character, and in her head and description, and seeing the weirdness of the situation dawn on her but not startle her feels really appropriate.

Yes, for sure! This story holds together beautifully, patiently building the mystery around what will go "wrong" between Miss Emily and the speaker until that shift happens and the characters' truths are exposed. Threads from early in the story (e.g., the ruined things the son would find and bring to Miss Emily make something of) are delicately explored all the way through to the end here.

Yes! The thing I think is so successful here is how the author builds in voice and description into recounting a conversation; we don't have to get actual dialogue in order to hear the ways phrases were said. A great example of this is when we hear from our narrator that Miss Emily "had been—at one point in her life, so she knows these things—what people called trash. She’d improved herself, she said. Moved on up, pulled herself up by her bootstraps, got to work, and no one could use that word to describe her anymore. She made sure of that, she said.

Yes, the pacing and compression/stretching of time here feels very appropriate. The only time I wondered a bit was in the recounting the car accident paragraphs, which felt a little too quick for me as a reader, but overall, this is pitch-perfect, I believe.

Yes, the use of metaphor here is really exquisite--understated, and used in a way that adds up to something greater throughout the story. No metaphor feels gratuitous here. A couple that I particularly loved for their beauty and believability were "She brought items up to me as if they were dead animals, holding them with two fingers as she shaped her face into disgust" and "I guess it was like a child wishing to see a crowd of gold stars next to her name." I'm in love.

Yes, for sure. This story balances the interior and exterior beautifully, which I think could be especially hard to do with a story that's SO close to our first-person narrator. But getting to see the way that Miss Emily--and the world--are shaped and remade through our narrator's seeing is fascinating.

Yes, absolutely. There are a fair number of surprises here, and they're each handled in a measured and believable way. Even the biggest turn of Miss Emily becoming hyper-critical is handled believably because we're still understanding it through our narrator, who by this point the reader feels great affection for and understands as reliable.

Yes; where even to start with this? This is *so* finely handled. From the very beginning, the narrator adding that "he had this beautiful coat, the kind of fabric that made you want to reach out and touch" gives us a kind of look into her mind: her attention to detail, her observing of others, her lack of self-consciousness to describe it as "beautiful." As a reader, I immediately know that this is a narrator I want to listen to. Also, to start a story with the weirdness of "I don’t know why I didn’t think of someone like Miss Emily. It never occurred to me to imagine her," I know as a reader that I'm in excellent hands. 

Miss Emily is the most unlikeable character of course (and moreso as the story continues), but because of the way we see our narrator having affection for her in the beginning, despite Miss Emily's obvious condescension, the "betrayal" of her change is all the more arresting. Statements such as "She talked about her son as if she had been married to him for twenty-five years and was now emotionally spent" also make Miss Emily seem more believable, with real-person flaws.

Yes; although the narrative of marrying into a different "sort" of family has been done thousands of times before, this story manages to make it detailed and richly complicated in ways that make it feel novel.

Yes, for me as a reader, part of the story's success comes in the way the writer uses the narrator's voice to lend credibility and lead us as readers to insights about who and what Miss Emily is and how she's treating the narrator.
Yes, I'd say so. The reader here can gain a subtle understanding of relationships and what we look for when we love or are in love with someone.

Yes, there's so much to love here in terms of the story's subtext. The narrator gives the reader many hints of how "her world" differs from the one she'll experience married to ol' what's-his-name: "If they didn’t like you, you’d know about it and they’d say it to your face. There was no pretending"; "But I didn’t think of things like that, impressions—first impressions—what they mean and how people don’t change their feelings about you even years after." 

As mentioned earlier, I am really smitten with the way the author sets up the idea of Miss Emily seeing herself as gatekeeper or restorer with the anecdote that "she said her son was always finding things like that—dead animals, caps and bottles, old books—and bringing them home. She said he always asked her to make something out of them." Similarly, the narrator seeing the story as a place where "You didn’t have to own any land or take out feed or work up the nerve to kill anything that had a face. Someone somewhere did that work for you, and it was all there on display" reveals much to the reader about her anxieties and struggles.

Yes, and this is largely done because of the mastery of voice. Descriptions like "He seemed real glamorous, and I hadn’t seen someone like that before so close up, looking right back at me" is gorgeous for the realness of the voice and for what is reveals about our narrator's level of investment in the world around her.

Yes, the characters here are really artfully handled. I love the details like "We don’t accept personal checks anymore, we were told to say." The voice here is excellently particular, and the syntactical variation throughout the story sounds like a real person speaking. And when the narrator says, earlyish in the story, that Miss Emily "was so wonderful to me, really," it's protesting enough to let us know that, when combined with the beginning statement about Miss Emily, all is not what it seems--or won't be what is seems like now by the ending. I love that the person she married is just "the son" or "Miss Emily's son"--it's a brilliant way to show us that his purpose in the story is to get us to the conflict between these two characters, and even the narrator seems aware here.

The story ends in what feels like an arbitrary fashion. Instead of following the progression that it sets up, which is to fulfill the trajectory of Jane’s ascent into high society and either finding or rejecting the comfort involved in it, or something more ambiguous, it rapidly paraphrases an encounter Jane has with her husband at a fancy party which serves as a stand-in for that trajectory that it does not meaningfully fill-out: “ Together, they were conquering this dazzling new world that had once seemed so alien and forbidding. She knew now without a doubt that they could face any challenge side by side. Her love for Paul shone as bright as the stars, a beacon guiding her through nights that once seemed endless. Hand in hand.”
Story makes sense of a sentence-level and it does not break its own flow or logic. While the narrative trajectory is ultimately unsatisfying, it is not unsound, only poorly executed.

The story struggles at maintaining a scene. In itself, this is not a problem, but because the story also stumbles in creating a textured space for its paraphrases, it begins to feel like it floats. Though there is dialogue, it is integrated into paragraphs and never given space to breathe or take on a subtext.

The narrative gets bogged down in the early scene/paraphrase depicting the narrator’s experience shopping. Given the story’s trajectory, the ending portion where the narrator confronts the party with her husband is equally important, but given significantly less time and recounted with less detail.

While the language is relatively constrained, it consistently relies on broad adjectives and adverbs instead of specific descriptions or unexpected comparisons. For instance, “gargantuan carved front doors” or “Jane mustered a wan smile…”
The sense of anxiety that Jane feels at her position within this upper class family is stated outright, but never shown or implied, giving it very little depth for the reader.

Though the trajectory of the narrative isn’t exactly expected, this is more because it does not feel as though it builds on itself meaningfully, instead it shifts from a paraphrase of the shopping section into a rushed account of the party which cannot bear the weight it is asked to.

The voice here relies on cliches and heightened language in the place of specificity. While it does, in a way, seem to match with its setting, which is to say it creates a narrative space of upper class decadence, it doesn’t match well with its focalizing character, who is intended to be out of place within that environment.
The story employs cliches and tropes throughout. Indeed, the trajectory and plot it depicts is a common narrative trope in itself and nothing is done to complicate or disrupt that trope.

The structure resembles a hinge—the first part focuses on the shopping, the second on the party. A structure like this can absolutely work if the two sections, or scenes, speak or interact with each other in some way. Here, there is a broad attempt to show Jane’s progression, that in the party she comes into her own, but that trajectory is not mapped out, no development occurs, it simply shifts. This is unsatisfying and difficult to accept.

In theory, the story attempts to unpack ideas of class and wealth divides, especially in terms of manners and ways of living or giving meaning to life. However, it is not able to investigate these subjects beyond a surface level—Jane wishes to be accepted into wealthy family and there is no critique happening on any level as far as I can discern, in any direction. This leaves the story feeling, in a way, without a theme.

There is no subtext in this story as far as I can tell, neither the plot nor the dialogue is able to imply meaning. Rather, it is consistently stated outright. For instance, “Jane felt intimidated, keenly aware of her modest upbringing and difficulties navigating the complex rules of etiquette that came so naturally to these elite socialites” or “She felt exhausted by Emily's constant criticism and demands, the foreignness of her lavish new lifestyle.”

While there is some sense of setting, it is consistently told with overwrought language (“She climbed the massive staircase to the suite of rooms she shared with Paul, overwhelmed by the ornate furnishings and dizzying amount of space. Her old bedroom back home could fit inside their cavernous walk-in closet. “) taking the place of specific descriptions. The tone of the narrative voice does some work to built setting, but it cannot take the place of specificity.

Jane is intended to follow a trajectory across the narrative, which is to say it is clear that she is supposed to begin as uncomfortable with her new family and their class status and find, by the end of the party, a confidence in her position. However, the party is so quickly depicted the possibility of this arc holding meaningful weight is minimal.

The story becomes increasingly ridiculous as it speeds through time and Sarah’s stature as an artist rapidly increases. The ending is a culmination of this overwhelmingly silly trajectory:  “And so, as the sun set on Sarah's remarkable life, it rose on a new era of storytelling, pioneered by those she had inspired. They carried forth her mission of spreading empathy, resilience, and hope through their own words, ensuring that her legacy would endure for generations to come.” The overwrought language and sentiment of these final lines more or less perfectly encapsulates the trajectory of the story up to that point.
Though it becomes increasingly absurd and ridiculous as it expends its temporal scope, it never loses legibility. The story makes sense. It is nearly impossible to accept, but it makes sense.

While the early part of the story attempts to stay relatively in-scene, it goes off the rails as soon as it starts following those temporal jumps, losing any meaningful sense of scene and largely getting stuck in broad, sweeping language. For instance, “Embarking on this endeavor, Sarah delved into her past, exploring her journey from a working-class family to her life as a supermarket cashier. The words flowed effortlessly, each page a testament to her resilience and determination. And when the last sentence was penned, Sarah knew it was her greatest accomplishment.”

The pacing becomes more and more ludicrous as the story proceeds. After two or so pages of clumsy in-scene work, the pace picks up to a breakneck speed and does not slow down. As it speeds up, the narrative also becomes increasingly broad and implausible.
The story consistently employs ridiculous overwrought language from the beginning: “The sky was a vivid shade of cerulean…” or “… the haze of uncertainty lingering…”.

There is limited interiority here and the story fails at implying anything which is not on the page. The emotions the characters feel are strictly binary, which is to say simple and without nuance. This causes the story to lack weight and its characters plausibility.

While the story takes some unexpected and frankly unhinged narrative turns, they are frustrating and confounding rather than interesting. This level of temporal speed can be a strong narrative choice. Here, it feels baffling, especially the impetus, which I’ll talk about later on re: theme.
The voice is overwrought and increasingly broad as the narrative goes on. Without texture, it feels inhuman.

The conceit of the story is itself a cliche; however, it is made worse by the reality that the least cliched elements of the story are also the least plausible and most baffling, namely that Sarah’s book wins the mother-in-law’s love and the happily-ever-after ending which follows. It is so absurd it could be parody.

The story has an interesting structure insofar as it is confounding—the temporal leaps are bold, but without meaningful texture in each “era” as it were, they fail both to convince and to connect to one another.

The story is about class and about Sarah’s attempt to fit into the upper class family she has married into. This attempt is given no critical lens—she simply wishes to be accepted and we understand this acceptance to be something it is possible to earn, within the story. The decision on the story’s part to have Sarah earn her mother-in-law’s love by way of becoming a writer and writing something which “….[captures] the essence of what it means to strive for something more" is completely absurd to me and the depiction of the relationship that follows and their closeness, which seems to happen immediately makes it even more so.

There is no subtext in this story. It states outright what it means and there is no opportunity for implication. This becomes especially difficult after the temporal jumps. For instance: “ They became beacons of hope, reminding the world that true happiness and fulfillment lie not in societal expectations, but in embracing our authentic selves.”
The story relies on overwrought language to carry the weight of its world, which cannot ultimately suffice. As the tempo increases, the attempts at creating space fade away into broad language.

The story clearly intends for Sarah’s arc to be one which is resonant and moving, that her relationship with her mother-in-law and their reconciliation is supposed to be a heartwarming narrative arc, especially alongside the success of her career as a writer which facilitates it. However, the narrative has a binary understanding of change for its characters—after Sarah writes the book, the relationship changes entirely without hard feelings. This is neither meaningful character development, nor does it make sense.

The ending is quite rushed after the meeting with the mother-in-law. Though there is a temporal jump, it is neither earned nor well-supported and takes up such a brief portion of the story that it feels like an afterthought.

The story follows a clear trajectory through Felicity’s life, explaining her relationship with Edward, her class position, and how it is changed by their marriage. This sets up the meeting with Edward’s mother. At no point is there confusion about what occurs on a plot level.

I like the idea of building the story through paraphrase up until the climax of the story and then switching to scene, but it requires a very deft hand and a clear sense of how to set that scene as both culmination of and foil to the paraphrase that precedes it. The story is unable to achieve that delicate balance.

The pacing of the story is relatively strong throughout the paraphrase until the transition into the scene with the mother-in-law. That scene is rushed, but, more importantly the rapid temporal shift which follows it makes the pacing and the narrative as a whole feel unbalanced.

The language here, while often overwrought and frustrating, can, at other moments, be imaginative and exciting. For example, “She wore the title like a thief— not a particularly skilled or dedicated thief who practiced his wicked craft by night, but an incompetent thief who desperately wanted to belong elsewhere, so she slipped on a new garment in the dim light of a thrift store dressing room and hoped it would be enough to pretend her way into a different upbringing” or “…as if she were a trapeze artist perched delicately atop a precipice, teetering between two worlds that neither fully accepted nor rejected her.”

Though the story does offer Felicity some degree of emotional depth. Her class position is unpacked, at least to some extent, and the imagery suggests complexity. However, these suggestions are not ultimately followed through upon. The ending suggests the possibility of complexity, nuance, and existential uncertainty, but it is too brief to convince the reader.

As I said above, the story struggles in fulfilling the potential of its structure, which while interesting, in this form, ultimately feels rushed and lopsided in this form. It is possible that in a better version of itself, it would feel natural and exciting, but it is hard for a story like this to truly feel unpredictable given the tropes it employs.

There is a voice here which suggests a sense of a world beyond the story and a character who has lived outside the page. Unfortunately, that sense is often deflated by the overwrought language which undercut the reader’s sense of Felicity’s class position and the authenticity of her voice.

The story brushes up against some original ideas, especially in its language, and has enough uncertainty in that penultimate paragraph for me to believe in its thinking. It does lean on cliches and it does not overcome them, but this is still something here which feels original at the same time.

While there is something interesting about the paraphrase-to-scene structure, as I mentioned above, the story struggles to make this structure overcome the tropes and genre conventions the story follows.

Almost. The ending is nearly there. Though incredibly overwrought, the penultimate paragraph gives the story a hint of darkness and complexity: “Unbeknownst to her, the day at the Hampton's estate became a crystallized mark of her anguished journey, a memento of her inability to bridge the chasm that separated her from her past and her present. Both a symbol of her ceaselessly persistent desire for acceptance and an ever-present reminder of her unattainable dreams, it lay hidden within the intricate labyrinth of her soul – a secret tableau of her deepest fears and fervent hopes, interwoven like ivy around the columns of her gilded prison.” This unexpected downbeat ending is then rejected in the final paragraph, which forces the story to end on a moment of hope which does not feel earned.

There is very nearly a subtext here. For instance, I am grateful for the way the story allows the mother-in-law’s dialogue to mostly speak for itself, but even then it does not allow the implication to carry the pain the words cause Felicity. Still, a softer touch is needed.
The story relies on overwrought language in lieu of specific details.

Though it is not sophisticated, there is enough complexity implied in the imagery and in Felicity’s consideration of her class position for me to also accept and appreciate the deflation at the story’s ending, even if it isn’t ultimately effective or earned.

The ending is incredibly effective, it both ties directly into an image mentioned early in the story—the narrator’s husband’s interest in saving/repurposing trash—and uses that image and its connotations to show the narrator’s trajectory across the story.
Story follows a clear trajectory. The narrator is dexterous in moving into and out of memory and some of these shifts are exciting and strange, but never confusing.
I suppose I just said this above, but the story is largely masterful at its balance of scene and summary and the way it transitions between them and ties them together.

The story’s pacing is nearly perfect. It moves into and out of scene, memory, and paraphrase, easily and fluidly. It is especially effective at using punchy lines to reset the narrative flow. For instance, “Her son was, after all, his own man.”
The language is sparse and clear. The images are integrated smoothly into the prose by way of stories-within-stories and memories. All of it is impressive.

The story does an excellent job of balancing implication and outright statement, of showing and telling. It uses images effectively in this respect, and the doubling of mother and wife is also compelling and complicated.

The story moves in an exciting way between different narrative modes. Likewise, it maintains complexity as it proceeds, never getting caught in a particular mode or image, but also never leaving any behind. Each scene, paraphrase, builds into the next and often is returned to thematically.

The voice is clean and spare. The narrator is able to depict complicated feelings about motherhood and relationships without reducing them. She is also able to imply and indicate flaws in herself, as well as observe other characters and vocalize our understanding of her through them and them through her.
The story avoids cliches and tropes. Its characters are never allowed to be entirely archetypal.

The way the narrative moves between memory, past, present, scene, and paraphrase is deft, and the way it is able to draw on images from each of these modes and make them recur in satisfying and semi-surreal ways is exciting and inventive.
The story offers no easy answers but allows its reader to witness events and come to conclusions.

The use of repeated images allows the reader to bring meaning to the story instead of forcing it onto them. Likewise the story is good about letting dialogue breathe and allowing the narrator’s thoughts to be flawed, both of which also create a second layer to the narrative space.

Though the specific setting is elusive, it is largely unnecessary in a story like this—the details of the apartments and what the characters wear and how they interact with their environments, especially, creates a sense of a living world.

The story’s characters attempt to be good people, attempt to follow their value systems, even as they make mistakes. Miss Emily is no less fully developed than the narrator. They grow together even as they cannot accept each other.

The story tied up all previous narrative and emotional threads of the story, including "revealing" the narrator. We find out that Barbara had the child, her relationship with her family afterwards, and that she recently passed.

There was a clear beginning, middle, and end to the story that worked together cohesively. The beginning of the story featured Barbara at the service, the middle featured the gunman arriving, and the end featured the pull back to what happened after and the "reveal" of the narrator's relationship with Barbara.

It's a bit tricky -- the story is told as a fictional character telling the story, so there are moments where the story is summarized but it's done in relation to the narrator's focus and voice, which is part of the story. Overall, the effect seemed intentional.

There is a "flash forward" near the end to show Barbara in the "modern day," but it's done to illuminate the events of the story. The rest of the story goes in-depth on the shooting and feels like it happens in "real time.

The story makes use of these but not necessarily accurate use -- for example, fresh paint is compared to "vanilla," although I can't think of anybody who would actually say that paint smells anything like vanilla. Descriptors like "hair like a nest of copper wiring" and "both hands beneath her belly as if she were holding a large salad bowl" are more accurate while still evocative.

We get a clear sense of Barbara as well as the external events that are occurring around her. We know that she's bored because we hear the droning of the rabbi, we know that she's hungry because she's thinking about chewing on her neighbor's shoe, and even when the events are described (like the shooter's rant) we still get it filtered through Barbara's perspective. (We know that he's ranting, but not what he's saying.)

The reveal of the gunman was surprising and appropriate. There aren't really any other turns; we know that the story is being told by somebody who's not Barbara, and once the gunman is introduced it's certainly expected that he'd use the gun.

The story provided a convincing perspective, although it sounded like the author might perhaps be trying too hard to convey a stylized "voice" by addressing the reader. ("That’s Barbara in the third row from the back of the sanctuary, the one with the sunglasses holding up her tangle of orange hair, see her?") It doesn't work because aside from that first paragraph, the reader isn't addressed again, so it's inconsistent.

I wouldn't say that the piece is without any clichés, but it's truly difficult for anything to be wholly original from start to finish. I didn't think that clichés were a problem here -- but am answering the question asked. The very concept of a shooter entering a synagogue could be argued to be cliché, but that's because it happens not infrequently in real life.

The story is clearly trying to be original by giving the narrator a unique style and voice, as if the narrator is having a conversation with the reader. (I provided an example of this earlier.) However, the form is not consistently applied throughout the story.

Not really -- it's clearly meant to touch on themes of radicalism, racism, anti-Semitism, etc. but the story is too short and moves past things too quickly to get any real meaningful sense of anything. There is a touching moment near the end where it's revealed that Barbara fights to see the humanity in the shooter rather than just painting him as a monster, but the moment isn't given much weight or detail.

This is a little trickier -- the story does work on a subtext level, but it's surface-level subtext. As mentioned previously, the story is clearly trying to engage in multiple levels of subtext, but it never gets into great detail about any of it. So, I would say that the story does operate on multiple levels of meaning, but not necessarily that it does so well.

As mentioned previously, the writer clearly intended and put effort into engaging the reader's senses, but the sensory details provided (fresh paint smelling like vanilla) sometimes felt jarringly inaccurate. Or, for example, Barbara's hunger leading her to think about chewing on her pewmate's high-heeled shoe -- wouldn't she simply imagine something that she really wants to eat instead?

Barbara is really the only character who's developed -- but you're meant to see things solely through her perspective, and she has a limited focal point of the other characters, so it works. She speculates at the motivation and emotional state of the gunman, and we know that the narrator admires her, but we don't get any sense of who the narrator is aside from the fact that Barbara's story is important to them.

Rather than getting "tired of writing," the piece feels like the author won't shut up -- there are about three or four spots where it should have ended, and it got more and more repetitive and unrealistic the longer it went. One paragraph begins: "And so, as the years turned into centuries, the legend of Barbara Adler continued to inspire, guiding countless souls through their darkest hours, and reminding humanity of its capacity for resilience, compassion, and love." The next: "Her story became a part of the fabric of the community, woven into the collective memory of generations to come." One after that: "Her legacy reached far beyond the boundaries of the synagogue or the community she had once called home." Then the one after that: "And so, the story of Barbara Adler lived on, growing more vibrant and powerful with each passing generation.

The elements of the story made sense and felt cohesive. The beginning featured Barbara's attendance at the synagogue and the shooter, the middle featured her trying to make sense of the shooting, and the end discussed the ongoing legacy both of Barbara and the shooter.
There are both scenes and summaries present in the story. The "flash forwards" discussing Barbara's legacy at the end are definitely summaries, but the shooting itself is described as a scene.
The story flashes forward into the future too many times at the end. Please see the above answer for more details.
There weren't really any idioms, metaphors, or allusions present in the story. I'm not sure what more to say to expand upon that!

I'm not sure the story does this well, but the elements and attempted balance are present. The discussion about Barbara's legacy is, obviously, exterior, but we get good interiority during the shooting: "As Barbara pushed her way through the crowd, she found herself being swept away, carried by the surge of terrified bodies. Every shout, every cry, seemed distant, echoing in her ears as the world spun around her. She reached out, desperate to grasp onto anything that could anchor her back to reality, but found only empty space.

The story contains turns that are surprising -- that the rabbi was Barbara's husband, for example -- but that are not appropriate -- she refers only to the rabbi as "the rabbi" and not by name or "her husband," for example, and is surprised when she finds that her husband is not next to her when the shooting begins when it was previously established that the rabbi is at the front of the congregation.
The story is a pretty rote summary of events -- almost like a book report. (For examples, please see the "multiple endings" discussed above.)
The aphorisms discussed above about courage, tragedy, etc. are pretty cliché.
I'm not a huge fan of this question in this context -- the story is told chronologically, which isn't original, but this story *should* be told chronologically.

The story tries very hard to convey a unique and original idea -- that sometimes the bravery comes from processing and living beyond a traumatic event -- but the idea feels rushed and clichéd and hammered into us. ("As years passed, Barbara became a beacon of hope and resilience for those around her." "Barbara's story became a legend, whispered amongst the community as a reminder that strength and compassion can arise even in the darkest times." "Barbara Adler's legacy lived on, a testament to the power of resilience and the indomitable spirit of the human heart." " He spoke of the power of forgiveness and the strength of community that had allowed him to forge a path of peace amidst turmoil.")

Again -- the story does, technically, operate at a surface and subtext level, as described above with the multiple descriptions of Barbara's legacy. But, crucially, this question doesn't ask whether or not it does so well. (It does not.)
There wasn't a huge amount of detail, but there was some, and I found it appropriate. Please see above answer regarding Barbara's experience during the shooting.

Again, Barbara is pretty much the only character, so she's developed appropriately. As described above, we get a lot of detail -- perhaps too much! -- about how the events of the shooting changed her and what she decided to do afterwards.

The end of the story feels well-paced and cohesive with the rest of the story. It discussed how the community reacted after the shooting and Rabbi Adler's memory and legacy, particularly as it related to Barbara's child.

The elements of the story work together and it felt cohesive. The story begins with the sermon, the middle is the shooting itself, and then the end discusses the aftermath and how the community responded.
There are both scenes and summaries present in the manuscript. The shooting itself is described as a scene; the description of what happened after the shooting is more a summary.
There are no unreasonable jumps in the timeline, and the progression feels fairly balanced.
There were not really any idioms, metaphors, or allusions in the story. I'm not sure what more to say!

There is a good balance between interiority and exteriority, but the interiority isn't executed particularly well -- it feels like a writer who's learning about emotions for the first time. ("Barbara started weeping uncontrollably. She had known Rabbi Adler ever since she was a little girl, and was very close to him and his family. She couldn't believe that something like this would happen to such a kind, caring man. Her heart broke as she heard Mrs. Adler's cries of anguish upon seeing her husband's lifeless body.")
The gunman appearing and killing Rabbi Adler was surprising, and was appropriate as it was the inciting incident of the story.

The story is told solely from the point of view of Barbara, and there are not really any others present. However, Barbara's perspective is at times inconsistent. At one point, she bemoans the fact that she'll have to tell her husband about his newfound responsibilities at the synagogue; in the next paragraph, she's fuming that he's always on work trips and never at home.
The concept of facing tragedy but persevering anyway is a fairly cliché one -- and, as mentioned, we never really learn about any other takeaways that the story mentions.
The story progresses chronologically, which is appropriate but is not original.
There are no "takeaways" from this story. A lot of emphasis is placed on Rabbi Adler's teachings, values, and legacies, but the reader is never told what those are.
Not really -- "persevering in the face of hardship" is a fairly surface-level story, as discussed earlier.

The senses aren't remarkable, but they are invoked when describing the service. ("At eight and a half months pregnant, every movement was an effort. She eased into her usual seat in the middle of the sanctuary with a soft groan of relief.")
Barbara is really the only character developed, but she's developed somewhat inconsistently, as discussed in an earlier answer.

Technically, the ending could be justified as "intentionally abrupt" to startle the reader as much as it startles the characters, but that's stretching it. It ends with the rabbi's abrupt (magical?) disappearance and the young man's response to his prayer, with no motivation or reaction given.

This story was incredibly confusing -- characters appearing and disappearing out of nowhere, a bizarre ending that makes no sense. ("This young man, however, was accompanied by a great, mysterious beast, beautiful in its terrible symmetry as it gracefully sidled down the aisle next to the nonchalant newcomer... The object in the young man's hand was edged with cold, brown paper. As he stumbled through the frigid muck, reaching for the shadowy tendrils of hope, Rabbi Adler opened his mouth to sing the blessings – the blessings of the Torah, to sing "Blessed are the animals that guard the crops, that sing away the thorns." But he vanished with puffs of cold breath as the shivering young man raised his cold left hand.

The necessary background was given as summary. ("More often than not, Barbara found herself overwhelmed with anxiety and spent a considerable portion of January nestled in the soothing darkness of the synagogue, her breath casting a warm mist above the gently flickering taper candles of the shammes.") The story itself -- the events of the sermon and the appearance of the young man -- was told as a scene.
There wasn't really any compression of time here -- everything seemed to happen more or less in "real time.

The story makes sophisticated yet sometimes nonsensical use of idioms, metaphors, and allusion. I gather from earlier stories and context clues that the "great mysterious beast, terrible in its beautiful symmetry" and "the object edged in cold, brown paper" refer to some kind of gun or weapon.

There is an appropriate balance between external descriptors ("As she eased herself onto the chair, Barbara's expansive belly rubbed against the trapezoidal seat back.") and a sense of Barbara's interior emotions, though often nonsensical. ("Barbara opened the shutters in her mind...

The turns are surprising but nonsensical -- it is absolutely unclear who the newcomer is and what he's doing there, as described above. It's certainly surprising that the rabbi disappears in a puff of smoke!

The only perspective in the story is, really, Barbara's, and she's portrayed accurately. ("Distinctly unsettled by the newcomer, Barbara felt the prickling cold sweat of instinct race down her spine," etc.)
There are certainly clichés present throughout -- the rabbi is, for example, "a forward-thinking individual hailing from the bustling metropolis of New York City.
The story is told chronologically, which is appropriate. I suppose the magical mystery surrounding the young man's appearance could be described as genre hybridity, if you wanted to be generous?
The story is too confusing to obtain any ideas from it, and no themes are explicitly presented as in other examples.
As discussed in earlier answers, the story is fairly surface-level and doesn't engage any deeper than that.

The writer attempts to make the fictional world believable at the sensory level, but the details are nonsensical -- details like "fixing a madeleine cookie to the clasp of a tight necklace" or "pressing a heavy invisible hand over her quickened breath.

The only character that's developed is Barbara, but it's done appropriately -- there's really not much development needed in this current iteration of the story, as she's only reacting to the events of the story and we don't get a sense of her after. So, there's no development -- but that's appropriate within the framework of the story. (If disappointing.)

The ending is movingly complex and rendered with a mix of resolution and unresolve that feels deeply human. We learn, or have confirmed, Barbara's feelings towards her husband. Her character as a human being is illustrated in a moment of obstinate and oppositional cultural defiance when she speaks in defense of the synagogue murderer. We are left with a clear understanding of both the narrator's affection and appreciation for Barbara, a type of role model, and for the type of woman Barbara bravely was in the context of her time and culture.

This essay is wonderfully constructed. Every element, from the epistolary form of address, to the movement from present to past tense, works together seamlessly. Barbara is a vivid, complex, and well-rendered character whose actions would be confounding to witness, but because of the access the narrator gives us to her history and thoughts, make surprising, illuminating sense. There is no narrative fat in this essay.

The use of present tense and epistolary address is highly effective in the scenes set in the synagogue, creating an appropriate immediacy for a moment of startling violence and an unusual reaction to that violence. We feel Barbara's alienation and boredom in those scenes. The dip into Barbara's recollections of her husband's bigoted and dismissive behavior is appropriately summary and brief. When we are in scene it is appropriately so, and when we move into a more distant, summary use of time it is likewise appropriate, providing context for the scenes that illuminates and adds to the reader's understanding of the text.

When we are introduced to Barbara she is in synagogue feeling checked out, a mood that is appropriately mirrored in the amount of time/text expended conveying it. When the startling act of violence occurs, it happens with appropriately abrupt, brief, narrative precision. When the narrator moves to put this event and Barbara into deeper context, it is done with a satisfying efficiency and economy of language.

The metaphorical language in this piece is fantastic. Examples: hair like a nest of copper wiring, hands beneath her belly as if she were holding a large salad bowl, the rabbi's words like shapes...raining from the skylights like fat drops of light, porcupine hair, unworldly silence that still coats stories of that morning.

This piece is outstanding in its ability to convey Barbara's complex interiority as well as how who she is as a person manifests through her actions. She is an obviously pregnant woman who decides to move against the crowd of people fleeing a gunman, even laughing at the dentists, chiropractors, and podiatrists calling out that they are doctors.

Because we are treated to such an intimate and well-rendered view of Barbara's thoughts and mood early on, her surprising actions later make total sense to the reader even as they upset the other characters in the text. Most people would expect a pregnant woman to appreciate being steered away from violence, but Barbara resists - and the reader roots for her in that moment. When she speaks up for the murderer at a family event later, it satisfies the reader's desire for Barbara to become a fully actualized woman, freed from the constraints placed on her by Howard and society..

Barbara herself is a complex, dynamic character whose actions confound the other characters in the text, but are lovingly rendered to the reader. The writer is able to render Howard, an unappealing man, with admirable economy. He is barely present in the text, and yet I could practically hear his voice as I read his words.

The ideas in this piece are unique, and expressed with original language. The metaphorical language referenced above is a list of good examples. Others include the moment when she slides her sunglasses down and everything goes darker; Rabbi Adler's monotonous drone rendered as--son...his...own...flesh; Barbara rocking like the overloaded boat she's become. This piece is practically bursting with new, exciting ways of expressing familiar things.

The piece as a whole is exciting in its use of structure and form. The reader is directly addressed throughout, an unusual and interesting move. Most of the essay is written as though in third person, but at the end the narrator inserts herself (I infer the writer is a she) into the narrative with the I-pronoun. The overall effect is a triumphant and coherent mix of the 2nd, 3rd, and 1st-preson perspectives

Barbara is a complex woman positioned in a highly specific way. She is a mother, a wife, a rebel, and a dissatisfied original thinker chafing under the constraints being inflicted on her from without. She expresses ideas that many would/will find morally repugnant, but because this is conveyed in a sophisticated manner, the reader gains insight into what might cause a woman like her to think and do the things she does. I will be thinking about Barbara for a long time after reading this piece, and perhaps even wondering, "what would Barbara do?" in moments where perceived truth must be spoken to power.

The reader infers unstated things about Barbara through her actions in this piece. Likewise, we gain a subtextual understanding of the narrator through her appreciation of Barbara, seemingly a woman bravely ahead of her time. Why was Barbara the narrator's favorite aunt?  Why would the narrator like to report that Barbara dumped Howard and moved to California or Morocco? The reader infers that the things that made Barbara different from all the other women in the narrator's life made her an inspirational figure. From this we gain a slim, but meaningful insight into the narrator's own life, constraints, and desires. This is an excellent essay.

Again, the precision and idiosyncratic language of this piece demands appreciation. The fresh paint of the synagogue smelling like vanilla, its triangular roof jutting  across the freeway like an airplane, the tactile sensation conveyed when Barbara's pregnant belly rests against the back of the chair in front of her as she leans forward. It is absolutely believable on a sensory level.

Barbara is fully formed from beginning to end. We understand her depth in the opening paragraph, a sensation that only increases as we witness her actualization of her internal state externally (by doing the opposite of whatever one else is doing and by vocalizing her own opinions later even though she must know they would be poorly received) as a result of the assassination of Rabbi Adler.

The ending relies on an impact that it does not make sense for Barbara to have had, or at least the mechanism for it is glossed over. WE are told that she became an advocate for peace, but the form of that advocacy and why it was so impactful is unexplained. Additionally, the essay repeatedly attempts to end several times, each time building on itself in superficial ways using similar language: As the years passed, Barbara became a beacon of hope (how?); In the decades that followed, Barbara's story became a legend (why?); As the world continued to grapple...Barbara Adler's legacy lived on; Years later, (Barbara's unnamed son) grew up to become a remarkable individual...an advocate for peace...carrying his mother's story with him; Generations passed, and each one carried forward the tale of Barbara Adler... I count 16 attempted endings in this format.

The overall narrative is confusing both logically and in terms of human nature. The death of Rabbi Adler seems to have no meaningful effect on his pregnant widow, Barbara Adler. I do not know why she went towards the shooter, or what caused her to lose consciousness when she did.
