Rabbi Adler seems to have been shot at the front of the synagogue, but then Barbara reaches for him as though he were seated near her, then she moves forward to confront the gunman to prevent further tragedy, but also maybe her husband, who was already shot? The essay then asserts an impact and renown of Barbara's actions that seem totally out of proportion to what she did, which appears to have been a trite internal realization that carrying on after a tragedy is an act of strength. It is unclear how raising her child was received as an act of forgiveness for her husband's murderer, or what form her advocacy took, or why it turned her into a legend.

The time spent in scene at the synagogue is conveyed in a simple, this-happened-then-that-happened manner that approaches summary. The expositional details that follow stretch credulity and evade the necessary narrative work of putting the information in scene.

The events of this essay are treated in a summary, superficial mode that does not adjust story time effectively. When the story moves from moments in scene at the synagogue (which are conveyed in an oddly removed fashion) to even more distant, summary expository descriptions of what happened afterwards, it is done with a lack of regard for those later actions. We are told that Barbara had a remarkable and accomplished life, but achieving such a life must logically involve many moments of tension and drama that are absent from the text.
The essay is littered with overly-familiar figurative language. Words wash over Barbara, her eyes snap open, people stampede. There are few if any metaphors.

There is almost no interiority in this piece. While we do learn some of Barbara's thoughts, they are asserted to us in a summary manner by the narrator, and they do not feel like the thoughts or feelings that a real person would have in those circumstances.

The plot twists, which is to say, Barbara's actions once the shooting happens, are more confusing than surprising or appropriate. What comes after that - Barbara becoming a legendary advocate for peace - stretches credulity.

There is no dialogue in this essay, and little to no opportunity for diverse perspectives to be presented. We know only of Barbara's actions and her decision to honor her husband by...raising their child? The characters in this essay are simplistically rendered and, other than the gunman, uniformly virtuous to a degree that does not reflect real life.

As indicated above, the piece relies on cliched turns of phrase to express actions and thoughts. Reality hits Barbara like a tidal wave; days turn to weeks (and weeks?) and months; she uses her experience to "bridge divides" and "heal wounds.

As mentioned above, the language of this piece is rife with overly-familiar phrasings (Words wash over Barbara, her eyes snap open, people stampede). more examples include: this evening would change her life forever, chaos erupted, her gaze was fixed, her maternal instincts kicked in, she became a beacon of hope, etc. These are ways of conveying this information that involve little to no work on the part of the author, because they are common usage. The plot, while unconvincing, moves in a straightforward and simplistic fashion towards a pat happy ending that does not reflect the behavior of real human beings. The one deviation from this is the repeated attempts at an ending, which must be unintentional.
This essay depicts characters who do not behave in a meaningfully human way. The ideas that it expresses - that forgiveness, courage, community, and peace are good things - are superficial.
I cannot identify subtext in this essay. Its events and actions are presented in a removed, simplistic, and superficial manner.
The few sensory details in this piece are simple and superficial: a bitterly cold evening, a loud noise shattering the tranquility.

Barbara Adler is not a believable character, because her thoughts and actions are confusing and context-less. Her inner change is asserted rather than shown, and does not seem realistic. The secondary and tertiary characters are flat and devoid of personality and depth.

The story seems to be about Barbara, but switches focus in the conclusion to the effect of Rabbi Adler's death on the community as a whole. He is initially presented to us as a righteous man of profoundly positive community impact, which is effectively reiterated in the final paragraph; he/his reputation is the same at the end as it was in the beginning, though of course his loss is presented as a tragedy. In a broad sense, Barbara and the congregation can be seen to have experienced narrative change in the sense that they go from a place of mourning to one of hope for the future. However, this change comes about through superficial mechanisms (the birth and naming of a child, the finding of a new rabbi who happens to be a woman).

The story follows Barbara's experience of witnessing the assassination of Rabbi Adler and her resulting grief, but seems to prioritize reiterating Rabbi Adler's importance to Barbara and his community impact over her growth as a character and person. Her husband dips in and out of the narrative to no meaningful effect. The story seems undecided as to whether Rabbi Adler could never be replaced, or if the congregation would find solace and purpose in replacing him with a woman. Threads like Barbara agonizing over her husband needing to lead the congregation in Rabbi Adler's absence are dropped, then seemingly contradicted by what happens later (a new rabbi).

This is a close call, but the piece does give a relatively balanced amount of scene and summary. Though I feel the turn to exclusively summary exposition in the final two paragraphs is executed ineffectively, it is a conventional writing move.

The use of time in this piece is vague and confusing. Barbara's husband is away on business in one paragraph, at the hospital in the next, then away on business again two paragraphs later, and it is unclear how much time has passed throughout. Without her husband's arrival, actions, and disappearance, I would have read this section as though Barbara had been in the hospital for a day, perhaps two.
There is little to no figurative language in this piece, other than common phrasings like "her heart broke." Its facts and events are recounted in mostly literal declarative sentences.

While the essay does move from exteriority to Barbara's interiority and back, it does so in a vague, superficial manner. Barbara's thoughts are repetitive and and so focused on what Rabbi Adler's loss would mean to the community that it is easy to forget that she is a woman who is giving birth after having just witnessed a murder. It doesn't track on an emotional level.

There are few turns in this essay. The one moment of interesting surprise is the congregation's choice of a woman for rabbi. However, this event is conveyed through a single mention and what lead to that choice, its effects, and how it occurred are elided completely.

Barbara is the only character into whom the reader is given any degree of insight, and she is a flat, static character whose thoughts and actions are ordinary and predictable. The other characters are barely present.
While the piece avoids overused expressions, its ideas and themes are hackneyed.

The essay proceeds in a conventional, step-by-step manner. The language is simple and expository, relying on pat phrasings to tell, rather than imply or show, what happened. For example: "Barbara brought baby Amos to synagogue for the first time to meet the new rabbi, a woman, symbolizing hope for a new generation." That final clause is typical of the language in this essay, in which the reader is simply told what happens and what meaning to make of it.
The ideas in this piece are simple and predictable. It expresses nearly universal values - that forgiveness, strength, community, and progress are good - in a conventional manner.
There is little to no subtext in this piece. It is conveyed through surface-level declarations of event, consequence, next event.

There is insufficient sensory detail in this piece for its fictional world to feel real. I know that the synagogue was cold on the day Rabbi Adler was murdered, but cannot find anything else to tell me what it looked, smelled, or felt like. Similarly, the hospital environment is completely undescribed. The physical world of this piece almost doesn't exist.

The only real character of this piece is Barbara, and she is handled in a superficial manner. The other characters are simply mentioned, and in the case of her husband, confusingly rendered. His decision to go on a business trip while his wife is hospitalized, about to give birth and having just witnessed a murder, would seem heartless if I didn't read it a lack of care given to tracking his actions and whereabouts.
This piece abruptly ends at what narratively seems to be its climax, the aftermath of which is not resolved or explored in any way. I am unclear as to what actually happens at the end.

This piece seems to shift focus with almost every paragraph. Numerous characters are introduced, then dropped, their presence seeming arbitrary and distracting. It is difficult to track them all - for example, we are told that the synagogue has a new, progressive rabbi, and are then introduced to a Rabbi Adler and a Rabbi Ben-Gurion. But it is unclear which is the new rabbi, or if perhaps they are even the same character? At the same time we are introduced to an Isaac Adler, who appears to be a young child. The story is full of confusing details ("this young man...was accompanied by a great, mysterious beast, beautiful in its terrible symmetry"). I cannot make sense of its ending, in which Rabbi Adler vanishes with puffs of cold breath as the mysterious young man chants what I assume is a religious verse while raising his hand that (maybe?) holds a gun. I do not understand what actually happens in this piece, which seems to end at an arbitrary point.
As this story effectively takes place within one long, confusing scene, there is no balance to be struck with exposition or summary.
The essay takes place entirely during the Saturday bat mitzvah recitals attended by Barbara. there is no meaningful manipulation of time that I can identify.

There is limited metaphorical language in this piece, and that language is confusing - Barbara can't wait until "any day now" would be added to her name (?), like "fixing a madeleine cookie to the clasp of a tight necklace." I do not understand that metaphor.

While there is an interesting moment in which Barbara closes her eyes and pictures various aspects of her home (?) and Detroit, it is unclear why this happens or what it means. This piece lacks coherence overall.
This story contains turns, but they are not appropriate. I am confused as to what actually happens, the sprawling cast of characters, and what is being articulated.

The characters in this piece are uniformly flat and border on caricature. Their religion and culture seem to be the only traits that they have, other than Mrs. Levine's tendency to gossip, which feels like a stereotype.

The characters in this piece are so defined by their religion and culture as to be flattened by stereotype. The events of this piece feel arbitrary, almost random. While that does grant it an unpredictability and a vague form of originality, it feels thoughtless.

While there are numerous examples of unconventional language in this piece, they are mostly strange and confusing: Barbara's "fragrant ear," Mrs. Levine's "spindly hand turning unnaturally white and cold," a vague "threatening pocket of inky darkness" reaching for Barbara with its "chilling, spiking tendrils.
This piece lacks narrative logic sufficient for its readers to obtain a unique and original idea. I am unsure what happened in this piece and why.
This piece is too difficult to understand for multiple levels of meaning to operate. I do not understand it on a fundamental level.

While many of the details of this piece are confusing, some of them make enough sense that its physical world is perceptible. The ornate filigree frame of Rabbi Adler's portrait, Barbara's breath casting a warm mist above the gently flickering taper candles, the stirring gray steel and billowing turbines of the town's (schmatta?) factory.
Every character in this piece is flat. Many of them are difficult to distinguish from others.

Yes, and WHAT an ending this is! The return to the rhetorical questions of the beginning here at the end is pitch-perfect, and frame the story beautifully without feeling contrived. When I read that final sentence--"Who would know, or care, that a pregnant relative of mine stood in the parking lot that morning and half wished she were carrying a martyr’s baby?"--it actually took my breath away for a moment. WHAT A WAY TO END THIS STORY. We're prepared as readers for the ending narratively but not emotionally; it's brilliant.

Yes, this is an excellently crafted story. The beginning, middle, and ending feel both unexpected as they come but also somehow inevitable. This is a hard balance to achieve, but the writer does so here with considerable grace.

YES. This is just so delightfully done! The story stays pretty solidly in scene, and because the scenes are so expertly crafted, this is a real strength. One particularly superb moment is, "Moments later, when the young man abruptly stops and swings around and says, 'Rabbi,' before shooting Rabbi Adler once in the arm and then again in the left side of the head, and then holds the barrel up to his own forehead and fires, Barbara is, again, bewildered." The author keeps this in the context of the scene, and uses Barbara as a means to both advance the plot and show us the stakes of the situation on a personal level.

Yes, and I'd argue this is one of THE most successful parts of a VERY successful story. Even small moments such as "and, for no reason she’ll be able to explain later," set the reader up to be kept somewhat off-balance by something that's looming. The focus on Barbara, the creep forward of the service, the details all point us toward the fact that something is unsettled and that the story is counting down to something--and then the way that the author uses punctuation to slow us down as we get to the climactic moment? DYNAMITE:

"Barbara is too far away to see what’s in his hand, and after he fires a single shot into the ceiling the sound is so alien to the space, so incomprehensible, that it takes Barbara a moment to start to register what has just happened, and even then she isn’t sure, in the jittery quiet that follows, exactly what’s going on." The interrupted syntax here is so purposeful and excellent.

Yes; my comments here are perhaps more related to vernacular and voice, but the narrator here feels exceedingly believable for the way they build up the scene through conversational diction. I suppose it's less an matter of idiom here, but I feel like this is the best place to comment on this strength. The metaphors here are also darn near perfect--sparse, and therefore meaningful when they come. I particularly love these for how much they evoke for the reader: "the triangular point of the roof inspires as it juts out across the freeway like a plane taking off" and "she rocks like the overloaded boat she’s become.

Yes, the familiarity with which the speaker talks about Barbara is crucial here, and we're able to get into Barbara's interior reactions without having Barbara as our narrator. This casts an interesting light on the narrator--one who is so intimately familiar as to feel capable of getting into another's emotions and able to do so while making it feel so believable.

Yes; this story is the most well handled I've read in a good long while when it comes to incorporating surprising turns in believable and seamless ways. This feels like true life: even as we know *something* is going to happen because of the way the story is constructed up until this point, the *what* is unknown until the very moment it happens--and that feels right and true for a story set in the world we all know.

Yes, this is also a real treat of the story. Barbara's complicated reaction to the "young boy," combined with the closeness we find late in the story between Barbara and a character who is a second cousin (I think that's second-cousin territory?), rounds out different perspectives here and challenges our beliefs about what a character stands for and our expectations about people more broadly. This is really dynamically done.

Yes--there's nothing here that struck me as cliche in the writing. The only cliche I noticed was "She was my mother’s favorite cousin, Barbara, a woman who, my mother says, always danced to her own beat," and because this is put into the mouth of the mother, it feels appropriate and believable, since characters can get away with a lot that narrators cannot.

Yes, here again, the story is an example to be followed when it comes to form and structure. A less compelling story would've maybe told us the who of our narrator at the beginning, which could be seen to lend credibility and authority to the narrator as one closely connected with Barbara. But waiting until all of the story's action has passed--until the third-to-last paragraph!--to reveal the narrator's connection gives even more importance to the "why" here, to the story's kairotic moment of the story's telling. Brilliant.

Yes, a thousand times yes. The revelation at the end is so weird and complicated, and it makes us go right back into the story (starting, ideally, with the story's title, which of course is absent here but wouldn't be for a regular reading situation), which is, of course, what a good story should drive the reader to do. The story subverts our expectations at nearly every point, and we're so much better for it.

Yes; gosh, this is great here. The surface is rich, and could almost even be enough, but of course, it wouldn't really be; the author's use of description--where the narrator puts Barbara's attention in the synagogue scene, and the way the story unfolds from the moment of the shooting--makes a satisfying and engaging subtext. I especially was wowed by the building of subtext here: "The force of the crowd trying to get out was too strong, and she was thrust into the parking lot and the thick, unworldly silence that still coats stories of that sunny February morning, even as car doors slammed and engines rasped to life and distant sirens moved closer.

Yes, this is a world that feels not only believable but one that we actually FEEL. Part of the beauty here is that we're not hit over the head with piled-on descriptions; they're given to us across the space of the story, so that the reader feels like the goal (or, at least, a central goal) is to communicate (rather than to impress us with lots of descriptions or something). This is precisely the way it should be!

Yes--these characters are really notable and full; even the murdering young man feels human in Barbara's/the narrator's gaze. And I love the inclusion of the narrator's feelings in this statement: "I’d like to report that she dumped Howard and split to California or Morocco, the kid in tow. A free spirit, my mother’s favorite cousin Barbara, but not too much of one." It's so carefully done and smart.

No, this ending suffers and fails before it even gets started, I'm afraid. The author keeps making "to-go noises" (signals that the story is wrapping up) for PARAGRAPHS before the story actually, finally, mercifully ends. The last...17?? paragraphs show this, filled with explanatory, conclusionary, clumsy transitionary phrases such as "And it was through these stories that Barbara came to realize," "Years later," "Generations passed," and "And so, the story of Barbara Adler lived on.

No, this one is pretty tough. The story fails on this criterion in large part because there doesn't seem to be an awareness on the part of the writer of how to create believable tension in a story yet. The "before time" leading up to the shooting is unremarkable and cliche, and the "after time" (or, during and after the shooting) is drawn out and tedious.

No; even the scenes are un-scenic because, for instance, the synagogue scene (the only real scene in the story) feels summarized and plodding. Everything here, scenes included, is too explanatory to feel satisfying. We're not shown anything of importance, but instead constantly TOLD by the reader why or what is supposedly important. The quickest way to get a reader to not trust the narrator is to have the narrator insist that they can be trusted--and all of these grand statements do just that.

No, this story seems to drag on endlessly; moments that could be big in a well-written story (e.g., the shooting itself, the birth of Barbara's child) are here reduced to feeling like a plot point in an outline of a story, rather than something that feels believably tense and important. This is also partly the problem of those weird transitionary phrases I mentioned above; we're actually supposed to believe that the story of this woman, which I'm afraid here is super forgettable, inspired people for not only years but "centuries [...] guiding countless souls through their darkest hours, and reminding humanity of its capacity for resilience, compassion, and love"? I don't believe it for a second, I'm afraid. Those entire 17 "ending" paragraphs are clumsily expansive in terms of time compression and thin on details of why anyone would actually remember her story. It's as if the narrator doth protest too much here, insisting that "no, really! Barbara's story was super inspiring!" Insert eyeroll here.

No; the idioms used here are in the narrator's exposition and descriptions of characters or scenes mostly, which undermines the narrator as, in some ways, reliable. This feels like a narrator with an agenda--which can work SUPER well and produce a compelling story, but the agenda here seems to be to "wash out" the entire scene and story, with too much focus on making tragedy palatable. This feels false and unsatisfying.
No, here we get very little by way of actual scene, and the stabs at interiority feel like B-rate Hallmark cards rather than actual thoughts, feelings, and subjective experiences of a real human.

No; I can scarcely think of a less surprising phrase than "Suddenly, a loud noise shattered the tranquility." The joke about "suddenly" is that it's, sonically, the opposite of sudden: it's multisyllabic, ends in a weak "-ly," and is a word that feels only reserved for the calm, un-sudden act of safe storytelling. That's not the whole issue here, but the turns in general suffer from clumsy, safe writing, and as a result, we don't feel any sense of tension or dread here.

No, there's not much here by way of diverse perspectives. I guess if we're being generous, we could say that Barbara's empathy for the shooter "counts" as diverse since she has compassion and understanding when few others might, but there's not enough nuance to the characters or situations to make them convincing or accurate.

No, and I know I've belabored this point enough in this feedback so far, so I'll just add a few of the worst offenders here: "letting the familiar words wash over her," "sending shockwaves through the hearts of the worshippers," and "heart pounded in her chest." Again, if cliches come to us through characters, that can build believability,  but when it comes from the narrator--especially one as omniscient and undefined as this one--it seems clear it's a writing problem.

No, the narrative progression here is pretty underwhelming. I feel like the writer is bogged down in cloddish phrases that work against storytelling in general, as when the narrator says, "But little did Barbara know that this evening would be different. This evening would change her life forever." Ewww. I already don't trust it; between the cliches and the boring way it's laid out, this feels like the early ideas of a story rather than a story itself.

No, here again, the story stalls out at the level of cliche and empty statements: "Barbara struggled to make sense of the incident." "But in the midst of her grief and confusion, Barbara found solace in the support of her community. They rallied around her, offering comfort and understanding. One by one, they shared their own stories of resilience, of surviving through unimaginable tragedy." This doesn't strike me as anything even remotely related to the experience of trauma and its aftermath, and the narrator works against any sense of importance in the story by using so many cliches.

No, there's not a subtext to be had here, I'm afraid. The surface level action and descriptions themselves are boring, ill-defined, and hazy, and anything that could be subtextual is dragged out into the light with cliches and clumsy explanatory statements.

No; this is in large part due to the at-odds-ness of what's being said and how it's being described (the "suddenly" problem from earlier). A phrase like "In that moment, chaos erupted" is too controlled to feel chaotic. And then we're supposed to believe that Barbara looks up and sees the shooter "holding a smoking gun"? And then, the overwrought description that "The young man's eyes met hers for a fleeting moment, and she saw a flicker of recognition in them." Un-be-lievable. Nope nope nope. This is the stuff of TV drama, not of real life.

No, there's very little attention paid to character here, funnily enough since the character of Barbara is obviously the focus of the story. But she feels hazy and underdeveloped, and the only other notable characters are the young man (stereotype of Emotionally Disturbed Shooter) and the son (who is devoid of qualities entirely).

No; although the story seems to be trying for this, it's too explanatory of an ending to feel natural and earned. Even the start of that final paragraph, "As life was celebrated, Rabbi Adler was remembered" feels hedgy and awkward because of the use of the passive voice.

No, this story, although infinitely understandable, follows *too* logical a path to be satisfying. The themes of the story are made too explicit and overt, and the story feels like it's only written to show us a moral--which is fine for fables but not good for stories.

No, this doesn't work for me as a reader, though I appreciate the attention in places to description. This writing shows the signs of a fairly unpracticed writer who knows that sensory details help to build scene, but can't quite follow through in making scenes yet. There's a LOT of exposition here with little pay-off in the scene category.

No. The story starts off with promise here but quickly falls into the trap of explaining rather than showing us anything real, and the way time is handled here feels impatient, like the writer is just trying to get to the moral of the story and be done with it.
No, any metaphors here feel overdone, and there's not much sophisticated use of idiom or allusion here.

No, and the story falls apart largely here due to the mistaking of stating feelings as interiority; we can be told how characters feels without actually having anything revealed about the character's inner life. A few moments from the story that would seem to show this misunderstanding on the part of the writer: "She couldn't help feeling grateful to her rabbi, who had already guided her through so many important life events, including her wedding and her bat mitzvah." (This is explained feeling, not felt feeling.) 

"She couldn't believe that something like this would happen to such a kind, caring man. Her heart broke as she heard Mrs. Adler's cries of anguish upon seeing her husband's lifeless body." (The cliches here work against any emotional center, and descriptions like "kind, caring man" feel like performative eulogy rather than actual feeling.)

No; although the turns here aren't terribly handled, I can't say that they feel appropriate and surprising. We know from the very beginning that something bad will happen by the inclusion of a super pregnant woman and the stab at tension created by "that cold February morning," and then once the shooting starts and so much focus is placed on Barbara as Pregnant Woman here, it's no surprise when there's potential impacts to the pregnancy and baby here.

No, there isn't really much that's a diverse perspective here. We do get the shooter, of course, but he's undeveloped (which makes sense given the POV of the story) and calling him "the assailant" puts even greater distance between us and understanding of him. (I'm not saying he deserves or doesn't deserve understanding here--just that the story isn't written in a way to extend that to him as a character).

No, I'd say the story does pretty well not falling into language cliches too terribly, but the whole moral of the story is a cliche, and it's not interestingly written enough to mitigate this. Of course, as...someone said, there are only 7 basic story plots in the world, and persistent themes are persistent for a reason, so this alone isn't enough to disqualify a story from being original. However, this story seems only vaguely concerned with the reader's experience and is overfocused on presenting cliche ideas as meaningful.

No, the story doesn't offer much by way of fresh experience for the reader here. The structure and form are predictable, and I'd argue there's too much emphasis placed on getting to the story's Big Ideas about Loss and Resilience and not enough on creating an experience for the reader.

No, afraid not. I do appreciate that the writer here is trying to craft a story about resilience, etc., but there's too much focus on making sure the reader Gets the Importance, and not enough on actually creating the scenes and progression that would let us understand that importance. An example of this follows, where we hear the narrator keep "interrupting" the narrative to explain Barbara's feelings (rather than showing us how she feels): "Lying in the hospital bed that night, she agonized over how to break the terrible news to her husband that now he would have to lead the congregation in prayers and handle administrative responsibilities in Rabbi Adler's absence." [We're told there's agonizing but it feels very calm and easy.] "She felt bereft without his comfort, uncertain of how they would cope with such a tremendous loss." [No bereftment to be had here, just statements that she is bereft. Boo.]

No, this story had promise in this regard, but ultimately fails to contain meaningful subtext. There's too much didactic rambling here to allow for subtext, although there are moments of real engagements on the surface level.

Yes, I think the story actually does pretty well in this regard. These moments are passing and small, but descriptions such as "filled with murmurs of prayer and the rustling of coats" and a detail like "At first she thought it might be the heating system acting up again" show that the writer is intent on making this feel like something more than an idea. I don't think it's doing all it could yet, but that's why writing is a process and not just a product.

No, this doesn't quite work here, but it's trying! Barbara is the closest to a believable character, but the husband is just a plot point, and honestly, so are the shooter and Rabbi Adler. These are empty vessels for the writer to pour the Important Feelings into, and as a result, they feel lackluster and mechanical overall.

No. I'm a pretty careful reader, and I have read a fair number of texts, and I have never seen anything that prepares me for this ending. It's like some kind of surrealist nonsense: "The object in the young man's hand was edged with cold, brown paper. As he stumbled through the frigid muck, reaching for the shadowy tendrils of hope, Rabbi Adler opened his mouth to sing the blessings – the blessings of the Torah, to sing 'Blessed are the animals that guard the crops, that sing away the thorns.' The frigid muck? Why all the mystery with the thing in the paper? Why is any of this happening?  

"But he vanished with puffs of cold breath as the shivering young man raised his cold left hand and chanted, 'Blessed are the bees and corn-cobs, the rain and the burning leaves, blessed are the righteous men who are righteous no more.'" That final phrase could be subtext or foreshadowing or something, but then the story ends, and it's led into with such nonsense that it's utter rubbish.

No, I'm afraid this story is pretty much nonsense. It was honestly difficult to get through, and at times it read as a spoof of Judaism (seriously, Larry works at "the schmatta factory downtown"? Ugh.), which is honestly just uncomfortable. Some of the most gibberish-y parts:

"If it were a boy, at this late stage and with her first grandchild expected in less than a year, the silver mugs would clang in anticipation, her youngest sister would be whispering softly in her fragrant ear that she must hurry up and return to her marital duties." This makes zero sense.

"Larry and his colleagues were known to indulge in enticingly long, smoky lunches at inviting locales such as the cool taverns and warmer, intimate bed-chambers of Nina's Bar and Grill." What the devil is going on here?

No, there's not any insight here, when it comes to scene versus summary or anything else here. Sentences like, "She was just a few weeks away from that revered moment when the affectionate term 'any day now' would be added to her name, much like fixing a madeleine cookie to the clasp of a tight necklace" would derail even the best story, and this is obviously not the best story. I wanted to stop reading at pretty much every turn.

No. The compression and/or stretching of time seems capricious. There are times when the story slows down--the part with the congregants and gossip, for instance--but it's for no particular gain to the story.

No, sadly not. There are metaphors here, and some idioms, but they don't *mean* anything; phrases like "navigating the soup-can of her swollen body" and "Rabbi Adler, his eyes like lingering dark pens marking the engaged crowd," do nothing but confuse; they're technically metaphors but don't do what metaphors should do, which is deepen our understanding of something--characters, situations, themes, subtext, etc.

No; the absurdity here doesn't feel purposeful, and there's nothing that we can trust that this narrator says, so even if there were interior life revealed or exterior moments of importance, it'd be hard to treat this as anything but meaningless.
No--I have very little understanding of what's happening here at any point, so even if there were a turn to be had, I don't think I'd be able to find it due to the piling-on of complete inanity.
No; there aren't diverse perspectives to be had here; in fact, there's very little perspective of any kind offered that feels like something from real life.

Yes? As much as I hate to praise literally anything about this gobbledegook, I would say that it's free from cliches. But, at least while we're here, we can point to one of the portions that's most offensively word salad: "Sam Katz, the pockmarked, deeply polished cantor with his vital annual salary carefully braided in intricate plaits that his thick fingers dipped and plucked – confidently strode through the synagogue with a beautifully plated Yad, shaking the rough, strong hands of the vodka salesmen he passed. It was whispered that Sam was due for a well-earned pension.
No; there's nothing original here about its form or structure, or the language, or the plot, or the format. Or maybe there is? But nothing makes enough sense of find any kind of through-line.
No, definitely not. There's a lot that's never been seen before, to be sure, but nothing that holds together with other parts of the story.

No, there's not even surface to be had here, let alone subtext. The surface only keeps the reader engaged in a train-wreck sort of way, and there's nothing built up to allow for subtext to be present.

No, there's nothing about the story that'd make me think it's believable. For instance, the narrator says that Barbara was "considered the best friend to each and every one of [the synagogue's] vibrant members." This strains credulity, to say the least. 

And then there's this, which is surreal, at best (and therefore outside of the rest of the piece), but that's giving the writing too much credit: "This young man, however, was accompanied by a great, mysterious beast, beautiful in its terrible symmetry as it gracefully sidled down the aisle next to the nonchalant newcomer. There was something unusual about this newcomer, something that caught the watchful eye of Sam Katz." Even if this was a real sight that people saw, it seems impossible to believe that a) it'd be described as vaguely as this, and b) that it'd take the "watchful eye of Sam Katz" to notice there was "something unusual about this newcomer." Could that unnameable, unusual something possibly be the "great, mysterious beast" next to him??? Woof.

No, these are not even real enough to be characters. The portrait on the wall of Rabbi Adler feels as real as any of these characters do. I can't believe that Larry would "lovingly [call] her 'the leaning Tower of Pisa'"--because this makes, um, no sense--though Larry calling her by this weird term of endearment makes more sense than "'Frankly, I thought she was a fashion model,' murmured the awe-struck Mrs. Levine, rubbing her nose with a touch of envy, 'with those endless legs of hers.'" Who are we talking about here? Why? It's apropos of nothing.

The ending was very good. The story was wrapped up by the end of the visit, but the mention of the next visit, when the mother was in the hospital lets us know that the visits will continue into the future, but also reminds us that that the mother is elderly and that she doesn't have unlimited time left. The mention of the gooseberries gone bad, which the mother had mentioned as being in season earlier, was a very nice detail on which to end the story.

I thought this story was very well crafted, all elements make sense, and as the story goes on, more and more details are revealed so that we get a full and complex picture of the relationship between the mother and daughter.

I also thought the balance here was very good. The author does a great job of inserting little details into the scenes that help the reader understand some larger truth about the lives of the characters and their relationship. For example, "her slightly sloppy movements those of someone used to eating alone." Another example: "'Paulette brought me some gooseberries. You wouldn’t believe how good they are. It makes sense, since they’re in season. Remind me to give you some before you go.' Paulette—a former neighbor who was my age—came to see her every week; she had never left C.
The pacing of the story was very good. Nothing felt rushed, or too stretched out. We got a feel for the visit, what the apartment was like, and how the mother probably spends a lot of her time.

I can't say that the story relied on sophisticated use of idiom, metaphor, or allusion. The strength of the language of the story are the ways that details evoke feelings, and give hints about the history of the relationship between these two people.

I thought there was good balance between the narrator's description of the surroundings and the action going on, with her own thoughts. This is done in this instance when action prompts a memory in the narrator: "I took the shortest route to the train, the one that goes past the Shell station. There, in the old days, I’d stop to prepare myself for her interrogating look when I returned from the cinema, bracing myself, wiping off what was left of my lipstick. What will people think of you?

The revelation of the troubled relationship when the daughter was younger was surprising, but also felt appropriate. As we grow older, we want to be dutiful and kind to our elderly parents, but the hurt feelings from youth never really go away. The author does a good job of revealing this dimension of the relationship in a way that the reader isn't expecting.

I thought I understood the narrator's perspective, but also that of the mother as well, through the details in the scenes, and from what the narrator reveals. For instance, "At the same time, she was firing off questions about my trip, the children, the dog. She didn’t answer mine. Afraid of being boring, always, when speaking of herself." Another example of this is the passage "She tried to come up with more subjects of conversation, so that I wouldn’t go too soon, leaving her alone with her desire for me, her longing to live with me, her daughter, forever.
The writing seems original, and does not use cliches.
The form and structure do not seem original. Yet the story is very compelling nonetheless.

I think the story prompts the reader to consider the ways that parent-child relationships change over time, and how those relationships are always laden with the feelings and expectations of the past. The reader feels for the mother, in her loneliness and desire to hold on to her daughter. However, she is not a completely sympathetic character either. The relationship feels very realistic.

I thought there is a great deal of complexity below the surface. The past is lurking underneath everything that is said and unsaid between the mother and daughter: "Her gray eyes, which had always suspected the worst of me, were fixed on me with a hungry softness. She had been counting the days, had told herself in the morning that this was the day I was coming, and there we were, the two of us, and half our time had already passed. The tone of our visit was playful and kind. The other tone, the violence from when I was fifteen, would not return.

There is a lot of good detail that brings the world alive in this story. Some examples: "At Motteville, we sat in the station for a long time. It was hot. It was quiet, both in the compartment and outside. I looked out the open window; the platform was empty. On the other side of the S.N.C.F. railroad barriers, the tall grass almost touched the lowest branches of the apple trees"; "The TV was on without sound, just the test pattern on the screen"; " I’d never seen her move her body in a natural, relaxed way; she never ran her fingers gently through her hair, never slipped a hand inside the neckline of her blouse while deep in a book. Her only gestures of abandon were expressions of fatigue: stretching with her arms above her head, slumping in a chair, her legs out in front of her. Less hardness in her face than there had been, less of that tension you need to make your way through life.

Both characters feel complex and well developed. This paragraph manages to reveal a great deal about both characters at once: "While looking for napkins, I found a stack of romance magazines at the back of the buffet. I didn’t say anything about them, but she guessed that I’d seen them. "Those little magazines—Paulette gives them to me, otherwise you know I wouldn’t read them. That’s all she reads, these little stories about nothing. Still afraid that I’d criticize her reading habits. I almost said that it didn’t matter if she preferred Nous Deux to the Malraux she’d just borrowed from the public library. She would have been unhappy if I’d seemed to think her incapable of reading the kind of thing I read." There is so much subtle suggestion of judgement and assumptions, and unspoken thoughts that pass between two people who know each other well in this paragraph.

The ending was much too drawn out, it just seemed like the same thoughts were repeated again and again: the narrator loved his mother, her memory stayed with him, her memory, they shared laughter and tears, etc.

Much of the story rambles in a redundant way. It isn't clear what the narrator and his mother share specifically, and much of the story feels vague and uninteresting. The narrative also seems to recount the mother's death twice.

The scenes require more detail to make them interesting, and without the details about the relationship between the mother and the narrator, the narrator's thoughts seem vague and not interesting. For example, "We spent hours immersed in conversation, swapping stories and reminiscing about the past. As we laughed and shared memories, time seemed to stand still. Every word and every laugh echoed through the walls of our shared history, creating new memories to cherish." What did they talk about? What were the memories?
Time proceeds vaguely ("though the seasons," "days turned into months"), and so a lot of the action seems to be disconnected from time.

The story does not make sophisticated use of language. Metaphors tend to be either cliche (e.g. "Our small town, once the backdrop of our story, became a beacon of hope and resilience") or strange/inappropriate (e.g. "Each change brought new stories and memories, etching themselves into the tapestry of our lives.")
Without any details about the lives of these people, the narrator's references to joy, laughter, tears, and memories seem vacuous and without any emotional depth.

The main turn in the story was not all that surprising, i.e. that the mother became ill and had to go to the hospital. It was appropriate to the story. And yet, we don't really know what was wrong with her, apart from a vague reference to the sun, nor do we know how she recovered.
The main perspective is that of the narrator. We don't get the perspective of the mother at all.

There are a lot of vague and cliche passages. For example, "The stories from its pages filled the room, intertwining with the memories of our shared past"; "The remnants of our last visit held no sadness or regret, but rather served as a reminder of the resilience of the human spirit, of the power of love to transcend even the harshest of realities"; "Each change brought new stories and memories, etching themselves into the tapestry of our lives. We shared laughter and tears, celebrations and challenges, drawing strength from each other's presence.
The form and structure are not original.

My takeaway was that the narrator loves his mother, saw her through an illness, was joyous she recovered, and now is recording her death. I was not invested at all in their relationship or in either of their lives.
The story is quite vague and flat. There does not seem to be much meaning below the surface narrative.

The physical world is not well developed. There are not many details about what things look and feel like. Some details are mentioned too many times. We are told the streets have cobblestones no less than six times.
The characters are not well developed. The story would need to include more details about the conversation between the characters, and more detail about the history of their relationship.
The ending felt vague and unsatisfying, and without the sharp focus on the specific details of the mother's character that we have in the beginning of the story.

The story starts off very strongly, there is a lot of detail and we get to know some specific things about the mother, and her relationship with the narrator. However, the story begins to get vague and lose its direction when we get to the paragraph that begins "As the days wore on, I found myself struck by a profound revelation, one that lingered with me long after the visit had ended." The point of this paragraph is not clear, and the story seems to lose its focus after this point.

I think the action of scenes and the exposition of the author are balanced well in the first half of the story, but that what was actually happening gets obscured a bit by the end. We have mostly the narrator's reflections here at the end.

The pacing is good for the most part, although near the end, the actions and thoughts of the narrator seem to become detached from the passage of time. What happened to the mother? Is she dead? Is she still in the hospital? It would be okay if it was left ambiguous, but the problem is that the mother as a person in the world, rather than as a memory or a symbol, seems forgotten.

I think the story is successful in the way language is used in the first half, but the language becomes vague and cliche in the second half. For example, this passage evokes a clear sense of the mother's appearance, movement, and personality: "She was in her morning wrapper, a cashmere shawl draped around her shoulders, the drabbest of slippers on her feet, and she wore this disarray with the preoccupied ease of royalty at home, leaning with one hand on the cane she had only recently begun to use, and waving the other with the flick of an archduke's plumes in my general direction." However, by the end of the story, we have a vague and cliche passage like this one: " A promise of company and protection even in life's most turbulent times; a bond of love as unwavering as the passage of the sun across the sky.

I think there is good balance through the story. The way the narrator leads the reader through the house when he returns and the mother is gone, all the while sharing his thoughts about how it feels, is interesting and done well.

I think the main turn, that the mother suffers sunstroke and the house loses its warmth and maternal presence is both surprising and appropriate. The way that the language of the doctor's letter is included is effective in helping us understand what the narrator might have felt when they found out; we are not just told that it happened by the narrator.

We only have the perspective of the narrator, although there are some details that hint at the mother's perspective, e.g. "I saw the familiar hangings intermingled with samplers and Japanese screens in their unaltered niches, all of which had borne witness to the endless progression of hours, days, and years ticking away beneath the portrait of my father.
For the most part, the writing seems original. However, it tends to become vague and cliche by the end. An example would be the last paragraph.
I don't think the form or structure are original.

I don't think the reader is left with much of interest to ponder by the end. Again, the focus of the story peters out by the end, which is disappointing. The main idea seems to be the narrator's sense of loss and nostalgia.

This story does not have the same kind of depth and nuance that Story 1 in this set has. The main difference is that the history of the relationship between the mother and child is not as complexly developed as in Story 1.

The story does include plenty of good details that make the physical world believable and interesting. For example, "She was in her morning wrapper, a cashmere shawl draped around her shoulders, the drabbest of slippers on her feet, and she wore this disarray with the preoccupied ease of royalty at home, leaning with one hand on the cane she had only recently begun to use, and waving the other with the flick of an archduke's plumes in my general direction"; "I saw the familiar hangings intermingled with samplers and Japanese screens in their unaltered niches, all of which had borne witness to the endless progression of hours, days, and years ticking away beneath the portrait of my father.
I thought the author did a good job of developing the mother as a character in the first part of the story, along with the narrator.
The ending seems natural; it makes sense that the story would end with the mother's death, and the aftermath is not too drawn out.

This story makes sense as a coherent whole, nothing really seems out of place, with the exception of this small detail: The daughter returns a month later after her mother has fallen, and the dishes from her last visit are still in the sink. This suggests the mother fell the day of or after the daughter's last visit a month ago, but it also seems unlikely that she would have waited a full month to visit her mother after such an accident.
I thought there was a good balance between the action and conversation in the scenes, and the narrator's reflections and thoughts.
I thought the pacing was good, the passage of time does not seem too compressed or drawn out. The one exception is the detail I mention in my response to the first question.

The story doesn't make sophisticated use of these literary devices, but neither does the story seem to suffer much from it. Toward the end of the story there are some expressions that seem out of place or inappropriate, e.g. "The hours stretched quiet and bittersweet, as if a stopwatch had been set ticking down in the background";  "Memories I would carry with me always, in the stained-glass corridors of my heart.

There is good balance between the details of the action and the surroundings, and the thoughts of the narrator. There are some places where more details would help to understand the characters' relationship better. For example, this passage: "When nightfall came we made popcorn and watched old movies we had memorized, line by line, commenting and giggling over forgotten details. We stayed up talking until the early hours of the morning, catching up on all the little details, big and small, that made up the fabric of our daily lives." Details are mentioned, but we don't know what they are.
The mother's accident is a surprise, but it also seems realistic and believable as something that someone with an elderly parent would need to confront.
I think we don't get much perspective other than that of the narrator.
The writing does seem original, and does not rely on cliches.
The form and structure are not original.

The takeaway from this story does not seem particularly unique or original. The details create a realistic character in the mother, but as a reader I didn't feel that there was much going on here beyond the joys shared between the mother and daughter. There doesn't seem to be much of a back story to give it depth. Hints of a history, for example with photos of the father, are not developed.

I didn't feel like there was much going on below the surface narrative here. Much like Story 3, it lacks historical depth; there is no back story, details from the past, that would lend additional meaning to the actions we observe in the story.

I thought this story does a good job in creating a world with a lot of specific detail, such as "The diner where Mom and I always stopped for pie after school—Mom always got apple, I always got cherry. The movie theater where I had my first kiss at 15, with Danny McPhee in the back row. The corner store that still boasted the same vintage peppermint-stick candy in its window that Mom would buy me as a treat when money was tight but joy was abundant"; references to the crossword, the details about the garden, and the food they ate.

I felt like both the mother and daughter characters were developed well. Depth comes from the narrator's own thoughts and interpretations, and we learn a lot about the mother's character from the details about her home, her crossword habit, and her cozy shared activities with her daughter.
As I said above, the image in the final paragraph connects to one of the culminating images in the story and restates the opening, creating and closing a loop.

It follows a logical progression and builds emotion and narrative through the layering of details, allowing the reader clear signposts of meaning. The ending connects to the beginning—indeed, it creates a kind of looped narrative, a return, a change, and the failure of the first narrative, to connect, as symbolized in the gooseberries.

Like many dialogue driven stories, this piece uses dialogue as a means to dip into and out of the scene—transitioning into the narrator’s memory, summary, or internal monologue and then pulling the reader back into the moment as needed.

The narrative displays a very adept sense of pacing. It shows this perhaps most keenly when it slows down before the shift in tone on page 2 when the narrative complicates the narrator’s relationship with her mother.

It deploys literary devices subtly and cleanly. The gooseberries in the final paragraph are the clearest example—an image is set up and then returned to, encapsulating both the narrator’s relationship with her mother and the broader narrative trajectory itself. Largely, the story follows the broad conventions for contemporary literary fiction. The prose is spare and the moments of flourish usually relegated to splashes of imagery, like how the “tall grass almost touched the lowest branches of the apple trees” in the first paragraph.

For the most part, the story maintains an external position. It depicts the narrator’s internal life through her vision of her mother, which is to say through her description of her mother’s life. This tendency is effectively broken at the bottom of page 3: “This time, once again, I felt that I was leaving badly, in a cowardly way.” These moments where the narrator speaks clearly about her internal state are paced such that they are emotionally heavy for the reader.

The most striking example is on page 2 with the shift in the narrator’s relationship with her mother. The intrusion of profanity explodes the story and our understanding of that relationship, it introduces complexity into the world of the narrative.

It depicts a complicated relationship between the narrator and her mother. Both have clear love for each other and yet also there is a kind of underlying grief which neither can shake the other of. The mother needs the daughter more than the daughter can bear and there is no easy solution or answer.

While much of what is being depicted here is standard ground for the genre, it proceeds in a way that avoids clear cliches or tropes and follows what is murky and painful. There are no answers here, and no easy endings. It also avoids using hackneyed language or imagery to force emotion out of its reader, relying on the now-standard tools of literary fiction to build a scene and cooly push the reader into feeling.

While I would probably say that this is a conventional piece of contemporary literary fiction and it follows the genre tropes therein, it nevertheless avoids a three act structure and neither provides a clear resolution nor an obvious moral or anything like this. It is a subtle piece of fiction, written to be murky and painful. I might find it conventional from my vantage point, but a different reader likely would not.

Again, this is, to me, a conventional piece of contemporary literary fiction. It does not feel hugely original to me in theme or content, insofar as it follows conventions for literary fiction—it is murky, grey, and reads like a howl of grief. Still, there is a challenge here and a pain here which feels as though it is coming from a distinctly original place.

Very clear use of subtext. The most obvious example is the gooseberries at the end of the story, but throughout the piece the way the narrator describes her mother is also the way in which we understand the narrator.

The story proceeds with a close eye to detail. It depicts smell, sight, taste, touch, and so on, through combination of its narration and in the dialogue and sometimes by contrasting these positions (internal and external). Much of the story is built through the description of the narrator’s mother and the environment she has built for herself.

This story follows a trajectory of increasing complexity. It functions by adding complications to a scenario until those complications reach a breaking point (in my view this happens when the narrator leaves the mother and with the line again “This time, once again, I felt that I was leaving badly, in a cowardly way.”

The narrative loops three times. Though this could be interesting in an experimental way, it instead feels like it has failed to follow a logical path. It reintroduces the mother's death as though it hadn't happened already. For example, "When my mother's time finally came, her departure left a void in our small town and in my heart. Yet, I sought solace in the memories we had created, the laughter we had shared, and the love we had nurtured. She may be physically gone, but her spirit lives on" followed by "And then, one fateful day, my mother's time came to an end. The void she left behind was immense, a testament to the impact she had on the lives she touched. But in the midst of my grief, I found solace in the memories we had created, the love that had bound us together.”
The narrative loops three times. Each time it does, it loses power and becomes more hyperbolic.
As I said above, though the first loop maintains a sense of scene, the story largely stays in paraphrase afterwards and it feels like this paraphrase becomes increasingly broad as the story goes on.

The narrative struggles to follow a coherent flow and has no clear sense of narrative time. Though the beginning of the story, perhaps I might refer to it as the first loop, occurs in-scene, I believe everything after it unfolds in paraphrase. Instead of slowing down, the narrative loops and repeats, maintaining its condensed narrative mode.

The literary devices here are often over-the-top and cliched. For example, “The day slipped away like a whisper in the wind” or "“Together, we weathered the storms of life, finding solace in the embrace of the community that surrounded us". Often, these devices are employed directly on top of one another and it is overwhelming and frustrating for the reader.

Likewise, the story's emotionality is stunted in this draft. Often, the story tells the reader what is going to happen before it happens. Then, after it happens, the narrator describes to the reader exactly what has occurred and what was thought and felt about without any subtlety. For instance, "I am reminded of the power of love. How it can transcend time and transcend even death. My mother may no longer be with me in body, but her spirit lives on in every act of kindness, in every moment of laughter, and in every memory we created together." This quote is just the feeling that the story is trying to conjure in the reader, but by stating it outright, it fails to make the reader feel it instead of think it.

There is a kind of structural unpredictability here in the way the narrative repeats, but it is neither satisfying nor coherent and it does not feel controlled. While this is intriguing as a narrative structure, it does not

The issue here is that the voice has little specificity, it leans on cliche and the story struggles to use external description or internal focalization to allow the reader to intuit about its narrator. Rather, the perspective feels flat.

The use of cliches is constant in this story. Some examples: "The bond we shared could not be severed by the cruel hands of time or the trials of life"; "...the walls of nostalgia that had surrounded us before would crumble beneath the weight of reality"; "Together, we weathered the storms of life..."; and so on.

I am a little torn in what to say here—the story does not have a conventional structure, but it also does not seem to be in command of what it does have. There is a lot that can be done with loops and repetition and though this story neither achieves those effects nor seems to be intentionally working towards them, it is something of an inspiring structure. Structurally, it reminds me very loosely of something like "The Early Deaths of Lubeck, Brennan, Harp, and Carr" by Jesse Ball, the possibility of layered feeling and dread remains, however unused and unexploited.

While there are moments which remain moving—for instance, the line: “I hoped, prayed, that she could hear me, that the sound of my voice could somehow bring her back to me”—they feel cliched to the point that I feel as though I have read them before. The larger problem here is, I suspect, that the narrator never feels specific as a character, and instead much more like a broad sketch or an empty vessel.

This is a story where what one sees is what one gets. The narrator more or less describes the emotions the reader should be feeling, just as she describes the emotions that she feels. For instance, "The void she left behind was immense, a testament to the impact she had on the lives she touched. But in the midst of my grief, I found solace in the memories we had created, the love that had bound us together"; "And so, we savored each moment, for we knew that our time together was a gift. The remnants of our last visit held no sadness or regret, but rather served as a reminder of the resilience of the human spirit, of the power of love to transcend even the harshest of realities"; "When my mother's time finally came, her departure left a void in our small town and in my heart."; "But it wasn't always easy. There were moments when the weight of the world seemed too much to bear"; and so on. While it is itself a hackneyed writing workshop phrase, this story struggles greatly in showing emotion to the reader as opposed to telling them. It is a strange reality to narrative and perhaps to life in general that feints and gestures can be more moving and communicate more clearly than outright statements.

The story broadly struggles at creating a clear picture of its scenes and either avoids sensory detail, when it is in its summarizing or paraphrasing mode, or avoids specificity, when it does try to stay in-scene. For instance, "The rooms were filled with remnants of our previous visit, frozen in time" or "As we laughed and shared memories, time seemed to stand still". In neither of these instances are details given—what are the remnants? What are the memories? They are signifiers without depth.

As with the scene-work, the characters are left vague and serve largely as empty vessels for the narrative, which is unfortunate because the narrative relies on the complexity and strength of its characters to find meaning. The issue, as I will describe in a moment, is that there is no real subtext to this story. Without any interplay between the way the narrator depicts herself or her mother and the way the reader reads the situation, without leaving anything unsaid, it is much more challenging for the narrative to find nuance within its characters or its narrative.

While the build towards the ending proceeds naturally, the ending itself does not find a satisfying conclusion—instead, it seems to reiterate the narrator’s decision to return home without finding a scene to put that return into. If I were giving advice on the story, it would be to spend a bit more time on the ending and provide more specificity on the sorts of memory and nostalgia that are drawn out from the return, as opposed to the overwrought and broad prose the story closes with in this draft.

The story follows a clear logical trajectory, beginning with the narrator’s arrival at her mother’s house through to the first departure, the note from the doctor, and then the return to the mother’s house. For better and for worse, there are no unexpected repetitions and the structure proceeds as would be expected.

Again, the motion between scenes and summaries here largely feels sophisticated. The story struggles with the specificity of those scenes, but it does well in returning to scene and in shepherding the story along. The scaffolding is largely effective. It uses markers of time (“As the days wore on…”; “The week drew swiftly to a close”) as both a way to pace the story but also to enter into and out of summary. These are not always so effective or elegant, but they function.

While I have some quibbles with the pacing, in particular the motion departing from the mother’s house the first time and then returning to it and speed with which the doctor’s note is introduced and then acted upon—it feels rushed to me—I can see the logic of the decisions that have been made. It feels more like a failure of execution than of intention. There are some other moments where the pacing is manipulated impressively. For instance, the transition out of scene and then back into it here: “I stayed with her for one week; during that time, we spent countless hours conversing, either in the soft warmth of the parlor or in the dim twilight of the fragrant garden after supper. There, she would sit wrapped in shawls, shielding herself against the damp evening air.”

While I find the choices here to be grandiose and displeasing, they are consistent and occasionally touch a kind of unexpected beauty. For instance, “…her small face peering out from beneath the wide white brim like a turtle's from beneath its shell”. The parts which I find frustrating I also have to admit do maintain some degree of consistent atmosphere. The line “I lifted her hand and clicked my heels together like a diplomat under presentation to the Court of a minor principality” aligns well with the broader depiction of their meeting, however annoying and over-the-top that depiction might be to me.

Though the subject matter is obviously emotionally charged, this is not a particularly emotional story. The narrative’s tendency to state outright the way things are without subtext, coupled with the grandiose prose, makes it difficult for emotional depth to be found. For instance, the narrator’s first departure: “Mother did her best to hide her sadness, of course, but I saw the quiet grief simmering below the surface as she waved me off down the driveway and back into the cold embrace of the vast world beyond.” This line effectively defangs what might have been a moment of emotional intensity.

The story proceeds more or less entirely as expected. It offers few complications to the relationship between the narrator and his mother, though the early impression the story gives of their dynamic is odd and intriguing. It does not follow through on those possible implications.

The narrator’s voice generally speaks what is meant and often says outright things that would be better implied. For instance, “The sunlight streaming through the open doorway lapsed into silence, heavy with the accumulated weight of all my years away from her.”  The narrator consistently uses a hyperbolic style of prose which does create a unified tone, but, in practice, this does not seem to suggest anything about the narrator in particular.

There is not a great deal of thought here below the surface. Some of the prose suggests original thinking insofar as the images, however over-the-top, can feel imaginative, but they have little staying power. The topics the story is thinking about, which I took to involve, broadly speaking, grief and aging, are considered on the surface level only. The aging of the mother is sad, the narrator is sad about it, and so on.

The narrative follows traditional tropes. As soon as the mother is visited, it is clear that the story will be about her age and her potential death. Of course, the issue here is not the subject matter, but the way that subject matter is unfolded. No attempt is made to reframe this narrative in an unexpected way. Although, to be clear, the conventionality of the structure is not, to me, necessarily a statement on originality. What reduces the piece’s originality, for me, is that it does not use its structure to disclose or excavate something about the relationship that might otherwise be hidden. Instead, what is on the page is all there seems to be.

The closest the piece gets to originality is in the strange tone of the narrator’s voice and the formal and playful dynamic hinted at in the early conversation between mother and son, but this ultimately offers little insight and has no meaningful subtext. The story follows conventions and does little either to subvert them or to lean into them to the point that they break, into feeling or otherwise

Again, the prose here is initially intriguing and it creates what feels like a unified voice, however frustrating I might find it. The problem is that the story struggles to give that voice context or depth—there is no subtext, no second-layer to be uncovered. That failure is, I think, the primary failure of the story.

Some attempts are made at creating sensory detail. I appreciate the possibilities of the exaggerated prose, but it is not quite specific enough to create a textured scene out of what it depicts. The space that it describes seems to change every time it is described. For instance, when the narrator returns to his mother’s house, the objects which he encounter have not been encountered before by the reader. The sense of permanence or grounding is missing.

Again, the closest the story comes to character development is through the exaggerated tone of the narrator’s prose, but it neither evolves nor changes and very little substantive is revealed about the narrator or his mother.

The ending logically follows the story that comes before it. Though it is a bit hackneyed and cloying—the crossword puzzle as an image feels obvious to me, though I suspect it would be a sophisticated inclusion for an AI—there is nevertheless a real pathos to it. The difficulty lies more in the rapid transition before the narrator’s second return.
The narrative follows a clear trajectory and though the narrator’s second return home is a bit choppy and rapid, the order and flow make sense.

Though the narrative relies heavily on summary, it is still capable of moving relatively elegantly into dialogue. I suspect this is because of the specificity of the environments and scenes it describes in its paraphrase—it convinces the reader that the paraphrase is lush and so dipping into it feels organic. Nevertheless, the story has difficulty settling into a scene and this could probably be improved in a revision process.

As I said above, he pacing is strong until the second return. “When I returned a month later, it was not for a pleasant visit but because Mom had landed in the hospital after a fall in the garden left her with a broken hip and wrist” is simply too fast of a transition—no time is given to the experience away from home or to adequately set up or solidify the initial departure.

The prose is clean and simple. It is relatively sparse in its imagery and rarely leans heavily on obvious metaphors or similes. There are sentences which are beautiful in their simplicity: “Rain began to patter on the windows as evening fell, the soothing sound of droplets on leaves outside lulling us into contentment.” The prose feels, for lack of a better word, honest.

While I desire significantly more emotional complexity, the story does an admirable job of focalizing the narrator’s experience through her internal monologue and creating our sense of her feeling of warmth for her mother through both statements of fact, but also through the way she describes her mother and the memories they share. It is this latter method which is particularly effective. To give an example, the tenderness of the line “heavy on the pickles” here conjures the sense of warmth that the rest of the paragraph then states outright: “I made us tuna salad sandwiches, heavy on the pickles, while Mom set out glasses of iced tea garnished with mint from her garden.”

Outside of the moment of transition I have already discussed, the motions the story makes are clear and subtle and the way it proceeds through the narrator’s first visit is elegant and exciting. The topic sentences especially are well-considered, not relying too much on any particular strategy.

The characters here are given very little opportunity to be anything other than sweet and kind, which makes the narrator, the narrator’s mother, and the relationship between them feel saccharine. As far as I can tell, there are no moments of complication or even meaningful conflict between the characters. This also limits the narrative’s power.

I am a little bit torn on this because I believe that the story is specific enough to create some sense of emotion. But, in the end, it is difficult to overcome the sense that I have read this story before. Again, it comes down to the lack of complexity I see within the characters and the neatness of the ending, which feels, for lack of a better word, too “easy”.

This is a traditional structure for a story like this. It does not create unexpected moments and there is no sharpness, subversion, or subtext that I can discern. It is also distinctly imperfect in its deployment of this conventional structure—the rushed second return home is, again, a significant place where the story stumbles.

Because of the lack of complexity within the characters and their relationship to each other, it is difficult to feel that the story is meaningfully sophisticated in theme. Though honest and painful in its simplicity, the grief it depicts ultimately feels too simple to be real—grief is a howl, I think, not a sadness with an answer as it feels like it is depicted here.

While this is not a particularly subtle story, the use of images like the crossword puzzles and the way the narrator describes the mother (as I talked about above) and the environment as a way to create a feeling which is not always outright stated give the narrative a degree of complexity. It is not the most impressive piece of writing in this respect, but there is some amount of complexity here.

It is not the most sophisticated story in how it builds its setting, insofar as it relies a bit more on proper nouns and brands than I might like—for instance, “The movie theater where I had my first kiss at 15, with Danny McPhee in the back row” or “The comforting smell of Chanel No. 5 and coffee enveloped me as her familiar laugh, as warm and sweet as blueberry pie, bubbled up“—but, nevertheless, it does so effectively. There is a particular place being described, however well or poorly, and I believe that is the intention of the story—to conjure a specific place. This is enough to convince me.
As I said above, the narrator and her mother both feel caught in a kind of saccharine mode. There is no room for complication or complexity in this draft. This is the failure of the story.

Yes; ending on those gooseberries was a surprising and delightful move, and the feelings--masked and hidden and denied and pushed aside as they are, by both the speaker and the mother--are captured so beautifully in the mundanity of that final image of the gooseberries. It's as if, with that description, we can see the mother's hands tying the knot so that the gooseberries wouldn't spill on the daughter's trip home--such an everyday but caring action--and now we're seeing its "evidence" in her absence--and that the daughter finds the now-rotten fruit still tucked in the vegetable drawer a month later points to the ways the mother has aged and changed while living alone (though not cleaning out one's vegetable drawer isn't so remarkable in and of itself) and the hurried way the daughter leaves, the guilt, the mother's ruined hope, the way the past casts a shadow on the present.

Yes--this story is really quite satisfying in the way it holds together, building in tension and significance as it continues. It's a quiet story, fairly insular, and even for the patience that it exhibits, every bit of dialogue, every detail feels like it adds up to something important and real about these characters and their relationship.

Yes; this story feels memorable for its use of scene. Details and descriptions such as "Her eyes on her plate, her slightly sloppy movements those of someone used to eating alone" are specific enough to give believability and nuance to the character(s), but not so specific that we get mired in minutiae.
