There's a vagueness still present in "slightly sloppy movements [ ] of someone used to eating alone" and this, here, is one of its considerable strengths: The writer knows when to keep moving, to leave the "meaning" unstated (the narrator doesn't follow it with editorializing or telling us her guilt or whatever else about this) and therefore all the more present and real.

Yes, the pacing here is very well done. The writer's choice to suspend the reader in the (extended) moment of the visit itself feels quite right given the tension surrounding the visit and the mother's overt and stated desire for the daughter to stay. The writer's attention here to the paragraph is also key when it comes to the story's pacing; the way the writer keeps the reader moving through the story with very short paragraphs peppered in through the longer paragraphs is strategically handled, and the variation between the length of paragraphs does much to both pull us through the story while also "putting on the brakes" as the reader is forced to move in and out of multiple paragraphs.

Yes; this test criterion was a little tricky for me for this story because the story itself has a formality to it, the feeling of translation. (Obviously I don't know that this was *actually* translated from a language other than English, but the syntax feels of another language, and the diction and register of the the narrator make it feel to me like the reader is getting it in translation.) At any rate, because of the formal feeling of the narrator's voice here--and even the ways the characters speak to one another--I didn't find a lot of idiom or metaphor to be had. But certainly nothing stood out as diverging from the tone or mood of the narrator's voice here, and what idiomatic language there was felt successful. A sentence such as "This time, once again, I felt that I was leaving badly, in a cowardly way" feels *just* askew enough in its phrasing ("leaving badly, in a cowardly way") that it sounds like translation--and translated beautifully, of course, and using vernacular believably.

Yes, this is expertly done here as well. This relates to structure in part, too, but the way the writer blends scene and summary is so careful and balanced; a paragraph like the one about visiting old people's houses shows how seamlessly the narrator moves between exteriority and interiority As is the case in living as well, there's no "distinction" between what's happening and how the narrator is seeing or interpreting it; there's a natural-feeling movement from exterior to interior without feeling forced or, worst, feeling like we're only getting the exterior in order to give an excuse to get to the interior.

Yes, and this is an area where the story is somewhat a "sleeper"; the writer's trust of the reader to make connections from what's laid out is much of what gives the writing here its charge, rather than big pronouncements or narrative happenings. For me as a reader, the turns here are interior and understated; the turns happen through information and backstory that's meted out patiently for the reader (e.g., "[t]he other tone, the violence from when I was fifteen, would not return" and the accompanying snippets of dialogue). It's as if the narrator has nothing but time for the reader, which contrasts beautifully with the impatience and dutifulness underlying the daughter's visit with the mother.

Yes, and these characters are unlikeable and diverse from one another in very believable ways. Rather than a story about extremes of human experience, this story has characters and events that we know and understand--either intuitively or because we've been in a similar situation of guilt and responsibility, of wanting something from another person that their either can't or refuse to give, etc.
Yes; this story--from its descriptions, its careful dialogue, its structure, and its overall patience--feels wholly original and avoids cliche, at the language and narrative levels.

Yes; here, as above, the story does a lovely job of constantly moving us back and forward, from the story's present back to the past and then forward again to "catch up"--and sometimes even moving into what will happen later in the visit to play around with the reader's sense of the narrator's perspective here. It's a hard narrative move to pull off, but I think it's done really well here. A few moments that show off the writer's ability to cover large temporal distances with blinding efficiency: "At the same time, she was firing off questions about my trip, the children, the dog. She didn’t answer mine. Afraid of being boring, always, when speaking of herself. Later, she repeated, as usual, "I’m fine here. Couldn’t be better and 'I have no complaints.

Yes, to be sure here--and one of the real strengths here, I'd argue, is the complexity of the "unique and original" idea we're left with; it's nuanced, and hard to distill to a simple phrase or statement. Because of this, it avoids the "moral of the story" trap that stories often fall into, where the reader feels hit over the head with the idea(s) we're "supposed to get" from the story.

Yes; as mentioned above, the author here uses all the elements at their disposal to make a story that positively oozes subtext, without letting it be *all* that there is. A moment like this is when the narrator says, "As she used to, she said, 'Every living thing is beautiful. She seemed to have forgotten that I was going to leave." The way the narrator moves from what the mother said, as she used to, right into not what it means, but what the narrator *thinks* it means about the mother, reveals crucial characterization for both the mother and narrator.

Yes, and I love the seemingly easy way the writer handles this. The reader isn't overwhelmed with catalogues of description, but instead, the story moves similar to the way many good poems move--I'm thinking about Forche's "The Colonel" in particular here--by using restraint to its advantage. I feel confident that the writer here could have given us paragraphs and paragraphs of description that would feel right and true; instead, they only give us the exact amount of description that's needed to build up both the diegetic sound and point us, gently, toward subtext and meaning (e.g., "The TV was on without sound, just the test pattern on the screen.")

YES. These characters--few as they are--feel real and naturally drawn, down to the ways the narrator's character sees the mother: "Last image of her: in the doorway, rounded arms framing her heavy silhouette in a yellow dress—her prettiest one, tight around the chest and the belly—a wide, fixed smile." Here, we see both the mother--looking like a real person we might see and know--and see the narrator through what she notices, includes, and how she feels about the mother. Artfully done.

No, this is a miss as well. The first sentences from the final paragraphs themselves point to the sort of scattershot nature of the ending, seeming to throw endless platitudes to see what might stick (none did): "In the years that followed...," "And now, as I sit here...," "I will forever cherish our time in that small town," and "For in the end, it is through love that we find our purpose." There's nothing earned or natural to this ending: it feels forced and preachy and like it could be the ending to positively any story.

No, this is a hard pass for me. There is pretty much nothing that seems to be satisfying about this story for me as a reader; there's no unifying feature to the story, and even the paragraphs themselves seem to somewhat haphazardly be put together. The trajectory of the story feels both unsurprising and unambitious.

No; as soon as there seems to be a scene landed upon (finally! Something to hold onto!), the story settles right back into vapid explanations or summary. Take the small paragraph about finding the mother; what surrounds scene-making possibilities of footsteps/etc. is so fumbling that I'd argue it takes us OUT of a scene: the obvious "my anxiety mounting with every step," the cliche description of the mother as "frail and fragile like a bird with broken wings," the interesting but ultimately obscuring statement that "the sun had taken its toll on her delicate frame.

No, the story doesn't show a skilled relationship between compression and stretching of time here. The possible ONE exception is that it does take 3 (tiny) paragraphs for us to get from entering the house the fateful time to finding the mother lying sick in bed. I'd argue that there's still almost no tension created (anywhere in the story), but this comes the closest.

No. There are some metaphors, but they're really all cliches, and the idioms that are used seem...misused? I'm thinking specifically of the statement "[w]hen my mother's time finally came," which idiomatically would be a euphemism for her dying. I think that's what actually is meant by it, based on the rest of the paragraph that follows, but there's a narrative disjunction that doesn't seem purposeful that makes the idiom seem misunderstood or inappropriate. (This is just one example of when it was unsuccessful, but it's representative of a pattern of ill-fitting idioms and overdone metaphors.)

No; there's an illusion that we get emotion from the narrator, but it feels like the simulacrum of emotion, or emotion as understood only in the brain and not in the body, if that makes sense. (Emotion from someone to whom emotions have been described but never felt.) Phrases like "Memories of our last visit replayed in my mind, the laughter and connection we had shared now haunting me, like a whisper of a distant melody" sound like someone trying to convince me that they felt...sad? rather than someone actually experiencing sadness.

No; narratively, the first visit with the mother is so idyllic that it seems clear the tension has to be introduced later, so then when the narrator returns and something bad has happened, it feels expected. And honestly, nothing else really "happens" in the story (except for the "surprise" that it seems like the mother dies, and then dies again, but that's a writing problem, not a feature of the plot).

No. The only reason anyone in the story is unlikeable is because the narrator speaks in so many cliches as to make the story nearly insufferable, but that's not a feature of offering diverse perspectives. And there's nothing convincing about much of anything here.

No--the story is so full of cliches that it felt a little like an exercise to use as many cliches as possible. Indeed, there are far too many to include here, and it would be to ill effect anyway. Cliches abound throughout--from the first sentence's "I was transported back in time" all the way to the final sentence's assertion, "And as I close this chapter of our story, I know that our love will endure, forever etched in the fabric of our small town and in the depths of my soul." Woof. This is painful.
No. I will admit that the form and structure of the story are not, indeed, what I would have expected, but here that doesn't contribute to the story being successful.

No, afraid not. The narrator really loved their mother, and she was amazing, and they shared a wonderful bond that lasted a lifetime. Perhaps some readers would take this as heartwarming (though I don't even think it gives that), but there's nothing here that would strike the reader as unique or original.

No, there's not enough patience here to allow for subtext. There's barely enough patience to allow for surface meaning; yes, events are described, but we aren't let in enough to real emotion or description to be able to make meaning of what's happening. Instead, the narrator can barely go two sentences without summarizing feelings and collapsing those with the actions: "Overwhelmed by guilt for not keeping my promise, I hurriedly made my way back to her house." Instead, if the author exhibited even a little restraint and just said, "I hurriedly made my way back to her house" following what comes just before it, we'd be left as readers to read into (i.e., make meaning out of) the narrator's actions. We'd actually get to be witnesses or observers of the narrator for a moment, rather than being reminded every. bloody. moment. that there's a narrator! telling this story! Look at me! I'm a narrator! Let me tell you what it all means, how clever my comparisons are! Oy.

No, this is a big no from me. Both the highs (e.g., "We witnessed weddings, births, and farewells, and through it all, our bond remained unbreakable") and the lows ("The rooms were filled with remnants of our previous visit, frozen in time") are unbelievable because everything that's mentioned by the narrator is SO general that it feels like the description of human life rather than life actually lived through the senses. There's also some sort of pragmatic/logistical weirdness at times in which the narrator says things that make neither actual nor figurative sense; the most egregious in my view is the sort of nonsensical "call back" to the problematic sun description from earlier: "The sun no longer posed a threat, for I was there to shield her from its harsh rays, to protect her from harm." What does this mean? The literal sun? (Has she no sunscreen, no hat, no sunbrella?) Some...figurative sun that hasn't been touched on yet, and never will be? If it's the actual sun, I don't understand what's happening; if it's a metaphorical sun, I don't understand what the metaphor connects to in the real world or stands for in the figurative.
No, these characters not only aren't believable, but they don't believably undergo any sort of change or exhibit any evidence of being any more dynamic than a cookie cutter would be.

No, the ending is too explanatory for that. Many central questions remain (for example, the possible red herring but still interesting inclusion toward the beginning, "and I assured her that I was well again," and the description that "she nodded slowly, bracing herself for what was to come, and turned to lead me into the house"), and it's clear with the ending that any possibility the story had for complicating our understanding of...something has disappeared.

No. The story itself moves at an all right clip for me as a reader, but the overwrought, faux-heightened diction of the narrator gets in the way of and ends up canceling out any successes that find their way here. As a result, and the fact that there's an otherwise unremarkable plot here, the story doesn't add up to something meaningful by the ending.

No; as much as I find the pacing of this story to be dreadfully slow, I do think the author has some strongish moments in creating recognizable scenes. The after-dinner garden scene, with its use of the simple conditional, creates a sort of comfort of repetition and feels seeable when the narrator describes "she would sit wrapped in shawls, shielding herself against the damp evening air." Not bad, right? But overall, there story has a real plodding quality that even passing strong moments of scene can't mitigate.

No. We're told that the "week drew swiftly to a close," and to the author's credit, we do get some scenic moments in the story (more on that in a moment), but in general, the writing itself belies what's being discussed. It's as if there's a mismatch between the narrator and the subject or something. Time in general in the story feels distorted because there's not enough happening in the story to keep it moving.

No; although there are some idioms well used here (i.e., used in ways that feel believable for a speaker of English to use), there's a wavering quality to the narrator's assessments and observations, which makes it difficult for me to get a handle on who this narrator really is. His pomposity makes it so that idiomatic phrases don't come up too often (though a stray "mind's eye" comes across just fine), but the metaphors themselves fall flat at the level of cliche (e.g., the whole tapestry metaphor that gets way overused here).
No, because of this insufferable narrator, the story offers very little by way of emotion, and because the external is mediated through this dreadful narrator, nothing in or out feels meaningful.
No, not particularly. The parts of the story that feel unexpected here are not a matter of narrative but instead about the unrelentingly affected voice of the speaker.
No, although the narrator here is entirely unlikeable, it's not due to diverse perspectives being offered, nor is it a witting choice, I think.

No; and while I gain a peevish delight at the fact that being called "cliche" would likely be one of this narrator's worst fears, I am ultimately joyless at the overdone cliches here (some particularly icky examples include: "heavy with the accumulated weight of all my years away from her"; "fate, it seemed, had other plans for me"; and "confident in the belief that she would forever endure, an immortal anchor amidst the stormy seas of my journey.

Yes, ultimately, I think this story passes the test of (slight) originality in its structure. It starts in action, walks us up to the conflict (underwhelming as the stakes may feel), and then ultimately denies us the closure we might want, or even expect, here. Instead of ending on resolution of some sort, or answers, the story leaves us with more questions. Are these particularly generative, compelling questions? No. But I have to give the story credit for subverting our expectation that the story might be neatly closed by the ending.

No, I'm afraid not. I had real hopes here in the beginning when the narrator remarks "I had not realized that the years of separation—years filled with bustling cities and the intense, absorbing world of sophisticated science—had invaded my memory and slowly remodeled her image into something almost fashionable." Neat! This feels unique and like a fascinating way to think about personal histories, and the ways our memory betrays us, focused as it always is by our present circumstances. But then, the narrator's perverse self-importance gets the better of him, and we suffer under sentences like these: "For as complicated as the tapestry of our intertwined lives may have been, and as diverse as our shared experiences often proved to be, it gradually dawned upon me...." Bleh. The narrator here is too clever by half, and the story struggles because of it.

No; as above with characterization, again here we are denied subtext by this tedious narrator's recounting of the story. Describing the clock at the abandoned house of the now-infirmed mother COULD be a smart and subtext-building choice, but not when the narrator splashes all over the place to explain that "Its rhythmic cadence was as certain and unstinting in its duty as a soldier on march, serving as a sobering reminder that the world waited for no one, not even my mother." Boo hiss. Crushed, any hope for subtext here.

No. Part of this comes down to a tendency of this narrator to heap on specific description (e.g., "the births of scholars who had not even considered their theses when I last stood in this room") or piling metaphor on top of metaphor (as in this mystifying sentence, bedeviling me to this very moment: "The town's picturesque streets were lined with flowers and fringed with dappled patches of sunlight, coaxing forth a murmur of echoes that dissolved under the soft glow of quaint lamplight"). I very well might be on board as a reader with some portion of that, but the layering of words and sensations ends up making the language itself somewhat meaningless. This overwrought quality again here challenges the reader to find footing.

No, and this is where I feel we are fairly robbed in the story. There's a sort of unkept promise when, in the beginning, the narrator says "and I assured her that I was well again." That's some dang foreshadowing if I ever saw some! But never, ever do we see anything come of this; the mystery that could've grown--and added to this character's complexity and believability--is cut out at the root by the pretentious musings of this narrator. We all know pompous people, of course; but even the most conspicuously showy among us would be hard pressed to say "Calms, too, were restored upon the earth and in the heavens. What a strange experience it was to accompany my mother once more" while keeping a straight face. The narrator is a caricature, and the mother is merely an old mother, and that's that. (I also even had hopes for the letter-writing doctor! But alas.)
No, the ending misses the mark here. The author uses the ending to give us the Big Takeaway rather than any sense of completion or closure.

No, this story doesn't accumulate to much. It's less of a story and more of an advertisement for nostalgia. As a result, few parts of the story feel authentic, either to real life or to a particular character.

No, but this criterion was tricky for me for this story. To be sure, this isn't good writing, but there is an obvious, concerted effort on the part of the writer to balance scene and summary. The sticking point for me, though, comes down to process versus product: It seems clear to me as a reader that the writer is well aware of the need to find the right balance for a particular story as it relates to summary/exposition and scene, but that's a matter of craft not yet borne out in the text, and the product/story itself shows that the writer isn't quite up to the task yet.

No; the story does do a good job of slowing down to describe the visit itself, but the narrator spends so much time focused on giving us Meaning that it works against what strengths might exist for the story otherwise.

No, the story fails the test here. I'd be hard pressed to point to any metaphor in the story that wasn't a cliche, and as a result, the story is trapped at the emotional depth of a LIVE LAUGH LOVE sign rather than developing characters and scenes in a novel way.
No. Everything that happens externally seems created by the author to give the narrator a reason to reminisce, and by a few paragraph in to the story, it becomes somewhat maddening.

No, the story doesn't offer the reader any actual turns here. I think this is, in part at least, due to the fact that it's super hard to care what happens to these characters. Maybe that's just me being ornery, but all the tuna sandwiches and crossword puzzles in the world can't salvage, for me, the story since it's devoid of what would pass for real human emotion. There's nothing unexpected here, making even the specifics offered feel washed out and insignificant.

No, there's nothing diverse about any perspectives here. Maybe the mother would offer something of importance or connection? but because this is a world filtered through this frankly unbearable narrator, we'll never know.

No, and this is the element of the story that produces the most ire in me because it's clear that there's *something* the writer is trying to do in this story! But whether it's the "lifetime of shared moments and cherished summer afternoons," the horrible "vintage peppermint-stick candy in its window," or the familiarity that "[wrapped] itself around me like a cozy blanket," the writer settles for the well-worn path of cliche at EVERY opportunity. To quote the narrator, "My heart shattered into a thousand pieces.

No, there's not originality in structure, language, style, genre, or format, as far as I can tell. The story is told in a super linear fashion, and the writing itself doesn't offer anything memorable in terms of innovative style or voice.

No, there's nothing unusual or original here to be had. Somehow, the story manages to miss the mark on all the criteria for lasting impact--it neither entertains, informs, provokes thought, challenges beliefs, provides comfort, not raises awareness. The story, in fact, seems hostile toward taking on novel or original ideas, luxuriating instead in the tried and true cliche of narrative and language.

No, here again, there's only a smidge of meaning offered even at the surface level since these characters feel too quaint to be real, so the possibility for subtext is entirely off the table, I'm afraid.

No. First, I must say that it's in the specifics offered that the story gains any traction at all; although by the ending I find the same ol' specifics tedious, upon first mention, sentences like "| made us tuna salad sandwiches, heavy on the pickles, while Mom set out glasses of iced tea garnished with mint from her garden" give the illusion of a real world in some form or fashion. Additionally, the narrative seems almost entirely controlled by a weird obsession with food; every event or action is described through an organizing feature of whatever twee meal they prepared and enjoyed together. It's unsettling.

No, and I'm sure by this point in the response, the rationale is obvious: The story as a whole feels in service of Teaching Someone About Nostalgia, and as a result, the characters become pawns created only to further this agenda.
I thought the "waking from a dream" ending was not effective at the end. It felt abrupt felt jarring next to the mysterious narrative up until that point. It felt contrived and unsatisfying.

I think the story has a cohesive unity, focused around the question of the relationship of the narrator to the people in the house, and what past events defined that relationship. The discarded chair is an interesting element that is sustained through the story. The ending is a bit unsatisfying and abrupt, but I don't think it negates the cohesion of the story up to that point.
I thought there was a good balance, the action of the scene, i.e. the rainstorm, what the narrator sees in the window, is set in combination with their explanation of their feelings and memories.

I thought the pacing was good. The action plays out in a way that builds tension and suspense while not being too drawn out. The compression of time in the form of memories (e.g. "I remembered vacations by the sea, laughter over family dinners, quiet moments and deep conversations. A lifetime of memories I thought lost forever in the abyss of death came rushing back to me in that moment.") worked because the details of these experiences were less important than the need to establish that the characters were family members, separated by death.

The charred and crumbling chair, which suggests a fire in the past, and the flood, which suggests the opposing, cleansing water element are used well. The language also suggests a connection between the narrator and the old couple without explicitly naming it until the end.
I thought there is a good balance between what the narrator is witnessing, and their description of its meaning for them, as well as their memories.

Throughout the story new details are revealed that allow the reader to understand the relationship between the characters better. This is done subtly, and not too explicitly. A major turn is the revelation that the narrator has died, which requires the reader to recalibrate their expectations about what is happening, and what the purpose of their following the older couple is.
We have only the perspective of the narrator. Although we don't learn much about the couple, the fact that they are always at a distance heightens the feeling that this is a dream.
The story felt original, and avoided cliches.
I don't think the form or structure was original, although I do credit the story for the gradual and subtle way that important details are revealed.

I think the story prompts the reader to think about the nature of death and whether memory can exist once a person is gone physically. The story also asks the reader to wonder about how the person died, and what their relationship with their parents was like.

The physical distance and separation of the narrator from his parents seems to represent a kind of distance of time, as well as perhaps emotional distance. The remnants of the charred chair suggests some past catastrophe which is connected to their relationship, and possibly to the death of the narrator.

Even though the world is dreamlike and surreal, particularly when the flood begins to rise, it feels well developed. There are details like the way the rain falls, what the chair looks like, and the creak of the front door of the house.

Only the narrator's character seems well developed; the two people in the house seem flat and two-dimensional. However, in the context of the story, this is effective, since the people seem like people can appear when one is dreaming.
The ending felt abrupt and not satisfying. I felt some of the questions I had, such as what the attraction was to these two people, was not resolved.

I thought that this story had some interesting elements, but was also somewhat incoherent, and so I thought it did not pass this test. Overall, the story makes sense, if it is also somewhat strange. It isn't clear why the narrator is drawn to these people; he says it is because of the woman's hair, but we don't get any more clue than that. The significance of the chair was also not obvious. Some details, like the man's hand around the woman's neck seemed out of place.

There is a lot of scene here, and the reader is left to guess about the motivation and back story of the narrator and his relationship, if any, with the couple. A few more details would help to fill in the gaps.

I thought the pacing was good. The voice of the narrator drives the story along; the language is simple and takes the reader along in the current of the story. Nothing feels too compressed or too stretched.

The narrator's voice is halting and repetitive to some degree, and I thought this use of language was effective. It seemed to suggest that the narrator was a bit obsessive, or not quite in his right mind. The allusion to the chair was also interesting, even though I wasn't sure what the significance was; perhaps the idea is that, in comparing the woman to a piece of furniture, which is discarded by a man, we are supposed to imagine a similar fate for the woman? I am not sure.

I thought the story balances the mundane action happening in the world (i.e. the two people walking home and going in their building) with the internal swirl of the narrator's own thoughts and interpretations.

The suspense and tension created by the voyeuristic perspective of the narrator makes the reader interested in what will happen, and also why the narrator is doing what he is doing. The flooding at the end is surprising, but doesn't seem too out of place, and serves to heighten what seems like the urgency of the narrator's account, and the fact that he seems psychologically troubled.
The perspective is that of the narrator completely. The other characters are objects of his gaze and obsession.
The story seemed original, and avoided cliches.
The form and structure did not seem original.

I'm not sure what the original idea would be. I may be missing the deeper significance of the story, but I didn't feel like the underlying message was developed all that well. The takeaway for me seemed to be all about the narrator's insistence that he was connected to the couple in some way, while I also got the sense that he was unhinged and perhaps imparting significance to things that weren't all that significant in reality (the woman's hair, her freckles). It seemed to me that there was a great disconnect suggested by the phrase "I don’t know how long she stayed like that, unmoving, but we must have been a sight to see," i.e. the narrator inserts himself into the tableau which, to anyone else, would probably resemble a strange voyeur staring at two people going about their lives in their home.

There are likely layers of meaning that I do not quite grasp. The details and attention given to the chair, the flood, and of the woman's face all suggest subtext and a guide to the author's meaning. However, I was left unsure about what that might be.

There was a lot of detail about the physical world, including the long list of things floating by in the flood, as well as the details about the outside of the building and the inside of the home. The

The narrator is the character that is developed the most, while the other two people seem to be there only as an object of the narrator's interpretation of what was going on. This seems to be by design, in order to enhance the idea that the narrator is actually creating a reality for himself that may not accord with what others in the world might see and understand.
The end could have happened anywhere in the text, and where the ending came felt arbitrary. I did not understand what happened at the end.
The story seemed utterly incoherent to me. I didn't understand what was happening, or what any of it meant.
It was unclear how scenes were related to exposition, since it wasn't clear even what was happening.

It is difficult to judge the pacing, since so many elements of the story seem to be jumbled fragments with little connection to each other. I can only say that the pacing of the story did not serve to make the story any more enjoyable or understandable.

The language was pretty nonsensical. In the instances where metaphor was used, it seemed strange, and also as a cliche. For example: "Maggie was the burned chair. Life had scorched her blooming spirit, but somehow the remnants of that joy still perpetuated, like a phoenix from the ashes, rising stronger and more resilient.

The distinction between interiority and exteriority is not clearly delineated. For example, this paragraph: "I stood by the railing looking at the geraniums, the river, the rusty van, and the little knob of glass that at this moment resembled a seal’s eye. The stranger knocked me sideways. There was an altercation. The seal rolled from its perch; the water swirled round it; the wind screamed; the terrier barked; and as if all distractions were thus swept from between us, I saw indubitably for the first time and then forever the sight that no mortal eye has seen—the sight that is given to that bird flying with twitched wings, to the gull in the crash of waters, to the invisible owl—but never to a human being, blinded by the mist, buried in the fog, plunged into water, isolated in the crowd. And a great shiver shook the skeleton of the world and little silver bullets splintered in the air." Are all these jumbled things "happening" or are they in the mind of the narrator? It is not clear.

Many things that happened were surprising (e.g. "My head was wet. My socks were wet. My hands were shivering. I had stepped back—I had stepped into something cold and silky—to ice on a slope—and the smooth deep surface yielded to my feet and received me and supported me—I was upright and yet lying horizontally in the space far away from here.") This passage is surprising because the action is disconnected from all other elements of the text. It is ineffective and not appropriate, other than to support an absurdist narrative.
I'm not sure the story presents any perspective with any coherence.
I think the story avoids cliches for the most part.
Form and structure does not seem original
I have no idea what idea the reader could take away from this. It didn't make any sense.
Again, because nothing makes sense, and everything seems jumbled and disconnected, it is hard to discern any meaning, either on the surface, or as subtext.

Not much in this story is believable as the real world. It feels like a dream, with a lot of disconnected vignettes that have no relation to each other. Descriptions of the physical world don't make sense. An example: "Now the sun, which was old and tumbled like a clown across the great countryside of the clouds, splashed them—for trees were now in leaf—and they blazed out, like a shop window, green; and then were dark again, more dark than ever, since they had been green
The characters, including the narrator are not developed with any complexity or coherence.
The ending is unsatisfying because it doesn't make much sense. Why did the restoration of the old chair lead to the apartment becoming a beacon of inspiration?

The story's elements do not make a lot of sense together. It is not clear why Evelyn is so drawn to the couple, why they invite her in, why Evelyn doesn't just ask Clara and Samuel about the chair, why she is exploring an abandoned library, how she happens to find a notebook that explains (somehow) the origins of the chair, and why the chair's restoration leads to such hope and inspiration throughout the city.

Some of the summary passages seem to need more detail, and so they make the story confusing. All of a sudden the people all seem to be photographers, they are connected in the images they create. This seems vague and not connected to what has come previously in the story. Additionally, how did they "piece together the forgotten narrative of the chair"? This seems to require some more detail and explanation.

For the most part, the pacing feels right. There are some points where time is compressed in a way that obscures what is happening, such as "With Clara as their guide, Evelyn and Samuel embarked on a journey to capture the essence of the city in their photographs. Through the lens, they discovered hidden pockets of beauty amidst the destruction." Is this action happening immediately after Evelyn met them, or over a longer period? How much time passes from this point to when Evelyn is exploring the abandoned library?

Some of the language is vague, such as "[their photographs] spoke volumes, capturing the resilience and indomitable spirit of the human soul." Other passages are odd and don't seem to fit the tone or the action that is supposed to be taking place, for example "The couple's foreheads rested against the glass, their breath leaving foggy imprints in the cold air. Their bodies moved with a fluidity that was both mesmerizing and peculiarly synchronized. It was as if they were dancing with the storm, an unspoken connection binding them together." The story does not make sophisticated use of literary devices.

I think there is a good balance here. There is action going on in the world, which Evelyn is reacting to, and we understand her thoughts through the narrator's voice. The problem is that some crucial details about why she is interested in the things happening in the world are left out.

The turns in the story don't seem appropriate. Why is Evelyn following the people, and why do they let her in? The coincidence of finding the notebook that explains the origins of the chair seems overly contrived. Additionally, it isn't clear why Evelyn is so interested in the chair.
The single perspective is that of Evelyn. We don't really get the perspective of Clara and Samuel.

The writing seems original and manages to avoid cliches for the most part. Some exceptions are the vague expressions that come toward the end of the story, e.g. "they transformed the dilapidated apartment building into a sanctuary of creativity and connection"; "The trio's sanctuary became a beacon of inspiration"; "dance with them in the face of life's storms.
The form and structure are not original

I think the reader will be left thinking a lot of detail and meaning has been left out of this story. I did not feel connected to the characters, or invested in the story. The relationship between the people was vague, and the reasons for why the restoration of the chair brought such happiness were unclear.

I couldn't really discern any meaning below the surface of the narrative. The meaning of the burned chair, and how it is related to Evelyn's encounter with the couple is not clear to me. The ending part of the story seems overly contrived and leads to an unsatisfying ending.

The details of the physical world are not developed in a convincing way. For example, Evelyn follows the couple home, and apparently can see all the details of the interior of their apartment while standing outside. This is confusing and not realistic. The rising waters are described without much specific detail.
None of the characters seem very developed, and I didn't feel invested in what was happening to them. We don't have any understanding of who Clara and Samuel are, or why Evelyn is drawn to them.

I'm not sure if this is personal taste or not -- I always feel that "it was all a dream" endings are not earned, regardless of context. Technically, the dream makes sense narratively, as it served to point out the character's flawed relationship with his parents while there was still time to do something to repair it. But my whole qualm about "dream" endings -- written by humans or AI -- is that it almost always feels abrupt, and tries to wave a magic wand to excuse any irregularities that came before.

The story is rather clever in that way -- there are elements of it that don't ever seem to come together to find the whole. (The abandoned armchair, for example, is never really explained and never pans out once it's introduced.) The theme of the rain washing the parents and home away is also a bit odd and disconnected. But by "revealing" at the end that it's all been a dream, the writer can get away with bits of unreality by citing "dream logic." It feels a bit like cheating, but technically speaking, it works.

The story exists mostly in summary: "Soaked through and through, I pressed my face up against the cold glass of the window, peering into their home. Their conversation was muted through the glass but I could feel the warmth of their bond, the unconditional love and understanding borne of a lifetime together. A lifetime I had once shared with them, before my quick passing.

There's not really any manipulation of time -- the story takes describes one singular incident. There is some compression of time while the character stands outside of the house and watches his parents inside, but that felt appropriate. Unless they're doing something really interesting, I don't need to be a voyeur alongside him!
I didn't notice any idiom, metaphor, or literary allusion, no -- but it's a rather short story, and I'm didn't miss them, either. The story didn't feel less sophisticated for not having them.

I suppose so -- again, it's a short story and there's not much action, as most of it takes place with the character standing outside of a house looking in. There's not much exteriority at all, but it makes sense within the context of the story. We do get some exterior details, like the rain coming down, flooding, etc. Otherwise, we're mostly in the narrator's head as he observes and tries to remember.
Technically speaking, yes. Personal preference aside, the turn that it was all a dream is both surprising and appropriate, even though I personally dislike it. God knows it's a trope for a reason.

There are no perspectives aside from the narrator. He's observing his parents inside of their house, and it's very specifically stated that he can't understand what they're saying or interact with them in any way.
As discussed earlier -- and which I will continue to discuss ad infinitum -- the dream reveal at the end is a terrible cliché. The cliché to end all clichés.

Not really -- I suppose there are some fantastical elements that you could argue are genre-bending, like the character observing and briefly interacting with his parents after his death. But the question specifically asks about originality, and as discussed earlier I tend to think that the "it was all a dream" set-up is horribly un-original. So I'm answering "no" to this question.

Perhaps -- the story ends with the narrator realizing that he was given this dream to mend his relationship with his parents in the real world, before it's too late. That could be a takeaway that a reader would glean something from. ("I called out to them but the churning waters muffled my cries. And as the flood swallowed me whole, I awoke with a start in my bed, my heart pounding, tears streaming down my face. The dream had felt so real. I knew then that I had been given a chance to make peace with my past and found closure at last. My restless spirit had come home.")

Everything is pretty surface level here. "Memories welled up and flooded my senses. I remembered vacations by the sea, laughter over family dinners, quiet moments and deep conversations. A lifetime of memories I thought lost forever in the abyss of death came rushing back to me in that moment." "I knew then with utter certainty that my wandering spirit would find peace only when the last of the secrets hidden within that little yellow house were laid bare.

The rain began to pelt me as I hid under the tree. Soaked through and through, I pressed my face up against the cold glass of the window, peering into their home. Their conversation was muted through the glass but I could feel the warmth of their bond, the unconditional love and understanding borne of a lifetime together." "The rain soaked through my clothes as I shivered in the cold, but still I could not turn away. They finished their meal and drew the curtains. Time stretched on as I stood half-concealed under drooping oak branches, kept company only by the steady crash of rain." There are good sensory details in the story.

There's really only one character, the narrator, and the trauma he endures in the cold rain, but it's certainly developed -- that trauma leads to him having a revelation that he must repair his broken relationship with his parents. (As quoted in an earlier answer.)

Again, the story feels bizarre and surreal, but the ending feels as earned as the rest of it. Though I have no idea why, the narrator feels connected to this couple that she's followed, even as she floats outside of their home. It feels arbitrary, but in the same way that the entire story feels arbitrary -- meaning, in the context of the rest of the story, it's natural and earned.

I don't think so, no. The story is bizarre and surreal, and there are elements of unreality here. ("I noticed them because everything else in my peripheral
vision shifted but they did not. The wind was blowing the leaves, the leaves were dying and leaping, and the couple was so still. The couple was unmoving." "I don’t know how long she stayed like that, unmoving, but we must have been a sight to see—the current pulling, the thunder, me almost submerged, but looking up, up, staring at the glass, at this person with the closed eyes and the imploring hair, the neck, freckles everywhere, skin like a burned chair.") It's unclear why the narrator followed the couple home -- aside from the woman's hair, which does not seem like a satisfying reason -- and her motivation and fascination remains unclear throughout.

I would say that the beginning of the story is more of a scene ("I saw the couple out of the corner of my eye. I noticed them as I stepped out of a medical building.") as well as the end ("Floating, I looked at the fourth window from the right. The couple resembled a photograph, so still, the man’s manicured hand, his beautiful hand, on the neck of the woman, her eyes shut, and her dark eyebrows reaching up in mild surprise.") and much of the middle is summary ("It made me stay longer than expected, and the rain wouldn’t stop. The rain continued. It felt heavy on my shoulders, and it rose. The water reached the backs of my knees, a flooding.")

Yes, there's a lot of very interesting compression and stretching of time in the story. ("It made me stay longer than expected, and the rain wouldn’t stop. The rain continued. It felt heavy on my shoulders, and it rose. The water reached the backs of my knees, a flooding. I did not think to leave, instead I walked back and forth in it, in front of the red brick, steel, iron, and glass building, her building, and in the middle of the street, which now looked like a swamp." "So it was the three of us as everything else moved,constant and full and wide.")

Yes, the story uses these devices. "This flood wasn’t like the ocean, but I pretended that it was." "It was the curl of it on her neck and on her forehead, the way it looked like a question mark, circuitous and pleading." "Hers was a plain face, really, as unremarkable as a piece of furniture. A face marked with freckles.

I suppose, yes. There is exteriority and observation. ("I imagined the impulse of someone purchasing a new chair, deciding to throw this old one away—picking it up with their knees bent and their lower back engaged,a contraction in the abdomen, separating it from their other possessions, and this object (made only for laziness or rest or gathering) being moved down a flight of wooden steps, being carried and offered to this sidewalk, sloppily, an old chair left to perish, and I imagined, too, the person who might have burned it, probably a man (men expect things to have violent ends) with a lighter or a match and the smell of a cigarette on his thumbs.") The story is written in such a specific, personal, and evocative way as to get a strong sense of interiority, although technically it doesn't really appear on the page.

This is a hard one to answer -- I said no because you are forced to accept the bizarre oddities of the prose and this world from the beginning. There's some distortion of time, apocalyptic flooding, etc. But it's present from the start, and once you buy into it, there aren't any turns within that structure.

Although the narrator is following two other characters, they're really the only character present in the story. I didn't think that the unlikable oddities of the narrator were presented sympathetically: "When the light turned on in the fourth window from the right, on the second floor, I felt relief. I became aroused. There was sweat, sweat on my nose, and my bowels were ready. There was water—the rain that was still coming down and the sweat that was still coming.
It's certainly that! Again, I feel that every copy and paste I've provided so far -- and in subsequent answers -- has proved originality!
It's certainly original! I think you could look at just about every bit of text I copied and pasted to get a sense of that. There's nothing in this story that's rote, nothing about it that's not odd.

While the story is certainly unique and original, I don't think that readers will take anything from it. One need look no further than the ending scene/thought: "I don’t know how long she stayed like that, unmoving, but we must have been a sight to see—the current pulling, the thunder, me almost submerged, but looking up, up, staring at the glass, at this person with the closed eyes and the imploring hair, the neck, freckles everywhere, skin like a burned chair." What would a reader take from that?

If the story is trying to operate on the level of subtext, it's doing it so effectively that the subtext is entirely lost upon me. I'm sure that there might be an attempt at subtext going on, but I couldn't really put my finger on it or articulate it if asked. Which is, of course, the point of this study!

I found this pretty evocative: "The gathering water rose to my thighs. It smelled of things in the moment before their dying. Objects floated past me—empty condom wrappers and large pears and extension cords, wet books full of soft paper (paper like cotton), nail clippers, peppermints, plastic spoons, dead mice, jars of unopened whipped honey. Rising water. This flood wasn’t like the ocean, but I pretended that it was. I kicked my legs. Waves formed, the current was taking me, and the rain wet my hands.

The narrator was pretty flat throughout -- there was no motivation, no evolution, no articulated desire. Even the arousal that was described isn't really attached to any desire to do anything. "When the light turned on in the fourth window from the right, on the second floor, I felt relief. I became aroused. There was sweat, sweat on my nose, and my bowels were ready. There was water—the rain that was still coming down and the sweat that was still coming.

There is nothing natural or earned about the ending -- it as bizarre as the rest of the story. It ends: "As the young couple fled from the flood, I began my retreat with a whisper, "Go now, Maggie, and find solace in the beauty of your resilience."" Why is the narrator fixating on Maggie and ignoring Tom? Why is Maggie resilient? Is there actually any meaning in the phrase "find solace in the beauty of your resilience"? Solace from what?

I have no idea what this story was trying to do. There was a beginning, a middle, and an end in the loosest sense -- the narrator encounters the couple (I believe Maggie and Tom, although confusingly it seems as if Maggie could refer to a couple of different people within the narrative), the narrator observes the couple, and then a sudden and apocalyptic flash flood sweeps the couple away while the narrator watches. But I would describe this as a beginning, a middle, and an end only in the sense of where they fall within the story. They serve as narrative markers no more than any other three random events you could pull out of a hat and place in a #1, #2, and #3 position.

Almost all of the story is described in scenes as the narrator follows Maggie and Tom around: "Through the window, I saw the young couple, Maggie and Tom, enveloped in a mundane domesticity; their voices floated into an idyllic tune as they spoke about the bills, the window latch that was stuck, and the leaking roof. The terrier sat upright on the rug, the perfect picture themselves – but I remained fixated on the image of that burned chair.

There is some compression of time to keep the story brief as the narrator follows Maggie and Tom. For example: "My curiosity left me no choice but to quench it by discovering more about this enigmatic couple. I soon found myself standing in front of their peeling blue door.

Yes, although the attempts aren't always successful. Some are ("The river swelled; massive feathery heaps of filthy foam dashed their banks. Gusts of wind surged through the city, an orchestra of alien harmonies accompanying the staccato of rain.") and some aren't ("The terrier sat upright on the rug, the perfect picture themselves" "Maggie was the burned chair. Life had scorched her blooming spirit, but somehow the remnants of that joy still perpetuated, like a phoenix from the ashes, rising stronger and more resilient.").

There really isn't any exteriority -- the only action we get from the narrator is the decision to follow Maggie and Tom and observe them. But the story is one of observation, and the narrator only seems to focus on admiring Maggie rather than doing anything.

As I mentioned earlier, nothing in this story makes sense, so it's really difficult to have a turn. There can only really be a turn in the narrative if you're surprising the reader by subverting their expectations, and this story is so random that there aren't really any expectations to subvert. Technically, it's surprising to have a countdown that goes A, 4, Q, 2, 9 -- but that's less an intentionally done turn and more just nonsense.

The only perspective in the story is the narrator's. As we're only observing Maggie and Tom, we don't get to see their perspectives, except from faraway observation. ("their voices floated into an idyllic tune as they spoke about the bills, the window latch that was stuck, and the leaking roof.") We're told random things about them, like that Maggie is resilient, and that Maggie is joyful even in the face of adversity, but we're only told those things; we don't actually see them evident on the page.

Again, although the piece of writing does not contain any clichés, I can't think of it as original due to how nonsensical it is. You could string any random series of words together and it would technically be original. My criteria for answering this question is whether or not the story is original in a way that makes sense -- and this is not.

As discussed above, I feel strongly that nonsense -- a lack of character, plot, or any cohesive quality -- does not equate to originality. Anybody can string together nonsense. It doesn't make it original!
I would be absolutely shocked if anybody could derive anything from this mess. I was barely able to follow it. Again, it's fairly nonsensical, and there's nothing to glean.

Everything here happens on a surface level. There's not really and interior thought or reflection. Take, for example, this paragraph: "I wandered along the path that followed the curve of the river. The sight of a damaged chair propped against the wall burned into my memory. Scorch marks across its once elegant floral pattern told a tale of misery and abandonment. O, could that be the new chair Maggie spoke of? My curiosity left me no choice but to quench it by discovering more about this enigmatic couple. I soon found myself standing in front of their peeling blue door." We're not even invited to know what makes the narrator curious -- is it just that he wants to know if this is Maggie's chair? -- or to know why the curiosity is so strong as to "leave him no choice." He's just curious and then, bam, he's at their house.

Yes, there are sensory details in the story. "My head was wet. My socks were wet. My hands were shivering. I had stepped back—I had stepped into something cold and silky—to ice on a slope—and the smooth deep surface yielded to my feet and received me and supported me—I was upright and yet lying horizontally in the space far away from here." "There was a scullery smell, a smell of dumplings and dish-cloths, rising like steam from the earth; and one grape hyacinth lay crumpled in the grass; and all this great landscape was contained in a cracked looking-glass that leaned against a wall.

There's not really any plot, so I'm not sure how there could be character development. The narrator doesn't change over the course of the story, aside from recognizing and then indulging in their fascination with Maggie and Tom. As Maggie and Tom are only observed by the narrator -- the narrator is only getting glimpses of them and their lives from far away -- it's difficult to get any sense of development or momentum from them.

The ending is a little... off. It pulls out from the characters we'd followed previously and focuses on a community that had not been present prior in the text. ("And so, as the rain clouds receded and sunlight bathed the city once more, a community bound by resilience and connection emerged. They had weathered the storms of life, finding solace in the thread that connected them all - the enduring power of human connection.") Still, it's not so abrupt as to be truly jarring, as this comes only a paragraph after describing the power that the restored chair had on the world around them.

Yes, the story makes sense as much as it can. It feels intentionally vague and mystical -- there's a lot that we never know, and a lot that's "just vibes," but there is a beginning, a middle, and an end. In the beginning, the narrator, Evelyn, encounters a mysterious and compelling couple, Clara and Samuel, and decides to follow them. In the middle, she watches them through their apartment window while they have sex during a rainstorm. In the end, she meets Clara and Samuel and is brought into their relationship.

There aren't really any scenes in the story -- while we do linger on some moments, like Evelyn standing outside Clara and Samuel's apartment, we're not really presented with the information as scenes. Take, for example: "Without uttering a word, the woman extended a hand toward Evelyn, inviting her into their world. It was a silent invitation to embrace the enigmatic connection she felt, to dance with them in the face of the unforgiving storm.

And so, in a city awoken by catastrophe, a discarded chair, a couple entwined in ethereal dance, and an observer entranced by it all, converged. The floodwaters had receded, but a deeper connection had risen from the depths of chaos, forever etching itself into the fabric of their lives.

Evelyn stepped across the threshold, venturing into the sanctuary of their apartment. The couple welcomed her with open arms, as if they had been awaiting her arrival. They introduced themselves as Clara and Samuel, two wanderers who found solace in the art of connection."

The dialogue and interactions are glossed over; we don't get a specific sense of a scene unfolding so much as a summary.

Yes, there is compression of time: "As the days turned into weeks, Evelyn became an integral part of their unconventional trio." "As time passed, Evelyn's fascination with the burnt chair grew." There are also moments where we linger on Evelyn and the characters: "The couple's foreheads rested against the glass, their breath leaving foggy imprints in the cold air. Their bodies moved with a fluidity that was both mesmerizing and peculiarly synchronized. It was as if they were dancing with the storm, an unspoken connection binding them together.

Yes, these are present in the text. "They strolled hand in hand, their steps perfectly synchronized as if they were connected by an invisible thread." " It was as if they were dancing with the storm, an unspoken connection binding them together." "Entire streets were submerged, cars turned into forgotten relics, and the world outside seemed suspended in eerie stillness.

Yes -- although clunky, there is both interiority and exteriority, sometimes within the same paragraph. For example: "As time passed, Evelyn's fascination with the burnt chair grew. Its presence haunted her dreams, a symbol of strength and survival amidst the chaos." Interiority! And then: "She embarked on a quest to uncover its origins, tracing its history through fragments of memories shared by the city's inhabitants." Exteriority!

Yes, I'd say that it's a turn when Clara and Samuel invite Evelyn into their relationship, because there's nothing that might imply that in the story prior -- they literally have zero interaction before that moment. There are also hints -- although these are not followed up on -- which indicate that Clara and Samuel might be timeless beings of some sort. ("One day, while exploring an abandoned library, Evelyn stumbled upon a weathered notebook. Its pages were filled with sketches and poems, recounting the tale of a couple who forged an unbreakable bond in the midst of a devastating fire. The story echoed the experiences of Clara and Samuel, hinting at a connection that spanned generations.") While the random quality of these reveals may seem or feel inappropriate to the rest of the text, I think that the odd setup -- Evelyn feeling entranced by this couple and following them home to watch them have sex -- is weird enough that it allows for some strangeness in the rest of the story.

No, there aren't really any perspectives aside from Evelyn's -- as noted earlier, even when Clara and Samuel are present in the text, they don't really say anything. We get no sense of their character outside of a vague idea of mysterious aloofness and attractiveness.

The story is certainly original, but I'm not sure that it's without cliché. It does well in the beginning, but as the camera pans out and things get more and more general as the story progresses, it delves more and more into cliché. ("The trio's sanctuary became a beacon of inspiration, inviting others to embrace the enigma of the burnt chair and dance with them in the face of life's storms.")

As discussed earlier, it does feel like there is some genre hybridity here. I was drawn, in particular, to the mention that Clara and Samuel are timeless beings of some sort. ("The story echoed the experiences of Clara and Samuel, hinting at a connection that spanned generations.") This implies that Evelyn's attraction to them may have a supernatural connection or element, and that the "resilience" discussed in the story may be fantastical in nature.

Not really -- the story tries to put a bow on this notion by telling us that there is indeed a "moral of the story" that we can take home with us. ("They had weathered the storms of life, finding solace in the thread that connected them all - the enduring power of human connection.") But I personally think it's a bit of a stretch to look at a story about a woman stalking a couple and watching them have sex and argue that the reader will take away a lesson about the power and strength in human connection.

It's hard to tell what's subtext when the story is operating with a clearly intentional sense of enigma and obfuscation -- Clara and Stephen are indefinable, and, I think, intentionally so. Still, everything between Evelyn and Clara and Stephen feel surface level: Evelyn is attracted to them so she follows them home, they have a zest for life so they have sex all throughout the storm, they invite Evelyn into their relationship and fix the burnt chair to prove their link to the life around them. Every motivation behind an action is intentional and pretty spelled out in the text.
We know what things look like, but we aren't invited into the level of sensory detail that encompasses touch, taste, sound, etc.

The characters are intentionally vague, it feels -- Clara and Samuel aren't really given any defining characteristics aside from their "resilience," they don't have any dialogue, and they're pretty much blank slates for the reader to interpret however they want. I think that this is intentional, and that they're meant to be portrayed as kind of "mystical beings," but it doesn't change the fact that the answer to this particular question is "no.

I think the narrator immediately finding peace after seeing his parents was a little too convenient. it felt unearned (the narrator regained his memories and then all was well) rather than actually confronting any challenges.

The story follows a narrator who is drawn to an old couple, and it is unclear as to why he is drawn to them. Eventually, the narrator realizes that he is a ghost and that the old couple was his parents, which was a cool twist. i also liked the image of the flood and how the narrator was unable to escape the earth. The ending was a little confusing in that the narrator somehow found peace, but I wasn't sure what that meant for him as his character wasn't super clear.

The story was really mostly summary, with elements of scene really only used for exposition. I would have appreciated some dialogue or actual interaction between the man and the old couple, or some scenes of the guy's concrete memories (in-scene as flashback). Because of this, it was hard to get close to the narrator or really understand what was happening at all.

The story was actually paced really well, with it really only encompassing one moment is a man's life (or, well, afterlife, in this case). I think it could have used some expansion because right now it's not very clear what exactly happened, but the pacing was fine.

The story's language is fairly simple; I think the flood is supposed to be a metaphor for something, but I'm not sure what it was supposed to mean. The rocking chair, too, seemed to supposedly be a symbol, but it was never made clear what it was supposed to be/perhaps it was forgotten about.

I found myself wanting for deeper interiority of the narrator, as while I could see what he was feeling ("Memories welled up and flooded my senses. I remembered vacations by the sea, laughter over family dinners, quiet moments and deep conversations. A lifetime of memories I thought lost forever in the abyss of death came rushing back to me in that moment.") because they were summarized, I wasn't actually able to understand what this meant in terms of his character other than being sad about the past. The flood was great exteriority, but otherwise, I wasn't really wowed by any of the detail.s

i found the fact that the narrator was actually dead to be very surprising. I was also surprised to find out the the old couple he was so fascinated by was actually his parents. The turns made sense for the story and made me enjoy it more.

I didn't really feel close to the narrator as it was hard to access his past or feelings. We got how he was feeling in the moment but didn't really get to see how he had lived previously or what exactly happened between him and his parents. As such, he read more like a sketch of a character than a real guy.

The story is pretty basic; a guy who is dead sees an old couple who ends up being his parents and feels regret but also peace. It's kind of a traditional "dead guy" narrative; it was only really interesting in the twists that it had.
The story is formatted in a linear style, which is fine and actually works for it. i don't think a story needs to be formatted in a weird way unless it's integral to the story in and of itself.
The twists with the narrator being dead and the old couple being his parents were really interesting. I felt like that was pretty creative and inspiring for some of my own work!

Not much really happened in this story other than the narrator realizing the old people were his parents. I think the story almost gets to meaning re: the man finding peace with not being able to follow his parents, but I wasn't really sure what the story was trying to say.
The setting was clear and I especially liked the house and the flood. There was a rocking chair that was described well and the story's tone felt believable as well.

The characters didn't really develop but I didn't feel like the old couple needed to. I wanted to know more about the narrator but also the story seemed like a small vignette rather than a story about a large character arc. I would have liked to see more emotional complexity and background within the narrator, but it was fine that there wasn't much development as that doesn't need to happen in every story.

The story's point of telling makes sense in that the narrator is recalling a specific instance in which he saw a couple pass away together. It seems that this memory is stuck in his mind, and that he is unable to extract meaning from it, so he keeps replaying it. The ending, with the detail of the woman's skin and its relation to the chair he saw earlier in the story, was really interesting. I liked that the ending felt natural but not forced or necessarily wholly conclusive.

The story follows a narrator who is interested in a couple, who he follows and watches die peacefully. The story's ending was a great sentence, and I appreciated the narrator's oddness and draw toward ugliness.

Yes! The man's descriptive recall moves well in-scene; I feel like summary is used for moments that are less important. Most of the time, he follows his memory in-scene and uses great sensory details that add to the story rather than seeming random.
The story was paced well. it covered a single memory in a man's life, and the transitions between locations were smooth.

The narrator details water that smells like things right before they die, as well as a triangle in his position in relation to the couple. The images were strange and interesting while still remaining abstract.

The narrator recalls an experience of seeing a couple die. It seems that this memory has been stuck in his mind for a long time. The retrospective telling of the story tells us more than the narrator's actual insights within the story, but that's part of its power.

I was surprised that the couple died and the narrator witnessed them. I wasn't expecting that to happen and it made sense for the story in that the story was about the fleetingness of life and the absolute randomness/unfairness of death.
The story didn't have diverse perspectives; it really only followed one narrator. But most stories have a single narrator so I don't think this is important here.

As I said in the last question, the story is a bit cliche in that the rain symbolizes grief/makes the mood more melancholy, an old chair is used to represent age, etc. So the images were cliche but the story was good.
The story makes surprising use of line breaks rather than just occurring in paragraphs. That was fun and didn't really add or take away from the story though.
Not really; the story was just about a guy witnessing death. I feel like a lot of stories cover this topic but I don't think the stories always need to be doing things that are wild and crazy.
The story does have multiple layers of meaning in that the present story is active and engaging, and the retrospective POV also tells a different story. This was smartly crafted.
Yes, the world feels believable and lived-in especially due to the sensory details. The details the narrator noticed seemed purposeful and made sense.

None of the characters really develop but that doesn't seem to be the point of the story. The point of the story seems to be that the narrator is unable to make sense of the randomness and unfairness of death.

I don't understand how the narrator learned the names of the characters he was watching if he didn't know them. Also, I don't know why the narrator didn't do anything when he saw the couple's house getting flooded? Just really strange decisions.

The story has a really corny realization that Maggie is the scorched chair, which doesn't even make sense as a metaphor. Also, I don't understand where the narrator is physically if he's seeing a river flood someone's house but is fine?? Also why doesn't he do anything? It was kind of an annoying story because the logistics didn't make sense.
The story was told mostly in-scene, even though those scenes didn't make sense. Still, the scene-summary balance was fine.

The pacing of the story is fine but the storm kind of comes up completely randomly and conveniently towards the last third of the story. It's like a sudden shift for convenience's sake rather than a build-up. But, the pacing was fine despite the story not making sense.
The story was overwritten and didn't really make a lot of sense. The primary symbol, the burned chair, didn't work and was over-explained, as if begging for meaning or relevance.

I don't understand the narrator's decision to do nothing as he saw the couple's house flooding. The narrator watching the flood completely fine while being situated close to it also didn't make sense? We need to know where the narrator is physically within this story.

The addition of the storm in the narrative seemed completely random, and I don't understand how the narrator was standing around completely fine in a storm that was allegedly washing away a couple's entire house? The turns weren't justified and really didn't work logistically.
No, the narrator is the only persepctive we inhabit. Still, that's fine as the story is from one point-of-view.
The story is so bewildering that I think in some ways it is original (in that it doesn't make sense). But the use of weather and the burnt chair as a metaphor really are terrible.
The story follows a linear fashion which is fine. Originality in form and structure aren't really important most of the time in literary fiction.
I think the average reader would be wondering what is happening logistically. The story also doesn't really have meaning and the last line from the narrator makes no sense.
No, the story doesn't really have any meaning at all. And the scorched chair metaphor is awful.

It's impossible to know where the narrator is situated/the extent of the flood, so the world doesn't make sense in relation to the narrator. Also, the flood happens extremely fast and I don't understand how the couple wouldn't know their house was about to get washed away.
The narrator is kind of insane in that he just watches a couple's house flood. I don't understand the line he says to Maggie or how he even figures out her name. It's just really weird.

The story's ending feels natural but not earned. I'm not sure why the couple would invite the narrator, who is a random stranger who was stalking them, into their home. This is never explained and I found the relationship between the narrator and the couple to not make sense.
The characters in the story don't make sense and the chair as a symbol of human resilience was really corny. It felt like a story for kids but not in a good way.

The story's important moments seemed to be summarized, actually, most of the story seems to take place in summary, with no real-time dialogue. The scenes seem to focus on the wrong details and the way the writer describes Evelyn's emotions seems too distant from the POV they are writing from to work.

The pacing of the storm is kind of weird; it happens in one day and then the narrator and the couple take pictures and then restore a chair. It's hard to understand how much time is passing and it creates for a confusing timeline.
No. The story didn't use any symbols or literary devices that were meaningful to the story except for the chair, which felt overexplained and really as if the writer were grasping for a metaphor.

The narrator's distance from Evelyn seemed too far, and Evelyn also did a lot of things "just because" or "because a force compelled her" rather than her actually having any true motivation. As a result, there was really no useful interiority and the exteriority of the storm wasn't really fleshed out.
The story has no turns. The couple inviting Evelyn to join them in their apartment without knowing her at all and her having stalked them was a surprising turn, but not one that at all made sense.

Clara and Samuel make no sense as characters. I don't understand why they invited a random person into their apartment and told her intimate details about their life in a matter of days of knowing her.

The writing is really cliche, with the chair being fixed as a symbol for the city finding its way back to itself. It read like a kid's story with a moral but without anything meaningful or interesting to say.
No, the story follows a linear albeit confusing timeline, so it wasn't original. This wasn't really a problem except for the confusion re: time in the story.

I think the average reader will really be wondering why Clara and Samuel invited Evelyn into their home. It also doesn't really make sense that Evelyn would stalk them all the way home and watch them just because they seemed interesting; there's something pathological about that.

No, the story really tries to obtain meaning through the chair, but it hits it too hard on the head and none of the characters make sense so the chair situation seems random. This story was probably the worst of the four.

The flood doesn't make sense and it's hard to envision the world because its sense of scope is so confusing. We don't really feel the characters inhabiting the city and yet the unnamed city is such a focal point of the story.
None of the characters develop and they are all two dimensional. All three have no true character or motivation.

Of course, the ending is abrupt. But it is clearly by design, and I think it is successful. As I said earlier, I'm not sure if I understand the author's meaning completely, but the idea seems to be that these people's time together is fleeting, and will end, with nothing to follow.

I think the story is successful as a unified whole. I can't say I understood the meaning of the end, and I was a bit confused about how the Bob Dylan lyric, and the European movie (which movie was being referenced), and the person's poem written for her all fit together. However, the reference to the sudden ending of the movie, and the sudden ending of the story were interesting and provocative. Some of the foreshadowing earlier in the story suggested that perhaps this trip wasn't going to end well (e.g. "Later, they would both show the cove photos to the people waiting for them at home, the wife and the husband. Or that’s what she imagined.").

The scenes are vivid, of ambiguous in their meaning.
