There is plenty of detail that helps the reader imagine the tension in the car as they drive to the beach, and the beer-drinking beachgoers in the distance even as the two main characters seem to be drifting apart from each other (literally and figuratively). I do think these scenes are balanced well with background information and exposition, which also include important details that fill in the gaps about the main characters, such as their imagined farewell at the station the next day.

I think there is good balance between the stretching of time in the description of scenes, such as their swimming in the cove. Things that happened in the past are not compressed too much, and we get interesting details, such as the gentle chiding of the Europeans they meet, and the exasperation of the house manager.

I thought this story is successful; even though there isn't a lot of literary allusion or metaphor, some of the allusions are interesting. These include the reference to Girl from the North Country, as well as the repeated theme of photos the two took. I like this, because it suggests that the main things that will remain from the encounter between these two people are the photos. The line "that's the way I remember her best" comes to mind from the song, even though it isn't mentioned explicitly in the story. These references are subtle (I may even be imagining them!), but overall they create a very nice atmosphere, a sense that all the attempts of these two people to enjoy their time together is really not working, and that there is nothing really that will follow from it.

Dialog and action is blended well with the main character's inner thoughts and interpretation about what is happening. This is effective, for example, when the two are apparently enjoying themselves at the beach, but she is actually longing for a beer from the other strangers.

The story kept me guessing along the way, but never became unbelievable within the context of the narrative. The author created a lot of tension, to the point that I imagined that something terrible might happen while the two were swimming at the cove. The fact that it didn't kept me wondering, and sustained the tension, right up until the end of the story.
Although we do get some insights into the man's character that give him some depth, his perspective is mainly hidden from us. The sole perspective is really that of the woman.
The story seems quite original and avoids cliche.
I thought the allusion to "certain European movies" that end suddenly, which then becomes the actual form of the story, was original and interesting.

I think the reader is left wondering about the meaning of the end of the story. It seems like there is an interesting idea here about how things end, whether they be art (e.g. films and short stories) or relationships. It made me think about the idea of what is "supposed" to happen in both. Art normally requires resolution (or at least, we expect resolution in art), and it is jarring when it is absent. And yet, in life, things pass unresolved all the time. Putting these two ideas together seems like an original and sophisticated idea.

There is rich subtext, as the main character seems continually conflicted about whether she wants to be where she is, doing what she is doing. On the surface, she is carefree, riding to the beach with the guy she met, skipping the ceramics and the museum, and whatever else. And yet, she is unhappy and unsatisfied, longing for a beer, imagining that if their relationship continued they would only hate each other. This tension is maintained throughout the story.

There are many sensory details that make this world believable and vivid. Some examples are: "He made a quick, nervous veer for an exit, her water bottle rolling off the dashboard"; "Some mornings, the wind knocked over the wicker furniture on the patio and blew tree branches onto the cracked tennis court and everyone stayed indoors, waiting silently for their turn at the Nespresso"; "Already the sun was drifting toward the ridge—it was later than she thought. She moved her towel to stay in the sun.

I think both of the main characters are developed pretty well. The woman is more complex of a character, because we have her point of view. However, there are details about the man that give us some insight about him as well, for example, "I miss you, he’d write to her later, back in the States, though the nights she went to his room he was nervous and spoke to the ceiling and they mostly just talked and he seemed relieved when she crept back to her own room"; references to his basketball shoes and big American swimsuit.

The ending seems arbitrary, mainly because no significant action or conflict has taken place. The concluding idea is vague and doesn't really reveal anything about these characters: "Heather and Del continued to build memories, existing together in an intricate balance between wanting and fearing.

This story was really incoherent, and felt like a kind of fever dream. Much of it did not make sense, and if we boil down the action, it is basically just two people standing together on the beach (with one occasionally laughing for no reason).

There is a balance between scene and exposition, and we have a blending of dialog with narrator's commentary. There are a couple of passages where the dialog is (inadvertently I suspect) very funny. I laughed out loud at this passage: "Heather's voice exuded warmth like the sun they'd been watching, as she replied softly, "I imagine the sun sinking into the sea, like melting gold flowing into its lover's embrace."

Del considered her words while still standing idly with uncertainty and a hint of suspicion. A malicious inner turmoil forced him to confront the gnawing question of whether to maintain his doubts or to give in to that spark of romanticism. Did she mean the sun melting the water and evaporating it, boiling the ocean's organisms into a state of life-extinction, or drying up the world until it became nothing but black sores of star-dust and cosmic desolation?

Del shifted on his knees and glanced down at his toes, where bits of seafoam playfully tickled the wet hairs. Dismissing his skepticism, he stifled his anxieties and decided to accept it as a poetic image. Putting on a brave smile, he said, "That's beautiful."
If intended as comedy, it is great, Del is utterly unaware about Heather's romantic take on the situation, has no idea what she is talking about, and yet manages to say something obliquely romantic as well. Was comedy the intention of the author (or the artificial intelligence that produced this)? I'm not sure.
Time is stretched much too thinly in this story, since nothing significant (or coherent) seems to happen.

A lot of the language is just strange and nonsensical. Some such passages include "However, she managed to laugh louder and louder until her laughter transformed into an embrace of the sun's atmosphere"; "Her head melted back into her flip-flopped shoulders, and her joy seemed genuine and resounding. Del's surprise turned to heightened uncertainty, his footing unstable like the sand beneath his feet"; "He placed a wager against himself about the idea of diving past the sea-streaks of red-purple heavens and plunging into the sweet ache of burning pleasure that light-burn caused behind his peeled eyelids. The cold seagrass would attempt to wrap around his legs like a sea creature, hungry for attention, persistently gnawing and nibbling its way beneath him. Del smirked at the idea of a slight tinge of burning pee that no one would ever know was there except him.
Much of the narrative seems to be the interior thoughts and interpretation of Del. There isn't a lot of action happening in this story.
Although the things that happen in the story are utterly strange, they aren't appropriate, and just seem nonsensical.
The main perspective is that of Del, and there isn't much in the way of Heather's perspective.

The problem isn't that the story relies on cliches as much as the language is convoluted and doesn't make much sense. An example is this passage: "Beachside, with the night young and Heather's chest filled with an innocuous laugh, he felt a renewed sense of hope. Time never seemed to move more slowly than when it kept pace with Heather's thoughts, all woven and adorned with the very shades of fascination that clung to their seaside forms.
There isn't anything original about form or structure.

I don't imagine the reader will come away with any unique or original idea. I could not really make much sense of what the takeaway would be. There is little in the way of conflict, character development, and it is not even really clear what the story is about.
There doesn't seem to be much of any meaning, either on the surface or below it.

The world does not seem real, instead the story evoked a dream where everything was kind of strange and a little off. There are elements of the real world, but they are arranged in a way where they don't quite fit together properly.
The characters are not developed in any sophisticated way. They say things and react in ways that don't seem realistic.
Nothing really happens after the characters reunite, and so the ending is basically "they stayed together in love until they died.

Much of the story is vague, and so it is difficult to become invested in the lives of the characters. What were the challenges they faced at the beginning to be together? Why was their love story so extraordinary? The second half of the story goes on and on and repeats the same ideas: art brought them together and their love endured. It is not a very interesting or satisfying story.
There is more narrator exposition, and some more scenes with dialog between the characters would help to give them some depth.
The chronology after they reunite is both vague and drawn out, so we don't get many interesting details, and yet the text continues for much longer than it needs to.

The story doesn't make very sophisticated use of language, which is often vague. Metaphors tend to be commonplace and not very effective. For example, "their love matured like fine wine"; "Sarah's hand found its place in Max's, threads of connection once again intertwined." There is a lot of weaving, intertwining, and etching going on, in a way that feels repetitive.
It would help if there was more action happening, and more detail about what conflict was involved in Max and Sarah being together. What was at stake, what did they overcome?
The main "twist" in the story is that Sarah and Max reunite, which is appropriate to the narrative, but not all that surprising. After that, there are no further conflicts or significant events.
The main point of view is that of the narrator, who treats Max and Sarah's points of view as virtually interchangeable. We don't really understand their differences as individuals.
The story avoids cliche for the most part; the main problem with the language is that it is vague, we don't have any details that make the characters interesting or worth caring about.
There isn't anything original about the form and structure.

There is not really anything for the reader to sink their teeth into here. Max and Sarah meet, they can't stay together for some reason, then they reunite and can be together for some reason, and then they stay together happily until they die. There doesn't seem to be much meaning beyond this.
There doesn't seem to be any meaning or complexity below the surface narrative.

The world feels very two-dimensional. There is a beach, a sunset, a studio, but not much beyond these vague outlines of physical reality. Even the dog feels random, and not really connected to anything else in the world or the story.
Both characters seem flat and not very developed. We don't know anything about their back story, their history together, or what distinguishes them from each other.
The ending feels natural. We know that this is the final chance these two have to be together, and that they have to go their separate ways. It thus feels appropriate to the story.

The story is coherent, and each action leads logically to the next. We understand the circumstances of this trip to the beach, some of the back story, and the impermanence which is at the heart of the story.

There is also good balance between action in the scenes playing out on this particular day, scenes from the past, revealed through Jane's memories, and summary based on her memories (for example, "He had been quietly confident, making wry observations about the eccentric group of creatives thrown together in communal living. His sardonic humor and reticent thoughtfulness had drawn her in immediately. However, her shyness held her back from striking up a conversation with him that night."). The scenes would be improved by more specific detail in the dialog between the two during their time together. For example, this paragraph would be improved with more specific detail: "Jane opened up extensively about her work, her past, her family, and her hopes while Mark listened intently, drawing out more details with his astute questions. She was surprised by their easy rapport, how fully she felt seen and how at ease she felt opening up to Mark. He recounted amusing anecdotes from past relationships, travel misadventures, eccentric neighbors and life in the city. His wry observations and witty stories kept her spellbound throughout the long, golden afternoon.

The pacing feels appropriate, the story is told over the course of a day, with Jane's memories filling in the blanks in the past to help the reader understand the history between these two. Nothing feels too drawn out or compressed. Two paragraphs are repeated in their entirety, which I assume is not intended.

The story does not make sophisticated use of these devices, but at the same time the simplicity of the language is not necessarily a weakness. Where metaphors are used, they are not brilliant, but also not awkward or over the top. For example, " She felt anchored to him by invisible threads, being reeled in bit by bit with each furtive look across the mess hall.

I think there is a good balance between Jane's thoughts and interpretation of events, and the events and action themselves. Again, some more detail in the dialog at the beach would help to give more depth to both characters.

There are not really any surprising turns in the narrative. However, the story does build tension through Jane's thoughts about Mark, both in her memories at the artist residency, and in the car and at the beach on this day.
We seem to have Jane's perspective exclusively. Mark is something of a cipher for her thoughts.
The story does seem original, and avoids cliches.
There isn't really anything original about the form and structure.

I think the reader comes away a bit disappointed by the story overall. There is enough detail about the events leading up to this day, and about the tension that exists between the two people, so the reader is. invested in them and what happens. Furthermore, the ending is not inappropriate, since we know this relationship must end. However, a further turn of the narrative, or something revealed about either of them during the trip to the beach would make the story more satisfying. As it is now, there is not much of an original idea for the reader to chew on.

There is not much development of themes below the surface of the main narrative, i.e. that these two are attracted to each other, and even though we wonder how it will play out, we know it will end. There is not much in the way of subtext beyond this.

There are good details about the physical world that help to make it believable. Some examples include: "Jane gripped the sun-cracked vinyl seat, glancing over at Mark behind the wheel. His brow was furrowed, focused on navigating the treacherous turns through the coastal fog. The radio played softly, an old jazz tune Jane vaguely recognized filling the silence between them"; "The Dodge emerged from the woods into a sandy clearing. The fog parted to reveal the wide blue ocean stretched endlessly before them, azure waters lapping at ivory sands"; "The chilled water was bracing, raising goosebumps on her bare skin.

Jane's character is pretty well developed, but Mark seems very two-dimensional. There is an opportunity for the reader to learn more about him during their time together in the car or at the beach, but the story doesn't develop in this way.

The ending of this piece is outstanding; its lack of resolution is clearly appropriate and earned. The entire story builds towards this moment of open-ended dissatisfaction and comparison between the protagonist's affair partner and a previous, more satisfying one (who is, evidently and importantly, not her current husband). It is a deeply nuanced and moving moment of interiority and humanity in which the reader uses what they have learned and inferred throughout the story to fill in the gaps. The fact that we leave the story in a state of unresolve and longing for more artfully simulates the subjective experience of the story's protagonist.

This is an excellent, expertly-written short story. The author doles out information in a stingy, deliberate, highly satisfying way. By initially withholding crucial information - who the protagonist is, what their relationship fully is to their partner, where exactly they are and why - the author induces curiosity in the reader; through skillful revelation and implication these questions are answered and hinted at wonderfully. This is a lean, textured, and viscerally human piece of fiction in which every thought, utterance, and detail adds to the reader's enjoyment.

The future moments conveyed in the first three paragraphs of this story's third page (later referenced to as "the next day") comes in a more summary, expository mode than the rest of the piece, which unfolds in scene with brief dips into further-past exposition. All of this is additive to the story.

The story begins in media res, which is to say in the middle of the action, plunging the reader into a situation that must be deciphered by the reader. We experience this intimate scene at a languorous, appropriate pace before zooming into the conditional future, learning things that the protagonist does not yet know, creating a resonant dramatic irony. This adds meaning, depth, and context to the piece's open-ended conclusion.

idiomatic language like "People must have acted dumb," "apron of concrete" (this might also be construed as metaphor, but apron in this context is also an idiom for the entrance to a driveway), "doggy-paddled" adds nuance and complexity and meaning to the text. Through the use of such language the author deepens the readers understanding of the characters' (in particular the unnamed female protagonist's) relationship to the environment they are vacationing in (presumably Spain).

This piece does an incredible job of balancing interiority with exteriority. Its use of free indirect speech ("people must have acted dumb all the time," "would either of them mention this was the wrong beach?" "this is the part where - ") to convey the protagonist's thoughts creates an intimate, subjective, and immersive reading experience. We experience what the protagonist does as though we are the protagonist, despite the story being told in the third person.

This story is full of fascinating revelations and turns, largely created by the author's masterful use of narrative withholding. We are constantly learning new things that add meaning and context - that the protagonist and the man who initially appears to be her boyfriend or husband are each married to other people, that they meet at the residency as opposed to having gone there together, that she is significantly older than him... These revelations keep the reader immersed and engaged throughout the piece.

The protagonist, clearly, is beautifully rendered. We understand her to the degree and in the fashion that one understands oneself - which is to say, both intimately and not nearly enough. She feels complex and human because of, not in spite of, her contradictions. Similarly, her partner, who we minimally understand through her perspective, feels like a human being that one has just met and whom we can't decide whether we respect or not. Reading him through the protagonist's perspective feels startingly true to life.

This language in this story is fresh and conveyed with originality. For example, the universal experience of being so different from others in a new environment as to feel alien is expressed in a fresh and specifically detailed way in the single-sentence second paragraph of the third page: Some mornings, the wind knocked over the wicker furniture on the patio and blew tree branches onto the cracked tennis court and everyone stayed indoors, waiting silently for their turn at the Nespresso, and that's when she looked around and thought, Who are these people?

This piece excels on both the line and form levels. The author makes unconventional decisions, like eliding quotation marks around dialogue, that create artful and immersive effects. The reader has to slow down and think in order to understand whether statements are dialogue or thought, and if so, whose. Grammatical structures like comma and em dash usage create complex, idiosyncratic sentences. Clauses are connected in ways that convey causal and contextual meaning. 

Example: They'd brought beers and an opener and towels from the residency to that first beach-the house manager had been angry.

In that sentence, list-like repetition of the conjunction 'and,' coupled with the specificity of "that first beach," implies an amount of effort that contrasts with the absence of and protagonist's desire for beer at "their last beach," at which the story mainly takes place. Connecting the independent clause "the house manager had been angry" with an em dash to this list implies a bewildering causal relationship that is explained in the following sentence. Reading this sentence meaningfully *feels* like it would to be the protagonist, only realizing that she had committed an infraction after the fact.

This story places us into the headspace of a specific woman experiencing something highly personal to her. Yet what she yearns for - human connection, freedom, release - are universal wants. Feeling these desires through her unique perspective induces contemplation and empathy in the reader.

This piece has an iceberg of subtext floating underneath it. The entire story is conveyed through the successful integration of subtext and text. The interactions between the protagonist and the man (Did you see me jump of the rock? No, she hadn't. Did he notice she had gone in the water too, that her hair was dripping? No, he hadn't.)convey a profound disconnect that causes the reader to wonder why the protagonist continues to suffer the presence of this man she clearly disdains and seems to view as an incompetent man-child.
Though this piece is spare with description, its details are specific and skillfully chosen. The sentence noted in the previous answer is a strong example of the author's world-building ability.

The protagonist is a complex, challenging, real-feeling woman, full stop. Her depth of feeling and observations, and her contradictory contempt for her affair partner (and perhaps herself) absolutely mirrors the complexity of a real person.

I do not understand what transpired to cause this pat, overly-resolved conclusion in which Del and Heather come together as one. This story is baffling overall, making it difficult to make sense of what actually happened at all, let alone how the conclusion connects to the rest of it. It's essentially a "happily ever after" ending that is simply asserted rather than derived from what came before.

This piece is so...adjacent to being coherent. It seems to be obsessed with conveying poetic-seeming imagery that doesn't actually make sense. There is no character arc to speak of, but rather an abrupt asserted resolution that does not connect logically from what came before. The descriptions of Del and Heather's actions, and Del's thought's specifically, feel like an alien describing human beings without having encountered one.
This story is one 21-paragraph scene onto which a summary and expository ending is appended without perceptible cause.
The piece unfolds as one long scene in which things happen almost randomly. Del answers questions that were never posed to him. There is no compression or stretching of time to speak of.

This piece goes wildly overboard with attempts at metaphor and figurative language that only occasionally approaches meaning. The sea is obsessively and meaninglessly described as a variety of colors "as though a whole tanker of oil had been spilled on the water," wading closer "in an attempt to absorb the last of the blues and the oranges and the purples and the reds into a wild dance of harmony and discord at the same time." Frequently this language is explicitly explained to the reader: "a love story etched in both the shifting sands and the transient waves, forever a testament to the mosaic of emotions they crafted together as one.

We frequently dip into Del's interiority, but the things he thinks are confounding. When Heather says she's thinking about "the sun sinking into the sea, like melting gold flowing into its lover's embrace," (an unlikely thing for a human being to say), Del wonders if she means that she's thinking about the sun literally sinking into the sea and extinguishing all of the life within it, and this thought is expressed in almost erotic figurative phrasing. It's bizarre.

The surprsing things that happen in this piece are surprsing because they are random and nonsensical. Del smirks at the tinge of his secret, burning pee? He tells Heather that he always wanted a fish for a pet, answering a question that is not present in the text?
There are two characters in this piece, and both do and say things that make no sense. They are not understandable as human beings.

This story says a lot of original things, but they are incoherent. What are "flip-flopped shoulders"? It uses imagery from a set of themes (color, sun, sea life, sand) in a rigid, obsessive, Terminator-like fashion without seeming to understand what the words actually mean.

There are occasional uses of unconventional sentence structure: 

She glanced at the water-a splash of blue-or the sand-a gentle brush-or the sky-a sea of blank space holding together this delicately balanced world-and found nothing to distract her gaze. 

However, this odd grammar does not read as intentional, and the idea being expressed seems self-contradictory. To the extent that one's gaze can be "distracted," isn't that exactly what's being described by that list of sights?

This story seems to be affixed to a romantic, painterly depiction of this couple's relationship, but in a way that doesn't seem to make a lot of sense. The themes of color, sun, sea life, and sand are obsessively adhered to without saying much at all.

This story reads as almost deliberately opposed to subtext. The nonsensical actions, statements, and thoughts of its characters are frequently explained directly to the reader:

"I did always want one of those fish as a pet," Del finally answered...although he had said that, he knew he didn't actually want one-it was merely a measure of whimsy masquerading as a deep desire.

That is a typical selection from this piece, in which things that don't make sense are followed by meticulous explanations that are themselves confusing.
This world of this story is hard to understand on a basic level. "Sea-streaks of red-purple heavens"? "Tiny flecks of sand that had bitten her feet for the past nineteen days"?
These characters are difficult to conceive of as real human beings. They consistently behave in bizarre, erratic ways that are vaguely adjacent to, but discordant with, actual human behavior.

The summary and abrupt ending goes on and on in an agonizing series of attempted conclusions, each of which follows the same formula of an initial time-setting clause attached to a trite attempt at poetic description, followed by a "happily ever after"-style conclusion.

Ex: "As the night deepened, and the stars sprinkled across the sky, they made their way back to the residency. Every step they took was slow and deliberate, their hands occasionally brushing against each other, but the weight of their imminent departures loomed between them.

In the days that followed, time seemed to slip through their fingers like the sand on the beach. Sarah found solace in her art, pouring her emotions into each brushstroke, while Max immersed himself in the solitude of his studio, weaving his experiences into the very fabric of his creations.

Finally, the day of their departure arrived. Tear-filled farewells were exchanged, along with promises to stay in touch. With heavy hearts, Sarah and Max bid the residency town adieu and boarded separate flights to their respective homes.

Months passed, filled with missed calls and unanswered messages. Life's demands had reclaimed their attention, and the ephemeral relationship they had built on that beach seemed like a distant memory. Yet, in the quiet moments of the night, Sarah and Max found themselves inexplicably drawn back to that special place, their hearts forever tethered by the bonds they had shared."

This move repeats over and over, and in fact makes up the majority of the text.

This is a superficial piece of writing in which flat caricatures of human beings behave in rote, simplistic ways. It attempts to end in a long series of oddly similar paragraphs that circle narrative closure but never land in a meaningful manner.
The scenes in this story are simplistically rendered, and the summary/expository attempts at an ending are not believable.
While the story does attempt stretching and compression of time, it is done in an incoherent, unbalanced manner that does not read as intentional. The above answer is an example of what I mean.

The language in this piece is overly-familiar and trite, with actions described the way one has seen a million times before. Sarah "gathers her thoughts," "takes a deep breath," and "tucks a stray strand of hair behind her ear and avoids meeting Max's gaze." If these phrasings were not so firmly embedded in the culture they would be examples of plagiarism.
There is little to no meaningful interiority in this story.
This story articulates a flat, simplistic understanding of human life that seems devoid of the complicated actions and thoughts of real human beings. There are no "turns" to speak of.

The characters are rendered in a flat, caricatured fashion in which their every thought and action is explicitly explained away, even though these thoughts and actions are transparent. 

Ex: Taking a deep breath, Sarah gathered her thoughts, searching for the right words to express the swirling turmoil within her. "We've been avoiding the inevitable, Max," she finally said, her voice tinged with traces of sadness. "During our time here, we've grown closer, and now that it's almost over, we can't just pretend like it never happened."

Max's eyes softened, his hand gently reaching for hers. "I understand, Sarah," he whispered, his voice filled with a mixture of comprehension and sorrow. "But how do we move forward? How do we navigate this complexity without unraveling everything we've built?

The language of this piece is full of cliches. "Their love matured like fine wine," "they strolled...hand-in-hand," "they remembered...the stolen kisses." Virtually all of the turns of phrase in this piece can be found elsewhere, and presumably were.

This is an algorithmic approach to storytelling that follows a set of rigid moves and sentence structure. The one original move, the odd 2.5 pages of repeated attempts at an ending, cannot be intentional.
The themes and content of this story are overly-familiar and derivative. There is nothing to take away from it, because it does not convey an understanding of human feeling or thought.
This story is superficial and goes out of its way to avoid subtext and explain every thing away, even though those things are obvious at a grade-school level.

The descriptive language of this piece is vague and straightforward. The town is repeatedly described as "idyllic," for example, rather than that meaning being conveyed through subtle and artful use of language.

The characters are rendered in too flat and simplistic a manner for them to feel real or complex. The things they say are literal and devoid of human-like meaning:

"Perhaps it's enough to acknowledge what we feel, to cherish these moments we've shared without putting unnecessary labels on it." 

"I can do that, Sarah. As long as we're on the same page, as long as we understand that this is a space we've carved out for ourselves, separate from the rest of our lives.

Like the 3rd story, this one falls into a circular pattern halfway through, though not to the same extent. However, the story exists on such a superficial plane, in which the characters are static and simple, that the ending just sort of happens. There isn't much to resolve in this piece. The characters begin it knowing that their time together will end soon and end it aware that there time together is ending.

The story repeats itself several times in an attempt to satisfy its prompt, creating an illogical path in which Jane says and thinks the same things, typically in the exact same language. Other times, it seems to 'forget' what has already been established, so that we are told that Jane feels self-conscious in her swimsuit under Mark's appreciative gaze (thus, we know he can see her in her swimsuit) only to slip off her sundress (a contradiction) in the next moment with Mark once again gazing on her appreciatively.

There are only the thinnest whisps of scene in this story. Rather, the reader is told what happened and how, then has why what happened matters explained away:

"Jane felt the residency was ending too quickly. Over the past month, she had started and scrapped three paintings, unable to focus because of her preoccupation with Mark. Her thoughts kept drifting to his dark eyes, his deliberate way of considering a question before answering, the glimpses of humor he allowed to surface when recounting some absurdist tale of life in the city. She felt anchored to him by invisible threads, being reeled in bit by bit with each furtive look across the mess hall. The hushed, intimate dinners they had shared, making eye contact across the worn farm table, left her breathless in a way she hadn't felt for years.
Aside from the circular algorithmic trap that the story falls into, its story time is nearly static. There is no meaningful stretching, lingering, or compression of time.

The language in this piece is littered with trite, familiar phrases. "brow was furrowed," "pangs of longing," "tucked away in the woods," "lingering glances," "furtive looks," "stolen moments," etc. All of these expressions, when used by human writers, are employed thoughtlessly because they are so familiar as to almost autocomplete in the mind.
This story is told through Jane's interiority and subjective experience, but in a simplistic, summary fashion. She does not believably reflect a human understanding of the world.
There are no meaningful or surprising turns in this story. The things that happened are predictable, obvious, and deliberately explained to the reader. it operates as though the reader is oblivious.

There is no dialogue in this piece, so what the characters say is painstakingly expressed through reported speech: "Mark asked Jane about her own work. She explained her use of dramatic colors and abstractions to convey emotion, while he nodded thoughtfully." Rather than diving into their mindsets, we are simply told what they said and did, and generally, why. They are flat, simple approximations of human beings.
As indicated in some of my previous answers, the language of this piece is highly derivative, filled with basic analogies and phrasings.

This story proceeds in a  lumbering, rote, paint-by-numbers "this happened, then this happened, then this happened" manner. Outside of its odd loops of repeated ideas, it shows no originality in form or structure. The language is basic grade school prose.
This is a flat, derivative piece that contains no meaningful ideas.
This story lacks subtext altogether, though to a less aggressive degree than stories 2 and 3.

The world is simplistically rendered. The beach is "sandy," the cliffside road is "winding," Jane's studio is "isolated." Basic, rote descriptions. Because the story only vaguely hints at scene, there isn't really an opportunity for it to build a complex, unique, or believable world for its characters to inhabit.
The characters are flat, simple, automatons. They are too shallow to feel real.

The story's ending seems inevitable in that we know the man and woman are growing apart, and that the woman feels nostalgic and lonely by the story's end. The couple's parting is bittersweet and the ideas about other towns etc. allude to perhaps other futures the couple could have had. I loved the last line "This is the part where--" which ended with unusual punctuation and another potential ambiguous situation, which mirrors the themes of the story.

The story follows a couple who is growing apart as they try to find a specific beach. Their house manager is upset with them because of their mess and beer, and the trip to the beach (the wrong beach, not the one they were trying to find) results in the woman feeling lonely as the man goes for a swim. There's a gap in their ages that the woman feels self-conscious about. The man says he misses her once she goes back to the states, and as they're driving back, before she's gone, the woman listens to a Johnny Cash song that resonates with her. All of these elements work to emphasize the couple's parting and the fleeting nature of relationships, elements which the prose mirrors in its sparse matter-of-factness.

This story is mostly in-scene which is great and doesn't seem to drag. The use of summary adds to the narrative momentum (i.e. description of the towns, the house manager, etc)., allowing the scenes to achieve maximum impact.

The story has a dreamlike vacation quality to it, which makes sense as the couple is on vacation. The story's use of this hazy, dreamlike quality works with the ambiguous situation the couple is in with each other, as well as the slowness and strangeness of departures.

The story uses an ocean and the lost beach as an extended metaphor for people growing apart and ending up in the wrong places. The parting trains also serve as a metaphor and allusion to the inevitable parting of the lines of people's lives, but all of these devices are used subtly enough to feel earned and refined.

Yes! We see a lot of the woman's interiority re: what she thinks of her fleeting relationship with this younger man, and we also see a lot of external action re: the search for the beach, swimming, the car, parting etc. The woman's associative logic makes following her interiority in the way that it relates to her external circumstances interesting, and I enjoyed the way the two interacted smoothly.

Yes; the couple's parting is inevitable but the change in focus from the beach to the car to the trains is beautiful and surprising. I fell in love with the language and style of the stream-of-consciousness/associative logic of the piece.

The woman is an interesting character whose POV we dive deep into, but the man's perspective is more ambiguous. This seems to be a typical white couple on vacation which is fine and I don't think the man's perspective is really important to this story, which is more about the woman, but yeah the narrators weren't really diverse.

This story used some cliches (trains as symbols for parting, the ocean) but analyzed them in a way that felt fairly fresh. I think a story's power comes from its ability to describe how a moment feels for a specific person in a specific moment in time, which this story achieved. I felt like the narrative felt true and personal, which allowed me to resonate with it.

Not really until the ending. However, I don't think this story's narrative structure needed to be very original (this story seemed to be more about meaning/vignette than innovative structure, which was fine, as I feel like this structure was right for this piece).
Yes! I think an average reader will be able to think about loss and parting and the ways in which different aspects of life and time enact this.

Yes!!!!! Again, the idea of the story was fairly simple (the inevitability of age, parting, change), but it was illustrated in a way that felt inspiring re: questioning how these ideas relate and resonate throughout our own lives. It was really beautiful and I was left feeling changed at the end of it :)
Yes! The landscape of the house, the beach, and the car felt lived-in and truthful. I could feel the warmth and graininess of the beach, as well as the coldness of alienation.

Both characters are actually quite static, in that they don't change, but I think the story wasn't one that was centered around growth and internal change, rather, the inevitability of loss and nostalgia. Therefore, this story felt appropriate in its scope re: internal arcs but the characters weren't particularly dynamic.

The ending didn't really make a lot of sense, with Del and Heather "building memories" together for an ambiguous amount of time after the story's end. It just felt like nothing really happened in the story and that nothing had really changed between them.

The story used lots of adjectives and images that didn't really make sense or felt weird; i.e. "enigmatic horizon," "feeling the extended yet gentle silence between them" etc. and also felt too on-the-nose in its descriptions of people's emotions. The story was melodramatic with little sublety, and I found it to be a bit cringe-worthy.

I think the scene-summary balance was okay but none of the scenes or summary were interesting. I think the writing style just really threw me and I had a hard time actually understanding what the point of it was. There was too much concrete interiority that was too easily resolved by the characters just forgetting about what they were worried about.

The story's sense of time seemed to really encompass one day, but so much time was spent over-explaining Del and Heather's emotions that I quickly lost interest. I would have wanted to know more about inner lives that didn't feel really contrived.

The story's descriptions were really overdone, with lots of adjectives piled on or weird images created that didn't really make sense. I found myself losing interest the more of these came up, and thought a bit more subtlety or ambiguity could make the story more interesting.

Again, the characters interiority didn't make any sense. Externally, Del kept thinking about "invasive species" at random times, for no reason and without explanation. I don't think their interactions with the external world made much sense.
The story didn't really have any turns or surprises. As such, I can't really say any of the non-turns were appropriate.

The characters were really weird in that I didn't understand how they were working despite their emotions being described so explicitly. Heather says: "I imagine the sun sinking into the sea, like melting gold flowing into its lover's embrace" which causes Del confusion; he overanalyzes the statement but it's such a bad sentence that I don't know what to even think. Then, Del "smiles bravely" which also doesn't make sense. I think the characters just didn't really make any sense narratively so I didn't feel engaged by their perspectives.

The story managed to be both cliche and emotionally indecipherable despite the over explanation of emotions. Lines about the sun being golden or "Before his lips could reach hers, Heather burst into peals of laughter. At first, it seemed like a prelude to a warning, a gesture that she could stand and leave him there alone on the shore to wallow in his misguided affection. However, she managed to laugh louder and louder until her laughter transformed into an embrace of the sun's atmosphere." I really did not understand what the writer was thinking here.

The story followed a straightforward structure but nothing happened in the story except for them walking. It didn't really feel like a story in that it didn't really have a clear progression from beginning to end.

I honestly think that the average reader, like me, would be bewildered by this story and not moved by it because of the fact that the characters emotions don't make sense and because the story doesn't really have a beginning, middle, and end. it doesn't really feel like a story.

The language was really bad and I don't really understand what was going on between the two characters. Things resolve way too easily by the end and I felt really confused by the story's character and narrative decisions.

The story does seem to be set at a beach and that is successful in that I knew where the characters were. The atmosphere was a bit weak since so much of the story was spent focusing on indecipherable internality of characters.
As I have said quite a few times, the emotional narratives of the characters don't make sense as they behave kind of randomly and easily forget about their conflicts once someone laughs or something.

Sarah and Max die while thinking about their beach trip. I think my problem with the ending mainly has to do with problems involving the scope and pace of the story: the story follows Max and Sarah from the middle of their lives to the end of their lives, and time passes far too quickly for this to be interesting. The characters are one dimensional and only think about their beach residency which doesn't seem quite believable. They die also thinking of this residency rather than any other complexity within their relationship or in their lives.

This story made a lot more sense than the last one in that Sarah and Max had a clear problem: their residency ending, and a a clear desire to somehow reunite with each other. I don't think the story was great, but it did follow a cohesive narrative.
The story was basically all summary after Sarah and Max meet the dog. Time moves too quickly and without any significant problems that change them or help them grow.

The pacing of this story is way too fast, following Sarah and Max in summary from their middle to late lives. I's hard to know exactly how old Sarah and Max are when the story begins, and they don't seem to really do anything other than make art and think about their residency for their whole lives.

The story's descriptions were simplistic and childlike in a way that made the story kind of boring to read. There wasn't really any metaphor or any work being done at the language level to make the story have nuanced meaning. Essentially, Sarah and Max become successful artists but still remember their residency experience (which typically takes place during mid-career of an artist's life) so that doesn't quite add up. The story was told so plainly that I found myself really wanting for something more interesting to be done at the language level.
The characters really had no interiority. The story is mostly a summary of their successful art careers and their nostalgia for their beach residency.

The story has no turns and instead just follows a couple as they happily pursue art with no difficulty while still remembering this one beach residency that they met at. The story is predictable and uninteresting as a result.
The characters only think about loving each other and their beach residency. Because they experience no problems, the characters read as flat and unrealistic.

The story just had no problems that occurred within it and Max and Sarah had no personalities. There weren't really any cliches but the story just really didn't have anything going on within it; it felt very generic.

The story moves too fast and while it makes sense in a beginning, middle, end sense, the characters experience no complications, which makes for a pretty boring read. There was really no tension in the story even in the beginning when they knew they were parting.

The story wasn't memorable because it did not provide any new insight due to the scope of the characters wants and narratives. We also didn't learn anything about the art they were making or why they were making it, which made the story seem very vague and unoriginal.

No, as I have said, the characters have no internality as they only care about their residency and encounter zero problems. There is no subtext as there is nothing to have subtext about. I think the characters need to have more depth and desire.
We can at least see the beach residency the characters go to, as well as the galleries and studio spaces. While sparsely described, at least they are existing in physical spaces.

Again, the characters have no depth as they only think about how they are happy and that they are nostalgic for their beach residency. The characters don't grow at all from the time they meet to the time they die, and they are very preoccupied with this one residency for some reason which doesn't make narrative sense.

The story doesn't feel like it ends at the right place; because it ends before the residency ends, or because any tension occurred, it just felt like it ended before it was supposed to be done and that the author became tired and just ended it before the story's natural conclusion.

I found the story unsatisfying as it was written entirely in summary and I didn't really understand Jane as a character outside of her interest in Mark. She's at an artist residency, but we don't learn about her art, and she's kind of a flat and boring character. Nothing really happens to threaten her relationship with him within the span of the story; there are two days left in the residency but we don't really know what happens after, and there is no dialogue.

The story was completely in summary, with no dialogue or scene. As a result, I didn't feel close to the characters or embodied within the world. I would recommend adding more scenes so that the story is at least 70% scene to 30% summary (a more ideal balance).

The pacing was fine in that the story really took place two days before the residency was supposed to end, but I don't think the story started or ended at the right time because the story lacked the tension of time running out even when that was supposed to be the primary problem. However, the timing of the actual narrative made sense.
There are no metaphors or interesting images within the story. Characters are clearly defined and there is little ambiguity of originality in rhythm or phrasing.

The narrator's interiority was basically just about her being interested in Mark and nervous that the residency was ending. I didn't feel like anything insightful was being said and was therefore unmoved by the story and left wanting for more interiority that had greater insight on the world.

This story had no turns so I wasn't able to be surprised by anything within it. The narrator is basically just really into Mark for some reason (we don't actually get to know anything about his character), and doesn't do anything about it. Then the story ends.

Again, the narrator really had nothing interesting going on in her head. She was interested in Mark and worried about what would happen because the residency was ending, but didn't act on that desire or have any complex thoughts on it.
The story felt generic in that it was about a person who was wanting a person and worrying about time running out. It didn't execute this concept interestingly and thus fell flat.

The story was structurally linear and thus unoriginal. I actually don't think stories need to be original in terms of form and structure to be successful; most stories actually follow similar structures; it's more about whether or not a story's structure makes sense for it and allows the story to achieve maximum effect. That being said, this story's scope was too narrow both in terms of time and Jane's "want" which was pretty much to start a relationship with Mark even though we really don't know how he feels at all. The story could have spend more time in-scene with their interactions as well as what is at stake for Jane if she is unable to make this relationship work.

Because Jane's want is so narrow, I was unable to really resonate with any of the themes. As a queer person, maybe that's just because this is a white straight narrative, but I also think it's because I didn't really know anything about Jane and her art or what about Mark was so interesting to her. As such, the story was flat and uninspiring.

Again, because Jane's want was so simple, there was nothing that could really be taken from this story. I wanted the story to say something more meaningful about life or art, but the story was too consumed with Jane's crush (we also didn't know why she had this crush or anything about Mark).

The setting of the beach, car, and ocean were a lot more clear here than in the past two stories; I liked the detail about the car's color and vibe, as well as the temperature of the water and the sun.

Jane doesn't grow at all from the beginning to the end; she simply desires Mark and then doesn't do anything about it. There's not really anything that happens internally that she realizes or finds meaning in.

The ending is unrealistically tidy and incongruent with real life. Because the characters are flat and unrealistic, their behavior results in a conclusion that feels neither earned not satisfying. There was nothing really at stake in this story, so the unrealistically easy "happily ever after" ending doesn't resonate on a human or artistic level.

While this story is not well-written, it does follow a logical path. Its basic beats - Daniel being  disturbed by memories of his failed marriage and desiring to be present in his current relationship, his girlfriend Isabel listening to his concerns and suggesting that they visit his old flat so that he can seek closure, his appreciation for his new partner afterwards - make sense and unfold in a coherent way.

My impulse was to answer no to this question, because the scene work in this story is so rote and flatly rendered as to be effectively summary. But there is movement between scene and summary, experience and exposition. The issue is that the writing is relentless in explaining to the reader exactly what happened and why, leaving no space for inference and little reason to care. When Daniel wakes up from his dream, we are technically in scene - but also explicitly told that "Daniel realized how truly different they were," a summary bit of information that takes away the opportunity for the reader to become invested in the story.

The moments in this story that matter most - Daniel's interactions with his partner Isabel - are rendered in a flip, quick manner. This story is told as a series of expository summaries that do not allow for meaningful narrative pacing.

The language in this story is elementary are highly dependent on premade, overly-familiar phrases. There is little to no meaningful use of figurative language like metaphor. There are idioms present, like "tossed and turned" and "chipped away," but these are deployed in a perfunctory manner that weakens the writing.
While we do move between interiority and exteriority, both are rendered in a simplistic, trite fashion that prevents investment in the story and its characters.

There are two turns in this story, both of which make logistical sense: Daniel waking up from his nightmare, at which point the reader learns that he has a new partner and that Daniel's dilemma is the impact of his old relationship on the new one, and Isabel's surprising eagerness to help Daniel solve this problem.

The characters are far too flat to be believed. Isabel is almost cartoonishly virtuous, or at least unrealistically secure and helpful, both to Daniel and the story itself. She is a device that moves the story from one stage to the next, and lacks any of the depth and complexity that one would associate with a real human being. Daniel's rendering is only slightly better. His problem is easily solved, because he is devoid of the thoughts and behaviors of a real person. Why does simply looking at his old flat help him heal at all? We're just told that it does and have to accept that.

This story is a series of cliches and stereotypes. Daniel and Rachel were once "young and foolish," Daniel was pragmatic and careful with money and Rachel was a spontaneous, free-spirited artist - this is Dharma and Greg and a million other stories that rely on this specific gender dynamic. Similarly, Isabel is a loving, patient, selfless female partner who seems to have no wants or desires other than to heal and support her male partner. That isn't to say stories can't ever include these dynamics, only that they are so over-used and recognizable that no value can be taken from it if they aren't rendered intentionally and with artistry.

The language of this piece relies entirely on overly-familiar turns of phrase and stock descriptions: images flicker, city streets bustle, Daniel wakes with a start, there were cracks in the foundation of his marriage. "Cheap flatpack furniture" is the single description that I could identify in this piece that felt new or interesting to me. 

The structure of the piece is paint-by-numbers. Wake from a troubling dream (with a start), talk about it, a solution is instantly identified, problem solved. There is little to no care taken in making this sequence of events interesting or meaningful.

The characters and their actions are static and basic. Isabel is not believable at all, existing only to support Daniel and solve his problem. Daniel's problem, that he is troubled by memories of his failed marriage, is resolved far too easily to leave an impact on the reader.

This piece explains itself aggressively. "A pang of guilt shot through him. His kind, patient girlfriend deserved better than for him to still be troubled by a failed marriage from years ago" "Though they had only been dating six months, he was beginning to imagine a future with this caring, compassionate woman by his side." 

Then there is the exposed exposition placed into dialogue: "It sounds like your subconscious is trying to work through some lingering feelings about that time," she said gently. "Maybe there are still some loose ends you need to tie up about the end of your marriage, even after all these years."

This is the opposite of subtext.

The descriptions in this piece that are generally rote, vague, and overly familiar: "the familiar street looked shabbier than he remembered," "the sagging green sofa," "the little cafe down the street.
As mentioned above, the characters in this piece are flat and static, lacking human depth.

There seem to be a few attempted endings. the final one in which Daniel and Isabel connect by going canoeing, which he used to do with Rachel, doesn't really make sense. The story itself is incoherent, so the ending cannot be justified by what came before.

This piece is confusing and incoherent. Daniel has dreams of a flat that his landlord insists exists below his home, but Daniel has never visited. Then later Daniel and Isabel ascend to this flat, where Daniel previously lived (even though we were explicitly told he had never been there before. Isabel talks about her ex Gracie, then says: "Our childhoods shape us. I've grown since then." Did she date Gracie when she was a child?
This piece is far summary and incoherent to strike a balance between scene and summary. The time spent in scene is confusing and rendered simplistically.

Though there are gestures at narrative compression, they are really just moments of summary and exposition that skip over the work necessary to show who these characters are and why they do what they do. One could simply cut out the moments of compression:

"For days, Daniel thought of their pasts: his divorce from Rachel, Isabel's separation from Gracie, and the honesty they'd shared that night. There had been no cruelty in their former lives, no viciousness beyond the everyday struggles that grated and bent. Daniel wondered if he was not destroying something with his memories and his dreams, and if he was not letting them fall against the protective fences he had built around Isabel's and his own heart. Their shared pasts hung in the darkness around them, like shadows in a firelit room. And Daniel wondered if that was what he had wanted, to share his darkness."

...and there would be no meaningful effect on the story at all, other than it would make slightly more sense.

There is one interesting use of figurative language - Daniel's dreams persisting for weeks, "like a fire burning through damp straw." Other than this, the language in this story is either simplistic and trite (the memory of Rachel paddling the canoe "shines like a beacon"), or confusing. Daniel bringing up his dreams is described as "letting a fragment slip.
The story is too confusing and lacks interior logic. Its characters behave in ways that one cannot understand, regardless of interiority or exteriority.

Things more or less just happen in sequence in this piece, without causation that makes sense to the reader. Why does Isabel want to hunt for treasures in the rooms of the flat that Daniel has never entered nor seen, yet also lived in with his ex wife?
The characters are flat, inconsistent, and difficult to empathize with. They lack the depth and complexity of real human beings.
The only parts of this story that aren't confusing are cliched. "bridge the distance," "water and oil," "shining like a beacon," etc.
The story proceeds in a rote, step-by-step fashion using language that doesn't quite make sense ("he dove into his club soda miserably") when it isn't cliched ("like water and oil, we separated")..

When the piece isn't confusing, it is trite. The characters are automatons whose behavior lacks the complexity and agency of real human beings. No meaning can be made of them, their actions, or the story overall.
This piece lacks internal logic. It exists on a superficial, confounding level, from which no deeper meaning could be derived.

The world, when described at all, is done so inconsistently. Daniel dreams of a flat he's never seen or visited (how?), then we learn that actually he lived there with his ex wife. It is below his apartment even though he's never seen it, and he goes to it with Isabel even though he seems to doubt its existence and location.

The characters are flat and odd. They say things that lack the grammar and logic of real speech: "I keep seeing that old flat-it's a dream I have of that old flat, and it frightens me." "I wouldn't dare to find out.

The ending just sort of happens, and when it does it is as a doom loop of repeated attempts at closure. The story itself lacks the internal logic necessary for it to conclude in a meaningful, satisfactory manner.

This story lacks internal logic and consistency. The flat that Daniel used to live in with Rachel abruptly becomes a house with a backyard that he used to live in, seemingly with Rachel, but then it's as though he lived there with Isabel instead. The story ends with a long, circular series of attempted endings that digress into memories and experiences that don't seem to have any reason for being in the text.
This piece exists on a highly expository plane. It is a long series of short, declarative paragraphs that summarize, rather than show, what happened.
Time is compressed throughout this piece, and we do not spend nearly enough story time experiencing what happened in scene.
The language of this piece is elementary and devoid of meaningful idiom, metaphor, and allusion.
There is no meaningful interiority in this story. The emotions asserted to be felt by the characters are simplistic and unconvincing.

This piece lacks the internal logic and consistency for its turns to make sense. When things are surprising, it is because they contradict what has been previously established (the flat where Daniel lived with Rachel becomes a house where he lived with Rachel, then a house where he lived with Isabel; his dilemma goes from needing closure to a previous relationship to needing to connect with his current partner)
The characters are flat and unconvincing. They lack depth entirely.

When this story deploys novel phrasings, they only approximate coherent language. How does one's "heart pound with curiosity," or at least in what way can that heart pounding be distinguished from a heart pounding with dread? Why would curiosity make one's heart pound? What does it mean to say that "the simplicity of life was encapsulated in the rhythmic strokes of paddles against water?" This is word soup.
The story is conveyed through rote summary and exposition, until it enters a spiral of repeated attempts at ending.
The story is both inconsistent and derivative. It relies on stock emotions and interpersonal relationships that do not have the depth and complexity one associates with real human beings.
There is no subtext to speak of in this story. Everything is conveyed superficially and directly.

The world is rendered in flat, basic, derivative language. River water laps softly, Daniel rummages through a dusty drawer, their kitchen is sunlit. One cannot picture the world of this story, because it is only vaguely gestured at.
The characters are flat and static. We have no access to what might make them believable, let alone relatable, human beings.

The ending is excellent, and builds logically and artfully from the rest of the story. We don't know how Daniel's relationship with Isabel will go - there is tension between them, and they struggle to speak with each other in truly empathetic ways. But throughout the piece, and especially at it's conclusion, we understand that Daniel is sincere in his desire to connect with his partner in a deep, respectful way, and to figure out a way to maintain this relationship.

This is a well written story in which complicated, human-feeling people struggle to articulate how they feel with kindness even though that's what they want to do. Daniel is troubled by a past relationship and doesn't know why, until he realizes at the end that he can learn from the mistakes he made in that relationship and make a meaningful attempt to do better in his current one. It was a pleasure to read.

This story has several excellent scenes. Whenever Daniel interacts with Isabel, and in the scene with Hilary, we are present and what is portrayed feels real and nuanced. When we go into a more expository mode via Daniel's dreams and thoughts, it adds context to the scenes, and vice-versa.

This story expands and contracts in the manner of an accordion, allowing us to spend just the right amount of time in every scene. When Daniel and Isabel have tense interactions, they are conveyed with admirable economy and subtext. We are introduced to their disagreement, or the tension between them, we quickly understand it, and move on.

Though there is not a lot of figurative language in this piece, what exists is novel and meaningful. Daniel dreams of his old home with Rachel as "the kind of place where a wounded animal might go to hide." Rachel "found him ridiculous, like a little boy playing truant." These are metaphors that add meaning to the text and do not feel copy-pasted from elsewhere or autocompleted in the author's mind. We can sense the presence of a human intelligence at play in moments like these.

Through Daniel's dreams and thoughts, and through the actions of the characters, and through the highly subtextual dialogue spoken by them, a lovely depth is constructed, considered, and maintained throughout this story.

Because this story does such an excellent job of portraying its characters as complex, believable people, surprising and appropriate turns abound. The best such moment comes in the end, when the reader anticipates that Daniel will attempt to bond with Isabel as he did with Rachel, and Isabel agrees to try canoeing with him - but instead, this time Daniel perceives her disinterest and reluctance, and chooses to lose the keys instead.

The characters of Isabel and Daniel are artfully and lovingly rendered. Isabel consistently says things that sting, but then tries to take them back, and the effect is to convey her humanity as someone who is struggling to contain her insecurity and resentment while also very much wanting to love and support her partner. When she brings up Geoff, it is a jab at Daniel, and an opportunity to imply that she has options just like the one she fears he is holding onto. This is a woman who behaves in the complex, contradictory, and human ways that we all do in real life.

The language of this piece is sparse, but artful. Daniel awakens from his dream reassured, but also extremely anxious, like a man emerging from a coma, uncertain whether he is alive or dead. He "lift(s) himself up on an elbow" to watch Isabel sleep.

While beginning a story with a dream is broadly a hack writing move, it is skillfully done in this story. by moving back and forth between Daniel's dreams and memories and his present life, we are given everything we need to make sense and take enjoyment from this story.

A reader who engages in this story will come away from it in a contemplative and reflective mode. By showing us something approaching the full humanity of Daniel and Isabel, the author induces a glimpse into something unsaid about human nature.

Daniel's interactions with Isabel are highly subtextual:

1. Isabel asked, What’s Rachel like, in these dreams of yours?

Daniel sighed.

Just curious, she added. Dreams are so vague, he said.

2. Isabel mentioned that her ex had been in touch recently. Geoff. He had sent her a link to some political article he thought might interest her. Sounding off about corruption.
Did you reply?

A line or two. To be friendly. But I never dream about being back with him.

These examples are typical of the subtextual meaning embedded in both the story and the relationship between its characters. They are saying what they mean without directly saying it, the way that real human beings do in real life. It is satisfying to read, because it is recognizable as a series of experiences we all have.

Again, this story focuses far more on human interaction and subtext than sensory descriptions. But when it does, it does so with quick bursts of just-enough imagery: the splintery table, the semi-basement flat, tiny insects flitting across the surface of the pond, which is choked with bright-green weeds. It doesn't need more than this to feel like a real, tangible world has been rendered.

This story absolutely excels at depicting its characters as complex human beings. I've discussed Isabel and Daniel in my previous answers. But even though Hilary is only briefly in the piece, even her humanity and relationships to Daniel and Isabel is powerfully conveyed:

"Uh-oh, Hilary said, laughing. Time for the analyst!"

From this we quickly understand a few things: Hilary is someone who blurts out things she probably shouldn't; that Isabel has confided things in her about Daniel that he wishes she hadn't ... this is a tense, human, and believable moment.

The ending of the story is unsatisfactory because it is too evident to see what the writer expects us to feel. I did not care for the characters and the events took place so quickly that the ending failed to arouse any emotions in me.

The story is simple enough to understand and follows a logical path. The problems in Daniel's relationship introduced at the beginning are addressed and resolved, though not in a very convicing manner. The story feels too simplistic to be satisfying.

There is an awareness of balance between summary and exposition, as displayed in the descriptions of the protagonist walking through his old apartment. There isn't, however, any insight in the author's handling of this technique. The story feels too much like a summary, and these moments of detailed description are not compelling enough to rescue it.

In order to write a very good short story (especially one as short as this one), there has to be a spark or engaging element that justifies its being a short story. When reading this piece I felt like this could have been a longer story, in which we learnt about the characters and experienced what they went through, but the way it was handled felt rushed. It reads more as a summary of a story than an actual story.

The language of the story is not interesting or original. Several of the images employed are too wordy and vague, for example: 'flooded by a bittersweet nostalgia for early days gone by'. There isn't a sense of literary allusion or a complex use of language.

The story makes an attempt at interiority but it is not successful. The way in which the characters' emotions are revealed is partly through dialogue, which is remarkably dull in this story. An example is Daniel's response to Isabel's suggestion that he visits his old flat: 'That's a wonderful idea. Thank you, my dear, for always knowing the right thing to do.' It does not have the ring of truth, or even an echo of it.

The structure of this story is too simplistic and detracts from its enjoyment. Every beat is predictable, and the revelations are neither surprising or thought-out. It does not feel like the author experienced these events themself, or has any awareness of how people would act in this situation.

The character of Isabel is unconvincing and flat. Daniel, the protagonist, also shows a limited and robotic range of emotions. His struggle to overcome the memory of his ex-girlfriend is not given enough depth, and does not resonate past the boundaries of the story.

The repetition of clichéd images and ideas makes the story painfully forgettable. The image of 'Rachel snuggling in his arms during a thunderstorm' is later repeated to little effect: 'cuddled in front of the TV during rainy Sundays.'

As discussed in previous answers, the structure is predictable and too simplistic. The author shows no awareness of form as a tool to convey complex ideas to the reader. This might be because the author has no complex ideas to convey in this story.

The idea behind this story is trite and overdone. A reader would be better off watching a sitcom if they are looking for a surface-level treatment of relationships and memory; and watching a sitcom they might at least enjoy themselves.
No, it does not. The story only serves one purpose and that is to reinstate old and shallow ideas.

The story fails to create convincing dialogue. The images it employs also lack any originality, and therefore do not feel real. There's a pervading vagueness, such as in this image: 'They would go on adventures in the city, searching for hidden treasures in thrift stores and trying out different ethnic restaurants.' Daniel's time with Rachel is described as 'thrilling and unpredictable'—I wish I could say the same of this story.

Isabel's character only plays one role in this story and it is to suggest to Daniel to visit his old flat. Rachel is not developed or interesting enough. We get a hint that she had a violent outbreak towards Daniel, but this isn't given enough credibility.

The ending is mismatched with the rest of the story in my opinion. The mystery that arose from the empty room downstairs, and the implications that might have had for Daniel, are pushed aside too easily at the end of the story.
The progression of the story is coherent. There is an element of intrigue thanks to the key and the room which Daniel doesn't want to enter.
The story shows a basic understanding of balancing scenes and summary. The scenes are descriptive enough to at least be vivid in the reader's mind.

The story shows a basic understanding of narrative time and employs it to its benefit. There is a leap in time near the end of the story, which is when we are led to believe Daniel comes to term with his past and decides to move on. I don't find this very convincing.

There are some interesting metaphors but I wouldn't call them sophisticated. While they are not necessarily clichéd, the images employed are vague and they mud our understanding of the story: 'they shared an uneasy feeling that there was a mingling of dreams and wishes flowing from the door.'
The first paragraph of the story is very successful at balancing interiority and exteriority. However later on I find the interior development of the characters less convincing.

As discussed before, the resolution of the story does not feel appropriate to the rest of the story. It doesn't even act as an 'anti-twist,' indeed, it fails to do anything interesting once it's caught the reader's attention.

There is an attempt to sketch the characters' thoughts through dialogue, and while more convincing than in the previous story, it still falls short. The dialogue is too short and conclusive ideas are too easily arrived at, for example: "Nothing ever made me feel like I had that love from her

There is an attempt at complexity in phrasing which often betrays a trite idea behind it, such as: 'to protect her from the darkness he found lurking inside himself.' These instances occur more often than not, and they detract from the enjoyability of the piece.

There is the hope, at first, that the story will use mystery to reveal something interesting about the protagonist's life or psyche. However this is never fully accomplished, given that the subplot of the haunted apartment doesn't resonate throughout the rest of the story.

As the story does not fully accomplish what it initially sets out to do, then it cannot be said that it will have any more impact on the reader than arousing their imagination slightly. There is too explicit a message underlying the story, that is, that by facing the past we may become liberated from it. This is neither new nor interesting.

There is a very basic attempt at subtext through the haunted room and what it represents to the protagonist. This is just enough to give the story a pass based on this rubric, but not to classify it as outstanding or remarkable

Some interesting touches accomplish a sense of reality: the 'effervescent' eyes, the 'warped brown door.' However there isn't a sense that the writer envisions a complete world that their story belongs to; that is to say the story doesn't extend beyond its pages, which prevents it from being outstanding.
As discussed before, a clumsiness in dialogue prevents the characters from seeming complex or developed. The story's ending also detracts from it.
The story has several endings, or what seem to be endings, except the story keeps going for no reason whatsoever. This made me irritated and completely put me off the story.

The plot elements are not held together. The memory of Rachel is completely swept aside, brought back for a moment later in the story, and then discarded again. There are several 'awakenings' that Daniel experiences, each diminishing the impact of the last.
There isn't a single scene that feels real. It is mostly summary of an unsatisfactory sort.
There is no skillful stretching of time in this text. Time is only used as a tool to channel Daniel's trite reflections.
